HEADLINE: AT THE MOVIES 

BYLINE:  By Dave Kehr 

 BODY:
Social Realism (In Los Angeles)
 At 65, Ken Loach continues to fight the good fight as Britain's most stubbornly dedicated social-realist filmmaker. The creator of 32 films, from classics like "Kes" (1969) to "My Name Is Joe" (1998), he remains dedicated to a politically engaged cinema set in a recognizable world, an ideal at odds with the film industries of the United States and Britain. 
 Mr. Loach's new film, "Bread and Roses," opens in New York today (review, Page 14). Based on the janitors' strike in Los Angeles 11 years ago, this is the director's first film set in the United States. 
"I've been working with the writer Paul Laverty for some time, and he spent a year in Los Angeles and got involved with the janitors," Mr. Loach said by phone from his London office. "We talked about it, and he was very enthusiastic about the story. We finally managed to get the money together three years ago." 
Why does it take a British filmmaker to tell this American story? "I guess the Hollywood people are too busy driving through these areas to look out the windows to see what's happening. Being an outsider, what strikes you is that Los Angeles is obviously two worlds living side by side and not really knowing each other."
The film is set in the Hispanic section of Los Angeles, a world he captures with his customary eye for detail. "We spent most of our time hanging out with the janitors and their friends, and just getting to know people, really," he said. "There's quite a few people in the film who knew the situation at first hand. There was always somebody there who said 'This is how we did it' or 'This is how it should be.' Filmmaking is a question of listening -- of listening rather than telling."
For him, the success of British imports like "The Full Monty" is no cause for celebration.
"For as long as I can remember, the British film industry has tailored what it does to hit the jackpot in the States," he said. "The economic logic dictates a certain pattern, which is that we behave like people who are colonized. We consciously present a picture of who we are that the tourists will like. It's kind of ironic for a people who had their own empire that we're turning ourselves into comic characters in a make-believe land to sell across the Atlantic. There's something really daft about it, and demeaning."

Those Ears! And Eyes!
In France, the season's phenomenon is a wide-eyed gamine named Amelie Poulain, who, as played by the newcomer Audrey Tautou, connives to make life better for her friends and neighbors in a working-class corner of Montmartre. She is the central character in "Le Fabuleux Destin d'Amelie Poulain" ("The Fabulous Destiny of Amelie Poulain"), a poetic fantasy that recalls the warmth and whimsy of Jacques Prevert, and the French have taken it to their heart. The film, directed by Jean-Pierre Jeunet ("Delicatessen"), will be known simply as "Amelie" when Miramax releases it in the United States this fall.
"Two and a half million people in two weeks -- for France, that's a lot!" Mr. Jeunet said in Cannes. "French people like it because, I think, they're happy to have a positive experience. I don't know why, but people return to see it several times. A lot of people have sent me e-mail and letters. Some say it has really changed their lives."
Mr. Jeunet's story finds Amelie, a shy survivor of an unhappy childhood, waiting on tables in a tiny cafe where she hatches ingenious plans to bring together the lonely, dispirited people she encounters in her daily life -- while she falls in love with a young artist (Mathieu Kassovitz).
"It's the Paris I discovered when I first arrived," said Mr. Jeunet, a native of Nancy. "I arrived and it was a Paris of dreams, you know?" To rediscover that Paris required much work, both during production -- "We changed the posters, we erased the graffiti, we took away the cars, so it looks like photos from the 40's" -- and in post-production, when Mr. Jeunet used digital technology to intensify colors and retouch the skyline. 
The film's most special effect, however, is Ms. Tautou, who has reminded more than one critic of her namesake, Audrey Hepburn. "I saw her the first time just on the poster of 'Venus Beauty Institute,' " Mr. Jeunet said of the film in which she made her debut. "I thought, maybe she is interesting for me. So I did some tests. She was just so good. At the beginning of the shooting, I said: 'I don't have to direct you. I'll do my job but you are perfect. I'll tell you if you change.' "
"It was the big eyes," Mr. Jeunet rhapsodized. "She's like an elf in a fairy tale, big ears and big eyes. She's special."

Ex-Con in Love
"There are two kinds of pleasures that come along," said Victor Nunez, speaking from the set of his new film, "Coastlines," on the Gulf Coast of Florida.
"Sometimes when you shoot a scene, it's exactly as you envisioned it when you wrote it six months ago or six years ago," he said. "And there's another kind of pleasure when an actor comes and does something much more, much deeper than what you expected, and you get to be there when that happens. We've had a fair number of both kinds of occurrences, so in the midst of the exhaustion we're having a good time." 
If anyone deserves the title of independent filmmaker, it is Mr. Nunez, who has never worked for anyone but himself and who directs, writes, edits and operates the camera on his films, including "Ulee's Gold" (1997) and "Ruby in Paradise" (1993).
"Coastlines," which is about halfway through its six-week shooting schedule, represents a departure for Mr. Nunez because its story -- an ex-con (Timothy Olyphant) returns to his hometown and becomes involved in a romantic triangle with his best friend (Josh Brolin) and his friend's wife (Sarah Wynter) -- is darker and more violent than is his custom. 
"If we pull it off, it will be something like a really good country ballad," he said. "I tell everybody that it's a story about human errors made through an excess of life and energy, rather than a lack of them."
"Coastlines" is based on a story Mr. Nunez wrote 16 years ago, a year after he filmed the John D. MacDonald thriller "A Flash of Green." 
"What was interesting for me is that it was conceived almost a generation ago, and then polished and put into a structure at this point in my life," he said. "It has a double perspective that one hopes will give it a deeper resonance. But when you're in the middle of something, you're almost afraid to say anything about it."
If all goes well, "Coastlines" may be ready for the Sundance Film Festival in January. "We'll know at the end of July, when we've done our first assembly," Mr. Nunez said. "We'll make it as fast as we can."

HEADLINE: Creating a Market for Vaccines 

BYLINE:  By Michael Kremer and Rachel Glennerster; Michael Kremer is professor of economics at Harvard and senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. Rachel Glennerster, an economist, is adjunct lecturer in public policy at Harvard's Kennedy School.

 BODY:
While pharmaceutical companies' agreement to lower the prices of some anti-AIDS drugs is good news, it promises little relief to the vast majority of Africans with AIDS, who live in countries with governments unable to buy these drugs even at the reduced prices. And even if the price were zero, weak health infrastructure and low levels of education would make widespread effective use of the anti-AIDS drugs difficult, as they require complicated regimens of dosage and control.
 The best long-run solution for AIDS and the other infectious diseases devastating poor countries is vaccines: they would be relatively easy to deliver and could be used by large numbers of people at low cost. But little money has been committed to developing such vaccines. Last month, a task force established by Britain's prime minister, Tony Blair, proposed a plan that might make new vaccines a reality. 
 The need for vaccines is most urgent for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, which newly infected more than five million people last year (70 percent of them in Africa); tuberculosis, which kills 1.7 million people a year and is spreading in drug-resistant forms; and malaria, which kills one million a year -- mainly infants, toddlers and pregnant women.
Because drug companies see little chance of recouping their costs, they undertake very little research on diseases that primarily affect poor countries. Of the 1,223 drugs licensed between 1975 and 1987, only 13 were for tropical diseases. Two of these were modifications of existing medicines, two were produced for the United States military and five came from veterinary research. Only four were developed by commercial pharmaceutical firms specifically for tropical diseases in humans.
The British task force has proposed that the industrialized nations stimulate research by committing to purchase effective vaccines, when they are developed, for malaria, tuberculosis and H.I.V. If other nations take up this challenge, not only will the incentive be in place for vaccine development, but price will not be a barrier to people using the vaccines.
If a commitment to purchase new vaccines fails to induce their development, it will have cost nothing; if it succeeds, it will save millions of lives at a few dollars each. For example, if the donor countries agreed to purchase a malaria vaccine at $5 a dose, the vaccine could protect the 50 million newborns and pregnant women at highest risk from the disease for $250 million a year. Markets of this size have proved sufficient to stimulate vaccine research in the past. And the government sponsors would not have to choose between competing research proposals -- something much better left to the private sector.
The more quickly action is taken, the sooner the world will have more of the weapons it needs against disease.

HEADLINE: Europe Central Bank Declines To Support the Falling Euro 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The euro fell to a six-month low against the dollar yesterday after comments by Wim Duisenberg, president of the European Central Bank, dashed expectations that the central bank would buy the currency to support it anytime soon.
 "The exchange rate of the euro is not a target for us," Mr. Duisenberg said at a news conference in Vienna. "It is only important if it would no longer support our inflation aim. That is not the case." 
 In New York, the euro settled at 84.62 cents, down from 85.70 cents on Wednesday. It touched 84.46 cents, its weakest since Nov. 27, and only about 2.2 cents above the record intraday low of 82.30, set on Oct. 26. 
Mr. Duisenberg's comments have set the stage for a move back to 82 cents a euro, said Brian Taylor, head trader at the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company in Buffalo. "Traders have the mind-set to test that" level, given the reduced likelihood of action by the European Central Bank.
Since the start of the year, the euro has shed 10 percent against the dollar amid signs of slowing growth in Europe. Reports last week showed first-quarter growth slowed more than expected in France and Germany, Europe's two largest economies.
There have been four cases of central bank intervention to bolster the euro. First came a coordinated round of buying by major central banks on Sept. 22, starting at about 87.50 cents. That was followed by solo intervention by the European Central Bank on three separate days in November, at levels between 85 and 87 cents.
Klaus Liebscher, a council member of the European Central Bank, also touched off selling when he told reporters that "circumstances are now different" from when the central bank intervened last year at similar levels. Analysts took that to mean the bank sees the recent decline as more orderly than last year's.
A falling currency can start a sell-off of bonds and stocks by foreign investors out of concern the investments will generate losses.

HEADLINE: Contributing to the Old Country 

 BODY:
Recent immigrants from Latin America play an increasingly decisive role in two economies at once -- in this nation's and in the one back home. Their impact here is likely to drive the coming debate on immigration reform, as Mexico and the United States discuss the possibility of legalizing the status of millions of undocumented workers and creating new guest-worker programs. But the economic significance of immigrants' remittances back home should be considered as well. 
 Not long ago capital flight from Latin America presented one of the region's most pressing economic problems. It remains a concern in Venezuela and Colombia, but over all, foreign direct investment and individuals' remittances sent back home have reversed the flow of capital. Last year emigrants sent an estimated $20 billion back to relatives in Latin America and the Caribbean region, typically in installments of a few hundred dollars a month. This amount, expected to total $300 billion over the next decade, vastly exceeds official development assistance, and benefits some of the poorest communities. 
 In countries like Haiti, Nicaragua, El Salvador and the Dominican Republic, emigrants' remittances add up to more than 10 percent of the gross domestic product. In the case of Mexico, the inflow of roughly $8 billion in annual remittances ranks with tourism receipts and oil exports as a major source of revenue. 
The Bush administration recognized the economic importance of remittances earlier in the year when it allowed Salvadorans living illegally in the United States to apply for 18-month work permits so that the money they sent home could help their country recover from two devastating earthquakes. Likewise, the joint declaration issued by hemispheric leaders at the Summit of the Americas in Quebec City in April also highlighted the significance of remittances as a source of development capital, and called on governments to lower their transaction costs and seek ways to channel some of this money into productive investments.
In addition to individuals sending money to their families, Salvadorans and Mexicans are increasingly coming together in American cities to send back funds for public infrastructure works, usually through a hometown association. President Vicente Fox of Mexico has started some innovative matching programs for such funds, and the Inter-American Development Bank is looking to do the same elsewhere in the region. Other experimental programs are aimed at helping migrants finance businesses they could return to, in an attempt to address the absence of economic opportunity that drives emigration in the first place. 
America's immigration policy cannot be dictated primarily by a desire to help finance development in Latin America. There are certainly more self-interested reasons for Americans to support healthy levels of immigration. But whatever the course of that debate, both legal and illegal immigrants will continue to send capital south of the Rio Grande for the foreseeable future. Maximizing its impact as a vehicle for development is a laudable goal.

HEADLINE: 120 Groups Join to Push $10 Billion Housing Plan 

BYLINE:  By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Business and community leaders are calling on the mayoral candidates to confront New York City's housing shortage with a $10 billion plan to build 100,000 homes and renovate 85,700 others in the next decade.
 Housing First! is both the name and the goal of the group, which has raised $500,000 to push housing to the forefront of this year's campaigns for city offices. 
 About 100 leaders, including bankers, builders, clergymen and unionists, filled the front steps of City Hall yesterday to push the effort. The coalition has already met with the candidates privately, shuttled them around the boroughs to visit model programs and planned a public forum. The candidates have discussed the issue at public meetings and are forming their own platforms. 
The city is in one of its worst housing shortages in decades, with high prices, overcrowding and homelessness. Surging population has driven up demand, and the supply has failed to keep pace.
The plan calls for building 33,000 one- to four-unit family-owned homes; 21,000 apartments for people with special needs, like the elderly; and 46,000 rental and cooperative apartments, as well as the renovation of 85,700 apartments. It also proposes revised building and zoning codes and the cleanup of polluted sites that could be developed for housing.
Among the 120 groups endorsing the plan so far are the Real Estate Board of New York, Citibank/Citicorp Foundation, Catholic Charities of Brooklyn and Queens, the Communications Workers of America, the Regional Plan Association, Acorn, the New York Community Trust, the New York Urban League, J. P. Morgan Chase, the Coalition for the Homeless and the United Way of New York.
"This is a coalition that has never come together before in these kinds of numbers," said Naomi Bayer, the coalition's coordinating chairwoman and director of the New York office of Fannie Mae, the federally chartered home-financing corporation.
Unlike past proposals focusing on poor people, the coalition plan also covers middle-class needs. Ms. Bayer referred to the "housing problems you hear every day in the elevators and hallways."
The group has a Web site, www.housingfirst.net, where the plan may be examined. The plan would be financed by the city's capital budget, Battery Park City profits, World Trade Center taxes, federal money, sales of city property, tax liens and other sources. 
"It's a moral issue," said the Rev. Calvin O. Butts, senior pastor at Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, speaking for an interfaith delegation. He said that housing fulfills the promise of the "glorious lady in the harbor" who welcomes the homeless.
Other speakers stressed the importance to business, which needs housing that workers can afford. Bruce Ratner, a developer, said, "There is probably not a single more important issue to the economic development of the city."
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani defended his record on the housing front, saying, "We have built a great deal of housing."
But he added, "New York City is always going to need housing, and there is always more to be done."

HEADLINE: California City Pins Hopes On a Big Natural Gas Field 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA WHITAKER 

DATELINE: DELANO, Calif. 

 BODY:
This small city's fate has always been tied to the land. Now Delano is pinning its hopes on what lies beneath the land.
 Notable for grapes and once the home of Cesar Chavez, the founder of the United Farm Workers union, Delano is in one of the richest agricultural areas in the United States. Yet the city has long struggled with high unemployment and deep poverty, particularly among its large Hispanic and immigrant population. 
 In recent years, city officials have relied on a prison and a fruit packing and distribution center to keep the economy afloat. But this spring the city's sights have turned back to the land, to a natural gas field that a local wildcatter speculates may be the second largest ever found in the West, after the giant Rio Vista field, also in California.
Though state officials and other experts express skepticism about the gas field, Delano officials sense opportunity in even the slim chance that the speculation will prove true. After all, natural gas is gold these days in a state that needs the fuel for plants generating electricity.
"It's brought a whole different outlook," Mayor Arthur B. Armendariz said. "Now I'm looking to become a generator of electricity."
The city owns and holds the mineral rights to some 400 acres in an area of 10 square miles that F. Lynn Blystone, president of a large Central Valley oil drilling operation, says has rich gas deposits.
Mr. Blystone estimates that the field may contain more than three trillion cubic feet of natural gas, but the amount has not been verified. And he acknowledged that he reported finding a natural gas deposit of 300 billion cubic feet in 1998 that never materialized.
In any case, the gas around Delano -- trapped in tightly packed sand that resembles concrete -- may be hard to extract. So Delano's dreams of fortune could evaporate like the vineyard dew.
"All of their optimism is based upon the drilling of one well," Don Drysdale, a spokesman for the California Department of Conservation, said. "We don't think that gives us enough information to go on."
But Mr. Blystone, who is president of the Tri-Valley Corporation, whose subsidiary, Tri-Valley Oil and Gas, is trying to raise $10 million to drill four wells to verify the find, said he was "very confident."
Tri-Valley, he said, has weathered bankruptcy protection, hostile takeover attempts and two decades of low gas prices in the last 38 years.
With all this in mind, residents with mineral rights, an elite group because the original property owners tended to keep those rights when they sold the land, are not getting their hopes up.
"If it pans out, it will be nice," Phyllis Kraft, assistant to the city manager, said. "But those of us who have mineral rights are not counting our chickens until our eggs are hatched." Ms. Kraft's family kept the mineral rights on a farm it sold decades ago.
Mayor Armendariz said word of the natural gas field set his phone ringing, as residents called to see whether they had mineral rights. Royalties typically range from 12.5 percent to 25 percent of gross production, Mr. Blystone said.
City officials said that even a little windfall could have a big impact on Delano's 38,000 residents. In recent years the city -- where 68 percent of the residents are Hispanic, 20 percent are Filipino and 5 percent are African-American -- has been losing its middle class to Bakersfield, 30 miles south. The downtown area has declined steadily. The unemployment rate is about 30 percent.
Although Delano recently landed a Sears distribution center and a citrus processing and packing plant, and plans are in the works for another prison, the ability to generate electricity would increase the city's attractiveness to industry, Mr. Armendariz said.
"This will enable us to control our own destiny," he said.
John James Thorton, who has lived in Delano since 1939, but owns no mineral rights said: "It would be a nice thing for the area. We wouldn't have to build any more prisons to find jobs."

GRAPHIC: Photos: F. Lynn Blystone, president of the Tri-Valley Corporation, stood at the well bore leading to what some say is one of the largest natural gas fields found in the West. It would be a big opportunity for pastoral Delano, Calif. (Monica Almeida/The New York Times); (Dan Ocampo)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Up Slightly in Rebound From Technology Sell-Off

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
Stock prices rose modestly yesterday as investors, fresh from a sharp sell-off of technology stocks on Wednesday, spent the day hunting for bargains.
 "The market just oversold itself, and now it's bouncing back," said Al Mirman, a market strategist at vFinance, a financial services and brokerage company. 
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 39.30 points, or 0.4 percent, to 10,911.94. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index climbed 25.99 points, or 1.3 percent, to 2,110.49, for its first gain in four days. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 7.74 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,255.82. 
Analysts described the day's trading as unremarkable and choppy. They offered few explanations for the rebound.
"Maybe the selling cooled off from yesterday," said Richard McCabe, chief market analyst for Merrill Lynch. "It's just a part of the noise that doesn't have a real reason for happening."
Technology stocks provided much of the gains yesterday, one day after the sector was punished because of weak profit forecasts from Sun Microsystems, Alcatel and RadioShack. Those three stocks edged higher yesterday, with Sun gaining 22 cents, to $16.47; Alcatel rising 28 cents, to $25.27, and RadioShack advancing 30 cents, to $27.23. 
Among the stocks leading the Nasdaq higher, Oracle rose 79 cents, to $15.30; Cisco Systems picked up 26 cents, to $19.26; Intel gained 41 cents, to $27.01; and Juniper Networks jumped $2.32, to $42.53.
Shares of Barr Laboratories surged $3.57, to $71.27, after an appeals court panel cleared the way for the company to sell a generic version of Prozac by late summer. The court upheld an earlier decision that said Eli Lilly's patent on the drug was invalid. 
Shares of Polaroid fell 69 cents, to $4.78, after its executives said the company faced stagnant growth for the next two to three years. The company attributed its weak forecast to competition from one-hour film developers and a heavy debt load.
Today, the government will report its employment statistics for May, but analysts said investors showed little reaction to a report yesterday that showed initial filings for unemployment insurance rose unexpectedly. 
Yesterday's tentative trading may signal an underlying apprehension surrounding the sustainable strength of the American economy. Investors are expecting more forecasts of weak corporate earnings in the coming weeks. And today's unemployment report is expected to show more job losses, indicating continued weakness in the sluggish economy. 
Some analysts expect further bad news will give the Federal Reserve more reason to cut interest rates for the sixth time this year when it meets later this month.
"It's really a case of bad news is good news," said Charles Pradilla, chief investment strategist at SG Cowen. "The unemployment numbers continue to make it seem like the Fed is going to ease again."

Treasury Prices Rise
By Bloomberg News
Bond prices rose yesterday on expectations that the economy shed jobs for the third consecutive month in May, bolstering optimism that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates for the sixth time this year.
The price of the 10-year Treasury note rose 30/32, to 97 7/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.37 percent from 5.50 percent on Wednesday.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 17/32, to 94 23/32. Its yield fell to 5.75 percent from 5.84 percent on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Xerox Says Its Auditors Found No Signs of Fraud
Xerox, whose auditors had refused to sign off on its annual report until they had rechecked the numbers, said that the auditors, KPMG, found some accounting discrepancies but uncovered no signs of fraud.
 KPMG did say the company had run afoul of generally accepted accounting principles, and Xerox adjusted its consolidated financial statements for the last three years. Shares of Xerox rose 88 cents, to $9.91. Page C2. 

New York Faces Power Woes, Too
In New York, a host of critics, from former staff members of the State Public Service Commission to business lobbyists to consumer advocates, say that electricity deregulation has gone awry. But few voices are calling for a return to the old system, in which the state oversaw plant construction and told utilities what they could charge for power. A1.

Aimster Up Next in Music Battle
The Recording Industry Association of America contends Aimster, its latest legal nemesis in the fight over online music, is essentially a Napster clone. But outside legal experts say it is unclear whether the recording industry could prevail over Aimster as easily as it did over Napster, given what they say may be crucial differences between the two. C2.

Stocks Gain in Bargain Hunting
Stock prices gained modestly as investors hunted for bargains. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 39.30 points, or 0.4 percent, to 10,911.94. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 25.99 points, or 1.3 percent, to 2,110.49. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 7.74 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,255.82. C8.

Allianz Defends Deal for Dresdner
The German insurance conglomerate Allianz and its chairman, Henning Schulte-Noelle, tried to reassure nervous investors that its $20 billion acquisition of Dresdner Bank, the country's third-biggest bank, will produce big savings and add to profits as early as next year. But even as Allianz was laying out its case for becoming an "all-finance" giant, Deutsche Bank broke off talks about a much more modest alliance with AXA, the big French insurance company. World Business, Section W.

Mexican Businessman to Pay Fine
Carlos Hank Rhon, one of the richest and most politically connected businessmen in Mexico, will pay a $40 million fine to settle charges that he violated banking laws when he bought Laredo National Bancshares in Texas. C4.

Venture Seeks to Enhance Shopping
The William Morris Agency and the Mills Corporation, an investment trust that owns, manages and markets shopping centers, have formed a venture intended to attract marketers by offering ways to create interactive experiences for consumers. Advertising. C6.

3 Reports Show Slumping Economy
Three reports had grim news for the economy. More Americans filed for first-time unemployment benefits last week, the government said, while another report said the risks of a recession had risen. And a barometer of manufacturing in the Chicago region fell. C2.

Euro Slides Against the Dollar
The euro fell to a six-month low against the dollar after comments by Wim Duisenberg, president of the European Central Bank, dashed expectations that the bank would prop the currency up. In New York, the euro settled at 84.62 cents, down from 85.70 cents. C8.

HEADLINE: Politics Thickens the Molasses in Albany's Budget Process 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 31 

 BODY:
The state budget is late again for the 17th year in a row. 
 For the last two decades, New York's budget system has not worked very well, but this year it does not seem to be working at all. The Senate Republican leader calls it dysfunctional. Today, two months after the budget deadline, Gov. George E. Pataki warned that there might be no budget at all. 
 Flaws in state law are partly to blame for New York's chronically late budgets. New York is the only state, for instance, that has a fiscal year beginning April 1, two weeks before income taxes are due and revenue forecasts become clearer. It also has one of the shortest periods for considering a budget, just two and a half months, a span that budget makers in both parties say is too short. 
But this year there are also political forces contributing to the impasse. The debate is taking place as the national economy skids downward a little more than a year before the election of a governor. Mr. Pataki, a Republican expected to run again next year, has argued that the state should save as much money as possible to hedge against an economic downturn. 
"We are better off, clearly, having a budget, but having said that, no budget is better than a budget that is billions of dollars beyond what the state can afford and sustain," the governor said at a news conference.
Mr. Pataki said both the Senate and the Assembly proposals, which would add to his $83.6 billion spending plan, were unrealistic given the weakened state of the national economy. He raised the specter of 1990, when the Cuomo administration overestimated revenues during a recession and ended up cutting school aid and laying off workers.
The governor's threat today to operate the government indefinitely on emergency spending measures underscored how far apart Democrats and Republicans remain over this year's budget. Impasses are nothing new. In 1997 and 1999, negotiations went on until early August, long past the April 1 deadline. In recent history, no other state has come close to New York's record. Still, many lawmakers believe this year could be the worst.
"The budget system in New York State doesn't work," said the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, a Republican. "It's dysfunctional. It's broken."
The Democrats who control the Assembly contend that the governor is using the downturn as an excuse to stash away money in reserves that he can spend in an election year. Even with the slowing economy, the Democrats predict that revenues will grow enough -- by about $2 billion -- to forestall cuts to nursing homes and to pay for a $1.7 billion increase for school programs, like statewide preschool.
"The issues facing us are, do you close the schoolhouse door to 4-year-olds because the governor is running for re-election next year and wants to build up a surplus of funds that he can spend in an election year?" the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, said. "Do we deny health care coverage to senior citizens in nursing homes because the governor is running for re-election next year and wants to be able to cut ribbons and dole out dollars around the state? There are no other issues in this budget."
The governor has countered that the Democrats are proposing irresponsible spending increases while the sluggish national economy is forcing states like California and Michigan to tighten their budgets. Already, he said, there are signs of lower tax revenues for April and May. 
"There is certainly at the best a great deal of uncertainty about the economy," Mr. Pataki said. "To go on a spending binge would be the height of irresponsibility, and I'm not going to let that happen."
In January, the governor opened the bidding with a proposed $83.6 billion budget, a 5.3 percent increase over last year's, though the part of the budget that is financed with state taxes would grow only 3.2 percent. In recent years, the governor's proposal has set the floor for debate, and the negotiations have focused on how much the Legislature will add to it. But this year, Mr. Pataki has said the economy is so soft that he cannot support any increases.
The Assembly has proposed spending $2.3 billion more than the governor, with about half of that increase going to schools. The Republicans who control the Senate have proposed about $1.2 billion more in spending, placing an emphasis on school aid and tax cuts to spur biotechnology research and other businesses.
Much is at stake for the governor in next year's election, political analysts say. If the economy slips into recession, as some economists fear, voters may well blame him for it. That perception will worsen if he is forced to make painful cutbacks just six months before voters troop to the polls.
The Democrats have accused the governor of failing to fulfill his traditional role in negotiating the budget with legislative leaders. They have criticized him for traveling the state and the country to preside over ribbon-cuttings and political events instead of staying in Albany and working out a budget agreement with the Assembly and the Senate.
"The governor is just absent and not providing the leadership," said the state comptroller, H. Carl McCall, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for governor. "Traditionally that's been the governor's role in New York, and this governor hasn't wanted to play that role."
Mr. McCall and other Democrats suggest that a delay benefits the governor. The longer it takes to pass a new budget, the longer the state continues to spend at last year's levels and the more money there will be available in next year's surplus.
Mr. Pataki dismissed as ridiculous the idea that he should be doing more to broker a budget agreement. He said that he has fulfilled his constitutional obligation to submit a budget to the Legislature and that it is now up to the two houses to make changes to those budget bills and pass them. 
As a practical matter, however, New York governors have always played an active role in brokering an agreement with lawmakers on how much the Legislature can add to the budget. Before 1998, those agreements were made in private horse-trading sessions with legislative leaders, a process that was derisively called "three men in a room."
In 1998, the governor and the Legislature tried to establish a more open procedure. The Assembly and the Senate passed their own versions of the budget, then worked out differences in a general conference committee. The governor had little involvement.
But the idea backfired on Democrats. Mr. Pataki vetoed more than 1,000 appropriations, the majority of them Democratic projects. Since then, Mr. Silver has insisted on reaching a three-way agreement with the Senate majority leader and the governor on the size of the budget before the conference committee meets to work out details. In essence, he has demanded assurances in advance that the governor will not resort to widespread vetoes if spending remains under a certain level. He got those assurances in 1999 and 2000. 
But this year, Mr. Pataki has refused to negotiate with Mr. Silver, much as he declined to do so for several months in 1999. He has insisted that the Legislature work out a budget in public committee meetings without his help and has refused to put restraints on his right to veto spending he disagrees with.
"I do not intend to go back to three people behind closed doors negotiating a budget," he said. 
Never in recent memory has the state failed to pass a budget. Over the years, however, the governor and the Legislature have perfected temporary spending bills that keep the government humming along at the previous year's levels. Indeed, delays in enacting a budget have few noticeable consequences until August, when school districts must send out their tax bills. Mr. Pataki said the government could be kept running with stopgap bills, though schools would have a harder time predicting aid.
Because the temporary spending bills shield the public from a government shutdown, politicians have discovered that they stand to lose less by passing late budgets than they can gain by holding out for programs important to their constituents, political scientists and lawmakers say. 
"No member of the government, either the legislators or the governor, seems to think they will suffer at the polls because of the late budget," Senator Eric T. Schneiderman, a Manhattan Democrat, said. "If there is no price to pay, there is no pressure to get it done on time."

PERSON: Jaime Benitez Rexach 

HEADLINE: Jaime Benitez, 92, Educator And Puerto Rican Politician 

BYLINE:  By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
Jaime Benitez Rexach, a former chancellor and president of the University of Puerto Rico who from 1972 to 1976 was the island's nonvoting representative in Congress, died on Wednesday in a hospital in San Juan. He was 92.
 Under Mr. Benitez, who became chancellor in 1942, the University of Puerto Rico increased significantly in size and quality, becoming one of the finest institutions of higher education in the Spanish-speaking world. 
 An overhaul of the university's statutes in the year Mr. Benitez took over laid the basis for the changes by sharply reducing political interference in university affairs.
The student body grew from about 5,000 to more than 40,000 by the time Mr. Benitez stepped down. The schools of medicine, dentistry and architecture were added and regional campuses established.
As chancellor, Mr. Benitez also attracted many distinguished scholars and artists who had left Spain in its civil war, including the philosopher Jose Ortega y Gasset and the Nobel Prize-winning poet Juan Ramon Jimenez. 
A close associate of the political leader Luis Munoz Marin, who became Puerto Rico's first elected governor in 1949 and helped achieve commonwealth status for it in 1952, Mr. Benitez drafted the Bill of Human Rights included in the new Constitution, which recognized citizens' social and economic rights as well as their human rights.
The two men fell out in 1957, however, when Mr. Munoz declared his "loss of confidence" in Mr. Benitez and accused him of using his university position to build a rival political movement to his own Popular Democratic Party, or P.P.D. They were publicly reconciled before the 1960 elections.
In 1966, the university statutes were changed again to permit greater political activity on the campus and Mr. Benitez was effectively kicked upstairs to the new and less powerful post of university president, which he gave up in 1971.
The next year he was elected on the P.P.D. ticket to a four-year term as Puerto Rico's resident commissioner in Washington, effectively representing it in the House of Representatives, where he sat as a Democrat though without a vote. His 1976 re-election bid was unsuccessful.
Born on the island of Vieques on Oct. 29, 1908, Mr. Benitez studied law at Georgetown University and political science at the University of Chicago. He joined the University of Puerto Rico faculty as an associate professor of social and political science in 1931.
He is survived by his wife, the former Lulu Martinez; two daughters, Clotilde and Margarita, of Washington, and a son, Jaime, of Albany.

HEADLINE: Nuclear Power: Worth the Risk? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "Hard Questions on Nuclear Power" (editorial, May 29) concludes that the case has not yet been made for large-scale expansion of this power source, citing the "risks" associated with it. But there are risks associated with every human endeavor and with every fuel source for generating electricity: coal mines collapse, valleys flood, oil spills and gas pipelines rupture. 
Fifty years of safe power production from commercial plants proves that nuclear energy is no riskier than the alternatives. And waste disposal is primarily a political, not a scientific, issue. 
 Nuclear power can help diversify our energy sources and reduce our dependence on imported oil and increasingly expensive natural gas.

BERNARD L. WEINSTEIN
Denton, Tex., May 29, 2001

The writer is director of the Center for Economic Development and Research, University of North Texas.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Pressure in Jakarta Builds So Far in Orderly Fashion 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 31 

 BODY:
Indonesia is on course to oust its third leader in three years. But unlike previous political upheavals, which were chaotic and violent, this one is unfolding with remarkable order.
 Parliament said today that it would convene a special session of the People's Consultative Assembly on Aug. 1 to consider removing President Abdurrahman Wahid from office. The decision was made a day after the legislators had overwhelmingly voted to begin impeachment proceedings against the president. 
 The timing scrupulously follows the Constitution, which stipulates that Parliament allow 60 days to prepare for a meeting of the assembly, the highest legislative body.
About 1,000 supporters of Mr. Wahid rallied in front of his palace today, demanding that he impose martial law and dissolve Parliament. But that option looked less and less tenable as the security minister and top military generals publicly opposed a state of emergency.
"Issuing a decree in a situation like this is not appropriate, and we hope this decision will not be taken," Security Minister Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono said after meeting military officers.
As the likelihood of a drastic response by Mr. Wahid waned, his supporters began dispersing, boarding trains for the president's home province, East Java. The anger has also largely petered out in East Java, where police officers and soldiers have clashed with Mr. Wahid's loyalists for three days.
"The legislators were very concerned about provoking violence, so they must be feeling quite relieved," said Harold Crouch, an Indonesia expert at the Australian National University who lives here. "But the final stage will be the most difficult, if they decide to sack him."
Mr. Crouch noted that the lengthy impeachment process had been devised by Indonesia's longtime ruler, Suharto, as a way of fending off challenges to his rule. Although some lawmakers are eager to accelerate the process, nobody is advocating that Indonesia follow the recent example of the Philippines.
There, the Senate convened an impeachment trial against the former president, Joseph Estrada, only to suspend it after the prosecutors suffered a setback. Tens of thousands of protesters took to the streets, and Mr. Estrada was forced from office in what experts describe as a soft coup. 
But in Indonesia, "neither side seems willing to short-circuit the process, which is good," James W. Castle, an American consultant, said. "One would hope that the dismal economy will pressure them to find a reasonable solution."
Few people see much chance for compromise between the president and the implacably hostile Parliament. Mr. Wahid, who once referred to the legislators as a crowd of kindergartners, ostensibly believes that they have overreached their authority. He has not even responded to Parliament's vote, brushing aside questions about it at a summit meeting of developing nations.
Still, Mr. Wahid is allowing the process to grind on, which gives people here hope that Indonesia will manage this transition more peacefully than it did the fall of Mr. Suharto, which occurred after a popular uprising and bloody riots. Mr. Suharto's successor, B. J. Habibie, quit the presidential race in 1999 after he oversaw the convulsive withdrawal from East Timor.
"If the people's assembly handles this with dignity, it will be a good precedent for succession in Indonesia," said Juwono Sudarsono, who was a cabinet minister under all three presidents.
Mr. Sudarsono noted that the military was walking a particularly careful line in the dispute. The army, which holds 38 seats in Parliament, abstained from the vote on Wednesday, but did not try to stop it.
The stately pace of the impeachment process has robbed the scene of much of its drama, which may not be bad in view of the unrest that bubbles just under the surface. Aside from Mr. Wahid's loyalists, few ordinary people are angry, or even particularly interested, in his plight.
If he is removed, he will be replaced by Vice President Megawati Sukarnoputri, a taciturn former homemaker best known for being the daughter of Indonesia's founding leader, Sukarno. Because Mrs. Megawati says so little, most people profess not to know how she would differ from Mr. Wahid.
"At first, we worried every time we heard he was in trouble," Lim Ka Giok, an ethnic Chinese merchant, said. "But it's gone on so long that we're just tired of it. We say, 'Go ahead and fight among yourselves.' "

HEADLINE: El Paso's Share of California Gas Market Is Questioned 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31 

 BODY:
The El Paso Corporation's share of the Southern California natural gas market may be smaller than an energy agency study showed because the survey did not include in-state production, storage or competing pipelines, the study's author said today during a hearing at the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission.
 Curtis L. Wagner Jr., the chief administrative law judge at the commission, is hearing testimony on whether El Paso artificially inflated natural gas prices in California, adding perhaps as much as $3.7 billion to the cost of the state's energy crisis. 
 El Paso had a 45 percent share of Southern California's market, the study said. The share would be less if the other supplies were included, said Jonathan Ogur, an economist at the commission. 
El Paso's pipeline unit, El Paso Natural Gas, is accused of selling about one billion cubic feet of pipeline capacity into California to its merchant energy subsidiary, which then withheld gas shipments to drive up prices. That contract ends at midnight tonight, and 30 suppliers will share the capacity on Friday.
"If gas production and storage were available, then they would reduce El Paso's share of the market," Mr. Ogur said during cross-examination.
El Paso, based in Houston, argues that in-state storage of 800 million cubic feet a day and production totaling 1.03 billion cubic feet a day provided competing options for the state's largest utilities to buy gas.
Storage and production were excluded from analysis of El Paso's share of the market because those supplies are typically sold under long-term contracts and are not available to gas buyers looking for lower prices, Mr. Ogur said.
The study considers Southern California as a separate market from the rest of the state when pipelines are full because gas does not move well within California and prices typically rise higher in the south, Mr. Ogur said. If the state were looked at as one market, El Paso's share of pipeline capacity would be 27 percent, he said.
El Paso estimates that it held 17 percent of the capacity to California under the contract, said Norma Dunn, a spokeswoman. California operates as a single market so that supplies from Canada compete with supplies from Texas and New Mexico, she said.
The California Public Utility Commission, Pacific Gas and Electric, and Southern California Edison accused El Paso of manipulating the market after the average price of gas in California surged above levels in other markets.
Judge Wagner extended the hearings through next Friday and would give lawyers until July 9 to write and respond to evidence gathered during the last three weeks. The deadline for final briefs was extended to July 24 from June 6, and a final recommendation to the commission will be made "within weeks" after that, the judge said after today's session.

HEADLINE: Late Credit Card Payments Rose in April 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
The number of Americans late in making their credit card payments jumped sharply in April from a year earlier, and card issuers wrote off substantially more bad loans, the debt rating company Moody's Investors Service said yesterday.
 Both the bad loan write-off rate and the late-payment rate rose more than 13 percent from their levels a year earlier, Moody's said. 
Neither rate had risen that sharply since the last negative credit cycle in 1995 to 1997, Moody's said. 
 "The recent rise in the unemployment rate and rising debt service burden on U.S. borrowers are among the factors leading to more delinquencies in credit card monthly payments," Christophe Germain, a Moody's analyst, said in a statement. 
Moody's said two other key measures of consumer credit quality, the yield and the repayment rate, were relatively stable. 
In part, Moody's attributed an increase in bankruptcy filings in the first three months of the year to the rise in the charge-off rate in April. For most credit card issuers, bankruptcy filings are written off as uncollectable within 60 days to comply with regulatory guidelines.

HEADLINE: Unemployment Claims in U.S. Are Reported at 7 1/2-Year High 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31 

 BODY:
More Americans filed for first-time unemployment benefits last week, and continuing claims reached their highest in seven and a half years, the government said today, while another report said the risks of a recession had risen.
 In one of several gloomy reports, the Labor Department said first-time unemployment claims had risen for the third consecutive week, to 419,000 in the week ended May 26, up from 411,000 in the previous week and the highest level in a month. 
 About 2.85 million people continued to collect unemployment benefits last week, the largest number since November 1993 and an increase from 2.76 million in the previous week. Analysts said the report -- which came a day ahead of May payroll data -- was a sign that the labor market was deteriorating, a potentially dangerous development for the economy. 
The National Association of Purchasing Management in Chicago reported that its index of regional manufacturing fell in May, to a seasonally adjusted 38.7 from 38.9 in the previous month. An index below 50 signals a contracting manufacturing sector, while a reading above 50 suggests expansion.
In yet another grim report, the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago said that although it remained unlikely that the economy had slid into a recession, chances of such a contraction rose last month.
The national activity index slid to minus 1.09 in April from minus 0.87 in March. The figure was the weakest since the economy began slowing in July and represented the 10th consecutive month the index remained below zero, an indication of below-trend growth. The three-month moving average index, which irons out month-to-month fluctuations, also fell, reaching minus 0.96 in April, down slightly from minus 0.94 in the previous month. The three-month index has dropped below minus 0.70 during only six periods since 1967, the start of the Chicago Fed's data, and only one of those times did the economy skirt recession, commonly defined as two consecutive quarters of contraction.
While the Chicago Fed said the April reading continued to be above levels hit during the five recessions the United States suffered in the last four decades, it said the three-month average indicated a growing recession risk.
The reports were released a day before the government is set to issue its snapshot of the employment situation for May. Analysts are looking for the report to provide important clues about the labor market. It is also expected to be a crucial factor at the Fed's next meeting at the end of June.
Economists estimate payroll employment fell 17,000 in May. Analysts also forecast that the unemployment rate rose to 4.6 percent in May, up from 4.5 percent in April.
But economists said the labor picture was not all bad. According to the claims report, the four-week moving average of initial claims actually fell for a second consecutive week, to 402,500 from 404,000.

HEADLINE: The Zero-Sum Tax Cut 

BYLINE:  By David Brooks; David Brooks, a senior editor at The Weekly Standard, is the author of "Bobos in Paradise."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
As I'm sure you do all the time, I recently spent an evening browsing through some old essays from the tax-cut debates of the 1980's. What was striking about those debates, especially compared to the arguments that now surround the Bush tax cuts, was how epic they were. The supply-siders considered themselves Reagan revolutionaries. They wrote tracts with grand names like "Wealth and Poverty" and "The Way the World Works." They believed they were leading a moral and cultural reformation, not just boosting the gross domestic product.
 Their central argument was that taxes must be cut in ways that encouraged risk-taking. "The primary and essential character of wealth is metaphysical, not physical," wrote Warren T. Brookes, a Washington Times columnist, "and is the direct result of the creativity of mind, not the availability of raw materials." 
 Marginal rate cuts were designed to unleash the creative juices in America's most daring individuals. The hero and moral exemplar in the supply-side world view was not the passive consumer, but the entrepreneur, who drives the economy and the country. 
The grandiose rhetoric drove the critics of supply-side economics crazy. But the themes, translated into Reagan speeches, hammered home the point that tax cuts were intended to revive the national spirit. They overwhelmed Democratic arguments that the top income quintile was benefiting the most. At their best, the supply-siders also reinforced a core value of the Republican Party. The early Republican leaders believed in the sanctity of work and ambition. "I hold the value of life is to improve one's condition," Lincoln declared. Through policies ranging from the Homestead Act to support for the transcontinental railroad, the Republicans encouraged and lionized industry and productivity. Following the model of Alexander Hamilton, they believed that one of government's primary tasks was to incite vigor in the populace. 
Under the Bush administration, the tone has dramatically changed. President Bush lionizes the nurturer, not the producer. He celebrates the teacher, the faith-based volunteer. The nation's greatness, Mr. Bush has declared, will be preserved through "small, unnumbered acts of caring and courage and self-denial," with the emphasis on small. These are not the values of the daring entrepreneur, but of the middle-class parent. 
In a country plagued by divorce, this family-oriented compassionate conservatism has a lot going for it. But it doesn't offer much in the way of guiding principles for reforming a major national institution like the tax code. Mr. Bush's main argument for the cut was that the surplus is "the people's money," not the government's money. Unlike the supply-side argument, this is a straight zero-sum proposition. There's a pot of money and we should have it, not the folks in Washington. No wonder the polls show only moderate support for a tax cut. "I want that money" is not exactly an inspiring rallying cry or a coherent organizing principle for tax reform. 
Substantively, the original Bush plan was ambitious, but it was chewed up in Congress by Republicans and Democrats alike. The bill that has emerged is a hodgepodge of slow-motion phase-ins and phase-outs, exemptions, deductions, and entitlements. Most of the cuts don't take effect for several years, and the whole bill becomes void in 2010. Meanwhile there are so many little goodies that reporters are still combing through and finding them. As a few economists have noted, rarely has such a big tax cut had so little social effect. Meanwhile, a once-in-a-decade chance at serious tax reform has been blown.
The grubbiest part of the tax cut was foisted on Mr. Bush by the Democrats -- the checks that will go out to taxpayers later in the year, at $300 for singles and $600 for married couples. This bit of pump-priming is exactly the sort of thing Reagan Republicans always fought. Instead of rearranging incentives to encourage innovation and production, it encourages more shopping. It treats wealth as a purely material thing: We've got some money. We're going to give it to you. We hope you'll vote for us. 
You may have loved supply-siders, or you may have thought they were ideologues and buffoons, but at least they had a theory of how to use fiscal policy for the common good. Every proposal was designed to produce entrepreneurial vigor and creativity. Now what we may be getting in divided Washington is not ideological gridlock but a mishmash of small-scale ideas and freely distributed goodies. In this way the surplus, and the remarkable opportunity it represents, are frittered away.

HEADLINE: Mr. Bush's Idea of Leadership 

 BODY:
President Bush has now occupied the White House for a little over four months. There is much to be said for the discipline and steadiness he has brought to the job. But at this point it is also fair to raise questions about Mr. Bush's vision of the office, his ideas about the exercise of executive power and his definition of the scope of presidential leadership and responsibility. The actions and inactions of these first months contain some troubling signs. He sometimes projects an air of detachment bordering on indifference even on issues of major concern. 
 His California trip this week provides a case study. On Monday he met with Gov. Gray Davis on the state's energy crisis, and on Wednesday did a photo op in Sequoia National Park. Twice he offered comforting words and minimalist policies out of keeping with his inaugural promise to be the president of Americans in every state, whether or not they voted for him. Californians have reason to wonder if they are being punished. Environmentalists, for their part, could be forgiven for feeling that the president thinks they do not know the difference between style and substance. 
 California has 34 million people. As a stand-alone country, it would be the world's sixth-largest economy. It preferred Al Gore by 12 percentage points in the last election, and its shrunken Republican Congressional delegation will be under severe pressures in 2002. What nearly every Californian wants is protection from the industrial shutdowns and air-conditioning failures that face them this summer. Any reasonable definition of presidential leadership would include concern for the health, safety and economic vitality of the nation's largest state. Mr. Bush was content to list the inadequate steps his administration has already taken, while flatly rejecting Governor Davis's pleas for short-term price relief. He was rather testy about it, too.
He was no more forthcoming on environmental questions when he appeared in Sequoia National Park two days later. The environment is an issue on which Mr. Bush has already discomfited a constituency that is even larger than California's ratepayers. These are the millions of Republican-voting suburbanites who worry that Mr. Bush's drill-and-burn energy strategy poses an unacceptable threat to clean air and wilderness areas. The White House is worried about losing them. Yet the best Mr. Bush could offer voters who were nervous about his plans to build hundreds of new power plants and open up sensitive public lands for oil and gas exploration was to repeat his campaign pledge to spend $4.9 billion on repairing roads and buildings in the national parks.
Even this commendable promise cannot stand close analysis. Since the days of Ulysses S. Grant, protection of the national parks has been a solemn presidential duty. But guarding what is already saved does not constitute a national environmental policy. And in this case, the economic aid is exaggerated. As the National Parks Conservation Association pointed out, there is only $61 million in new money in the maintenance program for this year. 
Infrastructure repair to the parks and cutting energy use in federal buildings are both reasonable steps that a president would routinely take. But they do not add up to visionary presidential leadership or serious intellectual engagement with the problems of citizens looking for a balanced approach to energy and the environment, or Californians facing a summer of crisis.

HEADLINE: From Germany's East to West, Conservative Tries to Span Gulf 

BYLINE:  By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: TEMPLIN, Germany 

 BODY:
In this quaint eastern town surrounded by lakes begins the story of the divided life of Angela Merkel, the politician who next year could become the first woman to lead modern Germany.
 It is a story with its share of German zigzags, one that has taken a member of the former East German Communist youth movement to the leadership of that bastion of conservatism, the Christian Democratic Party. "Nobody else from the east has ever made it this far," Volker Ruhe, a leading Christian Democrat, said simply. 
 In recent months, Ms. Merkel has toured America, chatting with Vice President Dick Cheney and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell. She has seen her party, hit by a financial scandal last year, consolidate its position in regional polls. And she has made clear that immigration will be a central plank of her campaign to be chancellor. 
"East Germans were used to a strong state," Ms. Merkel, 46, said. "And now they see this weak state apparently unable to punish abuses -- the Vietnamese spreading drugs, the Albanians stealing cars, the high crime rate among illegal immigrants, and the police doing nothing about it. This is how easterners think."
It is hard to escape the impression that this is also -- in some measure -- how Angela Merkel thinks. As elsewhere in Europe, immigration is an explosive issue here. Germany's lingering doubts about its identity after Nazism, then division, tend to complicate questions of who is German and who is not.
In theory, Ms. Merkel should be well placed to ease tensions. She understands the enduring cultural gulf between the east and west of the country. She is aware that a united Germany is still a work in progress. "We need a common understanding of what being in Germany means," she says.
But the fact is Ms. Merkel, like 17 million other former East Germans, was raised in a country almost devoid of foreigners, except for a large Soviet occupation force and a few thousand Vietnamese, who lived largely sequestered from Germans.
Now, the idea of a united Germany as a multicultural society of almost 80 million people with more than 7 million foreign-born inhabitants appears to trouble her. No other nation in Europe has as many foreigners.
"About 75 percent of the Turks in the world who live outside Turkey are in Germany," Ms. Merkel said. "We don't say that they should not be Muslims. But we do say that we are a country with a Christian background, and Turks must understand this."
Muslims are now the largest religious minority here, a status the Jews had in prewar Germany. Ms. Merkel said the situations were not comparable. "The Jews were Germans," she argued. "They spoke the German language. But this is often not the case with Turks."
She speaks calmly, with measured conviction. She is beguiling. She has a wide smile and a tendency to blush that led Helmut Kohl, the former chancellor, to call her "das Madchen" ("the girl"). But there is also a steeliness to her that belies the smile and a cool awareness of her unique position at the still troubled meeting point of two societies. 
In the last decade, former East Germans have tended to see heroes demolished rather than stars rising: they have learned that their gold medal-winning athletes were doped, their leaders liars, their friends spies. 
So the success of Ms. Merkel in a western party long dominated by men is seen by many easterners as a vindication of sorts. They respond to her plain-spoken manner, her unadorned style, her pleas for a new German patriotism.
Ms. Merkel, who was recently married, has also been through what an old friend from the east, Michael Schindhelm, now a theater director in Basel, Switzerland, called "this strange loss of roots, of identity, of context -- this experience of a cut that forces you to define yourself anew." It is an experience that almost all Germans from the east share.
But as she prepares for a likely battle next year with the Social Democratic chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, for the leadership of Europe's most powerful nation, the definition of the new Ms. Merkel still appears to be a work in progress.
Can she convince western skeptics that she is capable of running "Germany Inc."? Is she a woman of convictions or just an adaptable woman? Is she a new sort of German nationalist, one raised without the burden of shame carried by many western Germans? 
"It must be normal to sing the national anthem, to feel pride, to have a flag," Ms. Merkel said vehemently. "It must be normal at last." Yet there is little or nothing that fits the description "normal" in this woman's life.

Christian Family Goes East
Angela Merkel was a few months old when she was whisked from her birthplace, the elegant western city of Hamburg, to the backwater of Communist Templin, where her father, Horst Kasner, had accepted a job as a Lutheran pastor.
"It's straightforward why we came: we were needed here," said Herlind Kasner, Ms. Merkel's mother, a woman of startling blue eyes and directness. "We came as Christians helping other Christians. Some go to Africa. So why could we not go to the other part of our own country?"
But it was not easy as a religious family in the officially atheist east. Mrs. Kasner, a trained English teacher, was barred from working; her husband was kept on the margins of society; the three children absorbed official doctrine at school.
Still, little Angela thrived. She was a star student, entering nationwide competitions in Russian and math. "She was outstanding," said Hans-Ulrich Beeskow, a former teacher. "A friendly, open girl."
It was this friendliness, this desire for social contact that, as Ms. Merkel explains it, led her into the Pioneer Communist youth movement. She was communicative; she did not want to be an outsider.
"This was not a political decision," she said. "It was a decision to be among all the other people." She smiled, as if to say it was all as plain and simple as her trademark bangs.
But her decision -- a first taste of the compromise she has needed often since 1989 -- was not simple to accept for her devoutly Christian parents, who saw their daughter blend in beneath the atheistic banners of Communism. "Our approach is hard to explain in the west," Mrs. Kasner suggested. "But quite simply the children had a nice time together in these groups." 
Ulrich Schoneich, now the mayor of Templin, also grew up the child of a pastor in East Germany. His parents, resolutely opposed to the Communist state, stopped him from joining any of the youth movements -- and he suffered for it. "I think my father was right," said Mr. Schoneich. "But each family must decide for itself."
Ms. Merkel's view of East German society today is marked by the ambivalence of somebody who adjusted to survive. Yes, it was oppressive, she says. But there were family, friends, nature. "The system was evil," she said. "But not everything was evil. Even in a system like that, Christmas Eve can be nice."
Capitalism can also look less than nice. Unemployment in Templin, as in many towns in the east, is now 24 percent. The old furniture and textile industries have collapsed. Employment in the agricultural sector has plummeted.
"The world is not black and white," Mrs. Kasner said. "I went to America in 1986 with my association of churches and saw blacks with crutches lying on the church steps. Then I came back here and saw doctors living in the same apartments as workers. As a Christian, you may start to ask which system is better. It is not easy."
Still, the Kasner family opposed the Communist government. In 1989, as protests grew, their church was a center for peace prayers and discussion. Throughout the decades they lived there, Pastor Kasner would defiantly ring the church bell next to his house to usher in the New Year.

Adjusting Rapidly in East
What Lothar de Maiziere, the last leader of East Germany before unification, first noticed in Angela Merkel was her succinctness. Her press summaries, he recalled, "said twice as much in 20 minutes as my other spokesperson said in 40."
She had emerged from a job as a researcher at the East German Academy of Sciences in 1989, joining a short-lived movement called Democratic Awakening, and later the Christian Democrats under Mr. de Maiziere. He made her responsible for the media.
It was a heady time. "We had seen heaven on TV in the Deutsche mark," said Mr. de Maiziere, who is now a lawyer. "We thought we could have that and justice. But all we got is the rule of law."
Unlike many East Germans, Ms. Merkel adjusted rapidly. She was diligent, pragmatic, quick -- and she soon caught Mr. Kohl's eye. Asked why, she replied with crisp precision:
"I was from the east, a woman and young. As such, I represented three minorities within the party. That was hard to resist. And so I became a protege of Kohl as he sought to establish the party in the east."
She moved rapidly through a couple of minor ministerial jobs under Mr. Kohl. Then, when Mr. Kohl was dislodged by Mr. Schroder in 1998 and a year later became embroiled in a party financial scandal, she had the courage to confront her mentor directly.
It was that stand that ultimately projected her to the leadership of the party. "I came out and criticized Kohl because I really thought the Christian Democratic Party was in danger," she said. "That is no longer the case. Christian Democracy is stable."
It is true that German Christian Democracy, unlike Italian Christian Democracy, has survived the end of the cold war, the discovery of corruption, the decline of the church, and the erosion of traditional conservative values in Europe. It has adopted new agendas -- including what British politicians call "the race card".
Ms. Merkel, who took over the chairmanship of the Christian Democrats last year, is widely credited with this revival, which has placed her party in opinion polls within range of the Social Democrats at about 35 percent of the vote, compared with the governing party's 40 percent. Her fresh image helped stabilize a crisis-ridden party.
But, naturally, she is also resented by the many party honchos, all of them men, who had been jostling beneath Mr. Kohl for more than a decade only to find themselves overtaken by an upstart woman from the east. Being young, female and eastern is no longer the triple trump card it once was.
Mr. Ruhe, a former defense minister under Mr. Kohl who is now close to Ms. Merkel, said it was natural that doubts persisted. "The potential sympathy for her in the country is enormous," he said. "But she has never been a state premier. The question is: Do Germans believe she can do the job of chancellor?"
In the east at least -- and the electorate there swung the last national poll to Mr. Schroder -- people do seem to believe in her. Mr. de Maiziere said the main reason was that she understood the frustrations of the area.
"We have enough trouble defining ourselves," he said. "Where am I in this new country? Where do I belong? And then a foreigner comes along and tells me how to live or makes money in front of my face. Frankfurt has a population that is almost 30 percent foreign. But an eastern town like Leipzig would explode in those conditions."
Even in Frankfurt, there are tensions. Under a banner saying "Control Immigration, Promote Integration," Ms. Merkel appears at a rally to promote her party's new policies. A little overweight, her nails bitten down, her face moon-like beneath the bangs, she is clearly a far cry from the modern political products of image merchants and spin doctors. But it is this I-am-who-I-am stubborn streak that appeals to many Germans.
She knows what she wants. When Wolfgang Bosbach, the deputy chairman of the Christian Democrats' parliamentary group, rises to declare that "we want a clear rejection of a multicultural society," she applauds enthusiastically.
Later the debate is opened to the crowd, and a blond woman who appears almost hysterical with a mixture of nervousness and anger rises. "I do not want Islam," she says. "There are lots of them around me. Wherever I go, women are in headscarves. I do not want Islamic immigrants on the job market and our social insurance rolls."
Ms. Merkel nods, her lips pursed. Unlike the case in the United States, in most European countries foreigners arriving are immediately entitled to a range of social benefits, including free medicine and schooling for their children.
This stokes resentment, and debates rage as to whether European countries are a "safe haven" or merely a "soft touch" for asylum-seekers.
A number of statistics have been marshaled by Ms. Merkel as she takes her immigration roadshow around Germany. In the 1970's, there were four million foreigners, and two million of them had jobs. Now there are seven million, but the number in jobs has stagnated. "Immigration is not going into our labor market but into our social security system," she says. "That is the problem."

Staying a Western Nation
Her party's answer is to try to curtail the foreign presence by, for instance, speeding up deportation procedures for illegals and tightening regulations for family members to join immigrants already in Germany. At the same time, the party wants to lure highly qualified foreigners to the country. "For real specialists," Ms. Merkel said, "We want to offer much better opportunities."
"We must be part of the war for talent in the world," Mr. Ruhe said. That foreign talent, however, should not undermine the Western, Christian identity of Germany.
Ms. Merkel is irritated by American calls to bring Turkey swiftly into the European Union. Membership confers the right to work freely within the Union. Millions more Turks could pour into Germany. "Imagine," she says, "taking away the border between Mexico and the United States. It is just not possible in the forseeable future."
She continues: "Inviting Turkey to become a candidate for European Union membership was a mistake. There are differences of values. We do not have the same understanding of human rights. Try opening a Christian church in Istanbul."
Her old friend from the east, Mr. Schindhelm, is dismayed by the views she now articulates on immigration and German national identity. He had thought of her as a liberal. When he left the East German Academy in 1986, she gave him a copy of Gogol's "Dead Souls" inscribed with the words, "Go into the open."
Now he works in Basel, an open city whose population is 40 percent foreign. "I think she knows in her heart that we need openness," Mr. Schindhelm said. "So either she does not have the strength to push that idea, or she has adapted herself to the prevailing forces." He paused before adding, "And yet, I trust her."
