PERSON: Bobby Flay 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
A Duel of Wits and Crustaceans, Round 2

BYLINE:  By JOHN KIFNER 

 BODY:
THEY duel with lobsters.
 That's all we're going to tell you about the big "Iron Chef" grudge rematch between Bobby Flay and Masaharu Morimoto on the Food Network Sunday night. The secret ingredient is 60 Japanese lobsters, Ise-ebi, reputedly worth $10,000. We're not going to tell you who wins. More important, we're not going to tell you if Mr. Flay stands on his cutting board again. 
 "You really get into this -- it's like a battle to the death," Mr. Flay, who brings the bravado to cooking he once brought to schoolboy basketball, baseball and track, was saying the other evening as his popular Mesa Grill began filling up. "It's exhilarating." 
If memory serves, his last encounter with Mr. Morimoto ended bitterly. To reprise: "Iron Chef" is a Japanese program -- Julia Child meets the World Wrestling Federation -- with a cult following. The conceit revolves around one Chairman Kaga, a gazillionaire with feudal overtones, a red-draped Kitchen Stadium and four culinary gladiators -- the Iron Chefs -- masters of, respectively, Japanese, Chinese, French and Italian cuisine. He wears brocaded capes and sinister black gunfighter gloves and munches a yellow bell pepper. Each week, one of his Iron Chefs -- who rise majestically in clouds of smoke out of the floor, sternly clutching very big knives -- battles a challenger, usually winning.
The contest involves a secret ingredient, from which the chefs must make four or five dishes in 60 minutes. The action is covered like a sport with a floor reporter relaying excited snatches ("In the blender, Bobby Flay has coriander, spinach and chives. . . . Morimoto is tearing open that crab. . . .") to play-by-play commentators who deliver portentous analysis ("The crowd is starting to go wild. . . . We've never had a battle like this. . . ."). Except for Chairman Kaga, translated in subtitles, the whole thing is voiced-over in deadpan, slightly daffy English. It is a hoot.
In March of last year, the Chairman traveled here to match his man, Mr. Morimoto, who was the chef at Nobu, against Mr. Flay, the brash celebrity-chef owner of Mesa Grill and Bolo. Rock crab was the ingredient; it was a hard-fought loss for Mr. Flay. Early on, tense, he cut a thumb on the blade in his Cuisinart. Then he got a tremendous shock from an electric stove. But the most dramatic moment came when Mr. Flay, dishes finished, climbed atop his counter, pumping his fists in the air, shouting, "Raise the roof! Raise the roof!" as the crowd roared.
Mr. Morimoto was horrified. "He's not a chef," he told the floor reporter, looking stricken. "After finishing, he stood up on the cutting board. That's not right. He stood on the cutting board. Cutting boards and knives are sacred to us."
IT was like I killed his mother," said Mr. Flay, still stunned. "I was really upset. I had apparently disrespected Morimoto. That's the last thing I wanted. Nobu is one of my favorite restaurants.
"It was no big deal -- I do worse at a Knicks game."
Bobby Flay, 36, is one of those rare people who discover early what they love and make a huge success of it, with, so far, two restaurants, three cookbooks and two television shows. It was not always clear this would be so. A tough New York boy, he bounced through several high schools ("I was terrible"), finishing at a place, now closed, that he described as "the last-chance school."
His father, a scholarly lawyer, was a part owner in Joe Allen's, the theater district restaurant. When a busboy needed two weeks off for an emergency, he ordered his unemployed son to fill in. Soon he was helping the chef. He was 17 years old, and Joe Allen sent him back to school, paying for a six-month course at the French Culinary Institute in SoHo. Then Mr. Allen told him to move on, and he began cooking at places on the Upper East Side, ending up with Jonathan Waxman when he opened Jams, one of the first restaurants in the city spreading the gospel of the New American cuisine.
"It was crazy," said Mr. Flay, whose red-haired boyish good looks and macho style have helped make him a star. "For a young cook, rubbing shoulders with Wolfgang Puck, Larry Forgione."
But at 23, he was burned out. He skied six straight weeks at Aspen, then tried a job on the stock exchange. He went back to cooking at Miracle Grill, where he was discovered by Jerome Kretchmer, the restaurant impresario behind Gotham Bar and Grill. ("You're much better looking than me," Mr. Kretchmer said at the time. "This is never going to work.") They opened Mesa Grill, featuring Mr. Flay's distinctive, bold Southwestern food, 10 years ago, the day the Persian Gulf war began ("The first dish went out as we dropped the bombs on Iraq. Everybody went home to watch CNN.") to immediate success. Bolo, with the food of Spain, opened seven years ago. The two restaurants are very different.
"Squeeze bottles are our lives," he said in the kitchen of Mesa Grill, hefting the plastic vials used to apply squiggles of flavor, among them smoked red and yellow chilies, cilantro oil, red chili oil, lime glaze. A half dozen blocks away at Bolo, the squeeze bottles hold saffron, mustard oil, roasted garlic, green onion sauce.
"That's the palate here, the food of the Mediterranean, tons of garlic," Mr. Flay said in Bolo's smaller kitchen. "Here, no cilantro is allowed. At Mesa Grill, it's all about cilantro. I'm really big into flavor. Nobody will ever come to my restaurants and say the food is bland."

HEADLINE: Five Powers Delay Vote on Easing Iraq Trade 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 31 

 BODY:
The five major powers on the Security Council agreed today to postpone for 30 days a vote on a more generous trade policy for Iraq. 
 The extension is intended to give experts time to evaluate a detailed list of items that the United States wants to prevent Saddam Hussein's government from buying unless it obtains international approval. 
 A meeting on Wednesday in Budapest among Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and his counterparts from Britain, France and Russia appears to have resulted in a compromise to extend the existing "oil for food" program for Iraq for a much shorter period than Russia had been seeking. 
Britain and the United States wanted no extension, but aimed for a vote this week on a new plan that would lift restrictions on the sale of civilian goods to Iraq while trying to tighten controls on oil smuggling and military purchases.
The full Council may vote on Friday on temporararily extending the current program, which faces a renewal deadline of midnight Sunday.
Iraq immediately threatened again to cut off oil production if the extension is adopted. The program is usually renewed every six months.
"Iraq will not deal with it," Ambassador Mohammed Aldouri told reporters today as the Council met on the extension. "Consequently Iraq will not conclude any oil contract based on it, and this resolution will be for us just another dead resolution."
Diplomats and some United Nations officials say the Iraqi threat, if carried out, may not disrupt the oil market as much as Mr. Hussein may expect. This year, Iraq withheld oil from the market, and prices dropped, a diplomat said. 
A temporary extension of the "oil for food" program under which Iraq may sell unlimited quantities of oil to buy a wide range of goods, will give a divided Security Council some time for negotiations. Still, diplomats expect sharp debate over the American list of goods that Washington wants to monitor so that Iraq cannot reconstruct weapons by diverting material or equipment that also has civilian uses. The Russians and French have questioned some items. 
Secretary Powell acknowledged to reporters on the plane returning to Washington from Budapest that "the difficulty, of course, is in the details," adding that the list of items was "excruciatingly detailed."

HEADLINE: A Failed Energy Plan Catches Up to New York 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE and RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

 BODY:
To understand the troubled progress of electricity deregulation in New York, it helps to consider a cluster of gray prefabricated buildings at the foot of the Williamsburg Bridge in Brooklyn.
 Inside are the components of a small power generator, one of 10 that the state is hurriedly installing in the city to avert blackouts and price spikes when temperatures rise this summer. 
 Things were not supposed to turn out this way. When Gov. George E. Pataki set out to deregulate New York's electricity business five years ago, he offered a simple promise: break up the old utility monopolies, and the free market will deliver new power plants and reduce the high rates that were driving employers out of the state. 
But private power companies have not yet built any plants. So to ensure the city's lights stay on, the state has stepped in, installing its small generators and encouraging hundreds of businesses to turn on sooty diesel generators when demand is high. 
Meanwhile, with supplies tight, Consolidated Edison's rates -- the highest in the continental United States before deregulation -- have risen significantly, up almost 40 percent from two years ago. Just yesterday, the managers of the state's power grid predicted that peak summer rates could rise an additional 22 percent by 2003.
Now, Con Ed, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani -- even the State Public Service Commission, which drafted New York's deregulation plan -- are calling for increased government control over the state's electricity market. And the energy plan that President Bush issued last month lumps New York with California among the states with the nation's most severe energy supply problems.
Unlike in California, there have been no utility bankruptcies or rolling blackouts here. And few voices are calling for a return to the old system, in which the state oversaw plant construction and told utilities what they could charge for power. Nevertheless, a host of critics, from former commission staffers to business lobbyists to consumer advocates, say that deregulation in New York has gone awry. 
Other states took a cautious approach to restructuring an industry that had been under tight government control for decades. But New York -- driven by an urgent desire to lower rates and an abiding faith in the free market -- opted for sudden, sweeping change. 
The Pataki administration ignored warnings that prices could rise under deregulation unless steps were taken to ensure adequate supplies of power. It cast aside expert findings that the utilities' plans to sell their power plants to just a few buyers might invite the new owners to engage in price gouging. 
And while virtually every other state took pains to shield ratepayers during the transition to free-market power, New York let its leading utilities pass their costs through to ratepayers -- big companies upstate, and all of Con Ed's customers downstate. 
Officials in Albany note that the sharp rise in rates, especially in New York City, has primarily been because of surging prices for the natural gas used to fire many power plants. They say those fuel costs would have been passed along to consumers even under the old, regulated system. For now, they counsel patience.
"We understand that deregulation is in a transition period right now," Governor Pataki said in an interview. "We don't have the wholesale markets the way they should be -- not just in New York, but across the nation -- so we have to take steps to make sure the consumer is protected, and we've been doing that."
But the experience of other states reveals that their consumers are better protected, and that the transition need not be so painful. 
For example, in Massachusetts -- a state dependent on a comparable mix of high-priced fossil fuels -- rates have gone up just half as much as in New York, and are expected to hold steady through 2001. Con Ed's rates could go still higher this summer, if demand squeezes supplies.
The contrast, critics say, reflects the history of New York's experiment in energy deregulation: a study in faulty assumptions, unheeded omens and unkept promises.
"They thought it was a classic win-win situation," said George M. Knapp, a partner at the Coudert Brothers law firm who represents power producers. "What could possibly go wrong -- except everything that did go wrong?"

Relying on an Unreliable Market
When the Pataki administration unveiled its deregulation plan in 1996, New York's utilities were producing more electricity than customers were using. The plan assumed that the surplus would last until 2005, if not longer, by which time market forces would have lured new power generating supplies to meet rising demand. 
But the governor's proposal ignored a warning that New York was on the verge of rapidly losing its surplus due to increasing demand. A team at the Public Service Commission had forecast -- accurately, it turned out -- that New York would need new power plants by 2000. 
"The feeling at the P.S.C. was, 'Yeah, that's true, but the market will respond,' " said Lawrence DeWitt, who headed the team predicting trouble. "It was consistent with the philosophy. It was the big leap."
Now, though the demand is real, major new power plants remain years away. Power suppliers have proposed 21 large and mid-sized plants around the state, of which two have been approved. They will begin operating in late 2003, at the earliest, and neither is intended to serve New York City, where the need is most acute. 
Other states years ago took steps to ensure extra supplies of power. Massachusetts, for example, streamlined the application process for building plants -- without softening environmental or other regulations; that is helping New England add enough plants this year to provide power to 2.6 million homes. Michigan, as part of its deregulation plan, has instructed utilities to find a way to increase transmission in the state by about 50 percent by June 2002. 
New York, though, decided that its new power markets would be largely free of the state's hand. On taking office in 1995, Governor Pataki eliminated the state energy office, a planning body that he had derided during his campaign as a waste of money. From 1988 to 1999, no state agency had the authority to issue environmental permits for new power plants.
"Essentially there was a lot of rhetoric that the market would do the planning," said Carl Pechman, a former Public Service Commission supervisor and now head of Power Economics, a consulting firm. "The feeling was, 'You don't need an agency to plan when you need a steel mill or new refinery, so you don't need an agency to plan when you need new power plants.' "
Meanwhile, to deliver quick dividends on deregulation, the administration eliminated a two percent surcharge on electricity bills that had supported conservation programs. Utilities had used the money to conduct "energy audits" showing consumers how to use less power, and to subsidize their purchases of more efficient appliances. But big power users complained that the surcharge, which cost them millions each year, gave them few benefits.
In the mid-1990's, the state scaled back its energy conservation program, once the country's most aggressive, by more than 70 percent, a process that began before Mr. Pataki took office but which he accelerated. There have been increases since then -- particularly this year, as the state looks to conservation as one way to avert an energy crisis. 
But New York still spends far less on conservation than it did a decade ago. Environmentalists say that if programs had been financed at the old levels, demand would be about 500 megawatts lower -- equivalent to the output of a medium-size power plant. That, in turn, would ease the tight electricity supplies that have helped drive up prices.

Focusing on a Quick Payoff
The very essence of power deregulation was the state's requirement that utilities sell their power plants. The idea was that the new owners -- lean companies unburdened by the heritage of monopoly -- would compete to sell power to Con Ed and other electricity retailers, thereby forcing prices down.
But here too, critics say, the state's determination to get a quick payoff from deregulation took priority. 
The deals that the state negotiated with the utilities counted on proceeds from the power plant sales to finance the governor's promise of an immediate reduction in ratepayers' bills. To maximize those proceeds, the Public Service Commission went along with the utilities' demands to sell their plants in bundles of bigger and smaller plants. 
That indeed drew higher bids; Con Ed, for example, received nearly double the book value of its plants in the city. But it sold them in 1999 to just three buyers: Orion Power Holdings Inc., then a private company backed by Goldman, Sachs and the Mitsubishi Corp.; NRG Energy Inc., a Minneapolis-based company; and KeySpan, the energy company in Brooklyn. 
Some politicians and economists warned that the concentration of ownership might backfire. Miles Bidwell, an economist and former consultant with the Independent Power Producers of New York, filed testimony in 1997 with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission stating that New York's plan would create a market susceptible to price manipulation.
Like other analysts, he believed that the plants drew high prices because the buyers expected high rates for their electricity. 
"The fact that people were willing to pay such huge amounts for the power plants doesn't in itself mean they're buying market power, but it raises a flag, and you expect people to examine the issue more carefully," Mr. Bidwell said. "I said the economic analysis was never done about the impact of the sales."
Now the impact is becoming clear. 
Statewide, suppliers manipulated prices on the wholesale markets about 10 times last year, according to the Independent System Operator, which runs the state's power grid. Just one of those instances, it says, cost utilities about $100 million. In New York City, electricity prices on the real-time market -- where Con Ed purchases about 5 percent of its power -- have spiked repeatedly near the limit of $1,000 per megawatt hour allowed by the state, which is about 20 times the average price.
The Pataki administration, which long disdained the notion of government controls on energy markets, now wants the Independent System Operator to have the authority to order lower prices when power generators' bids are suspiciously high. It also wants the grid operator to have the authority to fine generators for price gouging.
But the Independent System Operator, which includes energy suppliers, has been reluctant to endorse a system of penalties, and both measures would require the approval of federal regulators, who to date have been hostile to such controls.
The power generators strongly deny any wrongdoing. "I don't believe there is a lot of gouging taking place," said Craig Mataczynski, chief executive of NRG. "Much of what is talked about is mythical in nature."
Other states, besides taking steps to assure power supplies were adequate before unleashing the forces of deregulation, laid plans to police their new wholesale markets more closely than New York. 
For example, the PJM Interconnection, the transmission system for all or part of Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Maryland, Washington, Virginia and Delaware, introduced its wholesale market in phases over three years. The idea was to monitor the behavior of power suppliers and iron out any problems.
PJM is not immune to price gouging. But it requires that suppliers report daily the actual cost of generating power at their plants, which makes it easier for the system's managers to spot price manipulation.
"PJM did things one step at a time," said Tim Mount, professor of applied economics and management at Cornell University and an expert on the electricity industry. "One only has to look at California to see how difficult it is to resolve problems on the fly."

Unheeded Warnings on Bill Shock
Experts had warned New York that energy deregulation, because it was complex and untested, could lead to higher prices, at least initially. As early as 1994, the Public Service Commission, under Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, said that in any deregulation plan, "the commission should strive to minimize 'bill shock' for any class of customers."
Customers are shielded elsewhere. California, the most extreme case, let generators charge market prices for power, but froze the rates that the utilities could charge consumers. That led to bankruptcy for the state's largest utility, Pacific Gas & Electric.
Other states have so far struck a balance protecting both consumers and utilities. In Massachusetts, for example, utilities are required under the state's deregulation laws to enter into long-term contracts for power. Such agreements mean that customers pay a fixed rate for electricity, and the utilities buy only a small portion of their power on volatile wholesale markets. 
But the negotiators whom Governor Pataki charged with hammering out New York's new power markets were confident that prices would fall. And so, unlike utilities elsewhere, Con Ed was allowed to pass the price of power along to its customers.
Con Ed insisted on the pass-through in its deregulation talks with the state. Because the utility takes no mark-up on power it resells to consumers, it says that the arrangement is fair. "Based on what we've seen transpire in California, I think it was correct -- not just for us but our customers," said Michael Clendenin, a company spokesman. 
In retrospect, the state's critics say that the utility's insistence on a pass-through should have been a red flag that it foresaw rising prices. But the state's focus was on other issues.
"They took a very strong position that if they didn't get the pass-through, they would be at risk financially from buying power on the market," said John O'Mara, who as chairman of the Public Service Commission from 1996 to 1998 was the architect of New York's deregulation plan. "In return, they were willing to give us a better deal over all."
Again, the aim was a big cut in customers' bills. And over the last three years, the utilities have delivered -- on the portion of customers' bills that covers the cost of delivering power to homes and businesses. Con Ed, for example, has reduced those rates by 16.8 percent. 
But unexpectedly high fuel prices, accentuated by the market power exercised by generators, have eclipsed the savings. Over all, Con Ed bills were 38 percent higher in January than two years earlier.
Upstate, the state allowed the biggest utility, the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, to pass through power costs to industrial customers, but not to residents and smaller businesses. The logic was that in a competitive market, big businesses would have enough clout to find cheaper power themselves.
Instead, new suppliers have offered upstate companies electricity at prices as high as Niagara Mohawk's or higher, a situation that customers attribute to tight electricity supplies.
As a result, large manufacturers that once ardently supported deregulation now pay hundreds of thousands of dollars more a month for power than they had budgeted. Some are considering leaving the state. 
In a little more than a year, the nation's largest brass mill, Outokumpu American Brass, has gone from bustling to staggering, choking on its vast appetite for electricity. It pays $850,000 a month for power, over $200,000 more than it did in late 1999. The Finnish-owned company, based in Buffalo, is now considering layoffs for the first time in a decade. 
"It's killing us," said Earl Robinson, an Outokumpu vice president. "I want everyone to understand that this is a crisis."

Power Politics
Tight power supplies and pioneering deregulation plans make the Northeast a focal point of the nation's energy crisis. This is the second article of a series looking at the political and economic roots of deregulation and at efforts to address energy shortages in the region. The first article, which appeared on Feb. 25, is available at: www.nytimes.com/metro

CORRECTION-DATE: June 2, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about energy deregulation in New York described the state's troubled progress in establishing a market-based system for generating and selling electricity.
Because of an editing error, the headline, "A Failed Energy Plan Catches Up to New York," exceeded the findings of the article. The reporting showed that officials had ignored warnings about the pitfalls of deregulation and that promises of lower electric rates had not been fulfilled. But the article also made it clear that the process was still in its early stages and that the state was taking steps to rectify some flaws in its plan. The headline should have reflected the calls for increased consumer protections pending an improvement in the system.
Charts with the article, explaining the components of a typical electric bill, were misattributed. The information was from the State Public Service Commission, not Consolidated Edison.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
High Rates for Argentine Bonds

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, June 1 

 BODY:
Argentina is offering to pay interest rates approaching 16 percent to persuade investors to swap an expected $20 billion in government debt for new bonds.
 The debt swap, which is being closely watched in bond markets in the United States and Europe, is a major element in the government's effort to revive the moribund economy. 
 Argentina wants investors to exchange some of 46 existing bonds, most of which mature before 2006, for five longer-term bonds to stretch out financing costs. A three-year recession and a rising budget deficit have raised concerns that the country may not make payments on its $128 billion debt. Today, the government disclosed price and coupon details about the five new bonds, and the results of the swap will be announced on Monday. 
A global dollar bond due in 2008 was priced at $78.55 to yield 15.97 percent, J. P. Morgan Chase, one of the banks managing the swap, told investors. A 2008 bond in pesos will yield 15.99 percent, while global dollar bonds due in 2018 and 2031 were priced to yield 15.25 percent and 14.91 percent, respectively.
The rates are higher than the range of 14 to 15 percent that was expected by investors early this week, and may almost double the country's finance costs beginning in 2006, analysts said.
"It's certainly a high price to pay," said Robert Koenigsberger, who co-manages $100 million in emerging-market debt for Gramercy Advisors in Greenwich, Conn., and who is not swapping his Argentine bonds. "It does not bode well for economic growth and private-sector financing when the interest rate that the government is forced to pay is so high."
The government needs to offer a premium to attract investors to the swap, insuring an exchange worth as much as $20 billion. 
Local banks and pension funds, which hold about $39 billion of the $66.7 billion in bonds eligible for the swap, may account for 90 percent of the transaction, analysts said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS; 
Rallies in Dow and Nasdaq Erase Some Losses for Week

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
After a cautious reading of reports on employment and manufacturing that offered conflicting messages about the strength of the American economy, investors embraced battered technology stocks yesterday and touched off a modest rally.
 The Nasdaq composite index gained 38.95 points, or 1.85 percent, to 2,149.44, but it still ended the week down 4.51 percent, its worst performance since the first week of April. 
 The Dow rose 78.47 points, or 0.72 percent, to 10,990.41, cutting its loss for the holiday-shortened week to 0.14 percent. And the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 4.85 points, or 0.39 percent, to 1,260.67, off 1.35 percent for the week. 
Over all, investors seemed to interpret yesterday's economic data as "benign, roughly," said Jon Brorson, director of equities for Northern Trust, a money management concern. But it took investors a while to reach that conclusion.
The leading gauges opened on the positive side after the Labor Deportment reported an unexpected decline in the unemployment rate to 4.4 percent last month, from 4.5 percent in April. Businesses cut 19,000 jobs from their payrolls in May, a smaller decline than expected.
But prices came under pressure around 10 a.m. after the National Association of Purchasing Management reported a decrease in industrial activity for May, with its purchasing index falling to 42.1 in May from 43.2 a month earlier. That decline reinforced earlier signs of weakness in manufacturing, which lost 124,000 jobs in May.
By early afternoon, though, stocks edged higher, led by technology issues.
"The market just seemed to take every piece of information and extrapolate it into a trend" yesterday, Brett Gallagher, vice president of Julius Baer Investment Management, said.
Treasury prices rose in response to the weak manufacturing figures, as traders hoped the data would provide the Federal Reserve with more reason to cut interest rates later this month.
The 10-year Treasury note edged up 2/32, to 97 9/32, while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.36 percent from 5.37 percent on Thursday. The 30-year Treasury bond rose 18/32, to 95 9/32, while its yield fell to 5.71 percent from 5.75 percent Thursday.
Stock trading volume was somewhat modest yesterday, with fewer than 1.2 billion shares changing hands on the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts said this was a sign that investors remained cautious, bracing themselves as companies began forecasting their second-quarter earnings, many of which are expected to miss Wall Street's forecasts. Investors are also concerned about how aggressively the Fed will act on interest rates.
"The market is in kind of a quandary because on the one hand it shows that the Fed could ease, which should be good for the market," said Howard H. Mackey, vice president and head of the trading desk at M. R. Beal & Company, referring to the new economic reports. "But these numbers suggest that we're going to continue to see some negative earnings reports."
Among the stocks lifting the Dow, Boeing climbed $2.11, to $65, after it reached a tentative agreement with its machinists' union. Among the Dow's technology components, Intel gained $1.73, to $28.74; I.B.M. rose $1.09, to $112.89; and Microsoft rose $1.16, to $70.34.
The gains in Intel and other chip makers' stocks pushed the Philadelphia semiconductor index up 18.89 points, or 3.16 percent, to 617.60.
Computer software makers helped nudge the Nasdaq higher. Oracle rose 56 cents, to $15.86, while Veritas Software gained $2.88, to $68.79.
Among the Dow components outside the technology sector, Merck rose $1.21, to $74.20, and Johnson & Johnson rose $1.05, to $98.
Houghton Mifflin jumped $4.99, to $59.55, after it agreed to be acquired by Vivendi Universal for $60 a share in cash, or $1.7 billion.
In the spirit of the afternoon's optimism, investors granted DuPont shares a reprieve. They had fallen more than $1 after a company executive told analysts and investors that DuPont would continue to face challenges in the second quarter and that the operating environment in the last half of the year would be weaker than the corresponding period a year earlier. But by the end of the day, the stock was down only 33 cents, to $46.07.

HEADLINE: U.N. Chief Calls on U.S. Companies to Donate to AIDS Fund 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 1 

 BODY:
The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, appealed to American corporations today to dig into their pockets and give to a planned multibillion-dollar global fund to fight AIDS in Africa and other developing regions.
 Mr. Annan, who until now has focused on governments as major donors to the fund, has received pledges so far from only three nations, including the United States. Today, he tried to convince corporations that it was in their economic self-interest to contribute to the fund and to set up their own programs in the workplace to protect employees. 
 But with comparatively little American trade and investment in Africa, and relatively few big companies active on the continent, Mr. Annan faced an uphill battle. So he offered other arguments, including combating the growing sentiment against globalization. 
"As AIDS creates more poverty and deepens inequalities, it fuels the growing public backlash against globalization," he told executives of major corporations at the United States Chamber of Commerce today. "This sentiment will only get stronger and more widespread if we do not show ourselves determined to mount a really serious response." 
Businesses, which he described as profiting most from globalization, "will come under more and more public pressure to provide leadership." 
Mr. Annan, who is from Ghana, and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell whose ancestry is African and Caribbean, have joined forces in an unusually high-profile and strikingly personal campaign to beam a spotlight on the tragedy of AIDS in Africa.
In seizing the issue, they have encouraged the seven leading industrial countries and Russia, which will hold their G-8 summit meeting in Genoa, Italy, next month, to put AIDS in Africa high on their agenda. 
The two men met in Secretary Powell's office at the State Department immediately after Mr. Annan's speech. Secretary Powell returned this week from a tour of Africa, where he looked at AIDS programs, held hands with children afflicted with the disease and encouraged people to "send in their nickels and dimes and dollars" for the trust fund. 
Mr. Annan did not ask for precise amounts from the corporate executives present today, and no pledges were forthcoming. In answer to a question afterward, he said he expected "big bucks" from corporations. 
But the White House has had little success in a less public approach to corporate leaders to give to the fund, officials familiar with the effort said today. When President Bush announced that the United States would give $200 million as an initial contribution to the global AIDS fund, the White House also wanted to be able to say that corporations were giving as well. 
Because the structure of the fund had not yet been determined, corporations said they were reluctant to come forward with donations, the officials said. The companies were particularly unwilling to give to a fund run by the United Nations, the officials said. 
But now that it has been decided that the fund will not be managed by the United Nations bureaucracy in New York, officials expect that both corporations and individual nations will be more forthcoming. Mr. Annan explained today that decisions on how the money would be spent would be left to experts in recipient countries. The World Bank, which is part of the United Nations system, will hold the money but not attach conditions to it. 
Mr. Annan has said that his goal for the fund is $7 billion to $10 billion, well above the money currently available to fight AIDS, which is now about $1 billion. 
Britain announced on Thursday that it would give $106.5 million, and France announced a donation of $125 million. 
Mr. Annan also pointed to two corporate programs to help employees as models for what can be accomplished.
Anglo American, the world's largest mining company, has begun distributing anti-retroviral drugs and giving palliative care to its 50,000 workers in Botswana, he said. That is a big step forward for Africa, where only about 10,000 people of the 26 million who are H.I.V. positive receive the drugs, AIDS experts said. 
Mr. Annan also praised Volkswagen for its H.I.V. prevention program in Brazil. The company also provides treatment, including anti-retroviral drugs, he said. By 1999, the company had seen a 90 percent reduction in hospitalization among H.I.V.-positive workers, he said. 
Also, after several years of internal debate on whether to have the brand associated with AIDS, the Coca-Cola Company is planning this month to announce a project of AIDS prevention and education for its workers in Africa. Coca-Cola, which was in the forefront of carrying polio vaccine in its refrigerated trucks in India, is the largest private employer in Africa, with more than 100,000 workers.

HEADLINE: Commencements; 
College Honors Man It Tried To Discredit

BYLINE:  By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Fifty years ago, at the height of the McCarthy era, Brooklyn College permanently shut down Vanguard, a student newspaper, and branded the paper's 19-year-old editor "a bad campus citizen."
 The student, William L. Taylor, went on to Yale Law School and was later nominated by President Lyndon B. Johnson to be staff director of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, but college officials urged the government not to hire him. They told investigators with the Federal Bureau of Investigation of a "remarkable similarity" between editorials in the student paper and Communist literature. 
 And according to his F.B.I. file, which Mr. Taylor obtained a few years ago, they also condemned him for membership on the student council, which, one official said, had "espoused liberal causes such as the rights of the Negro in the South." 
But the Senate approved him anyway, and he played a major role in creating and monitoring federal civil rights legislation.
Yesterday, Brooklyn College, in a gesture that mixed contrition with pride, paid tribute to Mr. Taylor and his decades of civil rights work by giving him an honorary degree. Christoph M. Kimmich, the college's president, called Mr. Taylor "a person who represents what this institution is all about." 
Mr. Taylor, tall, with wavy white hair and a relaxed manner and robed in a long black academic gown, in turn praised Brooklyn College. He said it was there that he had learned the importance of engaging in the moral struggles of one's era, although, he allowed, it was a lesson that the college administration of the time had not intended.
"It was a character-building experience,"' Mr. Taylor, 69, said. "I learned that you could speak out for things you believed in and that nothing bad would happen to you. I have spent my life doing that."
He and some of his classmates recalled that the period after World War II was a tumultuous one for both the country and Brooklyn College, a public tuition-free institution that attracted highly motivated children of immigrants and other poor families. Some called the college, in Flatbush, the little red schoolhouse because of the number of faculty members and students believed to be Communist sympathizers.
The president of the college at the time, Harry D. Gideonse, an economist who had worked at the University of Chicago and Columbia, had been brought in to upgrade the college and repair its reputation. But he also banned anyone with ideas he considered radical from speaking or performing on campus.
"He was brought in to repaint the schoolhouse," said Alan M. Dershowitz, a Harvard Law School professor and a 1959 Brooklyn College graduate who also received an honorary degree yesterday. A third honorary degree was given to Melvin Edwards, a sculptor and printmaker, at the graduation for 2,500 students.
Speaking before the ceremony, Mr. Dershowitz said, "We all had fights with the president." He added that after he served as president of the student government, Dr. Gideonse did not recommend him for law school "because he thought I was too far left."
Dr. Gideonse had a running battle with Vanguard, which he saw as sympathetic to Communist interests and as far too independent. He shut the paper down in the spring of 1950, when it disobeyed his order not to print an article saying that he had refused to grant tenure to the chairman of the history department because of his political views. The college suspended some staff members and put others, including Mr. Taylor, a sports editor, on probation. 
In the fall, the college let the weekly newspaper reopen, and Mr. Taylor was chosen as editor. But after two issues it was shut down again, this time for good, after a student complained that his point of view had not been properly represented. 
The closing drew national attention, and Mr. Taylor was quoted in The New York Times as saying, "The dissolution of Vanguard can only be construed as an attempt by the college administration to gain control of the newspaper and squelch the expression of any student opinion which does not agree with that of the administration."
The day the article ran, Mr. Taylor recalled, Dr. Gideonse called him into his office and told him, "I hate to ruin anyone's career, but in your case I might make an exception."
Mr. Taylor and his fellow editors briefly ran an alternative newspaper, Campus News, off campus, until they ran out of money. Despite Dr. Gideonse's threat, he was allowed to graduate in 1952. He worked under Thurgood Marshall at the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund and later helped found the Citizens' Commission on Civil Rights, a bipartisan group that monitors federal civil rights policy and enforcement. He is currently the commission's vice chairman.
This summer Mr. Taylor is hoping to encourage other student leaders to continue the battle for civil rights. Along with two other organizations, the Leadership Conference Education Fund, of which he is president, is running a program called Civil Rights Summer for college students. The program received 1,300 applications for 20 places."That tells me," he said, "that there are a lot of young people out there who are interested in being activists."

HEADLINE: Economy Remained Weak in May As Employers Continued Job Cuts 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
The economy remained weak in May as American employers continued to cut jobs, though at a slower pace than during the previous two months, the government reported yesterday.
 Manufacturers, both traditional and high technology, caused the decline, eliminating more jobs in May than they had during any other month in the current slowdown. 
 The unemployment rate fell, to 4.4 percent from 4.5 percent, mostly because the number of people looking for work decreased in May -- for reasons that are not clear -- compared with previous months. To be counted as officially unemployed, a person must be out of work and actively searching for a job. 
Analysts said the drop, the first in nine months, masked an economy and a labor market that were still worsening. Over all, employment fell by a seasonally adjusted 19,000 jobs, leaving it virtually unchanged since January, after having grown by an average of about 250,000 jobs a month in the late 1990's.
As was the case in the 1990-91 recession -- but in contrast to almost any other downturn -- many college-educated white-collar workers have been among the first to lose their jobs, according to the report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics. 
Most analysts expect the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates by either one-quarter or one-half of a percentage point when it meets at the end of this month. The Fed has already cut its benchmark rate -- which affects the rates on many credit card, small-business and auto loans -- five times since January. 
"The change in the unemployment rate was statistically insignificant and a misleading sign of what is really going on," said Maury Harris, the chief United States economist at UBS Warburg. "It is not clear that the worst is over."
A survey of manufacturing executives that was released yesterday indicated that the number of orders they were receiving fell again in May. This suggests that the sector, hampered by high energy prices and sluggish business spending on new equipment, will be weak for the near future, economists said. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 10,990.41, up 78.47 points, and bond prices rose slightly as investors expected more rate cuts by the Fed.
In recent months, consumer spending on services, like transportation and day care, and on housing has remained mostly brisk, allowing these industries to add jobs and, so far at least, apparently keeping the economy out of recession. Employment in the vast service sector rose 70,000 in May, about half of its average increase over the last year and a half. Construction employment increased 31,000, well ahead of its pace of the last year and a half, partly because the interest rate cuts have encouraged people to buy a new home or remodel the one they live in.
The unemployment rate remained below 5 percent for the 47th consecutive month, the longest such streak since the 1960's.
Most analysts predict that economic activity will reach a nadir in the early summer, and then pick up in the second half of the year, as businesses finish unloading excess inventory and as consumers receive tax-rebate checks from the government. 
"I see no evidence in this report that we've reached a bottom," said Chris Varvares, the president of Macroeconomic Advisers, a consulting firm in St. Louis. "We probably still have a few months of manufacturing-employment declines to go. But we think we're getting close to the bottom."
Mr. Varvares added that yesterday's report caused his firm to take a dimmer view of the second quarter, and it now expects about a 2 percent contraction in the economy. It still expects the economy to grow 3 percent in the second half of the year. 
In the fourth quarter of 2000 and the first quarter of this year, the economy grew less than 2 percent, its smallest six-month increase since 1995.
Typically, manufacturing companies struggle before service businesses during a slowdown, because people can more easily delay the purchase of cars and appliances than health care or education, for example. In the past, a rapid decline in manufacturing employment has usually been followed by a recession. Today, however, many analysts believe a serious downturn can be avoided because businesses and policy makers are using technology to react to the economy's shifts more quickly than in the past.
Manufacturing companies cut 124,000 jobs last month.
Another unusual aspect of the current downturn has been the swiftness with which large numbers of college graduates have lost their jobs.
The unemployment rate for college graduates last month was 2.1 percent, down from 2.3 percent in April but up from 1.6 percent in October. By contrast, the jobless rate of people without a high school diploma -- 6.5 percent last month -- has grown only one-tenth of a percentage point since October.
"Traditionally, in a recession in the United States, almost all of the pain was felt by blue-collar workers," said Lawrence F. Katz, an economist at Harvard University. "The recent slowdown is more egalitarian." 
Manufacturing jobs require more technical knowledge than they once did, and American industry has become more devoted to turning out high-technology goods. As a result more factory employees hold college degrees than in the past. Companies have also become more aggressive in cutting a broad range of costs -- like the salaries of managers and clerical workers -- in an effort to increase profits.
Analysts and investors had expected yesterday's jobs report to show a larger decline in jobs than it did and for the unemployment rate to rise slightly. And the decline of 19,000 jobs, compared with an average drop of 60,000 jobs in March and April, did indicate that corporate cost-cutting was not accelerating.
"The weakness in May, over all, is a little less than in April," said Thomas J. Nardone, the head of the government division that compiles the report. 
Still, Mr. Nardone cautioned against reading very much into the jobless rate's fall. He noted that the government calculates the unemployment rate from its survey of households, which is more volatile than its larger survey of businesses. The overall change in employment -- minus 19,000 in May -- comes from the business survey.
"You always have to be careful looking at one month's change in the household survey," Mr. Nardone said. 
In addition, the government conducted both of its May surveys a few days earlier than usual because of the way the calendar fell. Because employment traditionally grows throughout the spring and summer -- and the government's seasonal adjustments account for this growth -- the May survey might have overstated the labor market strength somewhat, economists said.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 6, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Saturday about the unemployment rate in May misstated a change in the second-quarter projections by Macroeconomic Advisers, a consulting firm in St. Louis. Based on the jobless numbers, the firm now expects the number of hours worked by Americans to decline about 2 percent and the economy to grow about 1 percent. It does not expect the economy over all to contract 2 percent.

HEADLINE: At Baruch, Levy Urges Heeding to Altruism 

BYLINE:  By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
Harold O. Levy, a corporate lawyer who left a lucrative job at Citigroup last year to lead the New York City school system as chancellor, told graduates at Baruch College yesterday that financial success was hollow unless it was used "to heed the call of social responsibility."
 Mr. Levy urged the nearly 2,000 graduates at Baruch's commencement ceremony to contribute to the public good throughout their lives, no matter how wealthy they become. He said that Bernard Baruch, the financier for whom the college was named, was an icon in his family not only because he was a millionaire by age 30 but because he was an advisor to presidents and a dedicated philanthropist. 
 "Profit maximization does not preclude acting in a manner that is socially responsible," Mr. Levy said during the ceremony, at Madison Square Garden. "Acting on your better natures, trying to be what you can only be if you put your own self interest to the side, is what we crave most in society and ultimately what makes us proudest of ourselves."
Mr. Levy listed some of his own volunteer jobs, from arbitrating in small claims court to serving on the board of the University Settlement Society of New York and as a New York State Regent.
He also said that he had created the New York City Teaching Fellows, an alternative certification program for people from other professions who want to teach, to appeal to altruistic impulses in New Yorkers.
"To heed the call of social responsibility will make you a better person in your own eyes," Mr. Levy said. "That's why I started the Teaching Fellows program in the New York City public schools, and that's why I left my post to come here and lead the campaign for public education."
Mr. Levy, who made more than $500,000 a year at Citigroup and now earns $245,000 as chancellor, also warned the graduates not to be "ruthless rationalists" and urged them to instead take leaps of faith.
"Rational analysis fails to explain most of life's great decisions," he said.
Mr. Levy was awarded an honorary doctor of laws degree by Baruch, part of the City University of New York. The college's highest honor, the President's Medal, was given to Abraham J. Briloff, a longtime economics professor. 

City College
The 2,500 graduates of the City College of New York yesterday heard an assortment of speakers talk about the importance of overcoming obstacles, taking risks and not giving up.
Representative Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan accepted the college's President's Medal and said, "To see this group, you are indeed the gorgeous mosaic." Rita Moreno, an Academy Award-winning actress, was awarded an honorary doctor of fine arts degree.
The valedictorian, Olumuyiwa Ogunnika, 23, who received a bachelor's degree in electrical engineering, was born in Brooklyn of Nigerian parents. He is to attend a doctoral program at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
The salutatorian, Andrew Shearer, was one of 220 graduates receiving bachelor's degrees from the Center for Worker Education at City College. Mr. Shearer, 42, who lived in England before moving to the United States in 1993, worked full time helping the mentally retarded at the Shield Institute while completing his City College degree. He has been accepted into the New York City Teaching Fellows Program and said he hoped to teach high school English.
"America's given me a great chance I don't feel that I would have ever quite got in England," he said.

HEADLINE: Royal Family of Nepal Is Shot Dead in Palace 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
In a wholesale killing of royalty not seen since the deaths of the last czar of Russia and his family in 1918, the crown prince of Nepal shot the king and queen and several relatives in their palace in Katmandu last night, then killed himself, Nepalese officials said.
 The prince, Dipendra, a 30-year-old graduate of Eton College in England killed, among others, his parents, King Birendra Bir Birkram Shah Dev, 55; Queen Aiswarya; a brother, Nirajan; and a sister, Shruti, the Associated Press reported. CNN reported that he entered a sitting room of the royal palace at 10:40 p.m., dressed in army fatigues, and opened fire with an automatic rifle. 
 "He first shot the others, then shot himself," Nepal's interior minister, Ram Chandra Poudel, told the news agency Reuters. He said up to 11 people had been killed in the rampage, but gave no further details other than to call the attack "a national disaster" for Nepal, a Hindu kingdom straddling the Himalayas. 
The British Broadcasting Corporation's correspondent for South Asia reported from Katmandu, the capital, that the crown prince had quarreled with his mother over his choice of a bride. Queen Aiswarya had long been associated in the minds of Nepal's democrats with a rigid, outdated penchant for absolute monarchy and social conservatism. Dipendra had made efforts to appear more open to the Nepalese people.
Nepal's privy council was expected to meet today to choose a successor to the throne. They were expected to pick the king's middle brother, Gyanendra, who was out of the capital, visiting a national park at Chitwan.
Nepal, a nation the size of Tennessee with 22 million inhabitants, is tormented by multiple crises, and over coming days any number of possible explanations for the tragedy may emerge. There is only speculation that some royal family members or servants in the palace may have survived to tell their stories.
Among the survivors, reports from Katmandu said, was another royal prince, Dhirendra, who was critically wounded. 
In Washington, the State Department said: "It is not clear who was responsible at this point. Both the State Department here and the embassy in Nepal will be monitoring the situation closely."
Nepal, the world's only Hindu kingdom, experienced a huge political upheaval in 1990, when a democracy movement threatened the future of the monarchy, but stopped short of forcing the abdication of the king, who was widely accepted by the Nepalese to be a reincarnation of the god Vishnu. Nepal then accepted King Birendra as a constitutional monarch. 
But there was always far less sympathy for the queen, and the king withdrew significantly from public life after that. 
More recently, as democratically elected governments of left and right run by a few upper-caste families with little grass-roots contact have stumbled, a powerful radical leftist movement, usually described as Maoist but not thought to be backed by China, has been on the march in the Nepalese countryside. The rebels gradually encircling Katmandu and severely damaging its economically important tourist industry.
Regions as far away as the approach to Mount Everest have begun to be affected by the rebellion. The army of Nepal, home to the much-feared Gurkha warriors, has been increasingly critical of the political leadership, saying it was not acting decisively enough to put down the insurrection. 
At the same time, international human rights groups were criticizing the government for being too tough.The killings throw Nepal's already shaky political prospects into complete uncertainty, said Ted Riccardi, a retired professor of Himalayan studies at Columbia University.
"There will be those who'll want to find a successor, to preserve the monarchy because they think it's so necessary for a country like Nepal," Mr. Riccardi said. "And there will be others" -- liberal democrats and the left -- "who'll say this is a golden opportunity to get rid of the monarchy altogether. The big question is what's the army going to do. That's always been the joker in Nepal. So far since 1990, they've played it quietly."
Underlying all the other tensions, the Nepalese continue to nurse a long-held fear that neighboring India may be behind the country's political problems. Leaders of Nepal's Congress Party, which was once banned but returned to political leadership a decade ago at the vanguard of the democracy movement, have acknowledged that they had considerable Indian support. 
India, which blockaded landlocked Nepal a decade ago to punish it for buying weapons from the Chinese, have again recently accused Nepal of growing too close to China and also of allowing Pakistani agents to operate from its territory. 
King Birendra, educated at Harvard, was heir to a royal family that had ruled Nepal, a country of 25 million people, off and on since the 1770's. 
The crown prince, Dipendra, was a karate black belt who trained some of his fellow students at Eton and had a reputation as a carouser. His duties have been largely honorific. For example, he met with Japanese dignitaries in April while touring the city of Kyoto and disaster management centers in Kobe. He attended the wedding of the king of Lesotho in February 2000. And in December 1998, he opened the World Buddhist Conference in the Nepalese village where Buddha was born. But the prince occasionally took on administrative roles. In June 2000, he served as chairman of a council that ran Nepal while his father went to London. for his annual medical checkup.

A1); Nepalese troops stood guard outside a hospital in Katmandu after the king, queen and members of the royal family were shot to death. (Agence France-Presse)(pg. A6)

HEADLINE: Auto Sales Off A Mere 1.2% Last Month 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 1 

 BODY:
The enduring strength of the auto market has surprised economists every month this year and did so again today, as auto sales fell only 1.2 percent from May of last year, while General Motors unexpectedly posted a small increase in sales.
 G.M.'s gain appeared to come mainly at the expense of Ford Motor, which suffered a sharp drop in sales, particularly for its Explorer and other sport utilities. George Pipas, Ford's manager of sales analysis, said that tire problems at Ford had not produced any clear effect on sales, and attributed the weakness partly to the generous rebates and other incentives being offered by Ford's rivals. 
 "They're high, they seem to be getting higher," Mr. Pipas said of the incentives. 
Economists and financial analysts at the Federal Reserve and elsewhere pay close attention to auto sales because they are one of the first economic indicators to come out each month, and because they tend to be highly cyclical and represent a significant portion of the nation's economic output.
Auto industry experts said that the slight drop in sales in May from a year earlier was particularly impressive because the economy was growing at an annual rate of 5 percent at this time last year, and it is estimated to be expanding at a rate of just 1.3 percent now.
Financial analysts had expected the auto market to be down 7 percent from last year, and were surprised that the drop was a small fraction of that. Ward's Auto Infobank, a data service in Southfield, Mich., calculated that the seasonally adjusted annual rate of sales was 16.6 million vehicles in May. The industry seldom topped 15 million vehicles a year until 1999.
"Exceeding 16 million is a healthy rate of sales," said Mark M. Cornelius, president of Morgan & Company, an auto forecasting and consulting company in West Olive, Mich.
May 2000 was the month in which sales began to slip as the stock market weakened and the economy started to slow slightly. The end of 1999 and the beginning of 2000 experienced an extraordinary boom in sales that strained the capacity of factories, and the industry was still operating at full tilt in May of last year.
By contrast, Ford announced today that it would extend by a week a planned shutdown of its Ranger pickup truck factories in Edison, N.J., and St. Paul. Ford said it was doing so to make more replacement tires available for installation on Ford Explorers and other Ford vehicles currently equipped with Firestone Wilderness AT tires; the Ranger has, however, been selling slowly this spring.
General Motors took the opposite approach today, announcing that it would increase production by 17,000 vehicles by the end of the second quarter, although this would still leave the company 14 percent below its production in the second quarter of last year. With inventories of unsold cars and light trucks swiftly dwindling from their bloated levels last December, G.M. also said today that its production in the third quarter of this year would be down just 6.4 percent from the third quarter of last year, when many factories were running almost around the clock.
Automakers based in Detroit reported slumping sales and sharp drops in market share from January through April, as foreign manufacturers invaded the growing market for sport utility vehicles and used the weakness of the yen and the euro to charge low prices for their models. But General Motors broke that trend today, announcing that its sales had inched up 0.6 percent in May, compared with the company's middling performance a year ago.
In May, General Motors began offering discounts in Western states of up to $1,000 on most of its full-size sport utility vehicles that are based on pickup truck designs, like the Chevrolet Tahoe and GMC Yukon. It was rewarded with a jump of nearly 30 percent in sales of these models, turning what would have been a drop in overall sales into a rare increase.
By contrast Ford and the Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler A.G. had declines of 11.1 percent and 8.3 percent.
European automakers did best last month, led by BMW with a 32 percent gain in sales from a year ago. Asian automakers had a mixed showing, from Hyundai, up 35 percent, to Nissan, down 7.2 percent.
Sales of Ford Explorers were down 16.5 percent from May of last year, which was the second-best month in the 11-year history of the sport utility vehicle. Still, Ford sold more Explorers in May than in any month since September. Sales of Explorers accelerated during each week of May, and it was hard to discern an effect from Ford's decision on May 22 to replace 13 million Firestone Wilderness AT tires, Mr. Pipas said.
Overall sales of pickup-based sport utilities fell 8.8 percent last month, as sales of midsize models like the Explorer withered while sales of big models like the Tahoe continued to grow, Mr. Cornelius said. Minivan sales slumped 11.7 percent last month.
Sales of so-called crossover utility vehicles -- models like the Ford Escape and Toyota Highlander that look like sport utilities but are made from small or midsize car designs -- soared 132 percent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
 Jobless Rate Falls Slightly As Economy Remains Weak
The economy remained weak in May as American employers continued to cut jobs, though at a slower pace than during the previous two months, the government reported. The unemployment rate fell to 4.4 percent from 4.5 percent. Analysts said the drop, the first in nine months, masked an economy and a labor market that were worsening. Over all, employment fell by a seasonally adjusted 19,000 jobs, leaving it virtually unchanged since January. Page A1.

Nasdaq Ends the Week Down 4.5%
Investors embraced battered technology stocks, touching off a modest rally. The Nasdaq composite index gained 38.95 points, or 1.9 percent, to 2,149.44, but ended the week down 4.5 percent, its worst performance since the first week of April. The Dow rose 78.47 points, or 0.7 percent, to 10,990.41, cutting its loss for the holiday-shortened week to 0.14 percent. And the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 4.85 points, or 0.4 percent, to 1,260.67, off 1.4 percent for the week. C3.

Top Editor to Leave U.S. News
Stephen G. Smith, the top editor of U.S. News & World Report, will leave the magazine and be replaced by Brian P. Duffy, the executive editor, people at the magazine said. A11.

Ford Plans to Shuffle Management
Struggling to regain control of tire problems in Explorers that have tarnished the image of Ford Motor, the automaker plans to announce a reshuffling of the company's senior management, possibly as soon as next week, people close to Ford Motor's leaders said. C3.

When Bridgestone severed its relationship with Ford, and then asked for a United States investigation of the Explorer design, the company showed a combativeness that surprised analysts and cheered many Japanese. C2.

AT&T to Raise Base Phone Rates
AT&T said it would raise basic residential phone rates as much as 11 percent, beginning July 1. The company, facing a decline in consumer long-distance revenue this year, will increase basic weekday rates to 30 cents a minute from 29.5 cents; night-time rates to 25 cents a minute from 22.5 cents; and weekend rates to 16 cents from 14.5 cents. C4.

Microsoft-AOL Talks Break Down
Talks over whether America Online will be included in Microsoft's new Windows XP operating system ended after the companies could not agree to new terms. Under an expired contract, Microsoft agreed to install access software for AOL's Internet service into Microsoft Windows and AOL agreed to use Microsoft's Explorer Web browser software. C3.

Attendants Strike Aeromexico
A strike by flight attendants at Aeromexico, Mexico's largest airline, stranded thousands of passengers. Airport officials said as many as 30,000 passengers a day could be grounded in the first major labor dispute to confront the government of President Vicente Fox. The walkout began with little public warning at 12:01 a.m. More than 300 domestic and international Aeromexico flights, including 10 jointly operated with Delta Air Lines, were canceled. C2.

$20 Billion Argentine Debt Swap
Argentina is offering to pay interest rates approaching 16 percent to persuade investors to swap an expected $20 billion in government debt for new bonds. The debt swap is being closely watched in bond markets in the United States and Europe. C2.

Severance for Guinness Workers
Workers at a Guinness packaging plant in Ireland, which is set to close, accepted severance packages that include payments of up to $150,000; health benefits; and 10 years' worth of free beer. Eligible employees will receive about 14 bottles of beer a week and more on holidays twice a year. C2.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
WALMART.COM TO OFFER NET ACCESS WITH AMERICA ONLINE

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 Walmart.com will finally roll out its own Internet service this fall with America Online, offering unlimited access for less than $10 a month. The details, along with Wal-Mart's plans to prosper in an economic downturn, were disclosed at the annual shareholders' meeting of Wal-Mart Stores in Fayetteville, Ark., yesterday. 
Wal-Mart's service, called Wal-Mart Connect, will be based on AOL's CompuServe platform. "Our aim is to bring more of our customers online to provide them with affordable accessibility," said Cynthia Lin, a company spokeswoman, in an interview after the meeting. Walmart.com had announced the alliance with AOL in December 1999, and originally planned to roll it out in the first part of 2000. Ms. Lin said that the site's redesign and a new technology platform had caused the delay.

HEADLINE: Leaving Small Businesses Behind 

BYLINE:  By Fred P. Hochberg; Fred P. Hochberg was deputy administrator and acting administrator of the Small Business Administration from 1998 to 2001.

 BODY:
Calvin Coolidge said, "The business of America is business." George W. Bush, the first president to have an M.B.A. degree, has issued a correction. If his first budget is any indication, the business of America today is big business. Small companies and individual entrepreneurs, it seems, are somebody else's business. 
 The administration's early approach to the environment, workplace safety and antitrust regulation has given the president's corporate supporters confidence that promoting big business is Mr. Bush's top priority. Regrettably, though, Mr. Bush's pro-business agenda does not include small business. His budget slashes funding for the Small Business Administration by 40 percent. Small start-up companies, full of energy and ideas, would lose crucial support. The budget would increase fees for borrowers and lenders, and the agency would have to start charging entrepreneurs for using small-business development centers -- regional offices where thousands of businesses have been able to receive free technical assistance and financial advice. 
 During the previous administration, the S.B.A. was considered an important vehicle for bolstering the initiative and drive of entrepreneurs. Over the past eight years, the S.B.A.'s guaranteed loan program nearly doubled. It was able to provide guarantees for more of the loans that banks are reluctant to make -- long-term loans to fledgling businesses, providing longer loan maturities and lower monthly payments. During that time the agency nearly quadrupled loans to minorities and tripled the number of loans it backed for businesses run by women. We also doubled the number of women's business centers across America -- increasing the flow of capital as well as the information that helps people succeed. Women are now launching businesses at twice the national rate.
Today, as growth begins to slow, President Bush is proposing to cut this economic engine. Even as big corporations have begun to make big layoffs, the Bush budget would cripple a small agency that can help pick up the slack. The nation's 25 million small businesses, which employ more than half of the private work force, have been responsible for more than three-quarters of the 22 million jobs created in America since 1992.
Budget cuts and higher fees would only worsen the credit crunch that the Federal Reserve Board warned about in a recent report -- making loans both tougher to get and harder to afford. The Fed estimates that 45 percent of banks have already tightened lending to small businesses.
Slashing the S.B.A.'s budget would exact a cost from our economy. I think of the story of a small technology company that in 1969 secured a loan of $300,000 that was backed by an S.B.A. initiative called the Small Business Investment Company Program. It was a small but critical investment in that company's future -- and, as it turned out, in the new economy. That company was Intel.
Today, Intel pays in income taxes about twice what it takes to fund the S.B.A. for a year. Returns on a minimal investment can be huge indeed. Big businesses like America Online, Apple Computer, Staples, Outback Steakhouse and Callaway Golf started out as small ventures and needed a helping hand along the way. How are we going to develop the big businesses of this century if we don't nurture small businesses today? President Bush has said that he understands small business growth. Now he needs to show that he meant it.

HEADLINE: Bloomberg Ads To Announce Mayoral Bid 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
Michael R. Bloomberg, the Republican billionaire, plans to announce his candidacy for mayor on Tuesday in a television commercial in which he introduces himself to voters and says the city cannot go back to the way it once was.
 "It's 'Hi, I'm Mike and I'm running for mayor,' " said Bill Cunningham, Mr. Bloomberg's political consultant, explaining the gist of the 60-second commercial. It is to be broadcast on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday in the New York metropolitan region on Channels 2, 4, 5 and 7. As an explanation of why the political neophyte is running for mayor, Mr. Cunningham said, Mr. Bloomberg will tell viewers that "this city cannot afford to go back to the clubhouse." 
 Mr. Cunningham would say little else about any positions Mr. Bloomberg might have on education, criminal justice, housing, public health or economic development. But he did say that "we want people to know that we are going to build on the successes of the Giuliani administration" and that Mr. Bloomberg would play up his role as the only successful businessman among the mayoral candidates.
"If they want to talk about experience going into an uncertain economic time, we'll be happy to compare notes," Mr. Cunningham said, in a conference room at the sleek new "Bloomberg for Mayor" campaign headquarters on East 56th Street, where cookies, potato chips, candy and drinks are provided free to the staff. "He's the only one who in the last 35 years was working in varying economies and who in the last 20 years built a very strong company." That company, Bloomberg L.P., is to be run by subordinates during the campaign, although Mr. Bloomberg will retain ownership. 
Mr. Bloomberg did not return numerous telephone calls over the past two days for comment, making him unique among the major mayoral candidates -- four Democrats and one other Republican -- who at this point in the race are avidly seeking, rather than avoiding, media attention. 
But in a brief telephone interview last month, Mr. Bloomberg said: "I've got to learn the issues. It's a whole new education for me. I am working very hard." He also said that he had not meant to announce his candidacy last month to a gossip columnist. His "I'm running" comment, uttered at a dinner, was subsequently plastered all over the front page of The New York Post.
"I'm not going to use Liz Smith as a vehicle for an announcement, rest assured," Mr. Bloomberg said.
Now Mr. Bloomberg will use the television airwaves at an opening cost of $350,000 for the three days of broadcasting, to be supplemented by another commercial that is to go on the air over next weekend. "There will be none of that traditional balloons and bunting kind of stuff," Mr. Cunningham said. "He will speak directly to the voters."
Mr. Bloomberg's opening-day television commercial on June 5 coincides with the first day that mayoral candidates can begin circulating petitions to collect the tens of thousands of signatures necessary to get on the ballot. It is also the same day that Mr. Bloomberg's eldest daughter, Emma, is to graduate from Princeton University, meaning that he will be out of New York that day.
But Mr. Cunningham said that Mr. Bloomberg would return on Wednesday for a full day of campaign events and interviews, beginning with a gospel breakfast for the Abyssinian Development Corporation to be held at City College, part of the City University of New York. The university is chaired by Herman Badillo, the other Republican who plans to announce his candidacy for mayor next week.
"If Bloomberg announces Wednesday, I'll probably announce Thursday," Mr. Badillo said. He added that he would definitely stay in the race, even under intense pressure from Republican Party leaders and aides to Gov. George E. Pataki to clear the way for Mr. Bloomberg, who is spending millions of his $4 billion fortune on the campaign. "There were people who want me out of the race, but I am not listening," Mr. Badillo said. 
Mr. Badillo dismissed Mr. Bloomberg's television commercial as nothing more than a financial bonanza for his media consultants. "That will make sure David Garth makes a lot of money," said Mr. Badillo, referring to one of Mr. Bloomberg's political consultants who is part of the team that made the commercials.
Hank Morris, the political consultant to City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, a Democratic candidate for mayor, called Mr. Bloomberg's coming television announcement "very weird." He added, "when he talks to live people, you don't get to have 30 takes."
So far Mr. Bloomberg has not had an entirely smooth entry into the free-for-all world of New York City politics, which he acknowledged in the recent telephone interview. "The thing that has disturbed me the most is that in this business, the press questions people in politics in a different way than the business press questions people," he said. Mr. Bloomberg cited no specifics, although he has said in the past that he was hugely irritated by a reporter who asked if he was delivering meals last December to a homebound elderly couple in East Harlem as a campaign event.
"You know, you look at these people up there, this is the highlight of their day to get a meal," he said at the time.
Mr. Cunningham acknowledged that Mr. Bloomberg could have chosen his words better. "I think Mike kind of looked at it when he saw it in print and said, 'Oh, that doesn't read well,' " he said. "If some day he gets out of his car and says Bushwick instead of Williamsburg, that can blow up."
Mr. Bloomberg's plans for the weekend included having dinner in Astoria, Queens, and waiting to hear whether he would get a crucial endorsement from the Liberal Party, to be announced today. His advisers were worried that Mr. Hevesi was the favorite.
