SECTION: Section 2; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk; Pg. 27

LENGTH: 2050 words

HEADLINE: MUSIC; 
Where Music's Mission Is to Help Heal

BYLINE:  By JAMES R. OESTREICH 

DATELINE: CINCINNATI 

 BODY:
COME spring, in this city of rich musical traditions, the thoughts of many turn to the venerable May Festival, the granddaddy of American choral celebrations, now 128 years old. It is a retreat into aesthetics and history, often seeming to have little to do with the concerns of the workaday world, and that is probably how most classical-music lovers want it these days.
 But Cincinnati has been otherwise occupied this spring, since the fatal shooting of an unarmed 19-year-old black man, Timothy Thomas, by a policeman, Officer Steven Roach, on April 7 and the ensuing riots. Even before the shooting, the American Civil Liberties Union had joined black civil rights groups in filing suit in a federal court in Cleveland, pointing to a longtime pattern of racial profiling by Cincinnati police officers. From 1995 to 2000, the suit pointed out, Cincinnati officers had killed 13 suspects, all of them black. 
 Officer Roach has been charged with two misdemeanors: negligent homicide and obstructing official business. The parties in the suit have hired a mediator: a music lover, it turns out, who named his conflict-resolution company Aria. A federal investigation of the police department has begun. And Mayor Charlie Luken has established panels to recommend reforms in all areas of civic life. Such commission reports -- no fewer than six in recent decades -- have a history of being ignored in Cincinnati. 
"If we haven't come up with something concrete in four months," Mayor Lukin said recently in his office, "we'll disband."
However much music lovers might like to escape such matters, the May Festival and the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, which administers it and plays in it, have no choice but to face them. Unlike, say, the Cleveland Orchestra, which lives in splendid isolation in remote University Circle, these organizations lie in the heart of the city. Both the orchestra, which was founded in 1895, and the May Festival perform in Music Hall, which was built for the festival in 1877 in a central city area then predominantly German, called Over-the-Rhine.
Now predominantly black, Over-the-Rhine has been the focus of the recent unrest. The Thomas shooting took place a block and a half from the hall. Washington Park, in which protesters gathered in the following days, lies between, across a cobblestone street from it. The police station on which the protesters descended is directly behind the hall.
Although the building, which is owned by the city, was not touched, orchestra and festival offices were closed for three days during the period of turmoil and curfews. The players were on a week's vacation, before Easter, so no performances were affected. Still, here is a classic case of an arts institution that can no longer take anything for granted and must put stock in music's vaunted power to heal the spirit, individual and communal.
Cliched to begin with, that notion took a beating here in another context. The simmering tension that underlay the start of the festival in mid-May boiled anew at its close, last weekend, when Taste of Cincinnati took center stage a few blocks away. Taste of Cincinnati, 22 years old, is a three-day open-air festival of food and pop music, sponsored by the Greater Cincinnati Chamber of Commerce and others. An earlier festival, Jammin' on Main, had already been scuttled because of the unrest, and a coalition of clergymen now called for a boycott of this one. The Rev. Damon Lynch III, a noted activist and one of three people appointed by the mayor to oversee the work of his reform panels, spearheaded the boycott.
Two rhythm-and-blues groups scheduled to appear at Taste of Cincinnati, Midnight Star and the Isley Brothers, withdrew in advance. But Mayor Luken intervened to salvage the situation, persuading James Brown to step in at the opening, on May 26.
Thus came one of the most volatile moments of recent weeks. Mr. Brown failed to arrive for 40 minutes, leaving a large audience, mostly white, to contemplate an empty stage with a banner -- "Justice, Peace, Healing, Community" -- and grow restive. Through it all, demonstrators, mostly black, chanted and brandished posters nearby, and a few shoved their way into the audience.
When Mr. Brown finally appeared, he stayed less than five minutes, delivering a few disconnected remarks above the uproar, and a couple of choruses of "Killing Is Out, School Is In." "I'm not here for the man," he said. "I'm here for the kids." The protesters, some carrying signs calling Mr. Brown the "Godfather of Sold," seemed unconvinced. Mr. Brown received $15,000 as expenses for his appearance.
"I don't know who got played on that one," Mr. Lynch said from his pulpit at the New Prospect Baptist Church in Over-the-Rhine last Sunday. "James got paid, and somebody got played. Only in Cincinnati!" The congregation applauded lustily.
"This is our Rosa Parks moment," Mr. Lynch said later, referring to the woman who famously refused to surrender her seat to a white man in a Montgomery, Ala., bus in 1955. " 'I ain't getting up this time. I got up every other time, but this time I don't move.' Not everybody is at that point, but many are."
Still, if the point was, as many said, that this was no time to celebrate in Cincinnati, no time for Cincinnati to pat itself on the back, to carry on business as usual, then why was so much attention devoted to Taste of Cincinnati and so little to the Cincinnati May Festival? One hesitated to ask, not wanting to plant an idea where it may not have existed and not wanting, either, to hear that classical music has become merely marginal to the culture at large. (Though why should any of that come as a surprise after so many years of escapism and aesthetic detachment?)
And sure enough: "The May Festival is not on the radar screen in terms of impact," Mr. Lynch said after the service. "The city drew a line in the sand on Taste of Cincinnati. The economic impact is much greater."
There may be other, more positive factors as well. "Music Hall looks like a big cathedral," said Magistrate Judge Jack Sherman Jr. of the federal court, a member of the orchestra's board. "It has that aspect, and that could be one reason it's never been touched. Not a brick was scratched."
The church remains a strong force in black neighborhoods in Cincinnati, Magistrate Sherman said. He sings in the choir of his own church, St. John's Unitarian in Clifton, which has moved about a mile from its former home in Over-the-Rhine.
If any single building can be taken to summarize the history of Over-the-Rhine, it may that vacated church, a stately but compact red brick, neo-Gothic structure, a smaller partner to Music Hall, which looms a block and a half away. A black cyclone fence and a white sign for the Apostolic Brethren Temple Church, attached to a corner, seem the most recent additions to the facade. But the name St. John's Unitarian Church remains artfully embedded in the partly shattered stained glass over the entry. And high above, chiseled in stone, is "Deutsche Protestantische St. Johanniskirche, Erbauet A.D. 1867" -- built, that is, 10 years before Music Hall.
Over-the-Rhine is accorded 15 minutes of dubious fame in the drug-drenched movie "Traffic," where it is put forward as the ultimate in urban squalor. But Anthony McGill, a brilliant young clarinetist and one of the orchestra's two black players, cautions against a monolithic view.
"I know what it's like to come from a general area that people think of as a bad neighborhood but that has many different characteristics, including middle-class people," said Mr. McGill, who grew up on the south side of Chicago and now lives a few blocks from Music Hall.
Indeed, Paavo Jarvi, the Estonian-born American maestro who becomes the orchestra's music director in September, says he plans to live in Over-the-Rhine.
Music Hall and its occupants may also have gained a certain respect and immunity in the area by being good neighbors, as by most accounts they are. The building is used by local groups for nonmusical as well as musical purposes.
"The orchestra is reaching out all the time," said Mayor Luken, who professed to no particular interest in classical music or knowledge of it, "as most of Cincinnati suddenly is."
Steven Monder, the president of the orchestra and the executive director of the festival, proclaimed: "The most significant thing we do is that we stay. We haven't abandoned the neighborhood. That's our statement: we are here, and we want to be here."
The May Festival has made concerted efforts to attract blacks and Hispanics into its chorus, which is made up of amateurs. Carole T. Rigaud, who is taking over as the first black chairman of the festival's board, described extensive outreach efforts, concentrated on drawing people from church choirs.
"The problem is that people are completely involved in their own choirs," she explained. Magistrate Sherman is an example, having just returned from an extensive tour of Europe with his choir. And although the May Festival runs only two weeks of the year, the chorus maintains a full schedule of activities year-round. As a result, even after all those efforts, only 6 of its 138 members are black.
The orchestra, like other major American ensembles, uses blind auditions but retains an almost completely white face. This may be the most intractable problem of all, for it can be solved only in the long run, through education. Professional musicians on this level must usually be built from the ground up, with training beginning in early childhood.
The orchestra, through its energetic community relations manager, Kathy Jorgensen-Finley, has begun working with Aaron P. Dworkin, the executive director of the Sphinx Competition in Dearborn, Mich., a program geared to developing young black and Hispanic string players. Chiefly through the efforts of Erich Kunzel, the conductor of the Cincinnati Pops, the orchestra is also involved in the establishment of a new public school for the creative and performing arts next to Music Hall.
Ms. Jorgensen-Finley has developed other programs to attract neighborhood youngsters, and several orchestra players mentor young aspirants. "I feel strongly about encouraging people to do that in all careers," said Norman Johns, a veteran black cellist in the orchestra, who practices what he calls "aggressive mentoring."
Even all of that is not enough, Mr. Jarvi acknowledges. "It's even more important to educate the parents," he said. "If they grew up in a family with Ph.D.'s and went to the best universities but have never been to a symphony concert, there's really no hope for the kids."
In any case, the festival came to a peaceful end, particularly edifying in a fresh and stirring account of the Mahler's all-encompassing Third Symphony on the final Friday, conducted by James Conlon, the festival's music director. (This symphony, which is about as minimally choral as music gets at the May Festival, nevertheless had its American premiere there in 1914.) In such exalted post-Romanticism, Mr. Conlon seems to be reaping benefits from his extensive work on the lesser figures around Mahler, like Zemlinsky, whom he edged only slightly awkwardly into a program of Russian music the next night.
With all the talk of long-term education and the need for patience at a time when patience may be running out, Mr. Conlon is one who holds out some quick fixes.
"I want to find some program ideas immediately to give things a jump start next year," he said. "It may mean some gospel. It may mean some works by African-American composers." The festival already has one such work in the bank, Alvin Singleton's "Praisemaker," commissioned for its 125th anniversary, in 1998.
Mr. Conlon also looks ahead to the opening of the the National Underground Railroad Freedom Center on the riverfront in 2004 as an opportunity for joint programming. Edwin J. Rigaud, the president of the center and the husband of Ms. Rigaud, the festival chairman, spoke enthusiastically of the prospect of collaborations with all of the city's cultural institutions.
But the words of Mr. Monder, the orchestra's president, continue to ring loudest and longest. "We're not going anywhere," he reiterated. "Life goes on. I refrain from saying things go back to normal, because obviously normal wasn't good enough."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Steven Monder, above, president of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra. At left, James Conlon conducts the orchestra and May Festival Chorus. (Photographs by Mark Lyons for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: TELEVISION/RADIO; 
A Los Angeles Station Tries to Be a Player for PBS

BYLINE:  By ALAN JAMES FRUTKIN; Alan James Frutkin writes about television for Mediaweek magazine.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
IN late April "PBS Hollywood Presents," a new series produced by the public television station KCET, made its debut. It was a proud moment for the Los Angeles station, but the long road to "Hollywood Presents" -- the first dramatic program KCET had produced for PBS since 1994 -- was also a reminder of past and present embarrassments.
 Sitting in the nation's film and television production capital, not to mention its second-largest TV market, KCET contributes relatively little original programming to PBS's national schedule. Its 45 hours in fiscal 1999 were approximately one-fifth of what PBS's top producer, WNET in New York, provided. 
 The numbers underscore KCET's long-standing struggle to establish ties with Hollywood's creative community. They also reflect PBS's own lack of success in reaching out to stations beyond core contributors like WNET, WGBH in Boston and WETA in Washington. And they point to the problems KCET continues to face nearly 20 years after it went through a crippling financial crisis. 
The first installment of "Hollywood Presents," "The Old Settler," adapted from the play by John Henry Redwood, began filming at KCET's Hollywood studios in February, five years after the station named the former NBC executive Al Jerome as its president. One of Mr. Jerome's initial goals was to create a national dramatic anthology series, and now three more installments of "Hollywood Presents," which adapts plays by American writers, are planned for broadcast over the next two years. The next will be Donald Margulies's 1996 play "Collected Stories."
"It took too long," Mr. Jerome said of the program's launch, adding that almost every aspect of development delayed the project, from securing PBS's approval to -- perhaps most frustrating of all -- raising the money to make the first four dramas. (Only $4 million of the $6 million needed has been raised.) The $1.5 million budget per drama is similar to that of many independent feature films. But where a movie like "The Blair Witch Project" made millionaires of its investors, "Hollywood Presents" offers sponsors a very different revenue model. More precisely, it avoids offering them a revenue model at all. And with advertising possibilities slim on public television, attracting backers can be difficult.
"Fund-raising from our vantage point is more of a philanthropic endeavor," said Mare Mazur, KCET's senior vice president of programming and production. "It's challenging to generate that level of philanthropy on public broadcasting right now."
Signing actors, writers and directors to projects has proved as elusive as landing underwriters, and for many of the same reasons. Brad Grey, an executive producer of HBO's "Sopranos" and a member of KCET's board since 1996, said the station's not-for-profit status remains a major hurdle in establishing ties with Los Angeles's top artists, no matter how charitably they might regard public television.
"When you're dealing with talent agencies and the studios and the creative community in Hollywood, after you've talked about what you're trying to accomplish, the conversation always turns to the budget and how much money can be made," Mr. Grey said. "Once you get into that discussion, you limit the number of creators and actors who would be interested."
Making matters worse for KCET is the competition it now faces from pay cable services like HBO and Showtime, which offer Hollywood talent a chance to spread its wings and still make money. "It only makes it more difficult," Mr. Grey said.
Despite such obstacles, Mr. Jerome says, the competition KCET faces from within the PBS system is more troubling than any threat from outside.
Two-thirds of PBS's regular series -- including "American Masters," "Frontline," "Great Performances" and "Nova" -- originate at two stations, WNET and WGBH. To maintain those series, PBS allots a large share of its production budget to programming from those stations -- approximately 45 percent in 1999.
Mr. Jerome said that although there is a need to preserve and strengthen those series, PBS's traditional focus on them may hurt potential projects from other stations. He suggested that KCET's low output may be partly the result of PBS's neglect. "If there really isn't an appetite for the development of new series, then there's limited opportunity to develop them," he said.
Conversely, the success of PBS's flagship series attracts underwriting from corporations like ExxonMobil and Salomon Smith Barney. Even supporters of KCET say that when PBS develops new series, it may be easier to get financing through established channels rather than hunting for new ones.
"This is a business of momentum," said Grant Tinker, the former NBC chairman, who, like Mr. Grey, joined KCET's board in 1996 at Mr. Jerome's urging. "I think there's an open wire both to WNET and WGBH because they've been running out front for so long, and they've found a clearer track to getting going and getting supported."
PBS, whose headquarters are in Alexandria, Va., continues to weather accusations of favoritism. "There's this feeling that everything is too East Coast," said Pat Mitchell, the president and chief executive of PBS since March, who responded to those accusations by placing regional programming executives in Los Angeles, Chicago and Miami.
Mr. Jerome says little will change unless PBS expands its national schedule. In 1995, PBS instituted so-called common carriage guidelines, to encourage member stations nationwide to broadcast the same prime-time schedule. The guidelines were intended to give PBS programs more national promotion and to guarantee national exposure for corporate underwriters.
Although many regional PBS stations prefer local programming, both Mr. Jerome and Ms. Mitchell say the current guidelines -- which cover about 350 hours a year, Sunday through Thursday nights -- are insufficient. "I would like a policy of common carriage that is based not on hours but on a full prime-time schedule," said Ms. Mitchell, who will present her proposal to member stations this month. "They may say it's too much common carriage, but I'm hoping they'll see this as a way to target some growth and to increase our value at a community level."
If any station could use a boost at the community level, it's KCET. In March, after falling short of its viewer fund-raising goals for both December and January, the station laid off 15 employees and eliminated 11 vacant positions, cutting the staff to 170, about 70 percent of its size in 1996 and less than 60 percent of its 1990 size.
Although Mr. Jerome says the cutbacks will not affect "Hollywood Presents," he acknowledges that they may reinforce lingering perceptions that the station has failed to escape its troubled past. 
"These layoffs in no way reflect that the company is not healthy," said Mr. Jerome, who oversaw another round of cutbacks in 1998, when 15 positions were eliminated. "It's all been occasioned by the same thing -- hitting an air pocket in the membership. It's the way KCET's business has been, and I'm certainly very committed to trying to change that."
MR. JEROME attributes last year's disappointing membership drive both to the national economic downturn and to the uncertainty surrounding the presidential election. Although he discounts dissatisfied viewers as a cause, he does suggest that people in Los Angeles may take KCET -- and public television -- for granted. "At the end of the day, we want people to start thinking about us as a regular part of what they pay for entertainment, in the same way that they pay for cable," he said.
To that end, Mr. Jerome and his staff are in the early stages of developing what he calls a "new membership transaction." Through the Internet, he said, he hopes to establish direct lines of communication with individual viewers that may someday lead to their credit cards. A small amount of money on a monthly basis, he added, will "let us know if we're doing something right."
But until he can rely on such transactions, he said, maintaining the station's fiscal health will require continual adjustments, as shown by the layoffs.
KCET's finances first came under scrutiny after the station produced the popular 1980 series "Cosmos." The 13-hour program, narrated and co-produced by the astronomer Carl Sagan, cost $6 million to $8 million, said Barbara Goen, a KCET spokeswoman. Combined with the fiscal mismanagement of a previous administration, it almost shut down KCET. The station cut its work force by a third in 1982, halted production on most national programming and brought in the longtime public television executive William H. Kobin to run things.
The strategy worked. By the end of Mr. Kobin's 13-year tenure, KCET's budget had tripled, to $45 million, and membership increased to 325,000 from 200,000. For the fiscal year that ends this month, KCET's budget is approximately $50 million, while subscriptions have dipped to 313,000.
Mr. Kobin also helped put KCET back into the PBS schedule. It was one of four presenting stations for the now-defunct "American Playhouse" series. It produced several children's series for PBS, as well as a number of limited documentary series, including "The Astronomers" in 1991. It also began production of what remains its signature local public-affairs show, "Life and Times."
After Mr. Kobin retired in 1995, Mr. Jerome transformed "Life and Times" from a taped program to a live broadcast five nights a week, renaming it "Life and Times Tonight." (The program is now shown live twice a week.) In 1997, the documentary series "The Great War and the Shaping of the 20th Century" -- which Mr. Jerome inherited from Mr. Kobin -- won an Emmy, a Peabody and an Alfred I. Dupont/Columbia award.
Although Mr. Jerome has kept much of the momentum achieved during Mr. Kobin's tenure, critics say he has yet to build on those gains in creating a strong national presence. With "Hollywood Presents," and with the recent announcement that KCET will produce PBS's Latino drama series "An American Family," the station finds itself once again cast as a phoenix.
Ms. Mitchell said the series represent "the re-launch of KCET as a major public television producing station." And Mr. Jerome remains hopeful that the station can live up to those expectations.
"We're anxious to do more," he said. "If we can just get that stone up the hill, then we can let it go."

HEADLINE: TELEVISION/RADIO; 
Bringing in Public Radio, and Bringing People Together

BYLINE:  By VALERIE GLADSTONE; Valerie Gladstone's most recent article for Arts & Leisure was about the Dance Africa festival.

 BODY:
BROADCASTING wasn't something Jay Allison planned on as a young man. He was more interested in acting and riding around on his motorcycle. "I was sort of a ne'er do well," Mr. Allison said. But in 1977 a friend who worked at National Public Radio in Washington talked him into coming by. Intrigued, he began to stop in at night, more to hang out than to work, until his friend loaned him a tape recorder.
 "Public radio was just inventing itself," Mr. Allison said, and in a sense so was he. He taught himself to record, edit and mix, and "insinuated" himself onto the air. In this unlikely fashion, Mr. Allison, 49, began an impressive career in radio and television. He has co-produced prize-winning documentaries like "Breaking the Cycle: How Do We Stop Child Abuse" (1989) and "Beyond Affliction: The Disability History Project" (1999), and cultural programs like "The Miles Davis Radio Project" (1991 and 2001) and "Lost and Found Sound" (1999-2001). In 1996, he won public radio's highest honor, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting's Edward R. Murrow Award. His series "The Life Stories Collection: First-Person Portraits" will be broadcast this summer. 
 Susan Stamberg, the NPR producer and host, remembers the "tall, blond and gorgeous" Mr. Allison arriving at the studios in the late 70's. "Jay came from a theater background," she said, "and suggested how to give stories a dramatic sound and add more sizzle. He's still the living embodiment of what public radio was at the beginning, with the same initial values and passion -- and he's done everything as a freelancer by piecing funds together."
Now Mr. Allison has pulled off his biggest coup: bringing public radio to his home base of Cape Cod. Last year, under the umbrella of Boston's WGBH, he launched two stations serving Cape Cod, Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket. They are the only public radio stations to go on the air since 1999.
After living in the Catskills, Boston and New York, Mr. Allison and his wife and fellow producer, Christina Egloff, moved to Woods Hole, Mass., on Cape Cod in 1985. "I got the idea for the stations for partly selfish reasons," he said in a recent telephone interview. "The signals from WGBH in Boston would drift in and out and I couldn't hear my own shows. I also thought the region would benefit from sharing a forum."
Mr. Allison's audience, spread across two islands and a 70-mile-long peninsula, is more fragmented than most. Nantucket, Martha's Vineyard and Cape Cod have strong senses of identity and history, with each community feeling itself to be more special than the others. "Yet the radio signal extends across them all, disrespecting boundaries," Mr. Allison said. "Our stories tend, almost miraculously, to break those boundaries and defuse age-old feuds and jealousies."
In 1992, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting identified the region as underserved, lacking a full-power, local public radio service. The same year, at a barbecue, Mr. Allison said, "A bunch of us got to wondering what it would take to have our own radio station." 
It took a year to establish a nonprofit community organization, Cape and Islands Community Radio Inc. (now named Atlantic Public Media), made up of local residents and public radio veterans. In 1997, the group managed to get Federal Communications Commission licenses and a $173,000 grant from the National Telecommunications Information Agency to build stations in Nantucket and Woods Hole, using the last available noncommercial FM frequencies in the area. WNAN (91.1 FM) would serve Nantucket and WCAI (90.1 FM) would cover Martha's Vineyard and the upper and mid-Cape. (Streaming audio is available at www.cainan .org.) Nonetheless, the delays and red tape continued. "I dreaded walking around town," Mr. Allison said, "because I was becoming known as the guy who was forever starting up a new public radio station that you couldn't hear."
Hoping to speed things up, the nonprofit group voted to seek a regional partner and found that WGBH, the distinguished public television and radio station known for its cultural and news programming, was amenable. It agreed to build and operate the stations, contributing about $1 million in start-up money and assuming the $1 million annual operating expenses. John Voci, operations director at WGBH, said, "We could provide them with shows, such as 'All Things Considered,' 'This American Life' and 'Fresh Air,' but the region also needed its own local service and that's what we wanted to encourage."
After three more years of zoning hearings, tower problems and transmitter site changes, WNAN went on the air in March 2000, followed by WCAI in September, both 24 hours a day. "We've all spent a lot of time," Mr. Allison said, "developing a template for how a big station can adopt a little one, keeping local character alive while achieving economies of scale through shared infrastructure." The independent radio producer and consultant Steve Rathe said, "Jay's significant achievement is taking independent radio-making the next step -- institutionalizing the process."
Despite a limited budget and a full-time staff of three plus a few stringers, producing local programming has been a breeze. For years, Mr. Allison has been fascinated with how people function; here was another chance to explore humanity and at the same time possibly unite communities. "When you sit with people, finally what they're talking about is their inner lives," he said, "and I try to express that on the radio."
ONE way he does it is with "Sonic ID's," which are brief anecdotes, essays, poems and soundscapes created by local people that are interspersed with local news throughout the broadcast day. A woman recalls how her elderly cousin survived the hurricane of 1938 by digging himself into a sand dune; another woman describes how to put wash on the line on a windy day; a teenager new to Martha's Vineyard from New York City compares his old and new schools, and a little boy imitates the sound of a lawnmower. 
Mr. Allison also installed a "listener line" that lets people tell their stories on voice mail. "We pick the good ones," he said. And, trying to get all listeners into the act, the stations also loan out portable tape recorders to whoever promises to use them. "The process teaches quite a bit about the power and technique of radio," Mr. Allison said.
On Sunday nights, he does his own show, "Arts and Ideas." To involve kids, he encouraged the establishment of a radio club at the Martha's Vineyard Regional High School. His goal is transparent. "You know Martha's Vineyard people think they're infinitely superior to Nantucket people and so on," he said. "Well, now that they hear each other on the air, it's tougher for them to maintain those old prejudices. A fisherman from Martha's Vineyard tells a funny story about his work and a Nantucket fisherman can't help but laugh and say, 'Hey, I like this fella.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jay Allison, in Woods Hole, Mass., hopes to use radio to help unite fragmented communities. (Stephen Rose for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: IN PERSON; 
From the Knee of Her Bubbe

BYLINE:  By DEBRA GALANT 

DATELINE: NEW MILFORD 

 BODY:
IT wasn't the usual kind of graduation.
 Children belted out that old standard "Gott bentsh Amerika" by the Jewish-American songwriter Israel Balin. 
 That's "God Bless America" by Irving Berlin to most Americans.
Yes, many Jewish children go to Hebrew school, though few of them go to school to study Yiddish. But the children who belong to the Workmen's Circle Jewish School of Bergen County learn both. 
Roberta Starr Schiff, 61, is the educational director and resident muse of this unusual school which, in keeping with Yiddish, calls itself a schule (pronounced SHOOL-uh).
Workmen's Circle is a 101-year-old movement started by immigrants in the labor movement as a fraternal organization. It now functions largely as a substitute for Jews who are disenchanted by more traditional forms of Judaism, but who want to transmit a Jewish heritage to their children.
Then, as now, Workmen's Circle has always been more interested in Jewish culture -- or Yiddishkeit -- than in Judaism as a religion. There is another branch in New Brunswick, and branches in about a dozen major American and Canadian cities -- with a total of about 25,000 members.
Faithful to its labor roots, Workmen's Circle still emphasizes leftist politics, placing the pursuit of "social and economic justice" high in its mission statement.
Mrs. Schiff who is, among other things, a trained opera singer, seems an unlikely person to lead a Workmen's Circle schule. She was raised in an Orthodox household and was the first women accepted by the cantorial music division of the Herzliah Hebrew Institute in New York.
But Mrs. Schiff's initial disaffection with synagogue-based Judaism actually occurred as a result of breaking the cantorial gender barrier. After a newspaper article appeared, the former Ms. Starr began to receive hate mail ("Roberta Starr thought she could spit on the Torah" was a typical comment).
She became further alienated as a mother trying to find a meaningful Jewish education for her three children, who are now grown. First, she tried an Orthodox synagogue, where her children spent most of their time "decoding Hebrew" and "never got to learn about Herzl and Dreyfus." (Theodor Herzl was the founder of Zionism, Alfred Dreyfus a French Jew falsely and famously accused of treason in 1894.)
When she switched to a Reform synagogue, Mrs. Schiff found the Jewish education broad but shallow, or as she put it: "A mile long and an inch wide."
"It's true," she said recently. "I was very critical. I was the parent from hell."
Finally, she found her home at the Bergen County Workmen's Circle group 15 years ago, then headed by a Jewish ventriloquist named Jonathan Geffner. Mrs. Schiff became the group's education director in 1987.
As it turns out, her Yiddish education was every bit as formative as her advanced Hebrew training, or even her musical preparation. It came at the knee of her bubbe from the shtetl (Eastern European small-town grandmother), who lived with her family, first in Brooklyn and then Queens.
Mrs. Schiff's bubbe greeted her when she arrived home from school. "It was the most wonderful, warm welcome," Mrs. Schiff recalled. " 'Mine susse sheine medele. ('My sweet pretty girl.') What did you learn today? I hope you respected the teacher.' "
"The question always is, 'Why Yiddish?' " Mrs. Schiff said during an interview in the living room of her split-level home here. She paraphrased Golda Meier, the late prime minister of Israel, who also taught in a Workmen's Circle schule:
"Hebrew is the language of the Bible and the modern state of Israel," she said. "But Yiddish was the warm, wonderful language of the Jewish home and the street that united a scattered population for 20 years."
She added: "I love the Yiddish language. There are songs that can only be sung in Yiddish, stories whose charm and secrets, sadness and nostalgia can be conveyed in Yiddish alone."
Yiddish, a dialect of mingled German and Hebrew, was spoken by almost all of the Jewish immigrants from Eastern Europe in the early 20th century, a generation that Mrs. Schiff thinks deserves the title of "greatest generation." As those immigrants' children assimilated, however, the language has become almost extinct.
"Times have changed," said Paul Esterowitz, a computer programmer in Leonia, who was raised in a Workmen's Circle home in Brooklyn and sends his children to the Bergen schule. "The only people who speak Yiddish today are Orthodox Jews."
Of course, Yiddish also gets liberally sprinkled into the English language, like vinegar on bland food, especially in Hollywood, whose early moguls were mostly Eastern European Jews. 
"You can't open the newspaper without seeing maven," Mrs. Schiff said. (Maven, of course, means expert.) Nosh (snack) and chutzpah (nerve) have also become familiar, she pointed out.
Mrs. Schiff said she started the school's youngest students with Yiddish because it was easier to learn than Hebrew. Although Yiddish and Hebrew share an alphabet, Yiddish shares many more cognates with English, like hant for hand, or schule for school. Yiddish is usually taught at the schule through folk tales and plays.
Yiddish is also imparted through a special Passover Haggadah, which includes the traditional Four Questions in English, Hebrew and Yiddish, as well as the Yiddish song "Zog Nit Keyn Mol," or "Song of the Partisans," which celebrates the uprising of Jews in the Warsaw Ghetto in 1943. "It's not your father's Maxwell House Haggadah," Mrs. Schiff joked.
Hebrew and biblical study are also woven into the schule's curriculum. At the recent graduation ceremony, students put on two skits about the Jewish scholar Hillel. Appropriately, Hillel advocated an interpretation of Torah that was liberal for his time. He died in A.D. 10. "We even do blessings too," Mrs. Schiff said. "We're not militantly secular." She also trains students, privately, for bar and bat mitzvahs, although that is not a requirement of the program.
The inclusion of palpably religious content, however, is heretical to some members. One of those people is the Workmen's Circle-weaned Mr. Esterowitz. 
"Bible study? I was kind of aghast," Mr. Esterowitz said. "Workman's Circle was born of the labor movement and they were Socialists. These people were not religious. They were free thinkers."
Were there bar mitzvahs when he was growing up?
"Absolutely not," he said. Nevertheless, Mr. Esterowitz's wife, Gail Noble Esterowitz, would like to see their daughter Maxx Anne, 9, have a bat mitzvah with Mrs. Schiff when she turns 13.
"I say we're an interfaith marriage," she explained. "He's an atheist and I'm agnostic." Of course, when it comes to Workmen's Circle, Mr. Esterowitz is a devout hard-liner -- just as Orthodox Jews are about traditional Judaism.
But at the Bergen schule, a third-generation Workmen's Circle member like Mr. Esterowitz is the exception. More typically, families there are fleeing a synagogue experience they found oppressive.
"You know the old joke about how you get mice out of a synagogue?" one member said before the graduation ceremony last month. "Bar mitzvah them."
Mrs. Schiff explained: "They remember what it was like for them, and how they hated it."
A preponderance of members, as it happens, are psychotherapists. "And I don't think that's a coincidence," she said.

HEADLINE: For Art and Profit, On With the Shows 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD WEIZEL 

 BODY:
FOR the nearly 20 years that David Sekac was a machine operator in a metal works factory in Clinton, he dreamed of finding a job he loved so that he would not dread getting up every morning to go to work.
 Then two years ago after returning from a vacation in England, Mr. Sekac, 46, found a way to make that dream real. It happened when he went to a local shop to arrange for the framing of some photographs. 
 Two other customers noticed his work sitting on the counter and struck up a conversation. They told him the scene seemed to burst off the surface with dazzling color, and urged him to enter a photo contest. 
Though skeptical, Mr. Sekac agreed to enter the competition. When someone bought a photo of a small, tranquil English garden in Cotswell for his asking price of $195, Mr. Sekac was stunned. He started attending adult education courses in photography and reading everything about the field he could get his hands on.
Last year he quit his factory job and has joined the more than 2,000 artists, artisans and crafts exhibitors in Connecticut who sell their work at crafts shows, fairs and festivals throughout the spring, summer and fall.
Some are like Mr. Sekac, trying to make a living at their craft or hobby after becoming bored with jobs or losing them. Others have jobs during the week and venture into the world of exhibitions on weekends to supplement their incomes. Still others are retirees who decide to turn longtime hobbies into part-time post-retirement careers.
"For a long time I had a secure, steady income in a job where creativity, independent thinking and freedom were not only discouraged, they were considered serious drawbacks and scoffed at by management," said Mr. Sekac, who operates Brookside photography from a studio in his Madison home. 
"Now I love what I do and I always feel excited the night before a show. But I never know if I'm going to make money, lose money or break even because the competition is brutal and sometimes people like your work, but just don't buy it. It's hard work and a lot tougher life than most people think."
Recently Mr. Sekac was among 15 photographers and more than 200 exhibitors selected to display their work at the 39th Annual Meet the Artists and Artisans Spring Show on the Green in Milford. He will be in Milford again for a weekend show on the green Friday and Saturday.
Linda Neely, a Killingworth artist, has been making and selling her colorful clay etchings at arts and crafts shows since 1980. She said that it took time to learn which shows to attend to make the best profit, and how to develop a rapport with potential customers that is relaxed enough not to scare them off, but friendly enough to keep them interested.
"It's a fine line to find a balance between the two extremes," Ms. Neely said. "It takes time and experience to learn that."
Along with her husband, Bill Neely, who handles all of the business details and helps with the more technical aspects of the craft, she appears at about 10 shows a year in Connecticut. In May she was at the four-day Dogwood Festival in Fairfield that is held every Mother's Day weekend.
"The first 10 years I did this alone, and it was very difficult being on the road away from my children and husband every weekend," Ms. Neely said. "But during the past 10 years we have done this together and it's been a lot more fun -- and a lot less lonely."
Bill Neely said that the world of arts and crafts shows was less idyllic than it might initially appear with profit margins dependent on factors beyond anyone's control -- such as the weather, the economy and whether other shows are taking place the same weekend.
"There is a great deal of freedom and independence in this kind of business, but it's also extremely risky and insecure and you really can't budget the way you can when you have a regular job with a steady income," he said.
David Anderson, a Newtown photographer who specializes in colorful outdoor New England scenes, particularly of Litchfield County, knows all about the frustrations of trying to make a living at the shows.
While his work dazzled more than a few customers at the recent Dogwood Festival, Mr. Anderson said it had become tougher to make a living at crafts shows because "it seems as though everyone is trying to do it."
Mr. Anderson, 54, said he had been selling his work at shows and fairs in Connecticut for 11 years and still enjoyed talking to potential customers and to other vendors. But he said he was getting tired of having to spend more and more time selling and promoting and less time doing what he loves most: taking pictures.
"I always loved going to crafts shows myself and always wondered if I could do something at them to earn a living," said Mr. Anderson, a former carpenter who still does handyman work to supplement his photography business, New England Impressions. "Now I'm doing about 25 shows a year, but finding less time to be outdoors and take pictures, which is why I started doing this in the first place."
Denise morris Curt, director of the recent Milford show on the green and of another one there in the fall, said most exhibitors had regular jobs and sold their art work and crafts products at weekend shows like the ones she has run for nearly 40 years.
"It's a very exciting lifestyle for a modern-day gypsy, but you have to have talent and be a certain kind of person who doesn't mind the unpredictability of it all," she said. 
Ms. Curt said the shows had become far more competitive over the years, with more than 450 applicants turned away from the recent Milford show, compared with the 200 who exhibited there.
Joseph Mehan, director of the nonprofit Connecticut Guild of Craftsmen and editor of The Craft Digest, a monthly newsletter magazine with show listings and articles about crafts people, said there were between 200 and 300 members of the guild when he started out in 1976. Now, there are more than 2,000.
"A lot of people laid off in the late 1980's and early 90's decided to try and replace or supplement their incomes by turning hobbies into part-time businesses where they could make money from things they made for fun in their leisure time," Mr. Mehan said. "But the advice I give most people is this: don't give up your day job. Trying to make a living selling at crafts shows is a long, hard grind that requires a lot of hours and many people don't last long."
A recent study conducted by the national Craft Organization Directors Association in New York found that the making and selling of fine crafts such as pottery, hand-blown glass, metalwork, wood and jewelry in the United States contributes $13.8 billion annually to the economy, which suggests there is money to be made in the field, said Mr. Mehan, "particularly when someone can come up with a product that is well made that people need."
That is what happened 17 years ago to George Abatiello, of Warwick, R.I., who discovered he was good at carving wooden decoys, wildlife heads, canes and walking sticks. At age 46 he began a second career carving wood after losing his longtime sales and food broker's job for a major food company. As owner of Eastern Waterfowl Ltd., Mr. Abatiello said he has never regretted his decision to enter the arts and crafts field.
"My wife has a real job; I do this," said. Mr. Abatiello, now 62. "I don't make a lot of money, but I do make a living. There was a time I sold somebody else's products, now I sell something that I create and it's the most satisfying feeling in the world."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Dylan Hotel; 
A New Boutique Hotel With Medieval Touches

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
THE ceiling of the room is a series of half round vaults, connected by raised ribs that rest on pillars partially emerged from the vertical walls. The window is of stained glass with illustrations suggesting strange, pseudoscientific rituals. The effect is one of a Gothic chamber in a medieval castle.
 Which is exactly what the designers and restorers wanted. The room is the Alchemy Suite of the Dylan Hotel at 52 East 41st Street between Madison and Park Avenues. It is a legacy of the time when the building housed the Chemists' Club, whose name is still carved into the stonework over the entrance. 
 Alchemy, which was intended to find a way to covert base metals like lead into gold, is considered a forerunner of modern chemistry. Although alchemists never succeeded in their objective, some of what they learned and their techniques were incorporated into modern chemistry, which began developing several hundred years ago. 
The Alchemy Suite is just one of the distinguishing components of the hotel, which is one of the pricey boutique hotels that have been opening in Manhattan in recent years. Most have highly designed public spaces and guest rooms. They emphasize in-room amenities like high speed Internet access as well as bathrobes and slippers and a staff trained to remember the names and requirements of repeat guests. Fitness centers with workout machines and business centers are usually musts as well.
This pampering comes at a cost, of course. Most boutique hotels have room rates well over $300 a night. The rates at Dylan are $435 to $535 a night.
Morris Moinian, the developer of Dylan, said the former club building provided a better base for the hotel than some of the office buildings that have been converted in recent years. In addition to the Alchemy Suite, the building included an expansive ballroom with a six-foot-wide working fireplace, a mezzanine looking over the ballroom and a marble and brass staircase connecting the first three floors.
The staircase is there mostly as a dramatic architectural statement, of course. As part of the renovation, new elevators were installed.
"You don't have spaces like this in office building conversions," said the 40-year-old Mr. Moinian. The Dylan, which opened late last year, is his first hotel in Manhattan, although he is an owner of the Wyndham Sugar Bay Hotel in St. Thomas, Virgin Islands. He said he had acquired another property on 28th Street in the Chelsea section of Manhattan for conversion into another boutique hotel, which will have 122 rooms.
The Chemists' Club sold the building and moved out in the late 1980's, and the building stood vacant, although it had several owners, until Mr. Moinian purchased it in June 1997. (The Chemists' Club still exists; it is at 40 West 45th Street these days.)
Mr. Moinian said other developers had advanced proposals to convert the 10-story turn-of-the-last-century building to housing or offices. For himself, he said: "I was thinking hotel before I even walked through the door. What had been a glorious private club could be turned into a glorious hotel."
TO improve the economics of the project, Mr. Moinian added four stories to the top of the building, an addition that yielded a total of 108 guest rooms. Although he said the addition was as-of-right under zoning laws, there were certain practical limitations.
"My engineers came to me with a good-news, bad-news story," he said. "The good news was that they could add the four floors; the bad news was that they wanted to put two columns in the middle of the ballroom." Since the old ballroom was to be the site of a restaurant, adding columns to the space with an intricately carved, 34-foot-high ceiling was clearly unacceptable. The solution was to expose all the columns in the old building, remove the protective brickwork, and reinforce them so that they could handle the loads of the extra floors.
Saved from the columns, the room now houses the restaurant Virot, named for its chef and owner, Didier Virot. Because of the limitations of the building, Mr. Virot does his cooking in the basement, just under where his customers are eating. The room is decorated with two huge mirrors on the side walls and a metal sculpture of birds going up the wall over the fireplace, where a gas fire is to be operated in colder months.
The interior redesign by Jeffrey Beers moved the bar from the main floor to the balcony, which was widened to accommodate two rows of tables and chairs for light snacks to accompany drinks.
Mr. Beers's lobby has the front desk to one side and a seating area to the other with sight lines into the restaurant and a new walnut parquet floor tying it all together. The desk itself is wrapped in leather with a marble slab on top. The area behind the desk is decorated by a clear resin panel embedded with translucent, round shapes.
On the opposite side of the lobby, to the right as a guest walks in, the walls are lined with sand-blasted glass to give depth to a relatively small space. Farther in, the staircase goes off to the left and is a practical way to get to the bar on the second floor without waiting for an elevator. 
There had been water damage to the room housing the Alchemy Suite during the time the building was vacant, and finding a contractor willing to undertake restoring the room to the condition it was in as the Chemists' Club library and exhibit room in the 1930's was difficult, Mr. Moinian said.
"People did not know how much it would cost, so it was hard to get bidders," he said. "Finally, we found a group of Italians who did it all by hand."
Adding modern amenities, like heat and air-conditioning to what is supposed to evoke a medieval space, was a challenge as well. After all, it would not do to have air-conditioning ducts hanging from the vaulted ceiling or grillwork cut into the walls.
The answer was to install the equipment in a vertical chamber next to the closet and trim it with the same wood as the closet to make it as inconspicuous as possible.
Unlike the rest of the room, the stained glass window was in good shape when he purchased the building, Mr. Moinian said. The window features two round, multicolored panels surrounded by rectangular and hexagonal panes of translucent glass.
Both are based on ideas drawn from alchemy. One of the round panels depicts a long-necked flask resting above a flame, presumable converting base metal into gold. The other shows a shining Sun face, beaming its rays through a magnifying glass into a beaker, similarly intended to create a chemical reaction.
During the reconstruction, the Sun face panel was neatly clipped out of the wondow. "When I called the police, they said there was a guy going around the city stealing stained glass," Mr. Moinian said.
The stolen window was not recovered, so a replacement was ordered. "Fortunately, we had a picture from the preopening brochure, so we knew what it looked like," Mr. Moinian said. From across the room, the replacement panel appears to match the remaining original, but on close observation the colors, particularly the deep blues, are clearly different.
The room originally had a small mezzanine office connected to it, reached by a spiral staircase. That space is now a limestone lined bathroom with a 14-foot ceiling.
As a club, the building had about 30 guest rooms, with one bathroom per floor -- this at a time in the 1960's when the rate was $20 a night, according to club officials. Each of the guest rooms, which have 11-foot ceilings, now has an attached bath with granite floors and marble sheathed walls.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Dylan Hotel, formerly the Chemists' Club, is owned by Morris Moinian; left, Alchemy Suite. (Photographs by G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
As the Economy Falters, the Hotel Market Cools

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
A LACK of capital, corporate budget tightening, a dip in business travel and a slower national economy have all combined to take some of the sizzle out of the hotel market in New Jersey as well as nationally. 
 While revenues for the state's hotels grew 7.8 percent last year from 1999, this year they are expected to rise 4 to 4.5 percent, according to PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting and consulting firm. And in the 12 months that ended in March, the occupancy rate in the state's hotels slid modestly to 67.6 percent from 68.1 percent. 
 While the supply of rooms grew by 2.1 percent, demand rose by just 1.3 percent, according to Smith Travel Research in Hendersonville, Tenn. The national occupancy rate for the same period was 63.7 percent, up slightly from 63.2 percent a year earlier. 
New Jersey's hotels, particularly first-class lodgings, "suffered a bit in the first quarter because of the falloff in commercial travel and the decrease in overflow from Manhattan," said Sean Hennessey, director of the New York office of the hospitality and leisure practice at PricewaterhouseCoopers. "Still. the market is softening, not weakening."
John A. Fox, a senior vice president at PKF, a hotel and real estate consulting concern in New York, added that New Jersey's 67.6 percent occupancy rate was above the break-even mark for the industry, which is 55 to 60 percent. In addition, average daily room rates rose to $104 from $97 from last year.
And Joseph Simonetta, executive vice president of the New Jersey Hotel and Motel Association in Trenton, added, "Everyone is still building and not talking about an oversupply." 
A spate of hotel projects are under way or will begin by the fall, ranging from a Hampton Inn on Route 1 and 9 in Linden to a Hyatt atop a pier in Jersey City. There are also conversions, like the planned transformation of a historic mansion in Morristown into a boutique hotel, as well as major renovations, including the proposed refurbishing of a Travelodge in Livingston as part of its shift to a Sheraton. 
But reflecting the financing pinch as well as rising construction costs. the number of projects added this year in the nation, as in New Jersey, will be fewer than in 2000, and a similar situation will happen next year, said Bruce Ford. Mr. Ford is director of sales and marketing at Lodging Econometrics, a division of National Hotel Realty in Portsmouth, N.H.
Mr. Ford said lenders had tightened their financing recently because they found that they had more than enough hotels in their investment portfolios. He added that in the last 18 months these lenders had not been able to resell their hotel loans.
Most analysts say the softness, barring any economic tailspin, will be short, with a rebound in occupancy and room rates beginning this year's second half or early next year. Still, hotel operators are taking "a wait-and-see attitude, trying to understand the magnitude and duration," said Donna Quadri, a vice president of sales and marketing at Hotel RevMAX, a Manhattan-based company that tracks the lodging industry for hotel companies around the world. "Clients are ardently watching occupancy and room rates to determine what discount, if any, is required to keep customers."
In New Jersey, Mr. Hennessey said the summer "looks good, given the state's tourism base." But in the fall, he added, while the number of conventions and meetings "should hold," there will be "fewer people attending them." 
Among the major new hotel projects rising or planned in the state is the first new casino-hotel in Atlantic City in a dozen years. Mirage Hotel and the Boyd Gaming Corporation of Las Vegas are building the 2,010-room Borgata, designed in the style of a Tuscan village.
Other new hotels will also be near transportation hubs like Newark International Airport, which will be expanded and increase its passengers by 10 million, to 44 million a year, by 2010, according to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. There are plans for seven hotels, with 2,000 rooms, in the airport area, of which two, each with 200 rooms, are under way by Marriott International, the Washington-based chain. They are among the more than 20 hotels the chain has under way in the state. Despite the current economic backdrop, Marriott said it fully expected to meet its projected dates for completion. 
Among the few new full-service hotels is one planned in downtown Morristown. In September, the Applied Development Company of Hoboken will start work on a $24 million conversion of the former Vail mansion into a 101-room hotel. The mansion was built in 1918 by Theodore Vail, the first president of AT&T, and is listed on the National Register of Historic Places.
THE Florentine-style mansion, last used as the municipal hall, will be renovated and a U-shaped addition will wrap around it. The addition will be clad in stucco to complement the granite and marble facade of the mansion, said Michael Barry, a principal at Applied. He added that when completed by the fall of 2002, the hotel would also have meeting rooms and a restaurant. Average daily room rates are expected to be $200. 
"This is an underserved market for upscale hotels," Mr. Barry said, noting that the building is close to the town's train station and accessible to local as well as area businesses. 
Similarly, developers plan to strip to its shell a three-story, 202-room Travelodge on Route 10 in Livingston and rebuild it as a 194-room Four Points Sheraton, that chain's low-rise brand. The new hotel will also include a catering hall and a restaurant. Daily room rates are expected to be $150 to $200.
The Kushner Companies of Florham Park will close on the purchase of the 5.8-acre-site in July. It will then develop the $20 million project with two partners in the next year, said Jeffrey Freireich, managing director at Kushner.
"This is a prime piece of real estate in a visible location, and there is a need for a quality hotel in the area," he said.
A 350-room Hyatt rising atop the pier at the Harborside Financial Center in Jersey City is the city's first full-service lodging on the riverfront. The hotel, with 20,000 square feet of meeting space, is to open by July 2002, said Dale Moulton, a senior vice president of development at Hyatt. His company is developing the hotel with the Mack-Cali Realty Corporation, a real estate investment trust in Cranford that owns Harborside. 
Much of the new construction, both in the state and nationally, however, will be of limited-service hotels, which has been the trend for the last few years. Typically, they do not have the restaurants, shops and abundance of meeting rooms found in full-service hotels and are less costly to build. 
Mr. Fox, the analyst, said such hotels, which also have lower room rates than full-service lodgings, will do well "in down times, as business travelers tighten budgets."
In Linden, Inn America Hospitality Inc. of Iselin is to start construction this month on a 149-room Hampton Inn on Route 1 and 9. The $14 million hotel, expected to rise in the next 10 months, will take advantage "of the growth of major corporations in the greater Newark metropolitan area," said David DeCicco, the development company's executive vice president. That the hotel is also part of the 650,000-square-foot Aviation Plaza "ensures success," he added. The average daily room rate is expected to be $110. 
Aviation Plaza, now under way, is the redevelopment of 66 acres that were formerly part of the 188-acre Linden Municipal Airport site into up to 16 stores, including Home Depot and Target; restaurants; and a 14-screen movie theater. The hotel "will provide built-in business," said Louis Ceruzzi, president of Starwood Ceruzzi L.L.C. of Fairfield, Conn., which is developing the plaza with the Cappelli Development Company of Valhalla, N.Y. 
The Prime Hospitality Corporation of Fairfield has slowed its construction activity from around 30 properties in 1998 to five or six projects, said Douglas W. Vicari, the senior vice president and chief financial officer. "It's a game plan we have not felt needs to be adjusted today," he added.
In Mount Laurel, off Route 73, the company will open a 125-room, six-story AmeriSuites in September. And it is renovating and converting two former Howard Johnson lodgings to its Wellesley Inns and Suites brand. Each conversion costs $2 million to $3 million.
One Wellesley Inn with 149 rooms opened last month on Route 23 and Ratzer Road in Wayne. The other, with 100 rooms, is on Route 10 in Whippany and is to open in mid-August. The average daily room rate will be $65 to $70 at each. 
"There is some weakness in hotel demand," Mr. Vicari said, "but no one predicts the softness will last long, and we are setting up for that."

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK 

BYLINE:  Compiled by Warren Strugatch; E-mail: libiz@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Pall Corp. Widens Plans for Layoffs
 Pall Corporation (NYSE: PLL) of East Hills has raised the number of jobs it will eliminate to 500, about 100 more jobs than it announced two weeks ago. The company will also take a fourth-quarter charge of under $10 million to cover the cost of the layoffs, which will affect about 5 percent of the global work force. 
 On Long Island, the company will reduce its work force by about 70 jobs, said Eric Krasnoff, chairman and chief executive. Jobs cut on Long Island will be across the board outside of sales and marketing positions, Mr. Krasnoff said.
Pall also warned it did not expect to meet analysts' consensus expectations for earnings. Pall released new earnings estimates for the fiscal year ending July 31 in the range of $1.08 and $1.13 a share. Analysts surveyed by First Call/Thompson Financial projected earnings to reach $1.17 a share on average.
Pall also reported that third-quarter earnings dipped to $36.9 million, down from $41.8 million for the third quarter a year ago, on revenues that rose less than 1 percent to $321.1 million from $318.1 a year ago. Earnings were 30 cents a share, down from 34 cents a share in the third quarter last year.
The company manufactures filters that are used in the pharmaceutical, aerospace and semiconductor industries. Last year sales topped $1.2 billion.
Mr. Krasnoff said in a statement that foreign exchange rates, the semiconductor industry slowdown and the sluggish domestic economy affected third-quarter profitability.

Around the Island
Langer Biomechanics Group (Nasdaq: GAIT) of Deer Park reported a loss for its fiscal year of $1.51 million, on sales of $11.6 million. Last year, it reported a loss of $335,274, on sales of $11.1 million. Andrew H. Meyers, president and chief executive, said the company, which sells medical devices to doctors treating musculoskeletal disorders, expected to bring new products and services to market this summer. . . . NetSat Express of Hauppauge said it had signed a $3 million multiyear contract with SkyOnline, a McLean, Va., telecommunications company. . . . Long Island Commercial Bank (Nasdaq: LICB) of Islandia announced completion of a stock repurchase program initiated in April 1999. It has repurchased nearly 334,000 shares, or 19 percent of its outstanding shares of common stock, at an average price of $12.40.

HEADLINE: In Public, Making Them Look at Least Twice 

BYLINE:  By Valerie Cruice 

 BODY:
DID you know the tree of life is growing in Farmington? Or that in Bridgeport simple tools of the trade are breaking down walls stronger than brick? Were you aware that in Willimantic a 16-foot-high book is an open door, or that an aquatic core sample cascades down three stories just a few hundred feet from Long Island Sound in Groton? Did anybody ever point out the words of the 18th-century Scottish economist Adam Smith illuminating the way to greater understanding in New Britain? 
 These discoveries can be found in the specially commissioned art that adorns public buildings all over Connecticut. As a result of the Art in Public Spaces program, established by state law in 1978, more than 330 works of art have been installed at 60 sites in 30 towns and cities around the state. There are paintings, photographic works, sculptures, wall reliefs, fiber works, ceramic works, murals and environmental installations, according to the Connecticut Commission on the Arts, which manages the program for the state. (The program's Web site is www.ctarts.org/Artpub.htm.) 
 Linda Dente, program director of Art in Public Spaces, explained how the artists are found and matched to the site. There are three professional jurors who select the finalists from a slide bank that is kept at the Connecticut Commission on the Arts as a resource. The jury also meets with a representative from the site where the art will be installed, as well as the architect.
Lately, the Art in Public Spaces budget has been running about $1 million a year; the amount varies depending on the amount of bonds issued for construction. "This program is very much tied into the economy," Ms. Dente said. "When we're building a lot, we're doing a lot of commissions." By Valerie Cruice

HEADLINE: Is It a Grand Idea or Just a Pipe Dream? 

BYLINE:  By COREY KILGANNON 

 BODY:
FROM Oyster Bay to Rye in Westchester in a matter of minutes without seeing the light of day? Sounds like some sort of molecular transport system straight out of "Star Trek."
 But you could also do it by driving in a tunnel under Long Island Sound. And actually, it's hard to say which method is more improbable. Various transportation experts demur when asked where the money and political will to build such a tunnel would come from. 
 But they say a tunnel is a viable proposition from an engineering standpoint. The possibility of building an underground passage, including a roadway and rails, from Westchester to Long Island has been the subject of news conferences, forums and discussions with state transportation officials. 
As envisioned by its principal advocate, a Westchester County engineer named Alexander Saunders, the cross-Sound tunnel would be incorporated into a plan to replace the Tappan Zee Bridge. The Tappan Zee is nearing the end of its designed lifespan, and with maintenance costs mounting the state has begun seeking proposals for a new Hudson crossing.
Many advocates want a new bridge, or to fix the old one; Mr. Saunders not only wants a tunnel, but one that would extend far beyond the banks of the Hudson to Mahwah, N.J., on the border with New York, duplicating the New York Thruway west of the Hudson and Interstate 287 in Westchester, then diving under the Sound to pop up at the northern end of the Seaford-Oyster Bay Expressway in Syosset. Crossing parts of Rockland and Westchester counties, it would have several exits.
The entire 45-mile plan would create the longest transportation tunnel in the world. (The Seikan railway tunnel under the Tsuguru Straits in Japan is currently the longest, at 33.5 miles.)
Mr. Saunders conceded that if his grand tunnel idea were treated piecemeal, the tunnels under the waterways make the best sense from both economic and transportation perspectives.
But he insisted that tunnelling far into Rockland and across Westchester makes sense, and that extending the tube well into Nassau County would tie in to the Island's existing road network and would burrow under some of the North Shore nimbys who spearheaded the rejection of Robert Moses's proposal, three decades ago, for a bridge from Rye to Bayville.
Mr. Saunders insists that it is inappropriate to compare his project to the 6.5-mile Moses bridge.
"That was opposed because it was so intrusive at both ends and such a presence in the Sound, which is such a great area for sailing and other recreation," he said. "Obviously this would not be intrusive that way. I think the main issue to deal with is that it would make Long Island easier to get to and increase traffic there."
Mr. Saunders, a 62-year-old resident of Garrison, led the campaign to persuade the state Thruway Authority to consider the option of building a Tappan Tunnel as part of its three-year study to determine whether to replace or rehabilitate the Tappan Zee Bridge. It made no such commitment to the extended project, including the Sound tunnel.
But over the past few months, he has unveiled his grand scheme in public meetings and met with local elected officials and transportation officials, including John R. Platt, the Thruway Authority's executive director. Mr. Saunders has also met with representatives of major tunnel-boring companies.
"Lots of groups have taken a great interest, or at least been very polite," said Mr. Saunders, who runs his family's foundry supply company in Putnam County and pursues the tunnel idea as something between a hobby and a Quixotic obsession.
Mr. Saunders envisions a tube sunk 100 feet below the sand and gravel bottom of the Sound. It would contain roadways on an upper level and train tracks on the lower level for freight or passengers.
The job would require at least one, but probably several, huge tunneling machines. A machine made by a German company, Herrenknecht, simultaneously digs and lines a tunnel at about 30 to 40 feet per day. It is the diameter of a small Ferris wheel, weighs about 1,300 tons and would cost more than $50 million.
Mr. Saunders estimates that a tunnel under the Sound would cost about $8 billion, based on costs for similar tunnels in Europe.
Transportation officials say it would cost several times Mr. Saunders's estimate. The 31-mile Channel Tunnel connecting England to France cost about $15 billion, but it is a rail tunnel only, and narrower than Mr. Saunders's proposed tube.
He says that whatever the cost, a cross-Sound tunnel would more than pay for itself in terms of convenience and in toll revenue. He also argues that a tunnel would:
*Ultimately cost less than roadways and bridges, to build and maintain.
*Replace Interstate 287 and restore the land there for parks or development.
*Reduce congestion by containing more traffic lanes than existing surface roadways and eliminate the hazards of sun glare, snow and rain.
*Last some 50 years longer than the typical bridge and road projects.
*Eliminate the visual intrusion of bridge and highways.
*Allow for an inter-county rail system.
*Fight pollution by installing devices to "scrub" automobile emissions vented from the tunnel.
Few public figures on the Island will acknowledge being intrigued by the proposal. One of them is Neal M. Lewis, executive director of the Long Island Neighborhood Network, an environmental and civic advocacy group based in Massapequa.
"The idea of a Sound crossing has been around for a long time, and has always raised a lot of local concerns, but as a tunnel, it deserves a fresh look," he said, but added, "Obviously, it's a long shot."
Mr. Lewis was speaking by cell phone and said he had just battled his way through Memorial Day traffic on his way upstate.
"It's always a mess having to go through the city in order to get north of the city, so it would be more convenient," he said of a tunnel. "But also, knowing that you can drive onto Long Island and hang a left and go up to Connecticut could also make through traffic worse. And wherever such a tunnel would terminate, there would be a huge traffic impact."
Many transportation people call the project a true pipe dream, saying that while constructing it is feasible, getting it approved -- or even considered -- is not.
Jon Orcutt, associate director of the Tri-State Transportation Campaign, a nonprofit advocacy group, said a cross-Sound tunnel project would certainly take a back seat to other transportation projects with much more support in the metropolitan area. They include a Long Island Rail Road link to Grand Central Terminal, a Second Avenue subway in Manhattan, a rail freight tunnel under New York Harbor from New Jersey to Brooklyn and an expanded commuter rail line to New Jersey and Rockland County.
Brian Muellers, the Nassau County legislator who represents parts of Syosset and several communities northward, said he would fight such a project tooth and nail.
"It will never happen as long as I'm a legislator and have any say whatsoever, whether that's six months or 10 years," said Mr. Muellers, chairman of the Legislature's public works committee.
"If they can get this tunnel to the end of the Seaford-Oyster Bay Expressway without moving one single tree, it's one thing," he said. "But if one tree has to be moved or one space invaded, then it should not happen. It only means building more roads and clogging our downtown streets and smaller arteries, and it encourages more people to get in their cars, get on the road and drive, instead of staying local and enjoying their communities and shopping there."
Mr. Saunders said that during construction, a large site would be needed as a staging area for equipment, and possibly after completion for train parking.
He proposed using the Cerro Wire site, a disused factory near South Oyster Bay Road and the Long Island Expressway. It happens that there are well-organized community groups in that area that have been fighting a proposal to build a shopping mall on the site.
Judith Jacobs, the presiding officer of the Nassau County Legislature, said the community would surely oppose making the Cerro Wire site a tunnel depot or busy staging area.
"Certainly no one would look agreeably on having some kind of depot there," she said. "It would bring traffic and oversaturation in the area, and that was the very reason we opposed the shopping mall."
In recent years, transportation groups considered a bridge from Suffolk to Connecticut, but a state study found that a bridge would cost $20 to $25 billion, depending on its location, and would never pay for itself.
Eileen Peters, a spokeswoman for the state Department of Transportation in Hauppauge, said that the state recently considered two proposals for a Suffolk-to-Connecticut tunnel. One would connect the Sagtikos Parkway to Westport, and another would run from the William Floyd Parkway to New Haven. Both plans were deemed too costly and ineffective in relieving congestion.
"They were not viable recommendations," Ms. Peters said. "It didn't make sense from a congestion point of view. As many cars would come on the Island as would go off, so it would not relieve our traffic whatsoever."
Lee E. Koppelman, who has been executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board since 1965, said that although a tunnel would draw less local opposition than a bridge, "in my opinion, it would never happen. But it does make a good conversation piece every few years."
Mr. Koppelman pointed out that the Throgs Neck and Whitestone bridges are not far from the Queens-Nassau border.
"The added convenience doesn't make it worth the problems," he said. "Rye is not that much farther up than the Bronx."
Mr. Koppelman compared the tunnel idea to a proposal to dam the Sound and make it a freshwater lake that would supply water to Long Island. A bridge to Connecticut would be built on the dam.
