HEADLINE: DATABANK: MAY 28-JUNE 1; 
Desperately Seeking a Silver Lining

BYLINE:  By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN 

 BODY:
A rally on Friday turned what had been a bad week on Wall Street into a not-so-bad week.
 Stocks tumbled early in the week as new profit warnings, most notably by Sun Microsystems, signaled that the economy was not likely to emerge from its doldrums any time soon. 
Some analysts saw the sell-off as a sobering reminder that the rally that began in April has been built mostly on optimism. 
 The unemployment report on Friday, showing sharp losses in manufacturing employment, coupled with a report on manufacturing activity, which declined for the 10th consecutive month, provided further evidence of economic weakness. Nevertheless, investors looked for the silver lining, believing that the news provided impetus for more interest rate cuts. 
 The major indexes all lost ground. The technology-heavy Nasdaq fared the worst, falling to 2,149.44, down 101.59 points, or 4.5 percent. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index ended at 1,260.67, down 17.22, or 1.3 percent. The Dow industrials were off only slightly, finishing at 10,990.41, down 14.96, or 0.1 percent. 
 Bond investors concluded there could be more rate cuts. The yield on the 10-year note fell to 5.36 percent from 5.49 percent. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

HEADLINE: Zimbabwe Doctors Flee As AIDS Crisis Widens 

BYLINE:  By HENRI E. CAUVIN 

DATELINE: BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe 

 BODY:
Like the rest of the country's hospitals, Mpilo Central is sick.
 Mpilo, the biggest hospital here in Zimbabwe's second-biggest city, is losing its doctors, its nurses, its pharmacists and, slowly, its spirit. 
 Fleeing the deepening hardships in Zimbabwe and following the lure of opportunities unimaginable here, medical professionals are abandoning the country as never before. The health care system, as a result, is sinking into crisis, consuming the colleagues left behind.
Mpilo, for example, which handles many of the most difficult cases in the region, now has just one general surgeon instead of three to serve its 1,037 beds. 
"I am on call every day," the surgeon, Dr. Julio Feliu, said one afternoon after completing seven scheduled operations before heading off to teach a medical school class.
Over the last few years, as many as 100 doctors and hundreds -- if not thousands -- of nurses are estimated to have emigrated from this nation of 11 million people. While losing medical professionals is neither new nor unique to Zimbabwe, the scope appears unprecedented. With one of the world's worst AIDS epidemics and with its economy in turmoil, the country could hardly be more vulnerable.
Indeed, business executives, teachers, engineers and others are leaving too, costing Zimbabwe much of the enormously successful investment it made in education after blacks won majority rule 21 years ago. 
Their marketability is a testament to Zimbabwe's successes in improving education and nurturing a black professional class. But those achievements are in jeopardy as people flee.
Zimbabwe's economy, once one of Africa's most promising, is a wreck. A standoff over how white-owned farmland should be redistributed has roiled the country and harmed agriculture, the country's economic base. Exports and tourism are down, giving the country little of the foreign currency it needs for imports like fuel and drugs for its health care system.
Unhappy with the state's policies and priorities, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund have cut Zimbabwe off, and President Robert Mugabe has refused to make concessions.
Inflation is at nearly 60 percent. Professionals like the doctors at Mpilo, who envisioned lives of at least modest prosperity for their families, instead find themselves struggling to cover their bills.
"It's money first and foremost," said Dr. Zulu Mahlangu, the acting medical superintendent of Mpilo, when asked what was luring away his staff.
Doctors in government service typically earn $550 to $1,100 a month and nurses $350 to $500, according to the Health Ministry and the nurses' union.
So when countries like Australia, Britain, Canada and the United States, all facing critical health care staffing shortages, have come calling, they have found legions of workers looking for something better.
"It was mostly junior doctors at first, but now even people who are in private practice, senior doctors, are leaving -- it's a lot more now," said a specialist in his 40's who works for a government hospital. "They are worrying about the education of their kids, their security, the general economic climate."
Opened in 1957, Mpilo Central would, in another time, seem a decent place to work. Set on 28 acres a couple of miles northwest of the city's central business district, it appears spare, but well kept. It is not cutting edge, but neither is it a medical wasteland. 
Such mundane charms apparently no longer suffice for many of Zimbabwe's medical professionals. Of the 600 posts for doctors in government hospitals, nearly 100 are vacant, as are 600 of the 5,000 positions for general nurses, said Davies G. Dhlakama, the Health Ministry's director of technical support.
Dr. Barton Matshe is one of three staff obstetricians at Mpilo -- which delivers 11,000 babies a year. The other two are on loan from Cuba, and go home for several weeks each year.
By Dr. Matshe's reckoning, Mpilo should have at least six obstetricians; by the hospital's, it should have at least five. No one expects more anytime soon.
Dr. Matshe came to Bulawayo, eager to go where his skills are "really needed." Now, however, there are days when he questions his judgment.
A 37-year-old father of three, he was born in Shurugwi, 125 miles northeast of here. After studying at the University of Zimbabwe Medical School in the capital, Harare, he fulfilled his required government service at the city's public hospitals. Then, like many other young doctors, he left the country to train in his chosen specialty. He spent six years in Cape Town, South Africa, and Johannesburg and six months ago he started work here.
"Part of me thinks I made the right decision, but there are times that I think from a personal point of view and from a professional point of view," he said, "that it wasn't quite the right decision." The fees each term for his two children in primary schools come to more than his monthly salary.
Bulawayo, with 800,000 people, is the business hub of southern Zimbabwe. In many ways it is better off than the rural areas in its ability to attract doctors and nurses.
But then those small rural hospitals are not asked to take on the most challenging cases, as Mpilo is. "We hardly ever see any low-risk patients," Dr. Matshe said.
And Bulawayo finds itself a second choice for many specialists, who prefer to be in Harare. The capital has not been spared, however. Even medical professionals who remain in Zimbabwe are devoting more time to private practice, which offers the only, albeit diminishing, hope of earning a good living.
The sort of specialized treatment that was once available only in the capital is increasingly not offered any more. For example, children with rheumatic heart disease now have little chance of ever having the surgery they need. "It's disheartening when the children keep coming back and saying, 'Why can't I be fixed,' and you have to say, 'Because the government has no money for operations,' " said Andrew Bowman, a cardiologist and secretary of the Zimbabwe Medical Association. "It's very sad."
Parirenyatwa, the only hospital in the country with the facilities to perform open heart surgery, no longer offers this surgery. The equipment is still there, but there is no money for essential supplies, said one of the country's few cardiac surgeons.
What that has meant, the surgeon said, is that the few patients with medical insurance and enough money travel to South Africa for the surgery. "Those who cannot afford it," the surgeon said, "are dying -- and there are a lot of them."
The day-to-day frustrations erode the faith of many doctors and nurses in what they are doing and give them another reason to leave, on top of the economic hardships.
The medical professionals who stay say they understand the thinking of the ones who don't. "It's very personal, and you can't interfere with that kind of decision," said Dr. Matshe, the obstetrician at Mpilo Central Hospital.
After all, the idea of leaving has occurred to almost all of them. "I suppose all of us have at some point or another thought about, but somebody has to hang around here," said Dr. Mahlangu, Mpilo's medical superintendent. "I was born here. I was brought up here. This is home."

HEADLINE: Melrose Journal; 
5 Dogs, 3 People and One Immaculate Bedroom

BYLINE:  By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
There have been countless stories about the rich and their dogs: about doggie day care, doggie co-op interviews, Hermes dog carriers. This is a story about the animal passions of the economically average, or below average, the people who live in a one-bedroom or just one room, doubled or tripled up, on minimum wage or in the working class. These are the people for whom pets are a real luxury, both in dollars and in space, the people who could logically be expected to give up their pets when times grow tougher or apartments become even more cramped. 
 But logic has never been what governs the human relationship to animals, and so the Pet Store, also known as the Pet Warehouse, at Elton Avenue and 153rd Street in the Melrose section of the Bronx, was doing a busy trade last Sunday, as it almost always does. People came to buy kittens and baby chickens and fish and dogs. They came for food and collars and flea-control pills and coat-whitening shampoos. And they came for the company and conversation of fellow animal lovers. 
 Outside a window display of three puppies -- two scrappy cocker spaniels and a dachshund -- Jesus Ruiz, 35, who works in construction, was showing off his own baby, a Rottweiler named Diamond. He and his fiancee, Crystal Russell, 31 and unemployed, had to move to a one-room apartment recently, but they never thought of leaving Diamond -- whose full name is Diamond Russell Ruiz -- behind. They do not have a lot of money, he said, but they do not mind spending it on Diamond, whose coat glowed with good health. "If you love someone very much, you take care of them," he said. 
A woman passing by told of being in a homeless shelter when another resident's pet raccoon -- kept hidden for three years -- escaped. They commiserated over shelter rules that ban almost all pets. 
Inside the Pet Store, the manager, Charlie Alfaro, displayed his dogs' pictures in a plastic credit-card holder that some parents use to show off their children. There was the 30-pound pug, a male, and the 110-pound Rottweiler, a female. And then there was one of the "pugweilers" that their coupling had produced, and that Mr. Alfaro had sold for $100 apiece. 
Recognizing what passes for a home in New York, Mr. Alfaro's shop carries only small-breed dogs, like chihuahuas, dachshunds and little Yorkies. Cocker spaniels, selling at more than $600, are the most popular. "You get a 100-pound dog in a one-bedroom apartment, where you going to stick it?" he said. 
Ask Carlos Martinez, who has not one, but two, Rottweilers in a one-bedroom apartment. He had brought one, Napoleon, who has a killer's physique but a lover's temperament, to the store to hang out. Mr. Martinez, a veterinary technician, showed off Napoleon's training. "Charlie's not looking," he said of Mr. Alfaro. "Steal a cookie." 
Napoleon obliged. 
Lourdes Lopez, a 40-year-old home health aide, already has an iguana, finches and a parakeet, not to mention the cockatiel that flew away. She had come with her husband, Carlos, a factory pressman, to buy fantailed fish -- small creatures that incongruously combine enormous bulging eyes with genteel wafting tails. Pets relax her, Mrs. Lopez said. "I come from Puerto Rico, and I used to wake up to birds singing." Hearing them in her apartment, she feels close to the land. 
Then there was Elvin Ramos, 32, an auto mechanic, who had come in to buy a hot pink collar ("$6.99!" his wife exclaimed) for his miniature pinscher, Diana, purchased on layaway for $1,000. He also has four chihuahuas, and lives with all five dogs, snakes, hamsters, his wife and son in a one-bedroom apartment that he insisted was immaculate. He also had just seen a stray dog in the street that he was longing to take home, although his wife, Betsy, a telephone operator, had no such intentions. 
"We just get by," he said, but to him the pet expense is worth it. Six of their seven children are being raised by grandparents in Puerto Rico, so the dogs are a substitute. Diana is named for one of his daughters. 
In the back room, one family had come from church not to buy, but to look at the tanks full of fish with names like lines of poetry:
Colored Tinfoils
Pigeon Blood Discus
Sunset Gourami
Kissing Fish
Gold Mollies
And their shapes and colors prompted the family's 5-year-old boy to utter a little poem of his own: 
Ooooh 
My God 
Lookit Mama.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 6, 2001

 CORRECTION:
The Melrose Journal article and a picture caption on Sunday, about a pet shop in a poor and working-class section of the Bronx, referred incorrectly in some copies to the breed of a dog owned by an auto mechanic. It was a miniature pinscher, not a miniature Doberman.

HEADLINE: Our Towns; 
Rescuing Tom Thumb's House as Bridgeport's Children Struggle

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW PURDY 

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. 

 BODY:
IT'S easy to zip past the dilapidated house on North Avenue -- not to mention Bridgeport itself -- and avert your eyes. Many people do.
 Even Guy Paniccia, who owns the house and uses its overgrown yard for parking for his auto shop across the street, saw it as just a dilapidated house. The developer buying the property saw it as a dilapidated house standing in the way of a new shopping center. It took Charles Brilvitch, a local historian, to point out that the ramshackle hulk was a piece of history, once home to that glorified child Tom Thumb. 
 Suddenly, in Bridgeport, where P. T. Barnum was once mayor and remains an icon, saving the house of his miniature performer is a cause. The developer is sensitive to the issue. The mayor wants it preserved. Local officials are devising a rescue plan.
Leave no circus act behind.
Bridgeport needs all the acts it can get. Most Connecticut cities are like brackish puddles that suburbanites step around or over, if they possibly can. Anything that might draw visitors is worth a bet. This city has the Barnum Museum and the requisite minor league baseball team, and a sports arena is rising off Route 95. Mayor Joseph P. Ganim envisions Bridgeport as "the best entertainment center in Connecticut," so perhaps it's even worth rescuing the long-forgotten home of Tom Thumb, Barnum's beloved 19th-century circus dwarf.
"A family from Ohio on their way to Cape Cod with a car full of howling kids would see this on a list of things to do and want to show their kids the Tom Thumb house," said Mr. Brilvitch, who added that moving and renovating the house could cost up to $500,000.
But it may be more educational to visit the corner of Newfield and Stratford Avenues -- the perfect setting if someone wanted to develop a theme park based on the challenges of the great economic divide.
On Thursday evening, some of Connecticut's less-glorified children and adults waited there for the Rescue Mission truck to arrive with free lentil stew and used clothing.
Talika Boyd, 29, a home health aide making $11 an hour, came looking for clothes for her three young children. Cynthia Henry, 40, a single mother of three picking up free baby food, said an illness in her family had recently forced her to trade an $8-an-hour fast-food job in the suburb of Trumbull for a $6.40-an-hour one close to her home in Bridgeport.
Sabrina Jackson, 45, who said she had been unable to work since her two sons were murdered, was looking for clothes with her granddaughter, Tarrena, 8, whom she raises. Ms. Jackson was worried about scraping together the $16 as well as lunch money Tarrena needs for an end-of-year school trip. "I do the best I can," she said.
JUST to review the balance sheet: Connecticut has the highest per capita income in the nation and its cities are among the poorest. From the late 1980's to the late 90's, average annual income for the poorest 20 percent of residents dropped 26 percent, to $17,615, two Washington research groups reported last year. It rose 18 percent to $174,149, for the wealthiest 20 percent. After the booming 90's, child poverty was higher than in the late 80's.
"It's America," said Janice Gruendel, co-director of Connecticut Voices for Children. "In Connecticut we just have it more extremely."
Nowhere is the divide deeper than here in Fairfield County, one of the nation's wealthiest counties. AiMee Sims, who attends a private high school on a scholarship, was one of two Bridgeport teenagers -- and the only black -- selected to travel to Europe last summer with 33 other students. She was surprised that the other students, many from Fairfield County suburbs, were afraid of Bridgeport.
"We were all traveling the world, not knowing what would happen next, and we're talking about how they're scared to come to Bridgeport," she said. 
Back at Newfield and Stratford, Simone Fulton, 9, was walking home with bags filled with pants, sweaters and shirts, and even a clip-on tie, which she planned to wear to school on Friday. "My teacher is going to Russia," she said. "It's her last day of school. I want to look good."
Her brother Julian, 11, got stew from the food truck and a second helping for his mother. "You just have to add a little salt," he said. Then he headed back into his home, where there was at least as much worth rescuing as in the Tom Thumb house.

HEADLINE: Sour About Their Choices, Peruvians Are to Vote Today 

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, June 2 

 BODY:
With polls showing a tightening race and many voters disillusioned or undecided, Peru's presidential election on Sunday may yield no clear winner, but another difficult challenge for the country's young democracy, international observers say. 
 The election is the second for president in just 13 months after the collapse of President Alberto K. Fujimori's government and an intelligence network that throttled democracy through vote fraud, news media manipulation and torture. 
 In recent weeks, Alejandro Toledo, a former World Bank official who dropped out of a runoff against Mr. Fujimori last year after an election marred by cheating, has watched his lead in opinion polls wither, as he has been forced to deny allegations of drug use and sex with prostitutes. He has also been hurt by his refusal to take a DNA test to prove that he is not the father of a teenage girl who says he abandoned her. 
His opponent, Alan Garcia, a former president, has returned from a nine-year exile promising to burnish Peru's economy and human rights record, now that the terrorist bands that helped make his first presidency so disastrous have been vanquished. But his failed populist policies, which caused hyperinflation and lines for food a decade ago, as well as old charges of corruption, continue to rile voters. 
While there is no sign that the newly revamped election apparatus tilts toward either man, both sides already appear poised to charge fraud if they lose after a campaign that has so disgusted voters that as many as 20 percent say they may spoil their ballots in protest. 
Senior officials in the interim government are already preparing the security forces to control possible street protests. 
A potential crisis can be averted if either candidate wins by a substantial margin, say by 3 percent or more, observers say. But some pollsters see a far narrower finish in the making, one likely to produce a contested vote count and a winner with a thin and sullied mandate. 
No matter the outcome, opinion polls indicate that the people of this country of 26 million people, which has been a major ally in America's drug war, view both the potential presidents as deeply flawed. 
"Both parties could cry foul, and there is the potential for political instability," said Eduardo Stein, a former Guatemalan foreign minister who heads the Organization of American States observer team. "We are not anticipating a horror movie, but we have not ruled out that scenario either." 
Mr. Stein, who also led the O.A.S. team in last year's election, said he had urged both camps to remain calm and honor the results. 
But supporters of Mr. Garcia, who was president between 1985 and 1990, are predicting there will be many disputes over ballot tally sheets, leading some observers to believe that they are preparing to cry fraud. Congressman Jorge del Castillo, leader of Mr. Garcia's APRA party, has already complained that Interior and Defense Ministry officials are favoring Mr. Toledo, who is running on behalf of a centrist group, Peru Posible. 
International observers say, however, that they are satisfied with the independence and probity of election officials under the interim government and that the computer software to count the vote is efficient and fair. Where a breakdown could occur, they say, is at the local level. Hundreds of thousands of voters live in remote jungle and Andean villages, where Peruvian poll watchers are often not attentive to detail and may be open to corruption. 
Ballots are destroyed on the day of the election, according to Peruvian law, after tally sheets are sent to computer centers for tabulation. Any complaint about the validity of tally sheets will be up to 58 three-member juries to rule on. If the vote is close, some observers say, the officials on the juries will almost certainly come under intense pressure from the competing parties.
Aides to Mr. Toledo have privately warned that disciplined APRA cadres control several of the local electoral juries. 
In the first-round vote in April, 24,000 tally sheets representing more than a quarter of a million votes came under dispute, delaying the final official result for six weeks. 
Former Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, who is here leading an observer team from the Carter Center and National Democratic Institute, said she had confidence in interim President Valentin Paniagua and Prime Minister Javier Perez de Cuellar. She said she was encouraged by a conversation with the leaders of the competing parties in which both expressed "awareness of the possibility that they could lose." 
But referring to the charges of vast ballot irregularities in the past, she added: "These dangers exist. There were these manipulations before, and one cannot say flat out this won't happen." 
Mr. Toledo, long the favorite after leading the opposition against Mr. Fujimori, eked out just over a third of the vote in the first-round balloting. Pollsters say his lead has been dwindling the last several weeks. One national poll released today showed Mr. Toledo leading, with about 43 percent to Mr. Garcia's 38 percent. 
But even if a clear winner does emerge, the last several months of campaigning have left the electorate deeply skeptical that either candidate will serve the country well. The same poll showed 18 percent of voters choosing to leave their ballots blank or spoiling them as a protest. 
Other polls have shown that a majority believe that both candidates are dishonest and incapable of directing the economy out of recession. 
The days of hot debates over issues like land redistribution and bank nationalization have been replaced by nods by both candidates to a free-market economy, human rights and an independent judiciary. 
Despite much consensus between the two candidates, the public has become disenchanted with a campaign that has been dominated by mudslinging and charges of illicit sex, drug taking and money-laundering. Campaign rallies have been marred by a rain of tomatoes and stones, and both political camps have planted damaging reports in the news media questioning their opponents' financial dealings. 
The unappealing campaign contrasts sharply with the efforts by Mr. Paniagua and congressional leaders to clean up government corruption. 
In daily television broadcasts of scores of videotapes captured from the former intelligence chief, Vladimiro Montesinos, a parade of military officers, politicians, businessmen and television station owners have been shown taking bribes and doing favors for the old government, which collapsed in November.
The armed forces have been purged of scores of senior officials, and government prosecutors are putting together a case to extradite Mr. Fujimori from Japan on an assortment of human rights and corruption charges. Both candidates have promised to continue the efforts, but voters appear skeptical.
"The two of them are corrupt, but what can we do?" asked Mario Panca, a 45-year-old Uro Indian fisherman on Lake Titicaca deep in the Andes. "We need a government that can help the poor, but this election isn't going to help us."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Supporters of Alejandro Toledo watched fireworks at his last campaign rally, in Cuzco, Peru. His lead in opinion polls has slipped in recent weeks. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Political Briefing; 
No Jobless Pay For 'Fired' Legislator

BYLINE:  By B. Drummond Ayres Jr. 

 BODY:
Remember David Jaye, the Michigan state senator from the Detroit suburbs who was expelled by his colleagues a couple of weeks ago?
 They said he had to go because he had "a recurring pattern of personal misconduct." 
To wit: three drunken driving convictions and involvement in an incident in which he was accused of hitting a woman. 
 He denies doing anything worthy of expulsion. And, in any event, he says, he wasn't expelled, he was "fired."
So last Tuesday he applied for unemployment pay, contending that he was entitled to $300 a week because he had lost a $77,400-a-year job.
Unemployment office officials turned him down. Legislators who are out of a job, they said, are not eligible to collect unemployment.
Mr. Jaye tried again, arguing that he was not out of work because of an election loss.
Still no dice, the unemployment folks said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS; 
These Cheerleaders Say, 'It's Better Here'

BYLINE:  By AILEEN CHO 

 BODY:
WHEN Denver and Dallas were competing recently with Chicago to woo the Boeing Company, which wanted to move its headquarters out of Seattle, they deployed superstar athletes to greet the company's executives. When Plano, Tex., and Jackson Hole, Wyo., sought to attract California companies disaffected by the energy shortage, they sent flashlights along with their marketing brochures.
 In the end, Boeing chose Chicago -- not for its athletes, but rather for basic reasons like big tax breaks and a central location. And while a number of California companies are thinking about moving out of state, there is no evidence that they are responding to the California-bashing approach taken by some cities that want them. 
 Nonetheless, the news from Boeing and California illustrates the frenzy that has accompanied the growth of economic development organizations -- cheerleader groups of corporate real estate brokers, bankers, economists and marketers that showcase their areas to entice new business.
"In the early 90's, there were only a couple dozen in California," Paul Saldana, president of the Economic Development Corporation in Tulare County of California, said of groups like his. "Today there are several hundred."
The International Development Research Council, a corporate real estate trade association based in Norcross, Ga., that includes many economic development groups, has tripled in size since 1990, to nearly 3,300 members. And while they all share the same goal, they are often hungry rivals. 
Many cities, for example, anticipate that various California companies, exasperated with rolling blackouts and uncertain power supplies, may leave the state -- or at least expand elsewhere. Just last week, Craig Barrett, chief executive of the Intel Corporation, the largest producer of computer chips and one of California's biggest employers, said that if the state did not have reliable power within five years, "it would not be on any possible expansion list" for new plants.
And while no big companies have left California since the power crisis, many smaller businesses are thinking about it. A poll conducted by the National Federation of Independent Business showed that 20 percent of employers with 10 or fewer workers might choose to move out.
ECONOMIC development groups are not waiting for such decisions. They are trying to make them happen, using the hot button of energy. Some groups in Michigan sent glow-in-the-dark mousepads to California companies. In North Carolina, the Greater Raleigh Chamber of Commerce sent letters containing nine-volt batteries.
Others consider such efforts counterproductive. Development groups in Arizona and New Mexico, which have long tried to lure California businesses, have avoided playing the energy card.
"There's a huge backlash when you do that," said Rick L. Weddle, president and chief executive of the Greater Phoenix Economic Council. "We've suspended marketing to C.E.O.'s during the power crisis. It's respect."
Whatever happens in California, economic development officials say the sheer growth in their numbers means that the challenges of attracting new business have intensified.
"Come grow with us," Mr. Saldana recalled a former client, Kern County, Calif., saying in a proposed marketing pitch. "I showed them two other ads saying the same thing."
Mr. Weddle added: "Every Johnny said, 'Let's build a billboard.' Can you imagine a C.E.O. saying, 'We'll go to Community X because of a football player greeting us?' " 
The competition has spawned a subindustry of consultants who specialize in coaching regions on selling themselves. Development Counsellors International, for example, tries to help economic development groups find the right campaign and media audience. "Because these decisions are so complex, there's been a growth of our field," said Ted Levine, chairman of the firm, which is based in New York. "It's more empirical, less intuitive. They buy a lot less whiskey" for prospects, he added.
That means choosing targets and campaigns carefully. "We often tend to flood prospects with tons of data, half of which is not useful," Mr. Saldana said. Celebrity endorsements and statistics about a county's colleges, tax rates and weather are all well and good, but a company that depends on fast, efficient truck deliveries, for example, may be more interested in the highway system.
The Hampton Roads area of Virginia, which recently persuaded a small paper manufacturer from New Jersey to relocate, uses its deep and developing ports as a lure. Tulare County banks on its 19 percent unemployment rate appealing more to blue-collar businesses than white-shoe consulting concerns. Tacoma, Wash., concentrates on companies in nearby Seattle whose workers are tired of the traffic jams but not the region.
Mr. Levine said that for years, local politicians might have wooed company chief executives over golf, discussing the area's sports teams or opera company. Now, officials are more likely to pull out maps and talk about their city's planned light-rail line to the airport or its deep-water channels for large ships.
"In the 90's, it was often about lifestyle," said April Mason, an executive at Development Counsellors International. "Now it's back to the basics of power and transportation."
Boeing's chairman, Philip M. Condit, hinted as much at a corporate meeting in April, telling shareholders that clogged freeways were part of the reason for moving from Seattle. "Commuting is really tough," he said.
Taking a cue, nearby Tacoma is pumping $26 million into its share of a light-rail system that will eventually connect it with Seattle. Tacoma also promotes its $100 million high-speed fiber optic network. Juli Wilkerson, director of its economic development department, said: "We were dependent on Boeing. We had to diversify so that this is not a one- or two-industry town."
Jacksonville, Fla., is looking for ways to lessen its dependence on a different kind of commercial draw -- its National Football League franchise, the Jaguars. Although the Jaguars have helped raise the national profile of Jacksonville, which had experienced a decline in its paper-milling industry, the city is now pinning hopes on its sheltered seaport, rail connections and highways.
SOMETIMES, a region's effort to sell itself can strengthen morale and self-image, regardless of the outcome.
Mr. Weddle recalled that in his work for Tulsa, Okla., in the early 1980's, when the city was competing to lure a new Saturn automotive plant, there was widespread doubt that the effort would succeed. "But we made a papier-mache car 10 feet long and shipped it off to the city so that the mayor could unveil it" in front of the Saturn executives, Mr. Weddle said. "I'd be remiss if I didn't note that it did not work." 
Still, he said, it made the mayor happy.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
In Mexico, Stocks Rise As Growth Slows

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
WHEN America sneezes, the saying goes, Europe catches a cold. Using this logic, Mexico should be stricken with the flu.
 Equity prices in the United States and Europe are hurting, reflecting weaker economic conditions. The pace of growth is also slowing in Mexico. But stock prices there are soaring. So far this year, its Bolsa index is up more than 17 percent in local currency terms, and more than 22 percent in dollars. By contrast, the Standard & Poor's 500 is down 4.5 percent. 
 Jose Luis Gomez-Pimienta, who has managed the Mexico Fund since its inception in 1981, talked last week from Mexico City about the country's market surge. Following are excerpts from the conversation. 

Q. Why is the Mexican market holding up in the face of what is happening in the States?

A. We are seeing that this is not the end of the world.
Unless something traumatic happens, the Mexican economy will grow this year at around 2 percent to 3 percent, down from 7 percent in 2000. But inflation and interest rates are coming down. At the start of the year, short-term interest rates were 19 percent. Now they are around 11 percent. 
In addition, the high expectations that surrounded the election of President Vicente Fox last July are still in place. There are high hopes his policies will generate a positive impact on Mexicans, both in terms of income growth and employment. 
Finally, even with the rise we have seen in stock prices, in general valuations in the Mexican stock market are quite modest.

Q. Which sectors and companies have been doing well?

A. The banking sector, an important part of the stock exchange, has been a very good performer.
After the nationalization and the crisis in 1995, the banks were in a terrible situation. But over the past few years, they are reflective of a change in attitude in the country, a recognition that Mexico needs to open parts of the economy to attract systems, people, technologies and whatnot to improve the quality of life. 
There have been a number of purchases by foreign banks of Mexican banks in recent times, but the Citigroup/Banamex transaction stands apart. After this transaction closes, the majority of the Mexican banking system will be owned by non-Mexican investors.

Q. How many independent Mexican banks are left?

A. Three important ones, BanCrecer, Banorte and Bital.

Q. What about other sectors?

A. Retailing stocks have been doing well. Wal-Mex, the Mexican subsidiary of Wal-Mart, has been a market leader. Modelo, which makes Corona beer, has done well. Corona has replaced Heineken as the No. 1 beer import in the United States. And Femsa, which makes Coca-Cola, has also been doing well.
Cemex, the third-largest producer of cement in the world, has been a good market performer. So has Telefonos de Mexico.

Q. In the past, when one large Latin American economy or market moved, the others moved in tandem. This year, big markets like Brazil and Argentina are down. But Mexico is doing just fine. Why?

A. Mexico is much more a participant in North America than Latin America. We have much more in common with the United States than with other Latin American countries.
This is increasingly the case since the implementation of the North American Free Trade Agreement.

Q. The Mexico Fund, which is a closed-end fund and trades on the New York Stock Exchange, is up 26 percent so far this year and 40 percent over the last 52 weeks. What are your three largest holdings? How many stocks are usually in the fund?

A. Wal-Mex, Banamex and Telmex are our three biggest holdings.
There are 179 companies that are listed on the Mexican stock exchange. In the last couple of years, there have only been two initial public offerings. Today, we have about 27 names in the Mexico fund portfolio. That number has been as high as 35 or 38.

Q. Which United States-based companies are benefiting from what is happening in Mexico?

A. Big auto companies, like General Motors and Ford, used to be listed on the Mexican stock exchange. That is no longer the case. But some of the most efficient plants they operate have been built in Mexico.

Q. A number of Mexican stocks trade as American depository receipts. Could you name a few of the strongest companies?

A. Companies like Telmex, Cemex and Televisa, the largest Spanish-speaking production company for radio and television, trade as A.D.R.'s. So does Tubos de Acero de Mexico, which manufactures steel pipes and tubing for the oil and natural-gas industries.

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Column 4; New Jersey Weekly Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 4029 words

HEADLINE: In Control, but Losing a Grip 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA FITZGERALD 

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
DICK CODEY had reason to feel victorious as the state's leading politicians gathered at the Doral Forrestal Hotel Conference Center in Plainsboro one night in April. Mr. Codey's political strategy -- after a year of planning and calculating -- was falling into place.
 Democrats were close to winning a redistricting battle with Republicans that could tip the scales in their favor for the next 10 years. The 11th and deciding member of the redistricting commission -- a professor of political science at Princeton University, Larry Bartels -- had just told Mr. Codey, the Senate Democratic leader, that he would largely support the Democratic plan to carve out new voting districts in the state. 
 For Republicans, who have controlled the Assembly, the Senate and the governor's mansion for the last decade, the loss over redistricting was one more in a series of embarrassing events in recent months. It capped the growing turmoil within the party in a year in which New Jersey residents witnessed Republican leaders' titles change nearly as frequently as the spring weather. 
"I have not seen a year like this," said Roger Bodman, a prominent Republican lobbyist.
First Christie Whitman resigned as governor to head the federal Environmental Protection Agency. Then the Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, who assumed the role of acting governor, announced he would run for a full term in November. But after several newspaper articles appeared that raised questions about Mr. DiFrancesco's business dealings and ethics, he hastily dropped out of the contest and was replaced by Bob Franks, the former Republican congressman from Berkeley Heights who narrowly failed to win a Senate seat last year.
But the party's disarray can be traced even further -- to 1999, when after the decks had been cleared for her candidacy, Mrs. Whitman abruptly announced she was no longer interested seeking the Senate seat being vacated by Frank Lautenberg, a Democrat. Republicans were left scrambling until they came up with Mr. Franks to run against Jon Corzine, a political neophyte with a $500 million bank balance.
Although Mr. Franks had the heart, he desperately lacked the finances to go up against Mr. Corzine, dubbed by some as "a human ATM machine." As the campaign wore on, it became painfully obvious why Mrs. Whitman chose not to go head to head with Mr. Corzine, a former head of the Goldman Sachs investment firm with pockets as deep as the Potomac.
Even the Republican presidential candidate, George W. Bush, largely wrote off the state as a political loss. His calculation proved correct, though Mr. Franks put up a better fight against Mr. Corzine than most politicians -- Republicans and Democrats alike -- had foreseen.
So when it came to the issue of redistricting, Republicans -- hoping to keep their majority status in Trenton and protect their incumbents -- just wanted to tinker with the existing map. But that was not appealing to Mr. Bartels. He saw the Democrats' plan, which diffused some of the minority votes in urban centers, as more equitable. Democrats had convinced Mr. Bartels that their party was getting more votes every year, but continually remained underrepresented in the Legislature. They were being robbed, the Democrats contended, because the current map, devised after the 1990 census, favored Republicans.
Democrats had good reason to believe Mr. Bartels might be sympathetic to their argument. Having read everything the Princeton professor had ever written, the Democrats were keenly aware that he supported a "doctrine of fairness," which basically stated that the party that won the most votes in the state should have the most seats in the Legislature. Republicans believed that Mr. Bartels should apply the fairness doctrine when looking at a statewide race, however, not individual legislative races where in some districts, like Essex, the Republicans never even fielded a candidate.
In the end, Mr. Bartels agreed with the Democrats.
Quite a feat, Mr. Codey understood, since Mr. Bartels was chosen for the commission by a Republican appointee, State Supreme Court Chief Justice Deborah Poritz.
The Democrats figured that going into the redistricting debate, required every 10 years when new census figures are released, they were better prepared, better focused and better financed. The Republicans seemed complacent, and acknowledge now that they did not fully understand the keenly organized forces Mr. Codey would unleash until it was too late.
While Democrats were winning the support of Mr. Bartels, Mr. Codey saw the Republican leaders -- many who had planned on retiring from public life -- as resigned and disengaged. At one point, according to a Republican observer, a leading player on the Republican team was using down time in the hotel room to play computer solitaire rather marshal the party's collective energy to plot a better strategy.
"Who was it that said, 'You don't know what you've got till it's gone?' " quipped one Republican who asked not to be identified.
The Democrats, out of power in Trenton for nearly a decade, were hungrier. They caught Republicans off stride and seized upon a moment when the Republicans were making the transition from the regime of Mrs. Whitman to a new set of leaders.
"Ten years of wandering in the wilderness and you do get hungry," said Tom Wilson, a spokesman for acting Gov. Donald DiFrancesco.
In retrospect, it seems that Mr. Corzine's candidacy was crucial to Democrats in two ways. First, it reversed a predominant financial equation that historically played against Democrats in New Jersey -- that they simply could not raise as much money as well-heeled Republicans.
Second, it infused the party with cash that pumped new energy into races at the local level. Democrats have been in operating in an energetic overdrive ever since, while Republicans are kicking themselves for not sending more money to Mr. Franks.
"There are some people who think that if Franks had some more money he might have been able to close the gap," said one Republican consultant, Steve Salmore.
Mr. Salmore added that even $1 million more would have allowed Mr. Franks another week's worth of television advertising, which in a late-deciding state like New Jersey, could have introduced the congressman to more voters and made a crucial difference in the outcome of the race.
It does not help that although Mrs. Whitman has left the state, she has not left the headlines -- mostly in an unflattering way. For one thing, Mrs. Whitman has been portrayed as an out-of-the-loop chief at the environmental agency. And at a time when the issue of racial profiling is a top priority in Trenton, the former governor finds herself being sued for frisking a black youth in 1996 while accompanying State Police on a drug sweep of Camden. As it turned out, the youth had no drugs in his possession, and a photograph of the incident captured Mrs, Whitman -- in white exercise suit and gloves -- smiling for the camera. 
Ask most legislators in Trenton, and they will say that Mrs. Whitman's departure has not left any discernible void among Republicans. According to polls, there was little disappointment when she left for Washington and almost a collective sigh of relief among the lawmakers. Many acknowledge it was Mrs. Whitman's style to dictate, rather than negotiate with legislators, which goes a long way toward explaining why the Republican message in the governor's race so far has been to run away from, rather than highlight, her eight-year tenure in New Jersey.
To some political observers like Jon Shure, president of New Jersey Policy Perspective and an aide to former Gov. Jim Florio, it is interesting that Republicans, who presided over one of the state's longest periods of economic prosperity, would be running away from their past and toward a self-described "reform" agenda.
"Franks and the Legislature are not running on Whitman's record, and nobody thinks they should," said Mr. Shure. "It was an eight-year administration, it was an unprecedented economic time, and yet you don't see Republicans going around saying, 'What Christie Whitman started, I'm going to finish.' "
Mr. Salmore put it this way: "To a large degree, it is a reflection on Whitman. She never drove home the fact that she should be taking credit for the good times. She never really talked about it in '97. Instead, she was on the defense the whole time talking about auto insurance and property taxes."
The reform agenda being driven by Mr. Franks has ruffled some party stalwarts. They don't believe that ideas like voter initiatives, term limits and an elected state auditor are the kinds of issues that drive voters to the polls. They say the Republican Party is not doing enough to remind voters of what life was like under Governor Florio and the Democratic Legislature, including Mr. McGreevey and Mr. Codey.
"Our environment is cleaner and we're putting more people in prison," said Assembly Speaker Jack Collins. "Republicans have been in power for nearly a decade. Look at our success coming in after the Democratic-controlled government in 1990 and 1991. New Jersey was at its lowest ebb. Now, the G.O.P. has got major futuristic plans, including things like school construction, open space and the transportation trust fund."
For his part, Mr. Collins believes that Republicans should just take the ads devised by Mr. Corzine in his primary race against Mr. Florio and run them for the party.
"We should be constantly be nailing them with Jon Corzine's commercials talking about what life was like under Florio and Doria and Codey and Lynch," he said, referring to the Democratic Legislative leaders early in Mr. Florio's first term. "And then we should be asking people, 'Do you want to go back to that?' "
To the contrary, Republicans seem bent on dismantling some of what Mrs. Whitman put in place, including her former right-hand man, Peter G. Verniero, whom she promoted from chief of staff to attorney general and then nominated for the State Supreme Court.
Calls for Mr. Verniero's resignation surfaced this spring when lawmakers determined he misled the Senate Judiciary Committee in 1999 while testifying about his knowledge of racial profiling by the State Police. Mr. Verniero, who not so secretly floated the notion of perhaps running for governor, was was now being villified by his own party.
During Mr. Verniero's confirmation hearings for the State Supreme Court, State Senator William Gormley, the Atlantic County Republican who is chairman of the Judiciary Committee, and Mr. DiFrancesco had twisted arms to get Mrs. Whitman the votes needed for Mr. Verniero's nomination. Now they were angered because they believed that Mr. Verniero had misled them. Indeed, Mr. Gormley -- who ran unsuccessfully against Mr. Franks in the Republican primary for the United States Senate race last year and is expected to make another run next year -- immediately called for Mr. Verniero's resignation and asked that the Assembly begin impeachment proceedings.
The result was a party at odds with itself. For one thing, Speaker Collins was miffed, and did not want the whole Verniero affair dumped in the Assembly's lap. He refused to take up the question of impeachment, figuring that it was the Senate's problem. Still, the rift between Senate and Assembly Republicans is seen as little more than a scuffle that will be forgotten long before the fall elections, when the Legislature and governor's seat are up for grabs. 
"The common interest is their political future," Mr. Bodman said.
But the November battle poses its own problems for Republicans. The Democratic nominee for governor, Mayor Jim McGreevey of Woodbridge, has no opposition in his primary, and is already shoring up support from such important flanks as labor unions, ethnic groups and minorities. And like Mr. Corzine, he is also assiduously working the all-important elderly vote. In the meantime, the Republicans face a nasty primary battle between Mr. Franks, who is not opposed to legalized abortion, and Mayor Bret Schundler of Jersey City, a conservative who is.
If Mr. Franks wins the primary, he will have to embrace the conservative flank delicately while not alienating the moderates. He will also have to come to terms with the pro-gun lobby, perhaps carving out a position where it will quietly support Mr. Franks or, at the very least, stay out of the race.
While many blame Mr. Schundler for the leaks to the media that resulted in the unflattering stories involving Mr. DiFrancesco's ethics, others speculate that the pro-gun lobby -- a group that Mrs. Whitman actively courted while running for governor in 1993 -- was partly to blame for Mr. DiFrancesco's demise.
"They never got over the fact that Don wouldn't post the assault weapons repeal under Florio," said Mr. DiFrancesco's spokesman, Mr. Wilson. 
Already, factions of the Republican Party are peeling off. State Senator Bill Schulter, whose district was carved up during the redistricting battle, announced he will run as an independent candidate for governor -- though no one gives the veteran senator from Pennington a prayer. Still his agenda of campaign finance reform will probably peel more votes from the Republican base rather than the Democratic side.
In addition, State Senator Jack Sinagra, who has represented parts of Middlesex County for 10 years, has announced he will not run again, leaving his newly redrawn district seat largely to a Democrat, Barbara Buono. Mr. Sinagra has criticized an important aspect of Mr. Franks's reform plan, Initiative and Referendum, a method to give citizens a chance at making their own laws.
Those looking for a silver lining can say that at least the Republicans are grabbing all the ink. But there are many within the party who do not accept the notion that any media exposure is a good thing. There are many who want a do-over of the past year. And there is little denying that there remains a lingering anger on the part of some Republicans who still can't believe their party blew the redistricting decision. 
The way the final negotiations played out are telling. Even after Mr. Bartels told Mr. Codey he was going to support the Democratic map, Mr. Codey was not taking anything for granted. All he had left to do was pluck the professor from the hotel suite where Republican Party leaders were seething over Mr. Bartels's decision. Earlier that week, Republicans tried bolstering their case by hiring Walter Fields, a public affairs consultant and former political director of the state N.A.A.C.P.
Mr. Fields, who opposed the idea of diminishing minority districts, was stunned that Mr. Bartels had abruptly decided the matter. Republicans were under the assumption that their maps -- constantly being revised -- were still in play. They wanted answers, and Mr. Bartels was not going anywhere until he did some explaining.
Mr. Codey was not about to let them whittle away at Mr. Bartels' resolve. He needed to get Mr. Bartels out of the room quickly. First, he convinced attorneys that Republicans were questioning Mr. Bartels in anticipation of a lawsuit. Anything he said could and would be used against him, Mr. Codey said as he tried to extricate Mr. Bartels from the room. By now, Mr. Codey's plan to portray the Republicans as unreasonable -- and his weeks of cajoling, humoring and just plain charming the buttoned-down Mr. Bartels -- was working. 
Democrats had so successfully wooed Mr. Bartels -- not only convincing him that they needed to take a hasty vote but also that there might be physical threats -- that when the vote to realign New Jersey's voting districts for the next 10 years was finally taken, there was no public notice and security guards flanked the room. It was a master stroke by Democrats, who successfully urged quick action lest the unruly Republicans stop the vote. 
The truth was that nothing was going to stop the Democrats at this point. They had worked too hard to turn back.
"It appears that the Democrats have been at this the last 18 months and have had substantial help from the Democratic National Committee," said Assemblyman Paul DiGaetano, a Republican from Passaic who hopes to become the next Assembly speaker.
Mr. DiGaetano had hoped going into the process that he would emerge with a more Republican district. His 1997 race was so competitive that Mr. DiGaetano was forced to raise and spend unprecedented amounts to retain his seat. He even recently moved from Passaic, which is heavily Democratic, to Nutley in the hope of having a safer political district. But because of the dilution of minority districts, Mr. DiGaetano now has a district more laden with Democrats.
Mr. Codey, on the other hand, emerged victorious. With a majority of his district minority, critics say Mr. Codey understood it was only a matter of time before a member of a minority group would challenge him for his seat, so in picking up more white suburban towns, he has enhanced his own re-election efforts.
Mr. Codey acknowledged that Democrats had been preparing for redistricting for more than a year, amassing money and working with the National Committee for an Effective Congress, which is financed by the Democatic National Committee, to come up with a system to "unpack" New Jersey's minority legislative districts that were put in place by Republican maps a decade ago.
Republicans had no way of knowing that unpacking minority-based districts would be allowed. After all, the districts were put in place after the 1990 census as a way of giving minorities greater representation in the Legislature. If a Republican were to suggest that the districts be unpacked, there was little doubt they could have been seen as politically incorrect or simply racist.
"If Republicans tried the same tactics they would have failed," Mr. Fields said. "No one would buy the fact that Republicans were trying to protect minority interests."
But Democrats were able to convince minority lawmakers that the changes were a good thing. The mantra was repeated over and over, "It's better to be a minority in a majority than a minority in a minority."
"It was a very ingenious suburban strategy," said Mr. Fields. "They basically said that we will break up this urban base and connect with some of those white suburban voters that lean Democrat. They're going back and trying to get the Reagan Democrats -- a blue-collar working-class Democrat. It's very ingenious and at some levels, a very devious strategy."
For his part, Mr. Fields said the strategy offended him because the minorities made all the concessions.
"Rule No. 1 in politics is that you never give up your base," Mr. Fields said. "Now we're being told less is more."
The other thing Democrats had working in their favor was the sheer enthusiasm they brought to the table. While Republicans viewed Mr. Bartels as a statistician to be put up with, Democrats wanted him to be their good friend. Mr. Codey went so far as to order sweatshirts and hats from the colleges where Mr. Bartels had studied to be stockpiled in his car as a potential weapon of flattery and humor. He also read everything Mr. Bartels had ever written and would often cite his own research during his arguments.
While Republicans attended the meetings and scurried around to seek last- minute help from their Washington allies, the Democrats were focused on execution of their plan. One unstated rule was never to let Mr. Bartels hit a restroom alone. They would talk about sports, joke about families, make small talk, all while subtly portraying the image of the Republicans as out of touch.
"There's no question Democrats did a better job of manipulating the 11th member," Mr. Fields said. 
Some Democrat staff members jokingly referred to the Republican commission staff members -- all of whom were mostly white men -- as "the Blue Ridge Mountain boys" within earshot of Mr. Bartels or his assistant.
By contrast, the Republican contingent on the redistricting commission was mostly old-guard Republicans, and what might be perceived as a fatal error, few of whom actually had a political stake in the redistricting map. 
There was the chairman of the Republican Party, Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian -- an appointee of Mrs. Whitman -- who was told midway through the negotiations by Mr. DiFrancesco that he would be replaced in June.
One Republican said in disbelief, "I still don't understand the timing of that announcement." 
Once a powerful Assembly Speaker, Mr. Haytaian had been out of elective politics since 1994 when he lost a United States Senate battle to Mr. Lautenberg.
Next, there was Assembly Speaker Jack Collins, who last fall briefly floated the idea of running for governor. Mr. Collins, an intense man who lives on a small farm in South Jersey, soon threw in the towel when he saw how much time and energy the race entailed. Also on the commission was Mr. DiFrancesco, the Senate president. When he was named acting governor, Mr. DiFrancesco's seat on the commission was given to Senate Majority Leader John Bennett.
Republicans have used the redistricting loss to their best advantage, at least in the short term. Contesting the redistricting maps in court gave Republicans more time to reconsider their top choice for the governor's race. The Republican-controlled Legislature agreed to extend the primary election until the end of June, which gave Mr. DiFrancesco enough time to bow out.
In the long term, the Republican Party needs to figure out how to deal with districts that are simply more Democratic-leaning.
The strategy that Mr. Fields supports is the "High Noon" version, in which the Republican Party walks into the main streets of Newark and other urban areas, and effectively says: "The fight starts here. We're not taking any vote for granted."
"They've got to go in now and declare war," said Mr. Fields, who is being retained as a Republican consultant. "You have to meet them on the street and declare a duel, stating you will not cede any more votes. As a black, it is a very paternalistic notion that the only place I can go is the Democratic party."
Mr. Fields believes it is time for Republicans to go after the black vote because he believes the Democrats in New Jersey have done relatively little for the minority community.
"The Republican Party must make a commitment to aggressively court the black vote," Fields said. "It's been manipulated for a long time. The Republicans should not be afraid to walk into black communities and put money behind candidates in competitive districts. They also have to be pursuing an agenda that is not antagonistic in any way toward black interests."
Others say that is a costly course to pursue. 
"If you decide to slug it out in the belly of the beast you'd better have a lot of resources," said one Republican strategist. 
Another strategy is to cede a few more districts to the Democrats and pump even more money into the remaining competitive districts, still allowing Republicans to keep their majority.
The Democratic plan is not foolproof. It is built on fragile alliances with the minority community that could turn sour if blacks and Hispanics start losing their representation to white Democrats. If there remains no net gain for minorities, Republicans should be poised to broker new alliances with minority communities.
Republicans are already looking to make inroads. For instance, Franks has named Secretary of State DeForest (Buster) Soaries as his co-campaign manager.
Republicans say this year has taught them a lot of lessons. They vow not to be unprepared again in the redistricting debates. Their biggest challenge is to reinvigorate the fight in those who are used to being in power and perhaps take it for granted.
"The redistricting decision got a lot of people mad," Mr. Wilson said. "And that's good."
Mr. Wilson should know a great deal about motivation. He managed Mrs. Whitman's 1997 campaign, in which the governor narrowly beat Mr. McGreevey. Many believed the campaign was flawed because of a certain malaise Mrs. Whitman herself brought to the race.
Like a motivational coach, Mr. Wilson believes anger may be just what is now needed for the Republicans. "It makes you work," he said, "a lot harder."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
At the Fed, 2 Opinions Of the Same Storm

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
ONE of the more interesting debates within the Federal Reserve has been the one between Alan Greenspan, the chairman, and Laurence H. Meyer, a Fed governor with a reputation as a doctrinaire inflation fighter. In recent speeches, on the same day but thousands of miles apart, they went at it again, in their indirect way. 
 In doing so, they provided a glimpse into issues with which the Fed is wrestling as it tries to determine what the 2001 slowdown says about forces that reshaped the economy for the better in the late 1990's. And they illustrated that for all the deference shown to Mr. Greenspan on monetary policy, his voice is not the only one at the table. 
 Mr. Meyer is known for his belief in rule-based forecasting that assumes predictable interplay among economic growth, unemployment and inflation. Mr. Greenspan has a more pragmatic, intuitive approach. 
Mr. Meyer has been skeptical of the notion that the economy's capacity for noninflationary growth has been permanently improved by productivity increases. Mr. Greenspan has been an advocate of the idea that the economy is just beginning to reap the benefits of technological advances.
Mr. Meyer's belief that strong growth and unemployment in the 4 percent range would inevitably generate inflation was tested by a long period in which that combination did not put much upward pressure on prices. Mr. Greenspan's optimism about technology and productivity is being tested even now, as the late 1990's boom has given way to a slowdown. 
Neither man seems to have changed his view substantially. In an address to a financial seminar on May 24 in Scotland, Mr. Meyer acknowledged that productivity growth accelerated sharply starting around 1995, from an annual rate of 1.5 percent the preceding two decades to 2.5 percent to 3 percent. 
At first, enhanced productivity growth stimulated demand by spurring both consumption and investment booms, Mr. Meyer said. Technological innovation promised high returns to businesses willing to invest in equipment. Surging stock prices -- themselves in part a response to higher profit expectations -- left consumers feeling wealthier and more willing to spend. 
At the same time, Mr. Meyer said, the surge in productivity growth had a disinflationary effect. Because workers did not immediately demand higher wages as their payoff for improved productivity, "unit labor costs fell, profits rose, and then competitive pressures passed along the lower costs to lower prices," Mr. Meyer said.
The effect was to reduce the level of unemployment at which strong growth would ignite inflation, he said. But the benefits were "temporary bonuses," he said.
"Once productivity growth stabilizes, even at a much-elevated level, these forces dissipate, growth slows, and pressures on prices might intensify," Mr. Meyer said.
There is reason for optimism, he said. Still, he added, "some will have confidence in the productivity story only when it is tested by a cyclical decline," suggesting that he remained unsure whether the productivity gains would fully survive a downturn.
Mr. Greenspan, by contrast, appears confident that technology-driven improvements in productivity will yield long-term benefits. And while Mr. Meyer remains nervous about inflation, Mr. Greenspan made clear that it is hardly on his radar screen.
There is "ample evidence that we are experiencing only a pause in the investment in a broad set of innovations that has elevated the underlying growth rate in productivity," Mr. Greenspan said in a speech to the Economic Club of New York, a few hours after Mr. Meyer's remarks across the Atlantic. Mr. Greenspan emphasized that the economy faced many risks, including a drop in demand for capital equipment. But he said inflation was not one of those risks.
While some inflation measures have been creeping up, the broadest ones have been relatively stable, and "the lack of pricing power reported overwhelmingly by business people underscores an absence of inflationary zest," he said.
FOR all their differences, Mr. Greenspan and Mr. Meyer often agree on monetary policy. And both have signaled that they might support one or two more rate cuts.
They agreed on one other thing: the current slowdown is not the Fed's fault. The central bank, Mr. Meyer said, got it just right over the last two years, until the economy was blindsided by "a coincidence of adverse shocks," like rising energy prices and jittery financial markets.
Not raising rates in 1999 and the first half of 2000 "would have added fuel to an economy that was already threatening to overheat," Mr. Greenspan said, and cutting rates too soon "would have risked cutting short the adjustments needed to sustain long-term economic growth."
