HEADLINE: Social Security Options 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Hal R. Varian (Economic Scene, May 31) reports that the stock market has returned 7 percent over 100 years. However, workers under Social Security receive a yield now that will greatly exceed 7 percent for many, if all the program's benefits are factored in -- among them the money saved if one doesn't have to contribute to parents who are not indigent but would be in the absence of their Social Security benefits. 
 A negative effect of privatization is that the large sums that would come on the market would artificially inflate stock prices, which would become additionally divorced from reality. The current price-earnings ratio of 25 is likely the result of the substantial sums regularly added by 401(k)'s and I.R.A.'s. Social Security privatization would further inflate and destabilize the market.

DAVID LANGER
New York, May 31, 2001

The writer is chairman, Employee Benefits Committee, Actuarial Society of Greater New York.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES; 
Price of Oil Rises as Iraq Halts Exports

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Crude oil prices rose yesterday after Iraq halted exports in a dispute with the United Nations, which is considering a change to sanctions that would make it harder for the nation to import weapons components.
 Iraq, which pumps almost 4 percent of the world's oil, stopped moving supplies through a pipeline to the Turkish port of Ceyhan and to its own port of Mina al Bakr. Iraq said shipments would not start again until the United Nations backs away from its plan. Some of Iraq's OPEC colleagues said they would make up for any shortage. 
 "This is going to be a short-term fight between Iraq and the U.N.," said Edward A. Silliere, vice president for risk management at Energy Merchant L.L.C. in New York. "The Saudis and the other OPEC members can make up for any missing barrels, although there would be a short delay."
In New York, crude oil for July delivery rose 20 cents, or 0.7 percent, to $28.13 a barrel after rising as much as 2.9 percent during the session. Prices are down about 7 percent from this time last year. In London, Brent crude oil for July settlement rose 19 cents, to $29.26 a barrel.
The United Nations controls Iraq's oil income under sanctions imposed after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990. The Security Council voted on Thursday to extend the restrictions in their current form for a month while considering a British proposal to modify the sanctions to loosen controls on most imports while tightening them on suspected military equipment.
Iraq opposed the changes and favored a six-month renewal of the previous agreement. "The sanctions plan has obviously scared the Iraqis," said Bill O'Grady, director of fundamental futures research at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis.
Iraq's export halt comes as members of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries gather in Vienna for a meeting today on production levels. OPEC ministers have already signaled their intention to leave their self-imposed quotas unchanged.

HEADLINE: The Future of an Epidemic 

BYLINE:  By Michael S. Gottlieb; Michael S. Gottlieb, an immunologist, identified AIDS as a new disease in 1981 and reported it to the Centers for Disease Control.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
I remember standing on a beach on an overcast day in 1985, feeling as if I knew a tragic accident was about to happen and no one could hear my warnings. Now the world knows about what I feared then -- the enormous size of the AIDS epidemic -- but to look ahead from here is to feel again that not enough people appreciate how a failure to act effectively would undermine the quality of life for everyone on the planet.
 In the 20 years ahead, AIDS can be brought under much better control in the United States -- if we don't let down our guard -- but it will be devastating in some other parts of the world. 
 The incidence of new cases of H.I.V. could decline in this country from an estimated 40,000 a year to a few thousand by 2010. Future generations of antiviral drugs will reduce the virus further in body fluids. For those already infected, new drugs can be expected to push H.I.V. into a deep state of dormancy, though not to eradicate the virus. But to keep AIDS from continuing to spread, we need more culturally focused prevention programs, H.I.V. education in the schools must be routine, and we must treat drug addiction as a medical problem, so that drug users stop transmitting the disease through needle sharing and unprotected sex. 
Drug companies and government researchers are working now to develop vaccines. Promising candidates should be in use within 15 years but will require continuous modification to keep pace with the virus's prodigious mutation rate and recombination of strains. In the United States, the vaccines will probably be made available on a voluntary basis, especially to gay men, intravenous drug users, heterosexual partners of H.I.V.-positive men and women, the incarcerated, and people traveling to regions with high infection rates.
But in Africa, the Far East and the former Soviet Union, H.I.V. is now spreading virtually unchecked, and there is every indication that it will continue to do so for the next several years. According to United Nations statistics, the number of people who will have been infected worldwide by 2021 will easily top 150 million.
The United States Census Bureau has projected that in several African nations, deaths from AIDS will peak between 2010 and 2020. In Nigeria, 1.25 million are likely to die in 2020, at the peak of its epidemic, and by 2050 its population will be 73 million below pre-AIDS forecasts. In Southeast Asia, deaths in several countries are predicted to peak between 2015 and 2025. The Russian Ministry of Health recently predicted that 12 percent of the population of Russia will be infected by 2015.
By 2020, H.I.V. will have caused more deaths than any disease outbreak in history. The constant experience of suffering and death, and the privation that results as economies fail in AIDS-ravaged countries, especially in Africa, could lead to the downfall of governments and the breakdown of law and order.
The United States, the European Union, Japan, the United Nations, the World Health Organization and prominent American foundations have an opportunity to mount a coordinated effort at damage control. It is estimated that $10 billion annually is needed to develop health systems to deliver basic medical care and antiviral medications in Africa. In my opinion the effective deployment of these medications could reduce the mortality rate by at least 50 percent from what current estimates would predict, and completely eliminate transmission of H.I.V. from mothers to their babies.
Action by relief agencies will be needed to tend the dying and to assist the millions of healthy children orphaned by AIDS. The United States could foster stability by forgiving debt owed by African nations hard hit by AIDS. By the year 2010, I believe, several of the most promising H.I.V. vaccine candidates could be under study in controlled clinical trials in countries with the highest rates of new H.I.V. infection. And by 2021, one or more of these could have reached a level of effectiveness and safety that would allow its administration to children and adults in regions where the infection is most common.
We in the developed countries are finally beginning to grasp the size, scope, complexity and seriousness of the global H.I.V. pandemic. It took AIDS to teach us what Nobel laureate Joshua Lederberg meant when he said: "The world is just one village. Our tolerance of disease in any place is at our own peril."
If we provide the money for effective action now, when the costs are still relatively low, we can minimize the setbacks that AIDS will cause at home and abroad. If we stand by or make token gestures, we will allow AIDS to spiral even further out of control.

HEADLINE: Pataki Is Said to Weigh Emergency Budget 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 4 

 BODY:
With budget negotiations stalled, the State Senate majority leader said today that Gov. George E. Pataki had raised the possibility of sending a three-month emergency spending measure to the Legislature when the current one expires next week. 
 If the Legislature passed such a measure, the impasse over the budget would probably continue until at least mid-September, breaking previous records for late budgets. The latest date for the adoption of a state spending plan came on Aug. 4 in both 1997 and 1999. 
 The governor's office said Mr. Pataki, a Republican who is expected to seek re-election next year, had not yet decided whether to propose a three-month emergency bill.
"At this point, it's far too soon to speculate on the potential duration of interim budget bills," Mr. Pataki's spokesman, Joseph Conway, said. 
But aides to the majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, said the governor's staff had floated the proposal privately. In an interview on WROW radio in Albany this morning, Senator Bruno said Mr. Pataki was considering the option "to try to bring some semblance of order to the process."
The Legislature passed the April 1 budget deadline without adopting a spending plan for the 17th year in a row. Talks have become bogged down in differences about the economy's health and revenues. 
Last week, the governor said the state might fail to pass a budget at all this year. The Democrats have accused him of trying to save money for the election year by maintaining current spending levels. The governor has accused the Democrats of proposing unrealistic spending increases in the teeth of a national economic downturn.

HEADLINE: Putting a Tax Rebate to Use; 
Many Are Expected To Save the Money Or Pay Their Debts

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
The $45 billion or so in tax rebates and cuts that are scheduled to take effect this summer should give the economy a modest but important lift at a critical time, economists say, just as jobs remain hard to find and energy bills are draining money out of pocketbooks.
 Combined with five interest rate reductions by the Federal Reserve since January, the tax cuts should help the longest economic expansion on record continue through its 11th year, most economists argue. 
 "It's going to provide a little bit of a kick-start to the economy," said Michael Gregory, a senior economist at Lehman Brothers, "and it lessens the chances of a recession."
But economic growth is still expected to remain sluggish this year, according to interviews with economists, analysts and consumers in the 10 days since Congress passed the 10-year, trillion-dollar-plus tax cut advocated by President Bush. In part, that is because most of the immediate cut comes in the form of rebate checks that many people will consider little more than a temporary rise in income. As a result, they will save much of the money or pay debts, rather than spending it in ways that help spur the economy. 
"I'll take whatever they want to give me; really any amount would be fine," said Arlene Annerino, a 50-year-old secretary who lives on the South Side of Chicago and works downtown at a law firm. "But it's not going to make that much of a dent in anything."
Ms. Annerino said she planned to pay bills with some of the money and put the rest in her checking account.
If taxpayers follow historical patterns, they will quickly spend only about a third of the $38 billion rebate, but will spend almost all of the additional $7 billion or so they will receive this year after withholding tables are adjusted on July 1 to reflect slightly lower tax rates. The cumulative effect of the new purchases could cause the economy to grow by at least an additional half a percentage point in the third and fourth quarters, at an annualized rate, economists said.
In the first three months of 2001, the economy, adjusted for inflation, grew 1.3 percent at an annual rate, up slightly from 1 percent in the last three months of 2000, according to the Department of Commerce. The six months represent the weakest economic performance since the first half of 1995.
Some analysts think the economy could shrink in the second quarter. Business spending on equipment and technology remains weak, and employers cut an additional 19,000 jobs last month. Surveys in recent weeks have found that many people expect the economy to strengthen in the months ahead, but that they have yet to see evidence of improvement.
"Consumers are now at the crossroad," said Richard T. Curtin, the director of consumer surveys at the University of Michigan. "Either we're going to have a slow recovery, or we're poised for another decline, depending on what consumers decide will happen with the economy."
The rebate checks, which the Treasury Department plans to mail in July, August and September, are the centerpiece of the most aggressive government effort to hasten an economic recovery in two decades. Individuals who had taxable income of more than $6,000 last year will receive $300, and married couples with more than $12,000 in taxable income will get $600. Single parents who earned more than $6,000 will receive $500. Those with taxable incomes below the threshold will receive rebates equal to 5 percent of their reported income for last year.
Starting in July, taxpayers will also receive the equivalent of a small raise as the government begins withholding less money from paychecks. In general, the more one earns, the bigger the raise.
But with unemployment expected to rise and a gallon of a gasoline costing $2 in some cities, many Americans say the money will not change the way they live.
"That money isn't going to change my life one way or the other," said Richard Fulkerson, a banking regulator who lives in Littleton, Colo. "I'm not going to do anything crazy. I might just stick it in savings."
Steve Bottomley, a stay-at-home father and part-time boat mechanic in Van Nuys, Calif., echoed that thought. "It's just going to meld into the rest of my recurring expenses."
"It isn't enough to make you feel like you can do something," Mr. Bottomley said. Other people say they are likely to split the check.
Steven Rikert, a 36-year-old father of two who lives with his wife in White River Junction, Vt., said, "I'd save at least half of it for a house, we'd like to get a house someday, and use the other half for just whatever I think I might need."
In two surveys earlier this year, more than 60 percent of Americans said they would save most of a rebate or pay debts with it. Fewer than a third said they expected to spend most of the money on new goods.
The last time the government mailed rebates -- in 1975, as part of a similar effort to spur growth -- taxpayers quickly spent 25 percent to 40 percent of the money and saved the rest, for a while, according to several studies. At the time, households received $100 to $200, roughly similar to the current rebates in inflation-adjusted terms.
By contrast, people usually spend nearly all of an increase in their take-home pay. In the early 1980's, after President Ronald Reagan and Congress cut tax rates, consumers spent about 90 percent of their additional take-home pay on average, according to a recent study by Nicholas S. Souleles, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania. "People respond differently to different kinds of tax cuts," he said. 
Paul Nagy, a college student in Denver who also works as the promotions coordinator for a radio station, is an example. With the $300, he said, "I'll finally be able to pay off some of my school loans." But Mr. Nagy, who is 25, said the possibility of receiving a little more money in each paycheck had not even occurred to him.
Jill Blake, 53, works two jobs, one as a ticket agent at a bus terminal and one as a cook at the Black Angus Cafe in Quechee, Vt., where she lives. Out of her last paycheck of $400, $70 went toward taxes -- "a big bite" she said she cannot afford. She will use the rebate, she said, to pay some bills but wants to set aside the additional money in her take-home pay for a trip to Cancun, Mexico.
Shea Martin, a 26-year-old in Southern California who works as an actor and at an Armani store in Beverly Hills, said he did not expect to save any of the money. 
"As everyone out here is an aspiring actor, I'll put it into head shots or acting classes," Mr. Martin said, adding that he thought higher gas prices would eat up the rebate.
In fact, some economists think that despite what happened after previous tax cuts and what people have told survey takers, most Americans will spend most of the rebate. Unlike the rest of the tax cut, most of the money from the rebates will go to households with less than $50,000 in annual income, and many of these families live paycheck to paycheck.
"Such a large fraction of this is going to people with virtually no savings," said Jonathan Skinner, an economist at Dartmouth College, "that it seems reasonable that they will go out and spend it."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
PAYLESS CASHWAYS FILES FOR CHAPTER 11 PROTECTION

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 Payless Cashways said yesterday that it had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. 
The filing in United States Bankruptcy Court in Kansas City, Mo., came after the company's decision last month to lay off hundreds of employees and close 19 stores. Payless, based in Lee's Summit, Mo., sells building materials and finishing products. Its business is aimed at remodelers, contractors, property management and industrial companies, and do-it-yourself customers. Millard Barron, the president and chief executive, blamed poor economic conditions and an unusually harsh winter that led to lower-than-expected sales.

HEADLINE: Rule Limits Overcharging Of Roommates 

BYLINE:  By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
In a case threatening upheaval for many rent-stabilized tenants in New York City, a judge has ruled that landlords may evict those who charge roommates more than a fair share of the rent.
 The ruling involved a disabled 70-year-old retiree who took in a roommate at her Park Avenue apartment in March, charging him $2,200 when her monthly rent was $1,847.77. The landlord moved to evict them both, citing a new state regulation on roommate overcharges. 
 The tenant, Jean E. Mazzolo, contended that the law does not provide for such evictions. But last Wednesday, Judge Larry S. Schachner of Housing Court ruled that the owner is entitled to use that provision in its suit to remove the tenant and her roommate, Brian Moro. There still has to be a trial on the specifics of that case. 
The ruling strikes at an increasingly common practice, especially with the city's worsening housing shortage, that has even spawned a niche of agencies devoted to matching prospective roommates for a fee.
The trend was spurred by a 1983 state law guaranteeing every tenant's right to have a roommate, a law aimed partly at protecting unmarried couples from eviction. By 1999, a Census Bureau study showed that 158,238 New Yorkers were living in rent-stabilized apartments with nonrelatives.
The rule upheld by the judge prevents rent-stabilized tenants from making roommates pay more than their fair share, generally interpreted as half the rent.
"What we have here is a potential for mass evictions," said Mrs. Mazzola's lawyer, Darnay Hoffman, who is appealing the decision. "It creates a lot of mischief. It gives landlords the right to act as gatekeepers. This is going to have a significant impact on students, poor people, people in the arts, the elderly, gay couples or other roommates who don't get married, for whatever reason."
The real estate industry welcomed the decision. William J. Neville, a lawyer for RAM I, the company that owns Mrs. Mazzola's apartment, at 1000 Park Avenue near 85th Street, said: "The intent of the law is to prevent tenants from illegally profiteering on the owner's property. Profiteering is not the purpose of the roommate law or the rent laws." He predicted success in winning the ultimate evictions.
Jack Freund, the executive vice president of the city's leading landlord group, the Rent Stabilization Association, said, "We do hear of quite a number of situations" in which roommates are overcharged.
The rule on roommates is part of a disputed recodification of rent regulations by the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. Tenant representatives are challenging the revisions in State Supreme Court, arguing that the state violated procedures and overstepped its authority in making changes like the roommate rules. The state defends its actions.
"We're not talking about people profiteering, we're talking about people surviving," said Judith A. Goldiner, a lawyer for the Legal Aid Society. "Rents being what they are, almost everybody has a roommate."
The rule makes no allowance for roommates who pay more because they use more than half the space in the apartment, or for tenants who may pay less than half the rent but pay the cost of utilities and other joint expenses, Ms. Goldiner said. Evictions could also result when the person named in the lease is laid off, disabled or has returned to school, and the roommate -- who could be a domestic partner -- picks up the rent, tenants' lawyers said. 
Word of the rules is starting to spread. "We had a building where the landlord sent every tenant a letter demanding to know if they had a roommate and how much they were charging," said Michael McKee, associate director of the New York State Tenants and Neighbors Coalition. "It was pretty threatening."
Landlords should not pry into the personal lives and private arrangements of tenants, he said, but they are tempted to do so to empty apartments and raise rents for new tenants.
Mrs. Mazzola, a retired antiques dealer, has lived in her spacious two-bedroom apartment for 32 years, and says her annual income is $12,000. She suffers from emphysema and heart ailments, uses a wheelchair and relies on an oxygen tank. For several years, she has taken in a roommate to help pay her bills. "If anybody needs it, I do," she said.
She said her landlord wanted her out so it could sell the apartment as a co-op, which she estimated would sell for $1.5 million. She said she was never notified of the new state rule, and after her landlord challenged her and she called the state agency on three occasions, she was told that overcharge violations were not subject to eviction. 
Stanley Leibowitz, vice president of Classic Realty, which manages Mrs. Mazzola's apartment for the owner, said the case was about principle, not money. She should not be making a profit, he said. "I think it's wrong for people to do that."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jean E. Mazzolo, in the bedroom of her Park Avenue apartment, says she needs the rent she gets from a roommate to help meet her expenses. (Vincent Laforet/The New York Times)(pg. B8)

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN; 
Riposte From Franks in Governor's Race

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
 A 60-second radio commercial, "Grace," was released yesterday by former Representative Bob Franks in his contest with Bret D. Schundler, the mayor of Jersey City, for the Republican nomination for governor of New Jersey. It is running on conservative talk programs in New Jersey, New York and Philadelphia.

PRODUCER -- Smith & Harroff.

ON THE AIR -- An announcer's voice mocks Mr. Schundler's most recent radio commercial, a testimonial by Grace Bowen, a Jersey City resident.

THE SCRIPT -- Announcer: "Jersey City Mayor Bret Schundler is trying to convince Republicans that he never raised property taxes. But his outrageous attempts to cover up his tax-hiking record are almost comical. Listen to his latest."

Grace Bowen -- "I'm Grace Bowen. I've lived in Jersey City 77 years. Bret didn't raise taxes."

Announcer -- "Come on, Bret. The New York Times says Grace is actually a Hudson County Democrat committeewoman, who lives in a taxpayer-subsidized rental. That's right. She doesn't even pay property taxes. The truth is Mayor Schundler has taken over $800 million in aid from Trenton and still raised property taxes in Jersey City. Not only that, city debt's up, government spending's up, water fees are up, even sewer fees are up. In fact, the Schundler tax hike record is so bad, the only person he could find to defend it is a Hudson County Democrat who doesn't even pay property taxes. On June 26 in the Republican primary, vote no on Bret Schundler. We just can't afford him as governor."

ACCURACY -- Jersey City, like most other municipalities, has received annual financial aid from the state government; it is the second-largest city in New Jersey and thus receives more than most. The Franks campaign says the city has taken an additional $58.5 million under the state's "distressed cities" program; Mr. Schundler says he did so only after being threatened with a cutoff of other state aid. The municipal property tax rate has risen from 1992 to 2000, but at a rate slower than the inflation rate. Debt has grown by 14 percent during that time, also below inflation levels, Mr. Schundler says. But he says water and sewer rates have actually declined slightly. The Franks campaign relied on a comparison to 1994 and used water and sewer utility revenues, not rates.

SCORECARD -- Mr. Franks aims here at an easy target and hits his mark, but at some risk of reprisal. The battle between the two candidates has been over which of them is the more credible tax-cutter, and Mr. Franks once again does an effective job of depicting Mr. Schundler as a tax-and-spender. More important, dyed-in-the-wool Republican primary voters may well take exception to Mr. Schundler's use of a politically active Democrat to defend him and attack a fellow Republican. But Mr. Schundler has been arguing all along that he, more than any other Republican, is capable of attracting Democratic votes in the fall campaign. A Schundler campaign official said last night that he was considering counterattacking Mr. Franks for picking on a "defenseless old lady." DAVID M. HALBFINGER

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
United Airlines Buys Online Marketer

BYLINE:  By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Jumping into one of the most troubled sectors of the Internet economy, the parent of United Airlines said yesterday that it would buy MyPoints.com, an online marketing company, in a deal valued at $105 million.
 MyPoints runs a variety of programs that gather information about consumers, both online and off, and uses it to sell products and services to them. But it has been shrinking rapidly as the Internet advertising market has hit hard times. Its revenue in the first quarter was $10 million, down from a peak of $18.7 million in the second quarter of 2000. 
 The UAL Corporation, the parent of United, agreed to pay $2.60 for each share of Mypoints. That is well below the $88.50 it sold for in December 1999, but quite a lot better than the 50 cents that MyPoints shares hit in March. It soared 60 percent yesterday, rising 96 cents, to $2.56 a share. 
The purchase price is not much more than the $98 million in cash that MyPoints had as of March 31. 
While many big companies, like Staples, are closing separate Internet units and reabsorbing their activities, United is intent on building up its United NewVentures subsidiary, which operates the web site United.com and portions of its frequent-flier program as well as holding United's investments in several Internet travel companies. These include Priceline.com, Hotwire and Orbitz, an online travel agent it helped start that began operating today.
Scott Garner, a managing director at United, said United still believed that separating its Internet activities could help improve shareholder value, perhaps by allowing for a public offering of shares of the unit when the market for such divisions improved.
"We have identified areas of the company where we have assets that may not be fully valued by the market," he said.
But in the current environment, he said, United concluded that a simple holding company of investments would not be enough to attract investor interest.
"Our goal is to create a complete business that weaves together our other activities and creates additional value beyond that," he said. "MyPoints will be the glue that brings all those activities together."
John H. Fullmer, the chief executive of MyPoints, said that the company had not sought to sell itself but was looking at combining with other online marketing companies when an unsolicited bid came from United.
United said it expected that MyPoints, which is based in San Francisco, would continue to operate under its current name and management.
United will not merge its Mileage Plus frequent-flier program with the MyPoints' flagship rewards program, which gives users points when they read advertising e-mail or make purchases at certain merchants. The typical MyPoints user does not fly often enough to make airline miles valuable to them. But United will offer travel discounts as rewards for MyPoints points.
The deal would also give United a broader array of technology and potential marketing deals that it could link to its frequent-flier program. American Airlines and AOL Time Warner have created a program that gives American AAdvantage miles for online purchases, using technology from Netcentives, an ailing competitor to MyPoints.

HEADLINE: Building Boom and Less Demand Make Hotel Rooms Easier to Get 

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
It was just a few months ago, it seemed, that it was almost impossible to book a hotel room in Manhattan. But those days are over -- at least for now -- because of a slackening economy and a record construction boom.
 The hotel room occupancy rate for the first quarter of the year declined by 7.6 percent since the same period last year, the biggest drop since 1994, according to a report by PricewaterhouseCoopers to be released today. 
 The occupancy rate during the first quarter of 2001 was 72.3 percent, down from 78.2 percent in the same period last year, a reduction of 5.9 percentage points. That is the lowest since the first quarter of 1996, when the rate was 69.2 percent, according to the report. 
Some of the decrease can be explained by the economy and the decline in business travel, the report said. But the softening demand was also accompanied by a record boom in hotel construction. About 3,500 rooms were added last year.
"Last year at this time," said Sean Hennessey, the director of the PricewaterhouseCoopers's hospitality consulting practice, "most of the first-class hotels were turning away 40 to 50 guests a night from Monday through Thursday.
"If that level of demand had continued at that pace, these 3,500 rooms would have been absorbed without a drop in occupancy rates," Mr. Hennessey said.
The survey was based on room occupancy figures from about 70 percent of the city's hotels. Those figures showed that demand for rooms declined from about 4 million during the first quarter last year to about 3.9 million from January through March this year.
Without the new rooms, the occupancy rate would have dropped by only 2.1 percent, said Tim A. Simpson, a senior associate at PricewaterhouseCoopers.
Despite the negative trend, people in the hotel and tourism industry said there was no cause for hand-wringing.
"I don't think we are in any trouble," said John A. Fox, a senior vice president of PKF, a company that tracks the hotel business. "A lot of profits are continuing to be made, and we will continue to be healthy for the foreseeable future."
Diane Briskin, the corporate director of sales and marketing for W Hotels, which operates four boutique-style hotels in Manhattan, said that many companies were no longer spending freely to send executives to conventions and conferences.
"We get called all the time by companies doing belt-tightening," she said. "They are looking at renegotiating their rates."
At the Mark Hotel, a luxury hotel on the Upper East Side, business for the first quarter was down 8 to 10 percent, said Bill Dunphy, the marketing director.
He said that some customers were being lost to newer hotels in TriBeCa and other downtown neighborhoods. "Those are the new hot neighborhoods," he said. "They are a natural draw, particularly for the younger business traveler."
But much of the new hotel construction has occurred below 24th Street, and that section's occupancy rate has declined 15.2 percent during the first quarter of this year compared with the same period in 2000. That was the steepest of any of the five broad Manhattan areas in the PricewaterhouseCoopers report.
Some hotel operators shrugged off the slowdown. "I would not go so far to say we are recession-proof," said Brian Honan, the director of marketing for the Four Seasons Hotel on 57th Street near Fifth Avenue, "but there is a different layer of insulation at this level. C.E.O.'s, presidents and owners will always have to travel, and their expectation levels don't shift as the economy does." But he said that some guests were downsizing from suites to smaller rooms.
Leisure travelers, many of whom have been priced out of the Manhattan market in recent years, are expected to be the chief beneficiaries of the slowdown. The average daily room rate is still the highest in the country, but it increased only 2 percent in the first quarter -- to $200.47 from $196.60. Many hotels are turning to the Internet to fill empty rooms, often at bargain prices, said Jason N. Ader, a lodging industry analyst for Bear, Stearns.
It is too early to tell whether the lower occupancy rates were caused by a decline in tourism; the numbers will not be available until next year. Mr. Ader said that overseas travel to New York had decreased at least 5 percent, but other analysts said they did not think that the hotel figures showed that tourism was falling off.
Cristyne F. Lategano-Nicholas, the president of NYC and Company, the city's conventions and visitors bureau, said that the number of foreign visitors was expected to rise this year, though not at the same rate as before, in part because of the strong dollar. Tourism overall is expected to increase by 2 to 3 percent, she said.
"Because the last few years have really been gangbusters, we were expecting these phenomenal growth rates year after year," she said. "This is really an adjustment."
There are signs, Mr. Hennessey said, that hotel business is already beginning to improve, and PricewaterhouseCoopers has forecast that the industry will bounce back next year.
Mr. Dunphy of the Mark said that his hotel expected to reach an occupancy rate of 78 percent this month. In September, it expects to raise its nightly rate for a single room to $525 from $505, he said, although he added that many guests do not pay the published rate.
"The reality," Mr. Hennessey said, "is our occupancy rate is 10 percent better than the national average, and our room rates are more than double. Most hoteliers would be envious of us."

GRAPHIC: Photo: At the Mark Hotel, at 77th Street and Madison Avenue, business for the first quarter was down 8 to 10 percent, the marketing director said. (James Estrin/The New York Times)(pg. B8) Chart: "BY THE NUMBERS: Empty Rooms"Occupancy rates for Manhattan hotels for the first quarter of 2001 are down an average of 7.6% compared with the same quarter of 2000. The downturn in the economy and a hotel construction boom are among the factors for the decline. HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs; 
Turkey's Moment Of Truth

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL 

 BODY:
I thought Madonna had arrived. The place was the Ulus restaurant on an Istanbul bluff overlooking the Bosporus. The commotion started with police sirens blaring. Then there was a gaggle of a dozen television cameras and reporters, flashes popping. A murmur started to spread through the restaurant. Then the doors flew open, the reporters cleared a path, and the star walked in: Turkey's minister of economy, Kemal Dervis, had arrived for dinner. 
 Say what? Turkey's economy minister getting the Madonna treatment? Gotta tell you, it's the darndest thing I've ever seen. "Everywhere I go they follow me," shrugged Mr. Dervis sheepishly. This scene tells you everything you need to know about the unusual drama playing out in Turkey today. 
 Quite simply, Turkey's economy is on the brink of disaster. In mid-February the Turkish currency was devalued by 25 percent in one day. It was the culmination of decades of mismanagement and corruption, in which politicians used state banks and factories to pass out patronage and their patrons then used the money to buy and support the politicians. 
With little fanfare, the Bush team, which came to office swearing it would never do bailouts, as President Clinton did, quietly arranged for a $17 billion rescue package for Turkey from the I.M.F. and the World Bank. But on one condition -- that this time Turkey get real. Because there would be no next time. Turkey's feckless and squabbling politicians had no choice but to look for someone outside the political system who knew Turkey, knew economics and was not corrupt. 
Enter Mr. Dervis, a respected Turkish economist and vice president of the World Bank. Turkey's cabinet anointed him economic czar, with authority to drive through 15 reform laws that Turkey promised the I.M.F. and the U.S. it would pass in return for loans -- laws to end subsidies, create open bidding for government contracts and sell off state-owned assets, such as the phone company. If implemented, they will produce a revolution in Turkish politics. 
And that's the drama. The politicians know they have to implement these reforms. But they also know that in destroying the patronage system they will be undercutting their power bases and elevating Mr. Dervis, of whom they are insanely jealous. The Turkish public is widely rooting for the untainted, soft-spoken Mr. Dervis to succeed, hence the fascination with his every move. When he got up to use the restroom at the Ulus restaurant the elderly lady attendant handed him a towel and whispered, "Please don't quit."
But at the same time, people fear losing control of their lives to the I.M.F. "I really appreciate what the I.M.F. is doing," says Aysuda Kolemen, a student at Istanbul Bilgi University, "but I know that they are not doing it for me personally, so in the future they are likely to do things that I may not like or approve of, but I don't have a say in it. So I feel powerless, because any power I have as a citizen has now been transferred to some international technocrats." 
So Mr. Dervis is constantly, and so far deftly, walking a tightrope between coaxing his countrymen to do the right thing and not appearing to be a foreign agent. It's not easy. He regularly has to remind his cabinet colleagues, "But we promised the I.M.F. . . ." After the government slashed wheat subsidies, Agriculture Minister Husnu Yusuf Gokalp was asked why, and he said, alluding to Mr. Dervis, "You should pose that question to those having breakfast at the Hilton with foreign bankers ."
Last Thursday was a typical day here. At 10 a.m. State Minister for Privatization Yuksel Yalova declares that he will not sign a law -- which Turkey promised the I.M.F. it would pass -- ending subsidies to tobacco farms, which employ 600,000 people. At 11 a.m. Turkey's currency and stock market plunge. At noon I.M.F. officials complain. At 2 p.m. Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit repudiates Mr. Yalova. At 2:30 p.m. Turkey's markets recover. At 4 p.m. Mr. Yalova is forced to resign.
The last act of this drama is still to be written. Andrew Finkel, a longtime analyst here, remarked to me that for decades Turkey's politicians had enjoyed "power without responsibility" -- lining their pockets without worrying about the future. Now, says Mr. Finkel, they have "responsibility without power." On one hand, they deserve it. On the other hand, they may not be up to it. Stay tuned. This is going to get interesting.

HEADLINE: Public Interests; 
Bloomberg Beams In

BYLINE:  By GAIL COLLINS 

 BODY:
Michael Bloomberg is supposed to enter the race for mayor of New York today, not in the flesh but via a barrage of TV commercials. There is also a Web site, where you can dial up www.mikeformayor.org and find a photo and biography. ("The former Eagle Scout's passion for helping others comes from his strong belief that those who are fortunate have an obligation . . .")
 Voters' first impression of the campaign is going to be that the city has a hologram running for chief executive. 
 Mr. Bloomberg, the latest in the nation's long list of rich-guy candidates, is supposed to appear in person later this week. A billionaire who runs a financial media company, he believes he can win the election by running tens of millions of dollars' worth of commercials between now and November. He may not be experienced, but he'll be familiar. If it works, maybe the Taco Bell chihuahua can run for comptroller.
This candidacy has been in the works since at least last fall, when Mr. Bloomberg switched parties and registered as a Republican under the very reasonable assumption that the spindly New York City G.O.P. would have less competition for its mayoral nomination. Since then he has hired a whole mess of consultants, done a couple of interviews and walked in the Salute to Israel Parade. It was his first parade "since his Eagle Scout days," said his spokesman. That puts him approximately ten thousand marching miles behind the four Democratic mayoral candidates, a numbingly experienced crew that Mr. Bloomberg is hoping to portray as hacks.
According to his campaign, the TV ads are going to show Mr. Bloomberg introducing himself and warning that the city "cannot afford to go back to the clubhouse." New Yorkers are supposed to connect Mr. Bloomberg with Rudy Giuliani, who has been trying to assist his campaign lately. But the mayor has no coattails. When it comes to helping out, he is the political equivalent of Typhoid Mary at a cookout.
Voters may also wonder if the city can afford to bring another outspoken, iron-willed outsider into Gracie Mansion. Mr. Giuliani is, frankly, beginning to drive everybody crazy. Mr. Bloomberg, who is divorced, would probably not get us involved in his marital problems, or force us to pay for police guards for his friends and his sweetie. But you do not get to be an iron-willed, tough-talking billionaire without developing a tic or two somewhere. Eight years ago New York needed discipline and order. Now we just need a rest.
And for a guy who made his fortune in the communications business, Mr. Bloomberg seems surprisingly tone-deaf. The other day he was quoted as complaining that New York City public school students "have personal hygiene problems." There is an old sexual harassment suit, long settled but destined to be much discussed, in which Mr. Bloomberg was alleged to have responded to news of an employee's pregnancy by telling her to "kill it." He denies saying it.
Back in March, Mr. Bloomberg appeared on an MSNBC special on the dot-com economy, in which he and a bunch of other new-tech moguls sat perched uncomfortably on stools trying to sound pithy. Asked about wireless communication, he told Tom Brokaw, "I've carried a mobile phone for a number of years and I don't remember ever getting a call, and I think I'm a mogul, so, you know, if I don't get them, what do you need them for?"
Later on, Mr. Brokaw brought out a little girl named Jalissa who was too poor to buy her own computer, and invited Mr. Bloomberg to explain whether big companies were "doing enough" to erase the digital divide.
"Well, the problem, Tom, is that it's not clear that we need people to spend more time away from books and away from teachers and there's this implication that the only technology that matters is the Internet," he responded, totally ignoring the child -- a New York City child -- who was standing right in front of him.
"The problem is that a lot of people are using the Internet as a baby sitter," he concluded. "And it's just not clear we're better off for that."
Mr. Brokaw interjected that he, for one, wanted Jalissa to be able to do homework on a computer. If this had been a debate, Mr. Bloomberg would have been George Bush the elder, looking impatiently at his wristwatch.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Up on Gains by Oil Issues and Greenspan Remarks

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks rose yesterday as oil shares advanced on the prospect of higher crude prices after Iraq halted exports. 
 Investors snapped up oil shares because "there's a pretty high degree of certainty about what earnings will be in the energy group this year," said Eric Thorne, a money manager for the Bryn Mawr Trust Company in Bryn Mawr, Pa. "Profits are going to be really strong." He recently bought shares of Chevron and Schlumberger. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 71.11 points, or 0.7 percent, to 11,061.52. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 6.44 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,267.11. The Nasdaq composite index advanced 6.49 points, or 0.3 percent, to 2,155.93. Intel and Wal-Mart Stores declined, limiting the benchmarks' gains.
Stocks also got a lift after Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, told a conference in Singapore that inflation is not a threat to the American economy, suggesting that the central bank may trim interest rates further when policy makers meet on June 27. 
The Fed has reduced rates five times this year to revive the economy, which expanded at an annual pace of 1.3 percent in the first quarter after growing 5 percent in 2000.
Lower rates may help offset an expected decline in earnings this year that has sent the Nasdaq down 12.7 percent in 2001 and the S.& P. 500 down 4 percent.
Some 835 million shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange, the second fewest this year and 30 percent below the three-month daily average. Major indexes swung between gains and losses before climbing in the session's final half-hour.
"We have almost no economic data and no earnings reports" to speak of this week, said Peter Boockvar, a trader for Miller Tabak & Company. "There's a lot of volatility when people have nothing to hold onto" and the market probably will not establish any direction in the next few days, he said.
In the absence of hard data, investors are focusing on signs of what to expect from a number of company meetings scheduled for this week with analysts.
Intel rose as much as 46 cents and fell as much as 68 cents before closing with a loss of 24 cents, to $28.50. Executives may lower their most-optimistic revenue forecast for this quarter when they brief analysts after exchanges close Thursday, said Terry Ragsdale, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs. 
"We don't see how the news can be good," Mr. Ragsdale wrote in a note to clients, because demand for personal computers has not picked up. Intel is likely to forecast a revenue decline of 3 percent to 7 percent, compared with the first quarter, he said. The company now predicts revenue may be anywhere from up 2 percent to down 7 percent.
Still, he said he recommended the stock because Intel was likely to stop losing market share to Advanced Micro Devices Inc., and PC sales growth may pick up to 15 percent annually after this year.
Oil stocks gained after Iraq, the No. 4 producer in OPEC, halted most exports in protest over United Nations trade sanctions in place since the country invaded Kuwait in 1990. OPEC oil ministers also signaled that they intended to leave production quotas unchanged at a meeting that starts today, meaning oil prices are likely to stay near $30 a barrel.
Fourteen of 15 stocks in both the Amex oil index and the Philadelphia oil service sector index rallied.
 --------------------

Treasury Prices Increase
 (By Reuters) -- Treasury bond prices rose yesterday after Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, calmed investors' fears over inflation and left the door open for more interest rate cuts to stimulate the sluggish American economy.
Data late last week that painted an unexpectedly bleak picture for the recession-mired United States manufacturing sector and a still-contracting labor market sent Treasury prices bolting higher, pushing yields lower. Yesterday's light trading activity built on those solid gains.
"I wouldn't bet against Treasuries in the short term," said Robert Justich, managing director for fixed income at Times Square Asset Management, citing expectations for lower rates and Fed-led optimism that inflation will remain contained.
The 10-year Treasury note rose 9/32, to a price of 97 18/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.32 percent from 5.36 percent on Friday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 11/32, to 95 20/32. The bond's yield fell to 5.68 percent from 5.71 percent on Friday.

HEADLINE: Surplus of Finger-Pointing In California Energy Crisis 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

 BODY:
Natural gas prices have plunged in the last few months -- everywhere, that is, but Southern California. While gas in New York costs about $4 per thousand cubic feet, gas delivered to Southern California still costs more than $11 wholesale. 
 That such numbers demand an explanation was about the only thing President Bush and Gov. Gray Davis could agree on when they met in Los Angeles a few days ago to discuss California's energy crisis. Mr. Bush assigned Patrick H. Wood III, a fellow Texan confirmed last month as a member of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, to investigate. 
 To many experts, the woes of California's natural gas market are as profound as those of its electricity market: the state is short on pipelines, and the rules of the gas market, critics say, encourage sellers and traders -- including the biggest local gas utility -- to drive prices higher. 
At peak times, half of California's electricity is generated by gas-fired power plants, a higher proportion than in most parts of the country. And because 85 percent of the gas consumed in California comes from outside the state, the shortage of pipelines both into California and within the state has become a big handicap in fueling those plants. The strain has become especially acute as drought in the Pacific Northwest has curtailed imports of hydropower and gas-fired power plants have worked overtime to meet the demands of a booming state economy.
Vice President Dick Cheney's energy policy report last month proposed initiatives to speed approval and construction of new pipelines, noting that New England and other regions faced capacity squeezes, too. The report says that the United States needs 38,000 miles of new gas transmission pipelines, almost a 20 percent increase.
In the meantime, some industry executives and public officials take the argument one step further than the Bush administration, contending that today's shortage of capacity has made it possible for energy companies, intent on maximizing profits, to manipulate prices. 
"It really strains credulity to say this is a functioning market," said Representative Joe Barton, Republican of Texas, who as chairman of the House energy subcommittee has been leaning on the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to scrutinize the California gas market. "Reasonable people could conclude people have gamed the system." 
In one significant case, California utility regulators and Southern California Edison, one of the state's struggling electric utilities, have accused the El Paso Corporation of using its control of a major pipeline into the state to inflate prices artificially. El Paso officials deny wrongdoing and accuse California officials of making the company a scapegoat for the state's failure to build more pipelines. A judge at the federal energy commission is hearing the case in Washington. 
But fingers are pointing in other directions, too. 
For example, the Southern California Gas Company, the state's largest gas utility, has reaped huge profits buying and selling gas in the last year -- activity encouraged by state regulations intended to lower gas prices for consumers. But some gas marketers and electricity generators contend that the trading has contributed to price spikes, by tying up valuable pipeline space during peak times with gas shipments driven by financial deals, not power demands.
At the same time, Edison says that Southern California Gas failed to put enough gas into storage last fall for residential and small-business customers. If so, that would have driven the gas company back into the market in the winter, when demand from power plant operators was high, helping push gas -- and hence electricity -- prices yet higher, Edison complains. 
Between them, El Paso and Southern California Gas were responsible for $3.7 billion in excess prices for energy in the last year, Edison contends. 
Southern California Gas, a unit of Sempra Energy, denies that its trading has harmed the market. Rather, its executives note that electricity generators and industrial gas consumers -- which under state rules are responsible for managing their own gas supplies -- put very little gas into storage last year. By one estimate, large gas consumers in Southern California had only 11 percent as much gas in storage at the end of November as they did at the same time during the prior two years.
Another problem may emerge this summer, according to William L. Massey, a member of the federal energy commission. Mr. Massey said new commission rules intended to limit electricity price spikes in California will almost certainly prompt energy-trading companies -- which deal in both gas and electricity -- to manipulate gas prices. That is because the rules allow electricity generators to charge more if gas prices move higher. 
Similarly, growing attention is being paid to the role played by financial trading tied to the price of electricity and natural gas. Industry critics question whether huge trading volumes in these financial derivatives gives energy marketing companies the incentive to manipulate prices in tight markets.
Federal regulators "don't seem to understand that firms are really trying to make as much money as they can," said Severin Borenstein, director of the University of California Energy Institute, a research organization on the Berkeley campus. "That's what they do for a living." 
Fixing the problem is simple, Mr. Borenstein said. "If you build more capacity," he said, "you reduce both the scarcity issue and you reduce the ability of people who currently own capacity to exercise market power." 
Regardless of whether companies are manipulating prices, the California natural gas market is fattening bottom lines. In the El Paso case, testimony has shown that pipeline capacity acquired by the company's marketing affiliate in March 2000 for $38.5 million produced profits of almost $900 million over the next 13 months. 
El Paso said its share of those profits was $184 million, the rest going to other companies with which it entered into hedging transactions intended to limit El Paso's exposure if gas prices fell. About half of those transactions were with the biggest energy trader, the Enron Corporation, according to people present at briefings El Paso officials have given to California officials. 
An Enron spokesman, Mark Palmer, said it was possible that Enron took the other side of the trades, but he said that Enron would have resold the pipeline capacity almost immediately, thus profiting little from the rise of gas prices in California. 
Federal regulators, concerned that the high gas prices in California may not be legitimate, have proposed requiring companies selling gas in the state to disclose extensive data about their transactions. They are also considering whether to reimpose price caps on short-term sales of pipeline capacity that were eliminated early last year. 
Further, regulators are scrutinizing the so-called gray market in which energy marketers bundle gas and transmission capacity and sell it to large customers, like electricity generators, for one price. Federal regulators have oversight responsibility for the interstate portion of gas shipments, but they have not looked closely at these bundled transactions, Mr. Massey said. 
"The whole thing has fallen through the cracks," he said.
Nearly all of California's gas comes from the Southwest, the Rocky Mountain states and Canada through a few huge, highly pressurized pipelines. In California, the gas is shunted onto intrastate pipelines that deliver it to consumers and to underground storage fields for later use. 
Those pipelines are now largely running full, and their capacity is about 300 million cubic feet a day less than what interstate pipelines can deliver. The difference is the amount of gas it takes to continuously fuel a 1,300 megawatt power plant -- enough to light more than a million homes.
"It's not resources, it's straws -- the straws needed to suck this gas where it needs to go," said Thom Kelly, assistant executive director of the California Energy Commission. "If the straws are full, that's a problem." 
Operators of interstate pipelines have proposed new construction that could double delivery to the state. Indeed, odd as it seems now, some in the industry worry that California could be "overpiped" later this decade, just as it was in the mid-1990's.
Likewise, Southern California Gas plans only limited expansion of its in-state pipelines, partly because it expects demand to fall as hydroelectric power supplies return to normal levels and older, less efficient gas-fired power plants are phased out. 
But the gas company's intentions are regarded with skepticism by others in the industry. Some executives contend that Southern California Gas has damaged the marketplace through its enthusiastic embrace of a state program that allows it to split with customers the profits from buying, selling and lending gas. 
A coalition of power generators, including Reliant Energy, the Williams Companies and the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power, has complained to state officials that the program "creates perverse incentives" for the gas company. The generators say it results in extra demand for pipeline space when capacity already is at a premium, making prices more volatile.
The consequences of the gas company's low storage inventories were evident in early December, according to John Stout, a senior Reliant executive. He recalled listening in on a conference call as a Southern California Gas official talked about injecting gas into storage. "I was floored," Mr. Stout said. "Prices were sky high, and they were putting more upward pressure on prices." 
Lee M. Stewart, president of energy transportation services for Southern California Gas, called the criticism "bogus." The utility's storage and trading practices have neither hurt the market nor curtailed gas sales to customers, he said.
"To say gas prices drive electricity prices is a falsehood," Mr. Stewart added. 
But to many regulators, it is clear that gas prices play an increasingly important role in electricity prices. 
Problems in the California natural gas markets "haven't been given the prominence they deserve for the detrimental role they are playing in high electricity prices," said Linda K. Breathitt, another member of the federal energy commission. "Natural gas prices have been the stepchild of this California crisis." 
This article is part of a joint reporting project with the PBS series "Frontline," which will broadcast a documentary about California's energy crisis tonight.

HEADLINE: Teacher Pact Still Far Off 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
On the surface, it seems like an auspicious moment for advocates of change in the New York City public schools. 
 The teachers' union president says she is willing not only to see the mayor take control of the Board of Education, but also to make it easier to dismiss bad teachers and reward good ones with some form of merit pay. 
 At the same time, a phalanx of big-name business leaders is trying to pry enough money out of Albany to finance a huge pay increase for the teachers to bring salaries closer to those paid by suburban districts.
Yet, after a bargaining session yesterday, prospects for a contract do not seem bright. The teachers and the city remain far apart on the size of raises to be given to the city's 80,000 public-school teachers. 
Yesterday, union officials accused Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of setting a new and unreasonable demand in contract talks, saying he would not agree to a contract until the State Legislature gave him the power to hire and fire the schools chancellor.
Many business leaders, educators and parents agree a landmark deal is needed to address daunting problems in the nation's largest school system, most notably the dismal performance of many city schools and the shortage of certified teachers.
"This is an opportune time for a path-breaking deal because of the problems in hiring teachers and the need to hold teachers accountable," said Joseph P. Viteritti, a public policy professor at New York University who is a consultant to Mr. Giuliani on education. "And with all the focus on education nationwide, it's an opportune time, because whatever we do in New York has high visibility and sets the tone for the rest of the country."
The teachers' contract expired in November, but Randi Weingarten, the president of the teachers' union, has set today as a negotiating deadline, saying she will ask the state to appoint an arbitrator to recommend a nonbinding settlement if no agreement is reached this week.
Last Thursday, the state-appointed mediator, Robert L. Douglas, said that unless an agreement was reached this week, there would not be enough time for teachers to ratify the settlement before the school year ends. He has called another negotiating session for this afternoon.
Last week, several officials involved in the talks said they would fail unless the two sides made significant movement on salaries.
The city has offered an 8 percent pay increase over two years. But the United Federation of Teachers wants a raise of at least 20 percent over two years, insisting that a large raise is needed to attract enough certified teachers, especially since many suburban districts pay 20 to 30 percent more than the city does. This year, 60 percent of the teachers hired by the city were uncertified.
Mr. Giuliani has said that a huge raise is not needed, and that the teacher shortage is not as bad as the union says. But even if he changed his mind, some City Hall officials say the city simply does not have the money for a 20 percent raise, which would cost $1 billion a year. The starting salary for teachers is $31,190, and the maximum is $70,000.
Complicating matters, if the teachers are given a 20 percent raise, other unions, notably the police union, will undoubtedly demand an identical increase.
Labor experts see another obstacle to a deal: the well-known dislike that Mr. Giuliani and Ms. Weingarten feel toward each other.
Ms. Weingarten's offers on mayoral control of the Board of Education and on merit pay have been rejected as inadequate by the mayor. Ms. Weingarten said on Sunday that the school board should be expanded, with the mayor appointing six board members, up from two at present, and the five borough presidents each naming one. Under her union's plan, the board would still select the chancellor, but the mayor, saying he wants to reduce bureaucracy and increase accountability, wants to abolish the board and give the mayor the power to appoint the chancellor. 
Ms. Weingarten said that yesterday's negotiating session lasted less than 30 minutes, and that the mayor said there would be no contract until the Legislature enacted a bill giving the mayor power to hire and fire the chancellor.
"It's not appropriate to make this a condition of a contract, since this has to be done by the state," Ms. Weingarten said. "It's just another straw man not to do a contract."
City Hall officials declined to comment on yesterday's negotiations.
Ms. Weingarten, who said she had tried to meet the mayor halfway, asserted that the school board should be preserved because it gives parents a mechanism to air their concerns and preserves a modicum of independence in running the schools.
But Mr. Giuliani said Ms. Weingarten's proposal would increase bureaucracy. "What they're proposing makes matters worse, not better," he said at a news briefing yesterday.
As the mayor and the union tangle over salaries and the Board of Education, they face intense pressures to reach a settlement.
Kathryn S. Wylde, president of the New York City Partnership, the city's main business association, said: "There's a sense that New York City, our future, our competitiveness in a knowledge-based economy, absolutely depend on getting the public education system fixed and doing it now."
In recent days, the union has signaled possible concessions on three of Mr. Giuliani's main demands, for longer hours, merit pay and faster ways to dismiss teachers who are incompetent or misbehave. 
But City Hall officials suggest that the union's talk of flexibility is more public relations than substance, asserting that the union has not gone nearly far enough on merit pay. 
Mr. Giuliani wants individualized merit pay, in which some teachers in a school receive bonuses while others do not, depending on how their students perform on standardized tests. Ms. Weingarten has indicated she would accept schoolwide merit pay in which all of a school's teachers and support workers receive bonuses if that school shows improvement by various measures.
Some business executives and educators voice concern that if no agreement is reached this month, then, because of the summer break and distractions caused by the mayoral race, no deal will be reached until a new mayor is sworn in next January. Supporters of educational change say that the chances of far-reaching reform will diminish if Mr. Giuliani does not reach a settlement and hands the matter to his successor. 
Some education experts, like Professor Viteritti, say the time is ripe for a deal, because in their view Ms. Weingarten has shown unusual flexibility for a teachers' leader. Just two years ago her union seemed dead set against any form of merit pay, a weakening of tenure or mayoral control of the Board of Education.
Some educators and political analysts also say Mr. Giuliani can only gain by reaching an agreement that will help achieve his goal of remaking the city's schools. 
"We have a mayor who's in the final year of his term and for whom there is very little to lose and a lot to gain by reaching a settlement with the teachers," said Arthur Levine, president of Columbia University Teachers College.
In recent weeks, much has gone on behind the scenes to produce a deal. Business leaders, including Jerry I. Speyer, the real estate executive, and Henry Kravis, the financier, have lobbied in Albany for more money for the city's schools and teachers. Ms. Weingarten and Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy have quietly urged state lawmakers to make hundreds of millions of dollars available to make it easier for Mr. Giuliani to finance a deal.
"It does boil down to funding," Ms. Weingarten said. "If we want to ensure that there is a well-prepared teacher in every classroom, then you have to address salaries. Salaries have become a quality issue." 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: North Korea, Displeased, Said to Review Missile Pacts 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, June 4 

 BODY:
Citing their deep displeasure with Washington, officials from North Korea have threatened to pull out of two agreements under which that isolated nation had promised to halt missile testing and to stop building nuclear reactors that could be used to produce weapons, an American academic said today. 
 In a meeting in Pyongyang, Foreign Minister Paek Nam Sun told the scholar that the United States had made hostile and offensive statements about North Korea, the American said as he returned from a visit there. Mr. Paek complained to the visitor that the administration was backing away from commitments made by President Clinton. 
 Last month, a delegation from the European Union said the North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il, had told them that he would unilaterally extend his country's moratorium on missile testing and production until 2003 as a good will gesture. But the foreign minister appeared to cast doubt on that.
"It has yet to be decided whether we maintain the moratorium on missile testing," Selig Harrison, a senior fellow at the Century Foundation who has studied North Korea, related that Mr. Paek had told him. "That depends entirely on the policy of the new U.S. administration, whether it is hostile or not."
Since he took office in January, Mr. Bush has signaled that he intends to be tough with North Korea, rejecting the policy of cautious engagement that had characterized Mr. Clinton's last year in office. 
Administration officials have been openly skeptical about South Korea's "sunshine policy" of engagement with the North. The officials have also pushed for immediate and aggressive inspections of North Korean nuclear sites, actions that North Korea has said it will not allow. 
Mr. Harrison said four high North Korean officials had each told him that such policies could threaten the two loose accords that now form the foundation for relations between North Korea and the United States. 
Under the first, the Agreed Framework, signed in 1994, North Korea said it would stop producing weapons-grade plutonium, closing its lone operating reactor and shelving plans for two others in exchange for a promise to help meet energy needs. The plan called for the United States, Japan and South Korea to build two light-water reactors in North Korea by 2003. 
North Korean nuclear reactors produced plutonium that could readily be processed for use in nuclear weapons. The light-water reactors do not. 
The second agreement, when Mr. Kim agreed in 1999 to a temporary moratorium on missile testing in exchange for relaxed American economic sanctions, was negotiated by former Defense Secretary William J. Perry. In late 1998, North Korea alarmed the world by sending a long-range unarmed missile toward Japan.

HEADLINE: Look Busy, Feign Interest and Be Paid 

BYLINE:  By JULIE FLAHERTY 

 BODY:
Bored with the daily grind? Consider a job as an impersonator. It is quite the rage these days.
 As the service sector grows, an increasing number of people are being paid to pretend to be somebody they are not. They sit as make-believe jurors to help lawyers sharpen their oratory. They pose as customers in restaurants to check on the bartenders. They crowd the seats near the stage in talk shows to make sure somebody claps at the right moment. They even rush around normally placid workplaces to make a favorable impression on visitors. 
 That is what Robert, a 66-year-old mechanical engineer from Boston, did after he was laid off. A potential client was coming into the office, and his old boss wanted it to look busy. So he hired Robert to come in and feign work. "I sat at the computer and called up an old design I had worked on, and started playing with it," said Robert, who insisted that his last name not be used. "There was nothing else to do." He was paid the same wage he received when he did the work for real.
Padding staff is a common ploy among start-ups. Kate Brant, staffing manager for Pro Staff in Boston, remembers helping one young venture beef up its skeleton crew. "They mentioned that it is hard for their clients to understand how they can run a business of that size and not have physical bodies there," Ms. Brant said. She did ask that the company find some nominal tasks, like stuffing envelopes, for her workers.
Matthew Swanson, president of the Express Personnel Services office in Redmond, Wash., also took no particular pride in assigning mock jobs for a local company that wanted to add heft to its staff. "We just went along with it," he said. 
Temporary staffing agencies like his are usually the first resort for filling phantom jobs, whether the employer wants candidates to fake working or fake not working. Lisa Schmitter faked not working. She would come home from her day job at Express Personnel in Trevose, Pa., change into jeans and T-shirt, and go hang out in a bar. But while she always ordered a drink, she never sipped it. Ms. Schmitter, 25, was helping a large restaurant chain check up on the diligence of its staff and was noting whether the bartenders asked for her ID.
She had to make two trips to each of 14 restaurants each month, which was "a little time-consuming," she said, but it was easy and the money was decent. The worst moments came when bartenders were fired, often on the spot, for not asking for her ID.
"That made it a little difficult to continue," she said. "I tried to get out of there as soon as possible."
Professionals in her line of work, known as mystery shoppers, have been around for decades. But Christopher Causey, director of business development for TrendSource Inc., which sends out mystery shoppers, says the practice has spread to a greater variety of industries. TrendSource's revenue has shot up 40 percent a year for the last five and a half years, he said.
"Even during tight economic times, we will see companies that will look to initiate this type of service because of the realized benefits of increasing the quality of their customer service," Mr. Causey said.
Keith Alter, president of Alternative Solutions Inc. in Boston, sent workers to a bank with customer service problems to pose as customers demanding tricky transactions. He has also provided people as an audience for lawyers wanting to practice their courtroom deliveries. "They just wanted some people that would not cause any trouble," Mr. Alter said.
Diane Warner, staffing coordinator for Express Personnel in North Houston, Tex., also supplies mock jurors to law firms. "Some of my people said it was very boring," she said. "They had to drink coffee in between breaks to stay awake." At least they earned about $15 an hour, more than real jurors do.
The list of role-playing jobs is almost endless. Ms. Warner says one business asked her to send people over to play around with its Web site as if they were customers and to comment on its good and bad points. Leo Craig, owner of the Express Personnel franchise in Trevose, received a request from a market research company that was training employees to conduct market research interviews. He sent "everything from Ph.D.-candidate-type people to people from other countries," he said.
Perhaps the ultimate nonjob involves no questions, no talking, just standing around and looking tough. When a professional wrestling outfit was filming an event at the CenturyTel Center in Bossier City, La., Larry Wilson, the arena manager, said he put out a call for "gentlemen between 20 and 30 years old with a big build." Placed strategically next to doorways, the men had only to look like bouncers keeping order.
Others who crave the spotlight have found solace in talk shows. Often those well-dressed, professional-looking people sitting in the first few rows of the studio audience are being paid to clap their hands. Television producers find them more appealing than the T-shirt-and-baseball-cap crowd that lines up for free tickets.
"It's an easy job," said Lisette St. Claire, who works for Central Casting in Burbank, Calif. "You sit there and you get paid to clap and you have fun."
She also casts for laughers -- people who lend their guffaws, chuckles and titters to the taping of a show.
Pat Nixon, 70, of Glendale, Calif., tried out as a laugher a few years ago because she needed extra cash to supplement her Social Security. She describes her laugh as "titillating" because it incites others to laugh as well -- just what casting directors want.
While most audience work is sporadic, laughing can be a relatively steady part-time job, she said. When Fran Drescher, the actress, was threatened by a stalker, she made sure the entire studio audience for her show "The Nanny" consisted of hand-picked laughers and applauders. Ms. Nixon had that as a standing job for two years.
As if her funny bone were not already excitable, Ms. Nixon takes cues from the assistant directors, who wave their arms when they want an audience to laugh.
"They tell us to laugh, I laugh," she said, with a laugh.
