HEADLINE: Trees vs. Produce: Clashing Greens In Union Square 

BYLINE:  By REGINA SCHRAMBLING 

 BODY:
NEW YORK is not at its most savory in summer. One of the few compensations for the brutal weather and the weird quiet is the Greenmarket on Union Square. A Saturday morning there is like a cross between a mind massage and a trip to the country, without the shrink or the jitney.
 Manhattan simply has the best farmers' market in the United States, the model on which hundreds are now based. Founded exactly 25 years ago, when pea shoots and fresh basil were not even gleams in the most adventurous chef's eye, the Greenmarket has grown into a showplace of variety and perfection that would almost make a Parisian envious. Marquee chefs can be found there, picking through the sugar snap peas and the strawberries, along with throngs of other cooks, serious and vicarious. No wonder guidebooks list the market as a must-see in a city with no shortage of culinary (and other) splendors. 
 But this is shaping up as the summer of discontent for both the Greenmarket and its devotees. Union Square West, its busiest boundary, feels like a war zone while a century-old water main is being replaced; heavy equipment and construction barriers have invaded space normally clogged by dedicated shoppers as well as the dog proud and the stroller encumbered. Farmers are pushed leaf by jowl in what little room is left amid the dirt and the noise. And the market is still weeks away from the corn and tomato frenzy that makes it wilder than Times Square when the theaters let out.
Even if the market survives without the construction driving away customers, though, farmers will soon face a more forbidding trial by renovation. Next year, the city's Parks Department plans to revamp the southwest corner of Union Square. And what that means for the market has fears festering under the white canopies between 14th and 17th Streets. Lacking any solid information from the city, farmers and their advocates are hoping for the best and envisioning the worst.
The latest dispute appears to be a flare-up from the last one, in December, when the Greenmarket blanketed the park with ominous notices of a potential shrinking of the market after drawings for a $6 million redesign for the southwest corner of the park were making the rounds. Greenmarket advocates worried that the design for new tree plantings would force some farmers out, and shoppers and chefs started voicing their objections. Then the dispute quieted. 
Now, with construction unsettling the market, those worries have resurfaced. At worst, advocates say, the market could indeed be truncated, forcing farmers out; at the very least, they say, the design could keep out the large trucks farmers rely on to bring in the tons of fruits and vegetables that supply not just home kitchens but also 60 to 85 percent of the menus in some of the city's top restaurants in summertime.
In an interview Monday, Henry J. Stern, the city parks commissioner, would say nothing specific, but offered comments ranging from, "We'll design it and then see what fits," and "I don't think one farmer or any farmer will be forced out" to "There will be room for 90 percent, or 95 percent" of the Greenmarket.
And so David Distler, a Manhattan lawyer whose small Friends of Greenmarket group coalesces whenever the market feels imperiled, is back on the ramparts. "If the Parks Department would honestly state what their intentions are, in detail, it could dissolve any controversy," he said on Saturday. "They're not saying anything, yet they're saying some things that are very scary."
Michael Batterberry, the editor and publisher of Food Arts magazine, was involved in the drafting of a letter in support of the market from top chefs like Daniel Boulud, David Bouley, Alfred Portale, Diane Forley, Wylie Dufresne and Michel Nischan. Mr. Batterberry puts it more bluntly: "There is something very pungent buried here."
It's hard to believe this all grows out of rhubarb and potatoes.
But the Greenmarket seems to function as New York's own Pauline, perennially strapped to the railroad tracks with a train barreling down. In the quarter-century since an urban planner named Barry Benepe recruited a handful of struggling farmers from the Hudson Valley to set up shop in what was then more drug haven than city park, both Union Square and the neighborhood have become magnets for money, developers and tourists. Location is everything in Manhattan, and the 65 farmers who set up stands on the asphalt four days a week at the height of the season are occupying some very valuable real estate and paying only small fees to the Greenmarket, which is run by the Council on the Environment of New York City. (Interestingly, it is Adrian Benepe, the founder's son, as Manhattan parks commissioner, who is overseeing the redesign so many farmers fear.)
The market sells to the homeless as well as to some of the most renowned chefs in the city; 40,000 shoppers come through on a typical Saturday in summertime, said Lys McLaughlin, the council's executive director. But even though the Greenmarket is also a tourist attraction, it doesn't exactly fit in the age of Disney. The KnollKrest Farms stand selling chickens and eggs may attract crowds worthy of the "Producers" cancellation line, but the market itself is not about T-shirts and corporate tie-ins. Instead it has become a national prototype precisely because farmers are allowed to sell only what they grow or can or bake themselves.
In the realm of agribusiness, it's hard for the one-crop farmer to be king, especially growing fragile foods like zucchini blossoms. Many farmers say they are totally dependent on the Greenmarket; and chefs say they prize not just the freshly picked food but also the accountability in an era of mad cow disease and genetic engineering. 
The market's blessing and curse is its location in a high-rent neighborhood, with the newest W hotel on one corner and restaurants and theaters all around. Advocates for the farmers say the relationship between the Parks Department and the Greenmarket has deteriorated as Union Square improved after the farmers moved in.
"When we first started, 20 years ago, my husband was mugged while setting up and spent four days over in St. Vincent's," Sue Gorzynski of Gorzynski Organic Farm said Saturday. "To push us out is not right. There weren't nice stores when we first started coming here. Henry Stern forgets that."
Mr. Stern, however, insists that he is "pro-Greenmarket" and that "we're happy they're there." But he also says, "when it comes to choosing between trees and trucks -- big trucks -- I'm for trees." 
The commissioner said in the interview the only problem was that "the Greenmarket has a couple of professional wolf-criers." His response to the letter from the chefs who banded with Mr. Batterberry says the Greenmarket was never given permission "on a permanent basis" to expand into the southwest corner and adds that "allowing large trucks into this area would displace park users and endanger trees and paving."
But as farmers and their supporters point out, there can't be a market without trucks. Chickens don't take the R train; some farmers drive five hours or more each way, from South Jersey or the Finger Lakes or even Vermont. They also can't just park in a lot because they need ready coolers. 
Originally it was actually just the Parks Department's plan for the water main that had farmers dreading this summer. Yet the agency was mostly praised by those I spoke with on Saturday. "They're doing a good job," said Suzie Dare, of Cherry Lane Farms in Bridgeton, N.J. "We've been rearranged, but it's not unbearable. I have no complaints, and I thought I would."
Many farmers gave up a quarter or half of their usual space so that others could squeeze in this summer. 
Ms. McLaughlin of the Council on the Environment, who is now the only Greenmarket official authorized to speak to the press, also put a positive face on the situation this summer. "We're willing to squeeze and reconfigure and all pull together," she said. "It's a real nice feeling. Reason prevails, we hope."
Not everyone agrees, of course. "A lot of customers have told me they won't come back because the farmers are so tight," said Ted Blew, owner of Oak Grove Plantation of Pittstown, N.J. "I don't want to sound like a real complainer, because the city has to have water, but the gross income is not here this year because it's harder for the consumer to get around. Farmers have taken their trucks out of the market, and there's still not enough space."
And then Mr. Blew, like so many others, brought up the beautification project. "At least with the construction we'll get our space back," he said. "We could lose farmers with the work at the end of the park."
Linda Paffenroth of Paffenroth Gardens, said: "No one is telling us anything. In summer we usually have three spaces. This summer we may have to consolidate and not bring both our trucks down. It's the unknown that's bad -- we have to buy seeds and plant in advance." 
A worker at a neighboring stand said he already had to divide produce between Union Square and a Greenmarket on East 47th Street. "We're cramped in here," he said. "We can't even park our truck. We have to take it to the other market."
It's not just farmers who are edgy. Mr. Dufresne, the chef-owner of 71 Clinton Fresh Food, says he relies on the market for 75 percent of his produce in peak season. "I've gone all four days the market is open for years now," he said. "I've seen it go through changes before. But mostly it gets bigger. It always seems to be having growing pains, but now it's having shrinking pains. The city does not value the Greenmarket for what it did in that park."
Both Dan Barber of Blue Hill in Greenwich Village and Philippe Bertineau of Payard on the Upper East Side say that up to 85 percent of their menus comes from the market in mid-June and July.
Some in Mr. Batterberry's chefs' group say they got stung when they tried to communicate their empathy and their dependence on the market. As Mr. Nischan recalls, the group was meeting to discuss an unrelated farm-chef project when they decided to fire off a letter last winter to Mr. Stern because "there was an awful lot of fuzzy gray area about whether the farmers would get an equal share in the redesign of the park." But he and the others were outraged when, last week, they got what they called a "very patronizing" response. 
"We're a powerful economic resource in this city," Mr. Nischan said. "It cheapened it to have him say we were writing because the Greenmarket told us to." In another interview, he said: "It's such a benefit to give our customers fresh food that's responsibly grown. Any elected or appointed official would see this as a good thing."
Mr. Distler, who heads Friends of Greenmarket, says he and others are suspicious simply because the Parks Department is being so closed-mouthed about the specifics of the design. The farmers and their advocates almost appear to be reduced to studying sheep's entrails to get a sense of the future: they pass around purloined architects' renderings and try to interpret how the placement of trees or the specification of blue paving stones will affect their trucks. On Saturday, The Villager, the neighborhood newspaper, was circulating among booths as farmers tried to read between the lines of Adrian Benepe's quotations on their rights to the park.
Mr. Distler says there's a reason so few specifics have been made public. A year and a half ago, he said, Friends of Greenmarket gathered 19,700 signatures in two weeks on petitions opposing another department plan. "Every time there's a disclosure, we stop them," he said. "I don't know why they're so antagonistic to one of the most successful amenities in the city."
But both sides might be surprised to learn they are in agreement on one point at least. Mr. Distler says: "I want the facts. This is not the way open government should work." And Mr. Stern said the constant agitation was "like mushrooms -- it flourishes in the dark."

HEADLINE: Rumsfeld Pays Visit To Troops In Balkans 

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: CAMP BONDSTEEL, Kosovo, June 5 

 BODY:
In his first foray into the Balkans, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld heard today from American troops and commanders about the difficulties of stemming ethnic fighting along the Kosovo-Macedonia border, where some Bush administration officials want to curtail the United States' role.
 Traveling by Blackhawk helicopter in the shadow of Kosovo's snow-capped peaks, Mr. Rumsfeld surveyed the intricate networks of mountain trails used by Albanian rebels to smuggle weapons into Macedonia from Kosovo. He also talked to soldiers involved in gun battles along the border and was shown dozens of weapons seized from smugglers in recent weeks. 
 Though Mr. Rumsfeld has said little about what he wants to do with the 6,000 American troops in Kosovo, he has made clear in the past that he believes American forces are overextended across the globe, specifically pointing to Bosnia as one place where United States involvement should be wound down.
During the American presidential campaign, Condoleezza Rice, now President Bush's national security adviser, called for having the Europeans take up more peacekeeping duties in the Balkans -- a position the administration has since backed away from. 
In brief remarks to several hundred soldiers inside a tentlike movie theater here, Mr. Rumsfeld did not mention the debate in Washington over peacekeeping missions, and instead praised the troops for having taken up a "noble cause" that he said has often been overlooked. 
Brig. Gen. William David, the new commander of the American contingent in NATO's peacekeeping force in Kosovo, told reporters that conditions seemed to have improved somewhat along the border in recent days. He said the recent decision to allow Yugoslav troops back into a buffer zone around Kosovo had allowed NATO troops to focus more resources on stemming rebel activity along the Macedonia border.
But General David said it remained difficult to stop the flow of fighters and weapons across the hilly and heavily wooded Kosovo-Macedonia border, where Albanian smugglers using mule trains and cell phones sometimes operate with impunity. 
Asked if he thought American troops were still needed to keep the peace, General David said yes. "This can be a deadly place," he said.
Camp Bondsteel is in a way emblematic of the growing entrenchment of the American military here. Two years ago, it was little more than an encampment of tents. Today, it is a sprawling, self-contained city with wooden barracks and command centers, a water treatment plant, makeshift helicopter hangers, a movie theater, gymnasiums and a hospital under construction. 
Mr. Rumsfeld and his contingent, aboard the helicopter protected by two Apache gunships, also dropped into a hilltop outpost just yards from the Macedonia border. During a brief clash in early March, an Army platoon captured the hilltop from Albanian rebels, who had been using a schoolhouse there as a base to fire mortars into Macedonia. 
As he surveyed the outpost, Mr. Rumsfeld, dressed in a dark suit and raincoat, looked like a politician on the stump, shaking hands, posing for photographs and entering a bunker to chat with the troops. "We're keeping track of you every day from Washington," he told them.
In Skopje, Macedonia, the secretary also inspected six unmanned aircraft known as Hunters that are being used for reconnaissance along the Kosovo border. The planes, slow-moving but hard to shoot down because of their small size, carry powerful cameras and infrared sensors that can transmit information almost anywhere in the world. The planes represent the kind of high-tech weaponry Mr. Rumsfeld has said should be at the heart of a new American military.
Mr. Rumsfeld began his day in Kiev where he met with the Ukrainian president and minister of defense to discuss the nation's recent political crisis, its efforts at military and economic reform and missile defense. Washington views Ukraine as an important buffer against Russia but has been alarmed by the recent ouster of its Western-minded prime minister, Viktor Yushchenko, and accusations that its president, Leonid D. Kuchma, ordered the killing last year of a journalist, Georgy Gongadze.
Mr. Rumsfeld said in a news conference after his meetings that he had been "impressed with the very solid commitment" of the Kuchma government to making political reforms and strengthening ties to the West. But he said he also urged Mr. Kuchma to conduct "a thorough and transparent" investigation into the death of Mr. Gongadze.

 BODY:

HEADLINE: A New Flight Plan 

 BODY:
Summertime nears, and the flying is not easy. Passengers experienced record delays in each of the past two summers, partly as a result of the air traffic system's failure to keep up with growing demand for air travel. Despite recent improvements, this summer may be no better, especially if some airlines are crippled by labor troubles. But there are heartening signs that the widespread outrage expressed by millions of inconvenienced fliers, and not a few members of Congress, may have galvanized the Federal Aviation Administration and others into formulating long-term solutions to what is not only an exasperating consumer issue but a serious economic one as well. 
 Today the F.A.A. will outline a comprehensive 10-year air traffic control modernization plan aimed at increasing the system's capacity by a third. Rather than a silver bullet, the plan is a long list of needed piecemeal measures, many of them previously announced, aimed at dealing with four categories of problems: capacity constraints at major airports, congestion en route, bad weather at airports and bad weather en route. Over all, the plan is estimated to cost $11.5 billion. 
 Skeptics will rightly point to the F.A.A.'s poor record of living up to its own ambitious goals in the past. The agency famously wasted several billion dollars in a failed modernization program launched in the 1980's, leading many of its critics to call for the air traffic control system's privatization. The agency, as a result, has preferred in recent years to make changes in a quiet, decentralized fashion. 
But even though many of this plan's components are already in the works, it was important for Jane Garvey, the F.A.A. administrator, to pull them all together into one coherent strategy. The severity of the current situation requires an ambitious response, and a move to privatize the agency would be likely to delay action, if not create further problems. The agency's plan rightly signals a sense of urgency and accountability. Rather than trying to monitor seemingly unrelated actions, the public and the Congress can now hold the agency to its plan's concrete timetable and promised improvements. 
Most of the 10-year plan's items entail building new infrastructure like runways or deploying technology, notably satellite-based navigation, to make better use of existing capacity. An F.A.A. study released in April of the nation's 31 busiest airports, which are used by more than 70 percent of the nearly two million daily passengers, showed that many of them are operating beyond their capacity. Some airlines are adjusting their schedules as a result, particularly at their hubs. 
Over the next decade new runways will be built at half of the busiest airports. Where capacity cannot be expanded, as at La Guardia in New York, the F.A.A. will look to new market-based means of rationing scarce landing slots. New ground radar will also allow for a safer and more efficient use of existing runway capacity. 
Greater flexibility is the operative word when it comes to improving the flow of airborne traffic. New weather-forecasting computers and closer coordination between air traffic control and airlines is expected to enhance the ability of flights to react to weather with shorter notice. Formerly restricted swaths of military and Canadian air space will also provide alternate routes around storms. 
Reliance on satellite navigation systems will be phased in, altering the old control-tower-to-cockpit dynamic. Pilots will be empowered to plot their own, more direct flight paths instead of being confined to existing jetways established by ground-based radar stations. More complete and reliable data in the cockpit also means that spacing between aircraft can be safely reduced. 
The modernization plan's more than 50 separate items add up to a realistic response to the current gridlock in the skies. But to work, it will require unprecedented cooperation between the F.A.A., airport authorities, airlines and contractors.

HEADLINE: Iran's Leader Says U.S., to Improve Ties, Must Ease Policy 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: TEHRAN, June 5 

 BODY:
President Mohammad Khatami, who is seeking to be re-elected on Friday, said today that the United States would have to change its policies toward Iran if relations are to improve. 
 "I see no obstacle in relations between the Iranian and American people," he said. "But American politicians ignore the interests of their people and American companies that want to invest in the region and Iran's growing economy. They need to make fundamental changes in these policies." 
 He also said the American economic sanctions on Iran were a major barrier to normalizing relations, adding, "The United States has been the source of much harm to Iran." 
The United States severed relations with Iran after students seized the American Embassy in November 1979, taking 52 Americans hostage for 444 days.
After his election in 1997, Mr. Khatami reached out to the United States with a call for "a dialogue of civilization." The Clinton administration relaxed sanctions, and Mr. Khatami made some overtures to Washington, but little progress has been made on improving relations.
At a news conference today, less than 48 hours before Mr. Khatami and his nine rivals wind up the election campaign, Mr. Khatami appeared decisive and in a good mood, contrary to a month ago, when he tearfully announced his candidacy. 
He defended the performance of his government and, without giving specifics, said his government had gone through "a tunnel of crisis" in the last four years.
"But I believe that we have succeeded because these crises and tensions did not lead to turmoil," he said. "And secondly, we never compromised on our pledge with people for the establishment of democracy and the rule of law. What I will not do is surrender to violence and extremism in this country." 
Mr. Khatami won in 1997 with nearly 70 percent of the votes. His supporters hope he can attract a large turnout on Friday as a stamp of approval for the reform movement.
Mr. Khatami is expected to win easily. But because there are a large number of candidates, his margin may be small. 
Ahmad Bourghani, a reformist close to the president, said Mr. Khatami's headquarters had arranged for 100 talks around the country during the campaign. 
Mr. Khatami also sent a message to his supporters today, indicating how a large turnout will matter. "The more votes the president gets, the more confidently he can carry out his plans," he said. "He can perform his duties more from the bottom of his heart."

GRAPHIC: Photo: At a news conference yesterday in Tehran, President Mohammad Khatami joked with reporters, even as he warned Washington to relax sanctions. He is expected to be re-elected on Friday. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Business Travel; 
The day of private supersonic jets may not be far off.

BYLINE:  By Joe Sharkey; The Business Travel column appears each Wednesday. E-mail:jsharkey@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
A BIG new Boeing Business Jet costs about $40 million, stripped. Add maybe $5 million more for furnishings and interior finishes and equipment, and you've basically got yourself a Boeing 737, refitted as a fancy private corporate jet.
 The BBJ, as it is known, has more than double the cabin space of its closest luxury competitor, the Gulfstream V series. It carries about 18 passengers, who ride on leather seats and plush sofas. Most models also have a conference room, two bathrooms with showers, and a bedroom with a queen-size bed. 
 Since the plane has a maximum range of about 6,600 miles, that means you can hole up in an airborne hotel room from New York to Cairo. "You can walk into the bedroom, close the door and go to sleep," said Richard T. Santulli, the chief executive of Executive Jet, the leading company in the business of selling fractional shares of corporate jets to corporations. 
So it doesn't get any better than this, does it? Actually, it might -- at least for those who argue persuasively enough that time is money. The day of the supersonic private business jet might well be approaching. 
Now that comfort, range, arguable bottom-line value and airline-free convenience are a given in the business-jet market, "the last major improvement will be breaking that speed barrier, and being able to do it economically," said Lee D. Monson, a vice president for sales at Boeing, who predicts that cost-effective supersonic business jets will become a reality "hopefully within the next 5 to 10 years."
Boeing is now talking with airlines about the design and manufacturing of a prospective new and fast commercial airliner, known as the Sonic Cruiser, that is tentatively being planned to fly just below the speed of sound. "We certainly are not committed as a company yet to go supersonic," Mr. Monson said.
Aircraft systems manufacturers like Boeing, Northrop Grumman, Lockheed Martin and others are, however, involved in government-sponsored research projects on the feasibility of more widespread supersonic flight. Once technological problems are solved and demand is clear, "we'll be in a position to be able to take advantage of it," Mr. Monson said. 
The two big technological obstacles are noise -- the sonic booms created when aircraft exceed the speed of sound -- and high maintenance costs. The commercial Concorde, grounded since a crash that killed 113 in France last summer, was notorious for high maintenance. Since Concordes mostly flew over the ocean, sonic-boom complaints were not a big factor.
The United States Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency is financing research projects, for both military and civilian use, into developing supersonic engines and airframes that, according to the agency, will fly "over land without adverse sonic-boom consequences."
"The consensus is very definitely, if you can't fly it over land, it isn't going to get built, because nobody's going to buy it," said Bill Dane, a senior aerospace analyst at Forecast International/DMS, an aerospace research firm that predicted "renewed emphasis" on development of supersonic business jets after the grounding of the Concorde. 
Mr. Dane said that aerospace engineers generally believed the sonic-boom noise problem was ready to be solved. "The implication seems to be, yes, if the money's there, we can completely eliminate it, or reduce it at least to the point where nobody's going to complain," he said. 
"If you can do that, you'd have a huge market," said Mr. Santulli, whose company, which was acquired in 1998 by Warren E. Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway, has said it will order a substantial number of supersonic jets immediately if the noise and excessive maintenance problems are solved. 
The price tag for a supersonic business jet is generally estimated to be $80 million to $100 million -- which experts say means that its main market will be in fractional ownership deals.
As to speed, "everybody seems to think it's going to have to be about Mach 1.5," or one and a half times the speed of sound, Mr. Dane said. The Concorde flies at about Mach 2.
Speed is the final frontier in business aviation, said Steven P. Brechter, the chief operating officer of Executive Jet. Billion-dollar deals are done by executives who meet face-to-face and then want to get home fast, he said; for them, "it's not about opulence, it's about time."
Records from the company's NetJets fractional ownership program show that many clients with a share in one type of aircraft, on occasion, require the use of another model, which the company arranges. The company's fleet ranges from seven-passenger Cessna Citations, which are made by Textron's Cessna Aircraft Company, to the top-of-the-line models like Gulfstream V's, manufactured by a unit of General Dynamics, and the new BBJ's. 
Many owners sometimes ask to use another type of plane, he said. But not those who own shares of the Cessna Citation X models, which, flying at Mach 0.92 (about 600 miles an hour), are the fastest business jets currently available.
The eight-passenger Citation X has a relatively tight cabin that is 5.7 feet high and 5.5 feet wide. By comparison, cabins in the fancier 13-passenger Gulfstream V's are 6.2 feet high and 7.3 feet wide. (The BBJ cabin is 7.1 feet high and 11.6 feet wide). 
But customers of the Citation X -- which flies coast to coast about 45 minutes faster than any other business jet -- typically decline to accept a temporary upgrade, even to a Gulfstream V. 
"The people who own the Citation X bought it for the speed," he said. "They dig their heels in for that extra 45 minutes."

HEADLINE: Productivity Declines 1.2%; Its Largest Drop Since 1993 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
The productivity of American workers declined 1.2 percent in the first quarter, the sharpest drop since 1993, as labor costs increased at the fastest rate in a decade, the Labor Department reported yesterday.
 After the boom of the late 1990's, which was fueled by investments in technology to help make productivity more efficient, this measure of the output of American workers was bound to decline, economists said. But the drop in productivity has created a debate over what level of growth is sustainable. 
 "It is the most important question facing the economy for the next five years," said Ian Shepherdson, the chief domestic economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y. "It makes a heck of a big difference in how the economy performs over a generation compared to its past performance and compared to other countries." 
Higher labor costs squeezed corporate profit margins in the first quarter. Unit labor costs -- the amount of labor expense to produce goods and services -- rose at seven times the pace of the increase in wages. The amount that workers received, adjusted for increases in consumer prices and other factors, rose at an annual rate of 0.9 percent, the lowest since the end of 1999, even though unit labor costs increased 6.3 percent.
In its preliminary figures, the Labor Department reported that productivity, which had increased annually at an average rate of 2.8 percent since 1995, declined 0.1 percent in the first quarter, the first drop in six years.
After the Commerce Department lowered its estimate of the economy's overall growth, the Labor Department had been expected to lower its productivity figures. Still, the extent of the revision, to a decline of 1.2 percent, surprised economists who had been predicting a drop of 0.8 percent.
The increase in labor costs comes at a time businesses are already struggling with smaller profits because of falling demand and excessive inventories. Higher labor costs are "a lagged response to the increase in headline inflation that took place in 1999 and into 2000," said John Youngdahl, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs. 
"We had very tight labor markets throughout that period," Mr. Youngdahl said, "and workers had a lot of leverage. They were able to claw back some of the costs they were experiencing."
In the manufacturing sector, productivity fell 2.1 percent, instead of increasing 0.3 percent as initially reported. Productivity in the manufacturing of durable goods fell 2.4 percent, while productivity in nondurable goods fell 2 percent. Output fell at a sharper rate than hours worked, the Labor Department said.
For all businesses except agriculture, Americans worked 2.2 percent more hours than in the previous quarter, and their output increased 1 percent. In the first quarter of 1993, the last time productivity declined, Americans worked 3.9 percent more hours and their output declined 1.3 percent. At that time, labor costs rose 5.8 percent, compared with the latest quarter's rise of 6.3 percent, the biggest increase since a 6.8 percent jump in the last three months of 1990.
The difference, and the reason some economists say that the drop in productivity is temporary, is that workers' output is still rising. The technological advances that fueled the economic boom have created a new class of highly paid workers, but they have also allowed businesses to quickly respond to shifts in demand and overstocked inventories.
New data emerged yesterday indicating that workers' output has declined since the second quarter began. For the service sector, the National Association of Purchasing Management said its nonmanufacturing index fell to 46.6 in May, from 47.1 in April, showing a significant contraction. Economists had expected the index to rise to 47.8.
And factory orders fell 3 percent, to $336.94 billion in April, the Commerce Department reported. The decline was most pronounced in orders for washing machines, refrigerators and other long-term investments that consumers make when they feel confident and when credit markets are loose. Economists had expected a drop of 2.8 percent.
The Federal Reserve has lowered short-term interest rates five times for a total of 2.5 percentage points this year, and many investors say they believe that Alan Greenspan, the central bank's chairman, and other Fed policy makers will act to lower rates again later this month. That action, combined with the increased spending from the tax cut, could help the economy maintain a productivity growth rate close to 3 percent, some economists said.

HEADLINE: Turner's U.N. Fund Plans World Resource Survey 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 5 

 BODY:
One of the most ambitious projects to assess global environmental damage from the rapid consumption of natural resources was announced today by an unusual coalition of scientists, corporations, foundations and international agencies. 
 Timothy E. Wirth, president of the United Nations Foundation, a sponsor of the project, called it "the first global report card on our environment." The fund, set up in 1997 with a 10-year $1 billion grant from Ted Turner, founder of CNN, has been looking for environmental projects to support. It has already made grants in areas like women's and girls' health. 
 In March, it approved its largest donation, $10 million, for a campaign to save endangered coral reefs. The fund will give $4 million to the effort to give the earth a physical checkup.
Other contributors include the World Resources Institute in Washington, whose president, Jonathan Lash, was instrumental in developing the project; the Global Environment Facility, set up after the Rio de Janeiro summit meeting on the environment in 1992; the David and Lucile Packard Foundation; and the World Bank.
Officials expect the project to cost $21 million, with $17 million already pledged. Up to 1,500 scientists will be asked to volunteer for the cause. Secretary General Kofi Annan, formally introducing the program today, said that it was "designed to bring the world's best science to bear on the present choices we face in managing the global environment."
The project, set up and run by the United Nations Environment Program, will also benefit from 16,000 satellite images donated by NASA. 
Officials expect a final report to be published in 2005, with interim studies released occasionally. 
At a news session today, Mr. Wirth, a former senator from Colorado and a former under secretary of state for global affairs, called the survey the first real assessment on the earth's life-support systems. 
"Why is this important?" he asked. "The very basic fact is that we are living off our ecological capital, and if we continue this approach, we will soon discover that this is a bankrupt way for us to operate. The bulk of our economy is rooted in five biological systems -- crop lands, forests, grasslands, oceans and freshwater ways. When the environment is forced to file for bankruptcy under Chapter 11 because its resource base has been polluted, degraded, dissipated and irretrievably compromised, then the economy goes down to bankruptcy with it, and so does everything else."
Angela Cropper of Trinidad and Tobago, a development expert who will be a scientific panel co-leader, saw much preliminary evidence. "Coral reefs are dying, the forests are being degraded and disappearing -- these things have to be rehabilitated," she said. "Fish stocks are being significantly depleted."
She said the world would have to learn to regulate and manage dwindling natural resources. 
Mr. Lash of the resources institute added that two-thirds of the agricultural lands were seriously degraded and that the number of people who depended on those lands for food was expanding. To revive that land, water is needed, among other items. 
"Water use is rising twice as fast as population," he said. "Seventy percent of water is used for irrigation, and that suggests a set of trends that simply do not lead to a good outcome."
Calling the report crucial to understanding how to deal with growing human pressures on resources, Mr. Lash said, "If it's successful, in a few years you will have a good statement of the state of the world's health in terms of its capacity to produce the goods and services that support all human well-being and prosperity -- food, clean water, fiber, the materials that make our world possible."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Nasdaq Leads Shares Higher, Despite Economic Reports

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
Stocks rose yesterday as investors, buoyed by positive news from technology companies, shrugged off several disappointing economic reports.
 Lucent Technologies and Xilinx both issued reassuring financial projections, helping to set off a rally in technology stocks. 
 "The public's back," said Jeffrey Saut, chief market strategist at Raymond James & Associates. "You couldn't get people to pry loose of their cash with a nuclear device back at the end of March and April. With the upside momentum that's been generated here, now they're excited." 
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index climbed 77.73 points, or 3.6 percent, to close at 2,233.66. 
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 114.32 points, or 1 percent, to 11,175.84. And the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 16.46 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,283.57.
Analysts said investors paid little attention to a series of economic indicators released yesterday that confirmed the widely held belief that the American economy remained weak. And the market's activity was only slightly tempered by the expectation of dismal earnings forecasts in the next few weeks, they said.
"The economic news is going to get worse before it gets better, but the market has the opportunity to continue upward," said Francis D. Gannon, a senior equity portfolio manager at SunAmerica Asset Management.
Yesterday's technology rally was led by Lucent, one of the day's most actively traded stocks, which gained 49 cents, to $8.49. Henry Schacht, Lucent's chairman and chief executive, told analysts yesterday at a trade show in Atlanta that the company's sales and earnings would improve over the second quarter.
Xilinx surged $4.02, to $45.61, after the company, a maker of specialty semiconductors, said its losses in the second quarter would be within the range it had expected and that order cancellations had slowed.
The news from Lucent and Xilinx spurred buying interest in other technology companies. Shares of Cisco rose $1.81, to $21.54; Microsoft gained $1.82, to $72.60; and Qualcomm was up $1.58, to $63.52. 
Shares of Intel rose $1.23, to $29.73. Other semiconductor stocks also rose, pushing the Philadelphia semiconductor index up 40.92 points, or 6.7 percent, to 647.90.
Computer makers and storage companies displayed strength as well. I.B.M. rose $3.33, to $116.97; EMC was up $2.85, to $34.50; Sanmina gained 99 cents, to $27.41; and Brocade was up $4.24, to $43.49.
Among the nontechnology stocks that pushed the Dow higher was Boeing, which rose 90 cents, to $66.93, after it secured a $4 billion contract with the United States Air Force to upgrade 500 of its C-130 transports.
Johnson & Johnson gained $2.05, to $102.19, after a UBS Warburg analyst, David Lothson, reiterated his strong buy rating for the company. --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
By Bloomberg News
Bond prices rose yesterday, pushing yields to a one-month low, after evidence of a slowdown in the service industries bolstered expectations for a sixth interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve this year.
"Weakness branching out beyond manufacturing may force the Fed's hand," and that is helping bonds, said Bruce Alston, who manages $1.5 billion at Value Line.
Bonds advanced after the National Association of Purchasing Management said its index of retail, construction and other nonmanufacturing businesses fell last month to its lowest level in four years.
The price of the benchmark 10-year note rose 14/32 , to 98. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.27 percent from 5.32 percent on Monday.
The 30-year bond rose 13/32 , to 96 1/32 . Its yield fell to 5.65 percent from 5.68 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
3 Interpublic Agencies Are Michelin Finalists

BYLINE:  By Bernard Stamler 

 BODY:
Michelin North America in Greenville, S.C., has narrowed a review for its account, with billings estimated at $30 million to $60 million, to three agencies from six.
 The finalists are three units of the Interpublic Group of Companies: Campbell-Ewald in Warren, Mich.; Carmichael Lynch in Minneapolis; and the Martin Agency in Richmond, Va., part of the Lowe Group unit of Interpublic. 
 The three agencies that were eliminated were Merkley Newman Harty in New York, part of the Omnicom Group; Leo Burnett USA in Chicago, part of the Leo Burnett Worldwide unit of the Bcom3 Group; and the Richards Group in Dallas.
A final decision is expected by early next month.
The Michelin North America account had been at the New York office of DDB Worldwide, part of Omnicom, for 17 years. It was eliminated from the review in April when Michelin, a unit of Compagnie Generale des Etablissements Michelin in France, selected the six agencies as semifinalists.
DDB New York laid off 26 employees out of 450 this week and is eliminating an unspecified number of posts that have been vacant. Marianne Flatley, a spokeswoman for DDB New York, attributed the staff reductions to "a general softening of the economy" rather than the recent loss of several accounts, including Michelin.
Also this week, the DDB office in Chicago laid off 28 employees out of 800. Amy Hoffar, a spokeswoman for DDB Chicago, attributed those layoffs to "the loss of the General Mills and Energizer accounts, reduced spending from a number of clients and the effect of a weakening economy."

HEADLINE: OPEC Maintains Output Levels, With Another Look in July 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

DATELINE: VIENNA, June 5 

 BODY:
The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries decided today to delay an increase in production levels, a move that could push crude oil prices higher in coming weeks if Iraq makes good on a threat to keep its oil off world markets.
 At a meeting at headquarters here, OPEC members agreed to meet again on July 3 to consider increasing output if a reduction by Iraq led to steeper prices. 
In its official statement, OPEC said, "Having reviewed the oil market situation and supply-demand expectations for the forthcoming period, the conference noted that stocks of both crude oil and products are at satisfactory levels."
OPEC is gambling that it can maintain relatively high though stable prices in the near term, as it has done for the last six months. Analysts said that individual countries like Saudi Arabia, the largest producer, would probably fill in for Iraq and informally supply more oil to major markets, like the United States. 
Yet at the same time, the analysts here and oil traders in the United States worried that such substitutions might not be sufficient as Americans enter the peak driving season and demand for gasoline increases.
"If we keep Iraqi oil off the market for a few weeks, it will have an impact," said Thomas P. Bentz, senior energy analyst with BNP Paribas in New York. "Supplies will tighten and prices will rise."
Today, the commodities markets reacted calmly to OPEC's action, which had been expected. In New York, crude oil for July delivery edged up 11 cents, to $28.24 a barrel. In London, Brent crude oil for July settlement rose 42 cents, or 1.4 percent, to $29.68 a barrel. 
On Monday, prices rose as much as 2.9 percent during the session on the news of the Iraqi embargo, then slid back, settling slightly higher, apparently reflecting doubts about Iraq's resolve. Late last year, Baghdad halted exports for several weeks before gradually increasing them again. Iraq exports about 2.5 million barrels a day, or about 3 percent of the world's oil.
Iraq said on Sunday that it would not resume oil exports until the United Nations Security Council backed down on a resolution adopted last week that extended the oil-for-food program by only a month instead of the usual six months. The Council voted for the stopgap extension to allow more time to consider a British-American proposal for a complete overhaul of the sanctions against the Iraqis. London and Washington propose lifting restrictions on civilian imports while cracking down on oil smuggled out to Iraqi neighbors. 
"A lot of traders feel that Iraq is like the little boy who cried wolf," said Phillip J. Flynn, senior market analyst for Alaron, a trading firm in Chicago, "and they think it will come back."
OPEC, by its successful managing of oil prices over the last six months, has gained a degree of credibility on world oil markets that it had lacked. Since January, the 10-member group has twice reduced production, totaling 2.5 million barrels a day, as the global economy slowed and oil demand with it. 
Supply and demand, analysts said, have so far found a balance. Oil prices have fluctuated between $25 and $29 a barrel, raining revenue into the economies of the OPEC nations.
Yet even at those prices, supplies of crude oil have risen. After markets closed today, the American Petroleum Institute reported that United States inventories of crude oil had risen 3.4 million barrels, to 325.3 million, from 321.9 million barrels a week ago. Gasoline supplies rose more than 3.1 million barrels, to 209.3 million. That compares with 203.1 million barrels this time a year ago.
"Over the last five months, OPEC and especially the Saudis, have kept prices high yet stable," said Roger Diwan, managing director of the Petroleum Finance Company, a Washington consultancy. "They have convinced the market of their ability." 
OPEC's unwillingness to act stems from a fear of touching off a sharp fall in oil prices. OPEC countries maintain that there is sufficient crude oil in the United States and that high gasoline prices are a function of crimped domestic refining capacity. They also worry about introducing more oil onto the market as the world economy weakens. 
Iraq's decision to halt oil shipments adds uncertainty to OPEC's calculations. Though Iraq belongs to OPEC, its export quotas are set by the United Nations under the sanctions set up after the Persian Gulf war ended in 1991, and the Iraqis have no vote in OPEC decisions. The revenue Iraq receives from oil exports is monitored by the U.N. to ensure that it is not used to finance Saddam Hussein's military aims -- an effort many say has failed.
"Iraq sees these 'smart sanctions' as sanctions that will never be lifted," said Vera de Ladoucette, director of Middle East research for Cambridge Energy Research Associates. "They don't see it as an improvement of their situation."
With OPEC holding to its current quotas and Saudi Arabia expected to make up for some of the lost Iraqi oil, specialists pondered the total effect.
"There are two clear indications that the Saudis will supply more oil to the market," said Edward L. Morse, executive adviser at the Hess Energy Trading Company. "First, last December, when the Iraqis did this, the Saudis exceeded their export quota by a significant amount. And secondly, they said to the U.S. government and the press they would do it."
The question is whether the additional Saudi output, or even a possible OPEC increase in July, would be enough to meet summer demand in the United States. It takes about 45 days for oil from the Persian Gulf to reach the United States. By the time a July increase reached American drivers, the supplies of crude oil and gasoline already here might easily have thinned, with retail prices, already increased, rising further. 
And if OPEC does add supplies, will it be able to keep up a high level of production if Iraq remains sidelined? Before the export cuts this year, most OPEC members were producing near capacity.
Much may depend on how long Iraq can go without oil revenue. Analysts estimate that it has about $5 billion in cash from the oil-for-food program it can use.
"Smart sanctions are a cornerstone of Colin Powell's Mideast policy," said Walid Khadduri, editor in chief of the Middle East Economic Survey, "and for Saddam Hussein, the old sanctions were a system he had successfully eroded for years. The stakes are too high for both sides to back down easily. How long can Iraq go without oil? From the war in 1990 to the start of oil for food, it went for six years."

HEADLINE: Transportation Chief Predicts Rejection of Airline Merger 

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 5 

 BODY:
The secretary of transportation said today that the proposed merger of United Airlines and US Airways would not be approved. 
 But both airlines disagreed with the assessment, and the Justice Department, which has final authority to approve or block the merger, said it was still evaluating the proposal. 
 The transportation secretary, Norman Y. Mineta, speaking to reporters at a luncheon at his office, said that he expected additional merger proposals "now that the United-US Airways proposal hasn't gone through." Asked whether he meant that it would never be approved, he said, "If I were to read the tea leaves as they are right now, yes." 
Mr. Mineta said his department had no role in the decision other than to advise the Justice Department, which was still conducting an antitrust review. A spokeswoman there, Gina Talamona, said this afternoon that the evaluation was continuing. 
With the comments, Mr. Mineta became the highest-ranking administration official to predict the outcome of the proposal.
He contrasted the United-US Airways merger application with the recently approved acquisition of Trans World Airlines by American Airlines.
"In that case, it was the ailing-carrier doctrine that allowed American Airlines to pick up T.W.A.," he said, adding that the combination gave American nearly a quarter of the passenger market. 
"We don't have a failing-carrier doctrine to rely on in this United Airlines-US Airways situation," he said.
He said that other carriers -- United, Delta, Northwest and Continental -- each with 11 percent to 17 percent of the market, would not "be able to sit out there with these kind of percentages trying to deal with a T.W.A.-American" with such a large market share. 
"Somewhere I think you're going to still find some consolidation going on," he said. "Who and where and in what form, I don't have the slightest idea."
At United, Susana Leyva, a spokeswoman, said, "We're still vigorously pursuing this acquisition." 
"The final regulatory review rests with the Department of Justice," Ms. Leyva said, adding that a number of elected officials of both parties have expressed their support.
United's senior vice president for finance, Jake Brace, said in April that no decision was expected before the end of June.
At US Airways, Lawrence M. Nagin, executive vice president and general counsel, said, "We are continuing to work constructively with the Department of Justice on the merger approval process."
Mr. Mineta also said today that he was concerned about the financial situation at Amtrak, and that the railroad might have to give up on a national rail system.
He compared Amtrak's rail service to margarine and said the railroad was trying to spread itself over the entire country.
"It may be," Mr. Mineta said, "that we're going to have to take a look at the Amtrak operations as Eastern Seaboard, Western Seaboard and maybe some kind of hub out of Chicago up to the Twin Cities, up to Detroit and down to New Orleans, and look at selected routes rather than trying to blanket the country with service that is not financially viable." 
He said he expected to be appointed soon by President Bush to the railroad's board.
But a spokesman for Amtrak, William Schulz, said in a telephone interview that the railroad's strategy since last year had been to add service "where it made economic sense."
The railroad recently announced plans for a new passenger train on Florida's east coast, Mr. Schulz said. "We believe there are other opportunities to expand service that make financial sense."
Congress has told the railroad to expect an end to operating subsidies by 2003. Mr. Schulz said that Amtrak was on its way to doing that, but Mr. Mineta said he was not sure and was concerned about a plan by the railroad to mortgage part of Pennsylvania Station in New York, which it owns, for $300 million. Mr. Schulz said Amtrak wanted the money to make up for revenue lost by the late introduction of its Acela service in the Northeast corridor.

HEADLINE: A Significant Lift for a Long-Ailing U.S. Industry 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
The Bush administration's efforts to limit steel imports won praise yesterday from industry executives, who said the action was long overdue, while analysts predicted the actions could provide relief to an industry suffering from a wave of bankruptcies and minimal profitability.
 "It's a significant move," said Aldo Mazzaferro, an industry analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company. "The administration has taken a major step to protect the industry. It will allow the steel industry to fully participate in any economic recovery." 
 For the last decade, the domestic steel industry has been awash in bad news. The Asian economic crisis of the late 1990's pushed down global steel prices, which have yet to recover. And while imports account for less of the domestic steel market than they did at the peak of the Asian crisis -- about 27 percent now, down from 30 percent -- steel prices have been so low that steelmakers complain that they are having a hard time making a profit, or even staying in business. 
Since late 1997, 18 steel companies in the United States have filed for bankruptcy, with five of those shutting down operations entirely. 
It is against this backdrop that the Bush Administration's action was soundly praised by industry executives. James G. Bradley, president of Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, termed the Bush decision "a major victory.
"It is an important message that the United States will not allow its steel industry to be destroyed by illegal steel imports," said Mr. Bradley, whose company is operating under bankruptcy protection. Thomas J. Usher, chairman of the U.S. Steel Corporation, said the action "sends a message to our trading partners that the United States will no longer be a dumping ground for the world's excess steel." 
Still, despite the industry's difficulties, domestic steel makers have seen their stocks outperform the overall stock market this year, even though they are still well below their historic highs. A reduction in domestic steelmaking capacity, as more steel mills are shuttered and recent decreases in interest rates help steel users finance purchases, have attracted investors' interest. And investors interested in undervalued stocks are looking for bargains in the steel industry. 
USX-U.S. Steel Corporation shares have risen 22 percent this year. Shares of Bethlehem Steel have gone up 122 percent, and shares of the Nucor Corporation have risen 40 percent. News of the president's action pushed the Standard & Poor's steel index up 6.7 percent yesterday to 49.09. 
Some analysts said the Bush action might simply accelerate the turn in the industry's fortunes. "I think we were ready to have good times, with or without the government," said John Tumazos, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. "The protectionist walls might go up. But the steel market would recover whatever the government does or doesn't do."
Peter F. Marcus, an analyst with World Steel Dynamics, a research firm, said the rise in steel industry stocks that preceded the Bush decision was a sign that "investors are guessing that the worst is over.
"It had been evident that the government was willing to seriously consider the plight of a number of steel companies," said Mr. Marcus. "And the drop in interest rates means that, at some point, the economy will get moving again. And when the government of a country says publicly that it wishes this industry were doing better, that's good for that industry."
In fact, if all goes well, the picture for steel makers could change greatly. "If there is a strong economic recovery," said Mr. Mazzaferro of Goldman, "and import quotas are in place, you have a steel shortage."

HEADLINE: Energy Crisis in Brazil Is Bringing Dimmer Lights and Altered Lives 

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 5 

 BODY:
At night, the lights on streets and beaches and in parks and tunnels are dimmed. Air-conditioners in the president's office have been turned off; nighttime sports events and concerts have been canceled. Government employees may soon be forced to shift to a six-hour work day, and private companies are talking of moving production abroad for the duration of the emergency.
 In response to what increasingly resembles a California-style energy crisis writ large, on Friday Brazil began at least six months of obligatory electricity rationing. 
 Three-quarters of the 170 million Brazilians have been told that they must immediately cut consumption by 20 percent or face rolling blackouts and unscheduled power interruptions, which would surely cripple the economy here, in Latin America's most populous nation. 
The government says the measures are needed because the country is in the throes of its worst drought in decades. With one of the most extensive river networks in the world, Brazil, which is larger than the continental United States, obtains more than 90 percent of its electricity from dams and has not invested extensively in alternatives.
Few ordinary Brazilians had any inkling of the seriousness of the crisis until the government announced the conservation measures in mid-May, sparing only the Amazon districts and the far south. But as the harsh reality of the situation sinks in, the initial shock and anger are giving way to a grim realization that nearly every aspect of life will be curtailed.
"We have been raised to think that ours is a land of abundance and riches, where nothing is ever lacking," said Lucina Trilho, a store clerk. "So yes, that may have led us to be wasteful. And yes, we may need to be re-educated. But it is going to be difficult, even frightening, to have to make all these adjustments."
Under the government plan, households that fail to meet conservation targets are to have their power supply cut for up to six days. Small consumers who manage to save more than 20 percent, on the other hand, will receive cash bonuses, while companies that cut consumption by more than that amount will be allowed to sell their extra savings to others.
Although Brazilians are used to government pronouncements that are quickly reversed or undermined, this time they are clearly taking the threats seriously: consumption fell by 10 percent even before the measures went into effect. 
"I've even disconnected the lights illuminating the little statue of the Virgin Mary in my living room," said Aurora Nascimento Fonseca, a jittery 81-year-old who lives on a small pension.
All across the country, in fact, the rationing plan and the penalties that go with it have set off a mad scramble to find ways to save electricity and money. Just try, for example, to buy a fluorescent bulb, flashlight, generator, gas-powered lantern, batteries or even candles.
"The demand for fluorescent lighting has shot up 1,000 percent in the last couple of weeks," said Eulalia Cardoso, a weary saleswoman at a hardware store where customers were lined up at the door. "We can't keep up with the requests, and neither can our suppliers. As soon as a new stock comes in, it immediately sells out."
Sales of electrical appliances, in contrast, have plummeted. As Miriam Leitao, a columnist for the daily O Globo, noted, items "formerly seen as symbols of status and comfort in residences are now being regarded with alarm and disconnected from their sockets."
In at least one sense, the timing of the government measures is propitious: with the Southern Hemisphere winter approaching, use of air-conditioners and fans is minimal. 
But most Brazilian households with power use electricity, not gas, to heat shower and bath water, which means millions must gird themselves for months of cold washes.
"At home, we're doing that and everything else we can to cut back on our electricity consumption," said Alfredo Rebello, a salesman whose monthly bill averages about $40. "We're watching television without lights on, doubling up the loads of laundry and disconnecting the coffee maker and microwave oven except when we have to use them."
Things are not much different at the office and residence of President Fernando Henrique Cardoso in Brasilia. 
"We're in the dark at the palace," the president said in a newspaper interview late last month. "We've turned off the outside illumination, and I've ordered all the interior lighting turned down, the refrigerators disconnected and the heat to the swimming pool turned off."
Here in Rio, a city of leisure-loving night owls, the municipal government has said the spotlights trained on Rio's most famous landmark, the statue of Christ atop Corcovado Mountain, will continue to shine. 
But outdoor street lighting has been cut by one-third, and nearly every nighttime activity in major cities is likely to be affected.
Gasoline stations across the country, for example, plan to shut from 10 p.m. to 6 a.m., which probably means fewer taxis and the loss of jobs for night-shift station attendants. Professional soccer games, concerts and other entertainments have been banned, but the level of protest has been less than expected because many people say they are afraid to go out into the darkened streets.
"The level of crime is already terrifying, so imagine how it is going to be with the streets darkened," said Maria Aparecida Guimaraes Gusmao, a 35-year-old homemaker. "I'm sure that the criminals are going to take advantage of these measures and that the ordinary citizen is going to remain at home, sitting in the dark."
The police plan more nighttime patrols, but the situation of other essential public services is less clear: barely half of Brazil's hospitals have generators, for instance, and private schools say they will have to struggle to cut consumption.
The rationing plan was first announced May 18. But the government's Energy Crisis Coordinating Committee continues to tinker with the measures, giving the impression that it is not in control of events and adding to the sense of confusion, frustration and uncertainty.
No sooner had the rationing been announced than lawyers said they planned to challenge it as unconstitutional. After a top energy official criticized judges "who must live on Mars," the government first issued a decree saying rationing takes precedence over the consumer protection code, which was to be the basis of the court case, but then backed down when a judge ruled otherwise.
Facing a long and costly legal battle, President Cardoso announced Monday that he was modifying a system of surcharges that had been a crucial part of the rationing effort. Even so, the public is irate.
"None of this would even be happening if the people in Brasilia had been doing their jobs properly all along," said Armando Tavares Araujo, an engineer. "I'm absolutely disgusted, indignant at the fact that we, the Brazilian people, are going to be made to suffer because for nearly 20 years the government hasn't planned ahead and kept up with demand."
Initially, the government had also said that if Brazilians met the conservation targets, that would be sufficient to avoid rolling blackouts. Now, though, officials are warning that it may become necessary to order the nation to adopt a four-day work week, giving employees Mondays off until the end of the year.
"All that is lacking is an official declaration that the country is in a state of emergency," Alcides Tapias, the minister of development, industry and commerce, said late last month in Sao Paulo, the business capital. "But in fact, that is the situation."
Brazil's economy, the eighth largest, grew a robust 4.4 percent last year, and initial forecasts were for a similar performance this year. But now, to the alarm of workers worried about their paychecks, those predictions are being scaled back by as much as half, raising fears of recession, inflation and the loss of foreign investment.
"Look, we're Brazilians, so we have already shown that can put up with just about anything," said Abrahao Miguel dos Reis Motta, a 29-year-old electrician. "But my big fear is that a lot of people are going to lose their jobs as companies cut back production, that this is not a temporary situation but the start of something that will only get worse and last for a long, long time."

HEADLINE: Diamonds Aren't Forever; 
After Years of Chasing the Next Koufax, Scouts Are Out

BYLINE:  By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY 

 BODY:
The drizzle fell steadily, the kind of weather that makes an old man ache. The New Jersey air stank of industrial solvents. It was beautiful. It was East Coast baseball.
 A group of gray men stood behind the backstop. They were major-league scouts of amateur talent, old-timers who when they meet a young ballplayer have the curious habit of examining his knuckles and inspecting the pads of his fingers. 
 They had come to this industrial patch near the turnpike to see the 17-year-old pitcher from St. Peter's Prep, Pete Duda, a right-hander who threw hard and had plenty of room in his chest to grow. Four old men: Eddie Ford; John Hagemann; Gil Bassetti, who works for the Baltimore Orioles; and a Catholic priest known in New Jersey more for his work behind the plate than in the pulpit. The four began a melancholic discourse about the waning life of a generation of meat-and-potato scouts in the Northeast. 
To hear the old-timers, they are an endangered species, for a variety of reasons. Bitterness shapes their theories, but so does cold reality, like the fact that more and more ballplayers are coming from foreign countries.
Some of the scouts think the front offices of major-league baseball teams are now filled with Ivy League bean counters more interested in the bottom line than in the box score. In this age of $250 million contracts, the relatively modest money scouts receive -- usually about $50,000 a year -- still gets plenty of belt-tightening attention.
New York is considered the densest, toughest, most difficult territory in the country to scout for amateur talent. The high school season is short, about six weeks. It is cold and dark and soggy, unlike Florida or California, where kids play year round on beautifully groomed fields rather than the mud lots and rock piles of the East Coast.
Some big-league stars have come out of the region: John Franco, Manny Ramirez, Jeff Bagwell, Mo Vaughn. But, weighing resources, baseball executives think they are more likely to find the new superstar in the Dominican Republic than in Danbury, Conn. So the old Northeastern scouts find themselves expendable or spread increasingly thin.
"Resources are moving south to the Caribbean, Venezuela and now the Pacific Rim," said Al Goldis, assistant to the general manager of the Cincinnati Reds, himself a former scout. He said clubs today tended to go with younger scouts who, armed with computers, can cover more ground. "The New York area has become less important in the scheme of things. The thinking is: give these young guys a straw hat, a stopwatch and a radar gun and send them on their way."
Mr. Hagemann, 63, spent the last 17 years combing the backwoods and the blacktop of the region for the Atlanta baseball club -- a Brave in Yankee country. Then in March, the Atlanta Braves announced the dismissal of 10 scouts and minor-league personnel, and Mr. Hagemann, well respected and well paid, was gone.
"I'm a pretty sophisticated man," Mr. Hagemann said. "I know what's happening with corporate America, but I honestly believed baseball was beyond that. I was wrong big time."
The decision came from New York. The Atlanta Braves became part of the AOL Time Warner conglomerate in January when America Online merged with Time Warner. Since the merger, the company has eliminated nearly 2,500 jobs. One of those on the list of the eliminated was Mr. Hagemann, who was instrumental in the trade for John Smoltz, a skinny 19-year-old minor-league pitcher in the Detroit Tigers' farm system. Mr. Smoltz went on to become the National League Cy Young Award winner for the Braves in 1996.
According to Mr. Hagemann, he was done in by dot-com guys.
Costs did appear to play a role.
"It was a simple monetary decision," said one Braves official who exchanged his frankness for confidentiality. "Sad but true. He cost too much."
"Ah, John, you deserved it," Mr. Ford managed to say through the whole pouch of chewing tobacco wadded in his mouth. "The question is: what took so long to fire you? We've been carrying you for years."
It was a joke, but Mr. Hagemann grimaced as though he were wearing a pair of ill-fitting shoes. "Yeah," he said. "I went from the penthouse to the outhouse before the first pitch of spring training was thrown."
Mr. Bassetti laughed, sipped his coffee and nodded. The same thing happened to him a few years ago. The Los Angeles Dodgers released him after 25 years. "Whole damn game has changed," he said.
Baseball scouts do not make the Hall of Fame. When average fans talk about the greatest of all time, they do not speak the names of Tony Lucadello, who in 50 years of scouting signed 50 big leaguers to amateur contracts before putting a revolver in his mouth in 1989 on a high school ball field in his hometown, Fostoria, Ohio; Hugh Alexander, known as Uncle Hughie, who had no left hand, couldn't pitch or hit, but knew promise when he saw it; or Ralph DiLullo, who always dreamed of signing a Hall of Famer and once almost did. But the Chicago Cubs were too cheap to sign a kid named Sandy Koufax.
The scout of amateur baseball talent, like John Hagemann, toils away in obscurity, gives his life over to the game. He crosses the country, combs the run-down ball fields, the streets and Little Leagues. He puts a million miles on his car, watches thousands of kids play the game, exists on buckets of fried chicken, sleeps in cheap motels and drinks plenty of bad coffee. His wife often eats dinner alone.
Not a single professional game could be played without the amateur scout. He is among the most knowledgeable people about baseball, the one responsible for finding the talent to put on the field.
The first whispers of such talent come from the "bird dogs," the local men like Mr. Ford who let the regional scouts know about the talented boys from the neighborhood. 
"The modern-day scout, he don't know nothing," said Mr. Ford, who used to scout for the Cubs. 
"They don't chew tobacco," he said. "They don't see six or seven games a day. They never played the game, and they couldn't tell a baseball from a watermelon." 
For these guys, the days are gone of scouting from behind the tree or the telephone pole or from the playground out in left field. The diamond in the rough, the farm boy or the swamp rat, is rarely found anymore. These days, every scout in the area knows about the big talent. Guys like Manny Ramirez, the Boston Red Sox slugger from Washington Heights, are heavily scouted and are as easy to find as a turkey in a supermarket.
It is the boys out of nowhere, kids like Rich Aurilia, the San Francisco Giants shortstop who leads the National League in hitting and who went to Xaverian High School in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, who are the true and increasingly rare finds. But who found him? In the scouting world, claims become matters of false credit, lies and pettiness.
"Since a guy gets drafted by a club before he gets signed to a contract, it's hard to know who was the first to spot him," Mr. Hagemann said. "But everybody now wants the credit, because everyone is trying to climb the scouting ladder into the front office. It didn't used to be like that. Guys wanted to be in the field, because they loved the game."
The young guys are little more than data collectors, the old guys say, their objectivity perhaps twisted by recent events. They say the young guys have no feel for the game. The radar gun can tell you the speed of the ball, but it never got a batter out. It doesn't tell you about a kid's aptitude. His head. His body potential. Scouts run in packs now. They share information. It didn't used to be that way, the old guys say.
Mr. Hagemann is unemployed, but still, he can't keep himself from these muddy games. Baseball is what he knows. He was a pitcher for the New York Giants AA farm team in the mid-50's, just a couple of dozen men away from Leo Durocher's bullpen. The game was there for him when his first wife died of cancer.
"Fifty years of baseball doesn't disappear with a pink slip," he said, his skin still tan from spring training in Florida, an Atlanta Braves World Series ring on his right hand.
"I don't like how they're treating the older guys," Mr. Hagemann said. "The front-office people aren't true baseball men like they were years ago. But the game will do all right. Baseball is bigger than any of us."
Mr. Ford smacked his pal on the back and spit out a puddle of tobacco juice.

(Photographs by Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Dutch Giant Buys Control of Mexican Insurer 

BYLINE:  By GRAHAM GORI 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, June 5 

 BODY:
Control of Mexico's largest insurer, Seguros Comercial America, will pass from a Mexican entrepreneur, Alfonso Romo, to the Dutch banking and insurance giant ING in a deal announced today.
 Mr. 
Romo, whose holding company is struggling with growing debts, will sell his 45 percent stake in the company to ING for $791 million. 
 ING, which bought 42 percent of the insurer last year for $809 million, said yesterday that it planned a tender offer for the other 13 percent of the company's shares, which are traded publicly. 
ING has expressed interested in strengthening its presence in Mexico, which is a relatively underexploited market, and elsewhere in North America. It recently bought 49 percent of Seguros Bital, another Mexican insurer. 
Similarly, over the last four years, New York Life acquired Seguros Monterrey-Aetna, GMAC acquired ABA Seguros, Kemper Insurance took over Seguros La Territorial, and a German insurer, Gerling, acquired Comesec. 
"This is a reflection of the tremendous growth prospect of Mexico's insurance industry," Francois Facon, a Latin American insurance analyst at J. P. Morgan Chase, said. He said the insurance business represents a little less than 2 percent of Mexico's gross domestic product; in the United States the figure is closer to 9 percent. 
The decline of Mr. Romo's fortunes is evident in his sale of the stake when others see so much promise in the business. In the last decade, Mr. Romo, whose business portfolio once ranged widely, has been concentrating on aggressively building up Seminis Inc., his biotechnology venture, now one of the world's largest breeders of genetically modified crop seeds. But the costs of the expansion program and the weak market for seeds have left his holding company, Savia, $1.4 billion in debt.
