HEADLINE: Another Chance to Make the Sale 

BYLINE:  By Alan Ehrenhalt; Alan Ehrenhalt, the executive editor of Governing magazine, is the author of "The Lost City."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Every once in a while a successful product, having fallen on hard times, comes back to the market in modest form, more or less as an experiment, to see if the old customer loyalty can be revived. This happened with Life magazine and Ipana toothpaste. It is happening now with the Democratic majority in the Senate. We are being asked to try out a 2001 limited edition of Democratic legislative power.
 For most of the past half-century, Democrats were dominant. They controlled the House for 40 years, starting in 1955, and the Senate for but six of those years. During much of that time they held roughly three-fifths of all the state legislative seats in the country. More recently, however, their product hasn't sold so well. 
 Now, thanks to the entrepreneurship of Senator James Jeffords, the product is on conspicuous display again -- at the Senate location. How will it sell? To answer that question, it's important to understand why the old version did so well in the first place. It's important, most of all, to understand what the product was.
The commodity that the Democratic Party sold successfully, until the debacle of 1994, wasn't an ideology or a platform. It was a collection of candidates who held on to power through a full quarter-century even as their ideas were viewed with suspicion by a majority of the electorate and their standard-bearers were at a distinct disadvantage in the more visible universe of presidential campaigns. 
Presidential politics is unlike the rest of politics. Outside the presidential fishbowl, talent and enterprise mean far more than public opinion or ideology. The results depend on thousands of individual candidates who must want the jobs badly enough to fight for them. This is the way Democrats won, year in and year out -- by producing a generation of candidates who could outtalk, outthink and outwork their Republican opposition.
It was the generation of Bill Clinton, of Al Gore, of Tom Daschle, and of officeholders at all levels of government who fit their profile: born in the early baby-boom years; educated in the 1960's and early 1970's; introduced to politics at the height of national ferment over Vietnam, civil rights and the environment. Consistently liberal on all these issues, they were also skillful and industrious enough to win whether the voters agreed with them or not. This may not be America's greatest generation of statesmen, but in terms of sheer political skill, we have rarely seen its equal. 
Take, for instance, Mr. Daschle of South Dakota, the new Senate majority leader. He graduated from college in 1969, spent three years in the Air Force and returned home disillusioned with the Vietnam War. He worked for an antiwar senator, returned home to plan his own Congressional campaign, rang 40,000 doorbells and took the general election by 139 votes. Once in office, he was tireless and unbeatable. Politics was his career and his life. Everyone who challenged him looked like an amateur.
Republicans, meanwhile, in a party suspicious of government, had difficulty attracting their brightest young people to public careers that shut out private employment for years at a time. The Republican Party produced a certain amount of careerist talent in this generation -- there was, after all, Newt Gingrich -- but not enough to compete for power effectively on all the fronts that the system required. Republicans had moments when the talent turned out -- as in 1980, when young conservatives all over the country were struck by Reagan tax-cut enthusiasm -- but the moments didn't last. Many of these candidates were back in private life within a few years, usually by their own preference. They tended to view running for office as a necessary evil, not a lifetime occupation.
Then came 1994, and the familiar Democratic world came apart. Democrats lost Congress; they lost 10 governorships; they lost control of legislative chambers all over the country. Millions of words have been written about the 1994 election and its consequences, and yet none of the standard explanations -- the Clinton health care fiasco, the congressional bank scandals, the revolt of the "angry white male" -- is entirely convincing.
There is, however, another explanation for what happened. The Democratic Party's superiority in talent, energy and commitment finally gave out. The liberal baby boom cohort was no longer entering politics, and the generation taking its place lacked any of the critical enthusiasm or motivation. There was no Vietnam, no civil rights movement, no perceived environmental crisis. There was no longer much sense of possibility about government in general -- little conviction that government could be the instrument for solving the hardest social and economic problems of the time.
And so, given a push from some short-term public issues and frustrations, the whole edifice collapsed. The Republicans didn't exactly seize power in 1994, even though it may have looked that way. The Democrats relinquished it. It wasn't so much that young conservatives had suddenly developed a craving for politics; it was that liberals had lost theirs.
This theory, if right, suggests what the Democratic Party needs to do as it gets another, albeit limited, opportunity: persuade bright young people that there are issues worthy of the sacrifices a political career entails.
Easier said than done. There are no Vietnams or civil rights dramas to attract youthful enthusiasm. But there are other things. The rise of the global economy and the growing dominance of impersonal market forces over everyday life -- from health care to telecommunications -- are creating new issues everywhere in the political system. Dealing with these issues will be a messy job, but somebody will have to do it -- in fact, thousands of people. The struggle to attract them is the one Democrats must win to reclaim their role as the party of government in the 21st century.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Michael Bierut)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
U.S. Takes First Steps To Limit Steel Imports
President Bush took the first steps toward imposing broad restrictions on imported steel, handing a victory to steel companies and unions that have long urged the government to grant relief from foreign competition.
 The president's action, which initiates a challenge to imports and could result in higher tariffs on foreign-made steel within months, goes beyond any protections that the Clinton administration proposed and is certain to raise tensions with trading partners. Page A1. 

Worker Productivity Falls 1.2%
The productivity of American workers declined 1.2 percent in the first quarter, the sharpest drop since 1993, as labor costs increased at the fastest rate in a decade, the Labor Department reported. And factory orders fell 3 percent, to $336.94 billion in April, the Commerce Department reported. Economists had expected a drop of 2.8 percent. C2.

Stocks rose as investors shrugged off the economic reports. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 77.73 points, or 3.6 percent, to 2,233.66. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 114.32 points, or 1 percent, to 11,175.84. And the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 16.46 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,283.57. C10.

Doubt Expressed on Airline Merger
The secretary of transportation said that the proposed merger between United Airlines and US Airways would not be approved. Both airlines denied it, though, and the Justice Department, which has final authority, said it was still evaluating the proposal. C10.

Tech Analyst to Open Hedge Fund
Jonathan Cohen, one of the few Wall Street technology analysts who preached caution during the bull market, is starting a hedge fund. Market Place. C7.

Pension Fund Manager to Be Sold
Joining a wave of consolidation among asset management companies, New York Life's investment arm plans to announce today that it is buying McMorgan, a privately held San Francisco firm that is a leader in managing union pension funds. C4.

Goldman Shifting Two Executives
Goldman Sachs plans to promote the top two executives of its brokerage business, Philip Murphy and Peter Kraus, to be co-heads of its investment management division after John P. McNulty retires this month. C2.

A Balance From Music and Yoga
Knight Kiplinger, editor and publisher of The Kiplinger Letter and Kiplinger's Personal Finance magazine, sings in the Washington Chorus. "When I'm part of an artistic whole, standing in front of a demanding conductor," he said, "I forget that I'm a journalist and the boss of a company -- which feels good." He has started taking yoga classes. "Singing and yoga, these are the kinds of things that give balance to a life." The Boss. C9.

Lucent Plans to Offer Buyouts
Lucent Technologies plans to offer more than 10,000 managers early retirement packages in yet another effort by the cash-short company to cut costs. It is not clear how many managers would receive and accept buyout offers. C6.

Amazon.com to Sell Computers
Amazon.com said it intended to start selling personal computers in the next few months and reiterated its intention to be profitable, on an operating basis, in the fourth quarter. C6.

Ex-Hewlett Chief to Quit at Winery
Lewis E. Platt, who left the top job at Hewlett-Packard for a second career as a winemaker, said that he was resigning as the chief executive of Kendall-Jackson Wine Estates. C7.

Next for Business Jets: More Speed
Now that comfort, range, bottom-line value and airline-free convenience are a given in the business-jet market, the last major improvement will be supersonic jets, which may not be far off. Joe Sharkey: Business Travel. C8.

HEADLINE: Wattage Where It's Needed 

BYLINE:  By Roger Anderson; Roger Anderson is director of the Energy Research Center at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory at Columbia University.

 BODY:
President Bush's energy plan, to its credit, takes on in a coherent way all of the supply and demand elements that make up the nation's energy system, something not attempted since the Carter administration. And as the long view demands, the plan calls for a national system of power transmission -- a national electricity grid. Our increasing use of computers, requiring ever more electricity, makes this grid an absolute necessity.
 Historically, demand for electricity jumped after each of three technological breakthroughs: lights and motors in the early 1900's, air conditioning in the 1950's, and the rise of personal computers and the Internet in the 1980's and 1990's. Many Americans are unaware of this last enormous surge in electricity use, and the current experience in California suggests we are not ready to meet what is sure to be continuing growth in demand. But a country with an information-based economy cannot afford unreliable supplies of electricity. 
 More than $50 billion in new transmission lines alone will be required to connect the country's regional transmission lines into an integrated whole, and computerized controls will have to be very sophisticated. A glaring omission in the Bush plan is its failure to supply financing to develop these computer systems.
There are nine separate and unconnected power grids in the United States today. Excess electricity from one region cannot be easily transported to satisfy shortages in another. Because the Bush plan to connect the grids involves taking land by eminent domain, some will find it scary, just as the interstate highway system must have been for some when it was proposed. And the regions with the most stable electric supply may not readily see what they have to gain.
But the national grid is a necessity if we are to solve the problem of local shortages. We have plenty of generation capacity in North America, but with energy-hungry computer equipment concentrated more in some regions than in others, local shortages are likely to increase. California's difficulties could spread to other parts of the country. New York's electricity industry, for example, has striking similarities to California's. Both states have been slow to build new power plants and were caught off guard in the last year as demand jumped. Both depend heavily on natural gas to run their generators, leaving them vulnerable to soaring gas prices. Both have deregulated their electricity markets so they no longer control the price of power.
The energy problem has sneaked up on us because the personal computer that is attached to the Internet uses most of its power in ways not seen by the consumer -- through servers, routers and other trafficking infrastructure located many miles away from the consumer in gigantic, air-conditioned warehouses called server farms. The facts about some of this little noticed energy use are startling.
In 1995 there were 20,000 servers in the world. Today there are six million. Just one new server farm, proposed for the economic development zone of the South Bronx, will draw more than twice as much power as the entire World Trade Center complex. Forty-six such developments proposed for New York and Westchester County over the next four years will increase the total electricity demand on Con Edison by 4 percent. 
These servers are connected to about 200 million personal computers around the world. And although the power efficiency of the PC continues to improve with each new generation, the information trafficking volume is increasing even more dramatically. Wireless technology, too, is contributing to the nation's electricity demand. According to one study, a Web-enabled Palm Pilot uses as much electricity as a heavy-duty refrigerator.
The Bush plan's great failure is its lack of financing for research and development for a national grid. A command-and-control system of great scope and reliability will be required to distribute electricity quickly and efficiently. Developing it makes updating our antiquated air traffic control system look like child's play.
It is not a matter of simply joining the systems that run the nine regional grids. As the Pentagon found out in trying to integrate computer systems for control across a whole theater, and NASA learned while putting together smaller systems for the International Space Station, predictability declines as the integration tasks become larger and larger. Breakdowns will occur that have not been foreseen from the experience with the smaller grids.
There is no holding pattern in the electric power grid. It will take only six one-hundredths of a second for power generated in Washington State to be consumed by that server farm in the South Bronx. The computerized control for this kind of system is unlike anything that currently exists in the commercial world.
As California's leaders can attest, those in control will pay a political price if demand gets ahead of supply. Failing to help develop the national power grid would be a serious misstep for the Bush administration.

HEADLINE: Bush Moves Against Steel Imports; Trade Tensions Are Likely to Rise 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 5 

 BODY:
President Bush took the first steps today toward imposing broad restrictions on imported steel, handing a victory to American steel companies and unions that have long urged the government to grant relief from foreign competition.
 The president's action, which initiates a challenge to imports and could result in higher tariffs on foreign-made steel within months, goes beyond any protections that the Clinton administration offered the industry and is certain to raise tensions with trading partners. 
 Administration officials said the decision came after a detailed study of the steel industry's woes. They described the once mighty steel sector -- with only a fifth as many workers as in 1980 -- as hobbled by an unending glut of imports from South Korea, Taiwan, China, Brazil, Germany, Russia, Ukraine and many other nations that often produce steel for less than their American competitors.
"I've told the world we're going to have an active, internationalist foreign policy with U.S. interests at its heart," Mr. Bush said this afternoon during a meeting with senators. "And it's in our nation's interest that if there are unfair trade practices in the steel industry we address them in a very aggressive way, which this administration will do." 
Mr. Bush's commitment to pursue a trade case before the International Trade Commission, an independent United States agency that adjudicates trade disputes, does not guarantee the industry that it will be granted relief. The trade commission must decide whether steel producers have suffered injury because of a sudden import surge. Only then would Mr. Bush have leeway to impose remedies.
Mr. Bush narrowly won West Virginia and narrowly missed winning Pennsylvania, two leading steel producing states, in last year's presidential election. Vice President Dick Cheney promised in an election-eve speech in West Virginia to do more for the industry than President Clinton had done.
Today's decision was hailed by the industry and its Congressional supporters because it put President Bush on the record as favoring help for the troubled industry, increasing the chances that steel producers will eventually get protection.
"This is what we begged for from the last administration," said Representative Bob Ney, an Ohio Republican whose district is home to steel producers.
While Mr. Bush's action could pay off politically, it means that his first major trade initiative is protectionist, intended to offer relief to an industry that is perennially seeking government aid.
Just last month, the president sounded more like a free-trade evangelist. He promoted opening the door wider to trade from less-developed nations as the best way to alleviate poverty and advance democracy.
"When we negotiate for open markets we are providing new hope for the world's poor," he said during a speech at the Council of the Americas. "And when we promote open trade we are promoting political freedom."
The rare step of beginning a case before the commission may help Mr. Bush gain support in Congress for his broader trade agenda. He wants Congress to give him the authority to negotiate trade agreements that lawmakers would then have to approve on a simple up-or-down vote, forgoing the right to tinker with details. Without that authority, the president's ambitions of leading a new round of global trade negotiations would be difficult to realize.
Mr. Bush announced the step before the administration had completed the details of its case, including which steel products would be included in what is known as a Section 201 investigation under the 1974 Trade Act. Administration officials said privately that the timing was dictated by the fact that Democrats took control of the Senate this week.
Led by Senator Jay Rockefeller, a Democrat of West Virginia , Democratic leaders had made clear that they would use their control of the Senate -- the first time they have controlled the body since 1994 -- to order the trade commission into action if the administration did not take the step first.
Administration officials said today that the matter had been under study for several months by the Treasury secretary, Paul H. O'Neill; the commerce secretary, Donald L. Evans; and Robert Zoellick, the United States trade representative. They found that the industry suffered heavily in 1998, when the currencies of emerging-market nations collapsed one after the other and steel imports spiked to new highs, the officials said. Though imports have since receded, the industry's finances have not recovered, they argued.
"We found that the industry faces troubles in nearly every category," an administration official said of its internal examination of the matter. As a result, he said, the trade commission will probably be asked to consider the potential impact of foreign competition across the entire steel industry.
The steel industry pushed the Clinton administration to take a similar action right up to its final days in office. The Clinton White House had in the past imposed import restrictions on a few steel products and taken other steps to help the industry. But administration officials decided not to open a trade case, in part because they were wary of ending their tenure, which had produced several notable trade-opening agreements, with a protectionist gesture. Former Clinton administration officials said they were also unconvinced that the trade case had merit.
"We were open to the idea," said Gene Sperling, the former head of the National Economic Council, "but a strong majority of the industry lawyers we talked to did not feel the case was strong enough."
Mr. Sperling said that while imports had shot up to a high of 30 percent of steel consumption in 1998, they had since dwindled. In 2000, imports accounted for about 27 percent of domestic consumption. The trade commission looks closely at import trends when judging whether the industry has suffered damage from foreign competition.
Moreover, if the United States does eventually impose new restrictions on the steel trade, trading partners will certainly challenge the measure at the World Trade Organization. The United States recently lost a case at the trade body over a Section 201 measure related to wheat gluten, the protein extracted from wheat when it is milled into flour. 
Still, Mr. Bush's action won him a measure of support from some unaccustomed quarters -- House and Senate Democrats and union members. Leo Gerard, president of the United Steelworkers of America, issued a carefully worded statement of praise. He and several other people who backed the action said the test would be whether they get import relief.
There is little question that the industry is being hurt. Since late 1997, 18 American steel companies, including the giant LTV, have filed for bankruptcy.
Yet the steel industry does not matter as much to the economy as it did 20 years ago, when big steel's decline became one of Washington's touchiest political issues. Steel producers employ roughly 160,000 people today, compared with 800,000 in 1980. The military depends far less on domestic raw steel than it once did.
Steel users, by contrast, represent a far larger slice of the economy and by some estimates employ more than eight million workers. And many of them complain that they will suffer from any restrictions in imports.
"We want the U.S. steel industry to thrive," said William Sopko of Stamco Industries in Cleveland, which uses finished steel products to make parts for heavy trucks. "But if we don't have access to high-quality products at competitive rates, including imports, then we're going to be put out of business."

HEADLINE: New York Life to Buy Union Pension Fund Manager 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
Joining a wave of consolidation among asset management companies, the New York Life Insurance Company's investment arm will announce today that it is buying a privately held San Francisco firm that is a leader in managing union pension funds.
 Executives of both New York Life and the San Francisco company, McMorgan & Company, said they hoped the deal would permit them to capitalize on a trend in union retirement plans in which individual members, rather than trustees, make investment decisions. Union pension funds have lagged American companies in shifting to these 401(k)-style retirement plans. 
 McMorgan has a commanding position in the union pension market, and New York Life brings sophisticated computer systems, administrative expertise and a string of mutual funds that can now be offered through the West Coast company. 
"It's a very good fit," said Alejandro Przygoda, an investment banker at Credit Suisse First Boston.
Neither company would discuss the purchase price, but analysts and investment bankers estimated it at $400 million, based on recent sales of asset management companies.
The deal adds $27 billion in assets to New York Life Investment Management Holdings, the investment arm, raising its assets under management to $145 billion.
Insurance companies, banks and large asset management companies have been buying other asset managers -- which manage mutual funds, foundation endowments and other money for institutions -- at a rapid pace. The goal is to gain economies of scale and market share as baby boomers save money for retirement.
There were a dozen deals last year, and so far this year, there have been six, up from 10 in all of 1999 and an equal number in 1998. The New York Life deal comes just two days after FleetBoston paid $900 million to buy the asset-management business of the Liberty Financial Companies, which manages $51 billion.
Last June, in one of the biggest combinations, Alliance Capital Management, the investment arm of AXA, an insurance company based in France, bought Sanford C. Bernstein for $3.5 billion. And in 1999, Allianz, a large German insurer, bought Pimco Advisors for $3.3 billion. 
There have been smaller deals as well. In April, Amvescap of Britain bought Pell Rudman, a Boston company with $8 billion under management, for $200 million.
"Some of these companies are trying to get distribution -- access to new customers," Mr. Przygoda said. "Some are trying to get more products to offer and others are going after scale. In this deal, New York Life gets distribution and scale."
One risk when larger financial companies take over smaller asset managers, some analysts say, is that the unique strengths of the small companies become diluted as the new parent pushes for more and more assets. But Gary Wendlandt, the chief executive of the New York Life money-management unit, said McMorgan would remain a separate operation under New York Life. McMorgan has been led for the last two decades by Thomas A. Morton, one of the founders, with increasing help from his two sons. 
"This company has a terrific franchise," Mr. Wendlandt said. "To disturb that would be foolish."
As a result of the combination, McMorgan will have 50 mutual funds to offer clients, up from 5 now. McMorgan will also gain the expertise that New York Life uses to manage $13 billion in individual retirement plan funds, which will help as more of McMorgan's clients shift away from trustee-managed plans.
Mr. Wendlandt said that of the $430 billion in defined-contribution retirement plans run by unions, only 10 percent are set up so members can decide how the money is invested. But increasingly, he and Mr. Morton said, members want that freedom. 
"This is just the beginning of this trend," Mr. Wendlandt said.

HEADLINE: National Briefing Washington: Postal Service Reports Loss 

BYLINE:  NYT 

 BODY:
 The United States Postal Service said it lost $166 million in the third quarter of the 2001 fiscal year. The service said it had expected to earn $146 million, but a weakened economy halted the growth in mail volume, so it could lose as much as $2.4 billion by the end of the fiscal year. To help increase revenues, some postage rates will rise for the second time this year starting on July 1.

HEADLINE: DESIGNED TO TRAVEL; 
Curating Relics of T.W.A. As It Prepares for Departure

BYLINE:  By TODD LAPPIN 

 BODY:
IF midcentury modern is your thing, you probably covet an Eames chair. If you're into Pop Art, you'll want a Warhol. For photography connoisseurs, it may be an Edward Weston. But I'm not interested in any of that stuff. I'm going for the airport look. Specifically, a T.W.A. departure lounge, circa 1962.
 I realize this seems odd at a time when air travel has become about as stylish as submarine duty. Nevertheless, my apartment is increasingly decorated in a style you might call midcentury airborne. A pair of small plastic Boeing 707's sit on my desk, alongside a Trans World Airlines swizzle stick with a streaking-707 silhouette. A mid-50's travel poster promoting T.W.A. flights to France hangs in my foyer. On the study wall is a lithograph of an early-60's T.W.A. 707. In the bathroom, my Q-Tips are kept in a vintage T.W.A. coffee cup. 
 I have a hard time explaining my addiction. I don't think it's an affaire de kitsch, and I'm not practical enough to think of T.W.A. objects as sound investments. It can't be nostalgia: I've never even flown on T.W.A. 
But I'm not alone. Ever since T.W.A. declared bankruptcy in January for the third and final time, selling itself to American Airlines, collectors have been circling like vultures. T.W.A. is the last of the aviation pioneers (Pan Am went under 10 years ago), and the company's design legacy provides touchstones that will endure even after the airline ceases to exist.
"Like a lot of people, I'm sentimental about the T.W.A. brand," said Steven Isaacks, a T.W.A. crew scheduler. T.W.A. is more than a job for Mr. Isaacks, 36. His grandfather helped set up T.W.A.'s first jet-engine repair shop in Kansas City. His mother worked for the airline for 40 years. Conveniently, Mr. Isaacks lives in St. Louis, also T.W.A.'s hometown. He has been collecting its memorabilia since he was 8; I've run up against him more than once on eBay during heated bidding for travel posters. Inside his St. Louis apartment lies a T.W.A. gold mine: about 10,000 schedules, 5,000 seat-pocket safety cards, 500 decks of playing cards, 75 travel agency posters and -- his most prized possession -- Rosenthal china place settings for 12 in First Class.
Obsession, of course, is always relative. Dan McIntyre, 67, of Granite City, Ill., who retired from T.W.A. in 1992 as a ground service employee after 40 years with the airline, pocketed his first swizzle stick in 1952. His current collection occupies most of his basement, including a 35-by-15-foot room, which he calls "my museum." 
Mr. McIntyre has good reason for his fixation. For one thing, he met his wife at T.W.A. For another, he remembers when air travel was a more neighborly experience. "When you worked on the ramp at the airport during the 1950's and 1960's, you saw a lot of things," he said, referring to days when passengers stepped from airplane to tarmac. "People hugging and kissing. People crying. Family reunions. Kids going off to war in Vietnam." 
Nonetheless, he kept his habit a secret for many years. "I came out of the closet around 1979," he confided, "when a friend took me to my first airline collectibles and memorabilia show. Before that, I thought I was just a freak."
In fact, T.W.A. has spawned several organizations, including Clipped Wings International (www.twaclippedwings.com), former T.W.A. flight attendants who collect cabin uniforms, and Save-a-Connie, a group in Kansas City that tours the country in a restored 1950's T.W.A. Lockheed Constellation (www.saveaconnie.org).
In airport hotel ballrooms across America, collectors gather regularly for swap meets. (Mark your calendars: the Tri-State Airline Historical Society is to meet at the Newark Airport Sheraton on Sept. 8.)
They have a lot of material to choose from. Founded in 1930 by a group that included Charles Lindbergh, T.W.A. was the first airline to offer true coast-to-coast service, taking passengers on a 36-hour journey with an overnight stop in Kansas City.
T.W.A.'s rise took place in the 1940's, after Howard Hughes obtained a controlling interest. By the 1950's, its graceful Lockheed Constellations had become synonymous with elegant travel. "Hughes made flying glamorous for the rich and the wealthy," said Don Casey, T.W.A.'s executive vice president for marketing. "When he was running the show, T.W.A. became known as the airline of the stars."
It was a reputation that Mr. Hughes happily cultivated, sometimes by commandeering a Constellation, filling it with Hollywood celebrities and embarking on giddy sightseeing flights. Joe DiMaggio flew T.W.A. Constellations from New York to Los Angeles to visit his wife, Marilyn Monroe. And isn't that a T.W.A. Constellation with Frank Sinatra on the cover of his 1958 album "Come Fly With Me"?
My entry into what could literally be called the stuff of this legend came in 1999 on eBay, where hundreds of auctions for T.W.A. collectibles take place each week. I paid $10 for a 1954-55 promotional calendar illustrated with a slender Constellation. A few dollars more secured a postcard boasting that the Super-Constellation Skyliner was "the latest word in swift, modern passenger aircraft." Addiction began to set in.
As I collected, I learned more. The jet age took T.W.A.'s visual identity in a new direction. Not long after it began flying its first Boeing 707 jets, in 1959, T.W.A. rolled out a new logo designed by the legendary industrial designer Raymond Loewy. 
Mr. Loewy created the airline's instantly recognizable logo, with the red T.W.A. initials superimposed over two golden interlocking globes. The logo was painted on the tails and above the forward passenger doors of T.W.A. aircraft. A red stripe followed the line of the passenger windows from front to rear like a wedge, widening as if stretched by speed. (T.W.A. pilots were said to boast that their jets seemed to be going 600 miles an hour even when parked.)
But during the 1970's and 1980's, T.W.A.'s global brand recognition became a liability because it made the airline a conspicuous target for anti-American hijackers. Deregulation and competition from upstart airlines, coupled with rising fuel costs, started an economic decline. When the corporate raider Carl C. Icahn acquired control of T.W.A. in 1985, he promptly sold off many of its lucrative international routes. T.W.A. filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors twice in the 1990's. As if to signal the beginning of the end, in 1996 T.W.A. Flight 800 crashed mysteriously off the coast of Long Island, killing all 230 people aboard.
Along the way, T.W.A.'s visual identity was neutered. The twin-globe logo was phased out in the 1970's. Since 1995, T.W.A. planes have been a staid black, red and white, with a globe adorning the fuselage. The globe is intended to evoke the glory of the airline's earlier years, but at a glance, you can tell the thrill is gone.
So as T.W.A. is subsumed by American Airlines, ultimately losing its identity, many will mourn. But for me it also spells opportunity. I still have room in my collection for a certain eye-catching Eero Saarinen terminal building.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S NEXT; 
Dashboard Miser Teaches Drivers How to Save Fuel

BYLINE:  By ANNE EISENBERG 

 BODY:
DUTCH and Swedish researchers may have an antidote for rising gasoline prices. They have developed a computer-driven dashboard display that advises drivers throughout a trip on ways to reduce fuel use. 
 City drivers who follow the dashboard advice on acceleration, braking and other maneuvers reduce their gasoline consumption by 20 percent, the researchers reported. The prototype was tested in and around Enschede, the Netherlands. 
 The computer program in the device keeps track of essentials like speed, steering wheel angle and distance to the vehicle in front, constantly calculating what the driver should be doing to minimize fuel consumption. The program takes a dim view of idling, a notorious gasoline waster, and of that staple of New York City taxi drivers, rapid acceleration followed immediately by an equally rapid deceleration. 
"If drivers change their habits -- and they can with constant feedback -- they can complete the same journey in similar travel times using far less fuel," said Dr. Mascha van der Voort, who just finished her graduate work at the University of Twente in Enschede. Dr. van der Voort devised the computer program and dashboard display with the help of two advisers as part of the work for her doctorate. 
In the long term, Dr. van der Voort acknowledged, the bulk of gasoline savings will probably come from improvements in engine efficiency, not from changes in driving habits. "But I wanted to do something right now," she said, "in the short run, to conserve fuel and reduce carbon dioxide emissions." 
Dr. Therese Langer, transportation program director for the American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy, a nonprofit group based in Washington, said that on-board devices that monitored and advised drivers about driving methods that could save gasoline could indeed play a part in energy conservation. But she added, "Devices like these are not a substitute for the automakers to make a concerted effort to improve their fuel economies."
Many dashboards can already tell drivers, for instance, how much fuel they are using for a maneuver. "This device is different," said Dr. Mark S. Dougherty, a computer science professor at Dalarna University in Borlange, Sweden, who supervised Dr. van der Voort's research project. "It gives you constant feedback during a trip on many ways to improve fuel efficiency." 
The program was designed for standard-transmission cars, which are far more popular in Europe than cars with automatic transmissions. But the program can be adapted to automatic transmissions, Dr. Dougherty said.
Dr. van der Voort and her colleagues tested the program first in computer-controlled driving simulations and then on the road. In the simulated runs, drivers read the advice on a display that was next to an indicator light; the light changed from green to orange and finally red when they delayed heeding the admonition. "The orange warning was when the driver was 10 seconds late, for instance, in shifting from second to third gear," she said. Red warnings were given when two minutes had elapsed. 
In the driving simulations, reported this year in the journal Transportation Research, drivers with on-board advice had an average fuel-use reduction of 16 percent. Drivers in urban areas did even better, reducing fuel use by 23 percent.
"We decided, based on the simulations," Dr. van der Voort said, "that drivers in city centers could really use detailed advice on how to drive more fuel-efficiently for the complex situations they meet."
In the actual road tests that followed the simulated ones, the advice was shown without the colored warning light to make the display less distracting. The system uses a dashboard liquid-crystal display; the idea of audio cues was discarded as too intrusive. The computer program was calibrated to the engine performance of the Volkswagens used in the trials, and 36 people, a mix of men and women, took to the roads, suburbs and highways around Enschede in cars with manual transmissions.
"People who had the device on the dashboard drove on average 11 percent more efficiently than people without it," Dr. van der Voort said. In urban areas the fuel saving was 20 percent. 
Some of the gasoline savings came from changing the patterns of gear shifting. "People were shifting too late from first to second, and from second to third," Dr. van der Voort said. People saved the most gasoline when they pushed down on the accelerator briskly and then shifted quickly, keeping the revolutions per minute low -- not by accelerating very gently. 
"It's not commonly understood by people who drive," Dr. Dougherty said. "They think that the way to get best fuel economy is to accelerate very gently, but that proves not to be the case. The best thing is to accelerate briskly and shift. 
"Don't give it everything the car has, but push down when you're going to shift, using maybe two-thirds of the available power, and change through the gears relatively quickly." 
Another time when gasoline was saved was during braking. "The main thing is to anticipate better when you are going to need to stop," Dr. Dougherty said. Then you should take your foot off the accelerator and use air resistance and friction to help slow the car. 
In Europe, a number of driving programs, sometimes known as eco-driving or ecological driver training, instruct participants in many of the gasoline-conserving techniques that underlie Dr. van der Voort's computer program. Christina Schaper, a project manager at Deutsche Umwelthilfe (the German Environmental Aid Association) in Radolfzell, Germany, coordinates her work on reducing carbon dioxide emissions from traffic with many of these groups. 
"Most of the groups I work with report about a 20 percent gas savings by teaching people the right way to drive," Ms. Schaper said. "Fuel economy is a big issue here."
Driver education programs that stress fuel economy were more popular in the United States after the gasoline shortages of the 1970's, said Philip Patterson, an economist in the Office of Transportation Technologies at the Department of Energy who works with automobile companies to make vehicles more fuel-efficient. "We had educational programs into the 80's, but most of them gradually dried up," he said. "It's time we started working on this again."
Dr. van der Voort acknowledged that some of her dashboard-delivered advice, however sensible, was going to be a tough sell in a world full of people who often either ignore warnings or paste black electrical tape over them. For example, New York City cabbies, if not the ones in Enschede, are sure to reject the advice to turn off their engines after idling in traffic more than 30 seconds. "Most people don't do that even here," Dr. van der Voort said, "but we are trying to teach them."

In This Best of 2000 List, It Isn't What They Say; It's How They Say it

HEADLINE: Rush-Hour Blues: The Transit Squeeze 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Manhattan: New Transit Approach Is Urged" (Metro Briefing item, June 5): 
 I'd like to applaud the five former New York City transportation commissioners for joining forces to bring New York City's transit woes front and center. 
Nearly 100 years ago, the city laid down miles of rail track in a short period of time because government officials were faced with the urgent need to solve population-congestion problems and to combat resulting disease. While the problem today may not be tuberculosis from overcrowded tenements, emergency measures are needed now, too. 
With subway ridership increasing and the growth of neighborhoods bringing traffic congestion, transportation is a quality-of-life and public safety issue that affects millions of New Yorkers. Not addressing it now is a detriment to the city's future economic growth.

JEAN KIM
New York, June 5, 2001

HEADLINE: Drop Expected in Sales of Semiconductors 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., June 6 

 BODY:
Worldwide sales of semiconductors are expected to decline this year, an industry group said today, as demand slows for the chips, which run everything from personal computers to cellular phones.
 Semiconductor sales may slip to $175 billion this year, a drop of 14 percent from 2000, the Semiconductor Industry Association said. 
The group's president, George Scalise, said in February that chip sales could rise 10 percent, less than half an earlier forecast. 
 Sales of semiconductors increased last year as manufacturers stocked up. As consumer spending slowed, electronics makers relied on their excess inventories, leading to weaker-than-expected sales for chip makers, like Texas Instruments and the Intel Corporation. 
Sales are expected to rebound 21 percent in 2002, to $211 billion, the association said. It forecast sales growth of 25 percent for 2003.

HEADLINE: Price of Success In AIDS Treatment; 
Hospitals Confront New Therapy

BYLINE:  By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
The 20-year onslaught of AIDS has radically changed the economics of patient care, and its effects are still being felt throughout the health care system.
 In the first years, when AIDS patients generally needed prolonged bed care and little could be done to keep them alive, hospitals across the country scrambled for resources to treat them. 
 Now many AIDS patients are much healthier, as long as they adhere to complicated drug regimens. They are less likely to be admitted as hospital inpatients, but their treatments require fine-tuning and monitoring, in outpatient clinics and the offices of primary care doctors. 
That care also requires extensive services and expertise on the part of hospitals and doctors. But unfortunately for hospitals, money to pay for the expensive new treatments has not always followed the patients from the inpatient floors to the clinics. Some hospitals are reporting heavy losses on outpatient care for H.I.V. and AIDS patients today, particularly as the disease has spread beyond an affliction primarily among gay men to attack more low-income people who are without insurance, including heterosexual intravenous drug users and their spouses. 
Many family physicians and internists have been significantly affected by the sweep of AIDS as well. In the early days, they were often reimbursed by indemnity insurance plans that covered all services when they cared for AIDS patients.
Now, although they often find themselves spending as much or more time with patients who are controlling their AIDS with complicated drug regimens, health maintenance organizations often pay a flat fee for physicians' services, classifying AIDS as routine general care. 
AIDS has been anything but routine for patients and the health care system, however. From the first handful of cases in 1981 in California and New York that were later found to be AIDS-related pneumonia, the epidemic surged to a peak of 249,000 patient stays in 1995 in hospitals across the country, according to the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
In the early years, hospitals that treated many patients with the disease rushed to assemble AIDS units.
At San Francisco General Hospital, 60 of the 300 medical-surgical beds were dedicated to AIDS patients in 1993 and 1994. In Miami, AIDS patients occupied 45 of 380 beds at Mercy Hospital. There were 40 beds for AIDS patients in Bellevue in New York, and almost half the 220 beds in St. Clare's Hospital were allocated to AIDS patients. 
"It was not unusual to have maybe 100 inpatients out of a census in the hospital of 220," said Sister Pascal Conforti, a member of the Ursuline order who is a staff chaplain at St. Clare's. 
Although hundreds of hospitals treat some AIDS patients, much of the activity was concentrated in a few. Five percent of the nation's hospitals were treating 55 percent of all AIDS patients in the mid-1990's. Public hospitals like Bellevue have been among the largest providers of care for H.I.V. and AIDS patients, including many poor residents. For example, 50 percent of the H.I.V. patients in Dallas County have been getting their care in the public Parkland Health and Hospital System.
In cities particularly hard hit, hospitals transferred nurses and resident physicians to AIDS duty from other units, especially cancer floors.
At first, the course of the disease was often extraordinarily swift.
"They would say, 'I get a little short of breath going up subway steps,' " recalled Dr. Victoria Sharp, who arrived at St. Clare's in 1989. "Three weeks later, they were dead. 
"I was feeling like I was standing there with my arms open and just catching people as they came into the emergency room," added Dr. Sharp, now director of the H.I.V. center at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. "It was truly horrific."
Dr. Paul Volberding, a San Francisco oncologist whose first patient, in July 1981, was "a young man with Kaposi's sarcoma," the virulent AIDS-related skin cancer, remembers that era as extraordinarily painful. "Deaths were absolutely routine," he said.
In addition to the sheer logistical challenge, hospitals had to contend with the stigma associated with AIDS and the fears of contagion from the strange new illness, even among hospital staff.
"It was a time when other people were not supportive,' Dr. Sharp said. "Dietary services, other specialties. There was a lot of fear, a lot of discrimination. It's amazing how far we've come."
Even as they raced to keep up with the patient flow, some hospitals tried to play down their AIDS services for fear of losing prospective patients with other diseases. Paula Sparti, a Miami family physician, said she was rebuffed in the 1980's when she applied for a salaried post at South Miami Hospital, where she had treated dozens of her AIDS patients. "They didn't want to be known as an AIDS hospital," she said.
And in at least one case, in 1991, a federal appeals court in New Orleans upheld a health plan that had singled out AIDS for special restrictions on coverage.
But concerns about finances took a back seat, for the most part, in the early years of the epidemic. 
Many of the early AIDS patients were young, white, homosexual men whose insurance paid for almost every test and medical service, with few questions asked. 
"In the first decade, we had a lot of gay men with indemnity insurance," said Shedrick J. Boren, director of special immunology services at Mercy Hospital in the Coconut Grove section of Miami. "They were financially profitable for the hospitals," he said. 
The Columbia Healthcare Corporation, the national hospital chain, saw AIDS treatment as such a lucrative business opportunity that it moved the big AIDS practice of Dr. Sparti and her partners into Columbia's Deering Hospital in Miami in 1992.
"In exchange for getting our admissions to the hospital, they were willing to put in a state-of-the-art H.I.V. unit" with full-time, dedicated H.I.V. nurses, said Dr. Michael Wohlfeiler, an internist in the South Beach section of Miami Beach who was one of Dr. Sparti's partners.
The economics began to change in the mid-1990's as the first AIDS drug cocktails revolutionized treatment. As the drugs gave many patients their lives back, but left them on complicated treatment regimens, hospitals found themselves facing the loss of a major revenue source but still needing to treat the same patients in outpatient clinics. 
The average hospital stay for H.I.V. and AIDS patients in the state of New York, which keeps the most complete records on AIDS care in the country, was 23.4 days in 1983, almost two weeks longer than the 9.6-day average stay in 1999, according to a forthcoming report by the state health department. 
Insurance companies and major employers who were faced with heavy costs for AIDS and other medical care began switching workers to managed care plans. And insurance companies started paying a flat fee for each day a patient was in the hospital or a case rate depending on the diagnosis. Hospitals could no longer bill for each service, no matter how necessary, and administrators pushed for quicker discharges.
Doctors treating AIDS now say they are often strained financially. Dr. Michael Somero, an internist in Palm Springs, Calif., who treats several hundred H.I.V. patients, canceled his contract with a local managed care medical group last August. The health plans were paying a flat monthly fee of $50 or $60 for each member to the medical group, which turned over $12 to the doctor. "That was a ridiculous amount for any patient, H.I.V. or not," said Nancy Green, Dr. Somero's office manager. 
Ben Singer, a spokesman for Pacifcare Health Systems, one of the H.M.O's with contracts in Palm Springs, said that for doctors with "a disproportionate number of H.I.V. patients, the insurance system, as designed, is challenged."
But he added: "The solution doesn't lie with any one H.M.O. or insurer" but with the willingness of society to continue financing care for AIDS at a cost doctors can live with.
Dr. Wohlfeiler in Miami said that H.I.V. patients require more time, they have more questions and more side effects to discuss. "In the eyes of the insurance company, we're just primary care physicians," he said. By 1997, Columbia-HCA Healthcare, as the chain was renamed, decided to end its contracts with the group of AIDS doctors in Miami. "Once they don't make the money they think they are going to make, the issues change," Dr. Wohlfeiler said. Jeff Prescott, a spokesman for HCA Healthcare, the company's current name, confirmed that Columbia had been "in a mode to get out of those contracts" as it retreated from deals with various types of doctors.
After H.I.V.-related hospital admissions plummeted 29 percent from 1995 to 1997, to 178,000 from 249,000, hospitals took even more drastic steps, closing their inpatient AIDS units or changing them over to treat contagious diseases of all kinds. Nurses and physicians were shifted to walk-in clinics for H.I.V.-related illnesses and to other parts of the hospital.
Mercy Hospital closed its inpatient AIDS unit in 1998 and dispersed the reduced numbers of patients around the hospital. Traffic at the hospital's outpatient AIDS clinic and the pharmacy that dispensed the drugs grew, meanwhile, and H.I.V.-related visits to outpatient clinics quintupled to 4,800 a year. Many of those patients were low-income intravenous drug users without insurance, money-losers for Mercy and other hospitals. 
"AIDS services have gone from being a profit center to being a loss center," Mr. Boren said. His unit reported a $400,000 loss in 2000.
Dr. Sharp at St. Luke's-Roosevelt said, "The change was wonderful news for patients but very bad news for institutions." She said reimbursement for her hospital dropped substantially from 1995 to 2000, costing St. Luke's-Roosevelt more than $1.7 million a year as inpatient admissions dropped by 600, to 1,800 a year, and outpatient visits soared to 47,000 from 4,500. 
She said that the hospitals received $10,000 a year, on average, for AIDS-related inpatients. Outpatient payments, amounting to about $100 a visit, did not make up for the loss of revenue. In New York and California, generous financing for AIDS programs fills the gap for hospitals. But in Texas, Parkland, for example, has a big deficit for AIDS cases, according to Dr. Ron J. Anderson, its chief executive.
St. Clare's, the first of 20 comprehensive H.I.V. centers to be designated and supported financially by New York State and New York City health officials, was pushed close to the edge by the rapid influx and even more rapid outflow of AIDS patients. In just five years, the hospital shrank from 220 beds with 110 patients with AIDS-related illnesses to 110 beds with only 15 or so occupied by AIDS-related patients. 
In the peak inpatient years, "We were a huge part of the business of that hospital: $35 million of $52 million in revenues," Dr. Sharp said. 
George Lowe, director of the out-patient Spellman Center for H.I.V.-related Disease, said the switch hit St. Clare's particularly hard. "The hospital has been knocked to its knees," he said. "There was even talk of changing the name because we had been known so many years as an AIDS hospital." 
With a federal loan to tide it over during three years of renovating, Saint Clare's continued to run the Spellman H.I.V. center and other out-patient services. Now it is marketing the hospital as "the new St. Clare's," Mr. Lowe said, a general community hospital with all new facilities: emergency room, operating rooms, intensive care unit, cardiac care unit, and plans for a new pediatric program.

AIDS at 20
Previous articles in this series have examined current research on new treatments and vaccines; the impact of AIDS on New York City; the lives of AIDS doctors; and the effect of AIDS on the federal government. 
Later articles will investigate AIDS cases in the rural South, increases in risky sexual behavior and the impact of AIDS on the arts.

HEADLINE: Travel-Management Deal Said to Be Near 

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Navigant International Inc., a fast-growing supplier of corporate travel-management services, is expected to announce today that it has agreed to acquire SatoTravel, for $45 million in cash and stock. 
 Sato specializes in providing travel management services to government agencies and large corporations and ranks seventh in that niche. Last year it generated roughly $1.2 billion in gross annual air sales representing about $120 million in net revenue. It has about 2,000 employees. 
 The transaction will create the nation's second-largest travel-management company based on airline ticket sales. American Express remains the leader in providing business travel services. 
Since it was spun off from U.S. Office Products in June 1998, Navigant has grown to become the nation's fourth-largest travel management service business.
The only travel-management service company that is publicly traded, it has relied on acquisitions to fuel its growth. 
In the last three years, the company, which is based in Englewood, Colo., has acquired 35 regional travel concerns in the United States, Canada, Britain and Brazil. Currently, it serves 22 of the top 25 business markets and has 4,000 employees. Its client base consists primarily of middle-market companies that spend from about $500,000 to $20 million a year on travel expenses. 
Though aggressive, Navigant is not the only business travel service provider that is growing through acquisition. Consolidation in what had been a highly fragmented industry is under way, and is likely to continue. 
"There are clear benefits of scale," Paul Keung, an analyst at CIBC World Markets, said. "Larger players are stronger players." 
While the current economic climate is dampening corporate travel plans, travel agencies have been under pressure since the mid-1990's, when major airlines cut commissions to most agents in half, and capped total commission paid on a round-trip ticket at $50. 
Revenues fell so sharply that hundreds of agencies have either gone out of business or have been acquired by other companies. The remaining agencies have been forced to move to a fee-based system. 
Thus far, the slowdown in the economy has not had a major impact on Navigant's business, said Edward S. Adams, Navigant's chairman and chief executive. 
"It would be naive to say the downturn hasn't affected us at all," he said. "Large companies react faster. But it takes longer to get down to the middle market. These companies realize they need face time with their customers." 
The purchase of Sato, which is based in Arlington, Va., is far and away the biggest deal Navigant has done to date. Mr. Adams said the price his company is paying for Sato is twice that of any of its prior purchases. 
"They are a great, profitable company in two business markets we are dying to get into, the government and military and large call-center transactions," Mr. Adams said. 
Under the terms of the transaction, Sato shareholders will receive 60 percent of the $45 million in cash and the remaining 40 percent in shares of Navigant common stock at a price of $12.25 a share. Navigant expects the transaction to close on Monday. 
Navigant, which is traded on the Nasdaq stock market, closed at $16.82 yesterday, down 8 cents a share. So far this year the shares are up 107 percent.
Founded in 1953, SatoTravel was owned by a consortium of 11 United States airline companies. In 1999, an investment group that included Lawrence Hough, former president of Sallie Mae, and a firm led by Peter and John Ueberroth bought the company for an undisclosed price. 
Mr. Hough, Sato's chairman and chief executive, will become a Navigant board member and retain operating responsibility for SatoTravel. 
Sato had been struggling since the mid-1980's, when it lost a near-monopoly hold on providing commercial travel services for the military and federal government. In 1984, Congress opened federal travel contracts to competitive bidding. In 1994, Sato lost three big Army contracts valued at more than $300 million. 
Mr. Adams said Sato had about 45 percent of the military travel market and 35 percent of the federal government market. 
Last month, Navigant reported revenue of $82.9 million in its fiscal first quarter, up more than 13 percent from the period a year ago.

HEADLINE: From a Woodland Elegy, A Rhapsody in Green; 
Hunter Mountain Paintings Spurred Recovery

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: HUNTER, N.Y. 

 BODY:
The Catskills had been laid to waste. Generations of loggers, leather tanners and farmers had stripped the valleys and hilltops of their trees. Streams were clotted with the debris of a dying forest. And the mournful painting of the wreckage that Sanford Robinson Gifford produced here just after the Civil War, called "Hunter Mountain, Twilight," became the woodland's elegy.
 Today, the trees are back, and Hunter is part of a new and vast green belt that stretches along the Appalachians through New York State and into Vermont and New Hampshire. How the land in the Northeast recovered -- from the scarred moonscape that Gifford painted in 1866, to the dense and verdant blanket that envelops Hunter Valley now -- is a tale of nature, technological change and conscious human intervention. Farms were abandoned, allowing the trees to advance. Other fuels replaced wood for heating homes. But in an odd and mysterious way, historians and naturalists say, the art of the Hudson River School -- and Gifford's painting of Hunter Mountain, in particular -- also played a pivotal role. Pictures helped shape and inform much of the debate -- still very much alive in the Catskills today -- about how the wilderness was to be treated. 
 Some of the images, drenched with glory and grandeur, made people fall in love with the landscapes of the Northeast, and then, in a kind of one-two punch, paintings like Gifford's galvanized them into action. 
That New York became the first state to enshrine its forestry goals in its Constitution, in 1894 -- with the famous language that some land was to remain "forever wild" -- was no fluke, conservation experts say. The New York-based painters helped show the way. 
"These were the first real images of ecological destruction," said Bill McKibben, an author who lives in the Adirondacks and has written extensively about the northern forest recovery. Mr. McKibben said that photographs and engravings in magazines like Harper's publicized the land's destruction further still, and the result was an emotional reaction that ultimately became political. "In the Catskills, and especially the Adirondacks, there was really an all-out effort to view these places as special and nurture their comeback," he said.
How art became a force for conservation is in some ways itself a portrait of a lost era, when science and aesthetic appreciation were interconnected subjects in the drawing rooms of the well-born classes.
Theodore Roosevelt, a scion of New York money, made the Adirondacks his wild woods playground as he rose in politics. Writers like John Burroughs and George Perkins Marsh captured the large and small glories of nights under the stars, and the risks to economic prosperity of a neglected environment.
Meanwhile, different economic interests were heading for a collision. Logging continued, and in some places intensified, as the nation's economy grew in the years after "Hunter Mountain, Twilight." But at the same time the families of the New York aristocracy were building their summer retreats upstate, and finding that the sound of a loon on a serene lake was something they wanted their grandchildren to hear as well.
And there was a man named Gifford Pinchot.

Capturing What Was Lost
Gifford Pinchot and "Hunter Mountain, Twilight" were made for each other. He was named for the artist, and born the same year, 1865, in which Sanford Gifford first sketched the scene that became the basis of the painting. His father, James, whose family had made its fortune in the lumber business, was an avid art collector, who became -- through his friendship with a circle of Hudson River School painters, including Sanford Gifford -- a passionate conservationist.
James Pinchot helped found Yale University's School of Forestry. He joined the conservation leagues that were springing up. He persuaded his son Gifford to go into forestry in the 1880's, at a time when such an occupation -- particularly for a young man of independent means -- was almost unheard of. And of course, he bought the painting that had inspired him, "Hunter Mountain, Twilight."
"James was very much affected by what these painters were trying to do," said Nancy P. Pinchot, who married James's great-grandson Peter Pinchot and is now writing a book about the family. "They were trying to capture something that was going to be lost -- he took what they were saying and turned it into policy."
And Gifford Pinchot took the family calling of forestry further than his father had dreamed. In the early years of the 20th century, Gifford Pinchot became perhaps the most well-known voice for conservation in the nation, as the first head of the United States Forest Service under President Theodore Roosevelt. Many historians consider Mr. Pinchot the father of modern forestry.
As the heady era of progressivism gathered force, Mr. Pinchot -- who later was twice elected the governor of Pennsylvania -- established a philosophical platform of land-use policies that became embedded in the nation's forestry doctrine. In the process he defined half of what came to be known as the Muir-Pinchot divide.
Mr. Pinchot believed that forests were renewable, manageable resources that should be used and cultivated. John Muir, the naturalist who was making his name in the Sierra Nevada Mountains at about the same time, argued that pristine wilderness left in as wild a state as possible was the only true measure of conservation. Their gentlemen's disagreement, played out over the subsequent century by disciples who took one side or the other, became a chasm.
And through it all, "Hunter Mountain, Twilight" and the Pinchots remained linked. The painting stayed in the family for nearly a hundred years. For more than 60 of those years it was literally embedded in the wall above the living-room fireplace of their home at 1615 Rhode Island Avenue in Washington -- a permanent part of the mantelpiece. It was the heart of a large art collection, and of their personal lives as well.
"That painting with all the stumps was more than just a picture," said Prof. Char Miller, the chairman of the history department at Trinity University in San Antonio and the author of "Gifford Pinchot and the Making of Modern Environmentalism" (Island Press), a book to be published this fall with Sanford Gifford's desolate Hunter Mountain view on the cover.
"Gifford's job was to put the trees back," Professor Miller said. "That's what his family geared him for."

Forested Lands Again
Jerry Franklin Pierce gestured with his hand to the wall of trees lining the roadside as he drove up Scribner Hollow Road, as though he were trying to reach out through the window of his pickup truck to touch them. Mr. Pierce, a 62-year-old retired civil engineer -- and distant relative to the 14th president, or so his family has always said -- has seen the rebound of the forests. 
He has lived in Hunter all his life, and the encroachment of the woods has become, he said, part the story of his life. There are a few places that he has followed almost like a biology project, including a 30-acre spread that as recently as the 1950's was open farmland and has since been reclaimed by the woods. Any hike, he said, will turn up cellar pits and hearths from even earlier days that are now reabsorbed completely. 
"There are places where I cut hay as a kid, and now they're almost totally forested over -- that's just in my lifetime," he said.
Across the Northeast, the return of the forests has been noted mostly by its consequences: deer and bear have returned, moose have drifted south from Maine and many naturalists say that wolves from Canada could eventually follow. 
But the basis of that resurgent animal life is a resurgent forest. In 1880, only about 25 percent of New York State was forested, according to estimates by the State Department of Environmental Conservation. Today, forests cover 62 percent of the land area. The Forest Service said that while many parts of the nation, especially in the West, lost forestlands in the 20th century, states in the Northeast -- New England along with New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania -- showed a big net gain, with more than 22.3 million new acres of trees. About six million of those acres -- an area roughly the size of Vermont -- were in New York alone.
Meanwhile, the decades-old argument between Mr. Pinchot and Mr. Muir about how best to use or conserve those woods is still being hashed out -- though these days the extractable resource in the Catskills is water, not wood. Over the last four years, New York City has bought more than 32,000 acres in the Catskills -- 5,600 within 10 miles of Hunter Mountain. Under an agreement with the Department of Environmental Protection, the city is trying to buy as much land as it can to protect the watershed and reservoir system that supplies much of its drinking water, in hopes of avoiding the need to build an expensive filtration plant.
But much of the land it buys becomes, in the name of water purity, off limits for many uses, including hiking and camping. The tightening belt of land enclosure has created a new tension point, with many local residents -- taking a page from Mr. Pinchot's book -- saying that they have been robbed of what should be a public patrimony. The city, staking out Mr. Muir's position, says its efforts are the purest form of preservation. People like Danny Murro, a former resident of the Bronx who moved to the Catskills a decade ago and now works in a hardware store just east of Hunter Mountain, said that all the terms are tricky.
"The word is control, not conservation," Mr. Murro said.

Tracking a Classic
Gifford Pinchot died in 1946, and when his wife, Cornelia, died 14 years later, "Hunter Mountain, Twilight" was still on the living-room mantel. Family members said that in the tumult after Mrs. Pinchot's death -- the house and its contents were later sold, and the family estate in Milford, Pa., called Grey Towers, was donated to the Forest Service -- they lost track of the painting. (It changed hands three times among private collectors and has been at the Terra Museum of American Art in Chicago since the mid-1980's.)
One of the enduring family mysteries, though, is what happened to about 200 other paintings that Forest Service workers found in the basement of the Pennsylvania home during its renovation in the early 1960's. All the family knows comes from a memo, which later turned up in government files, written by a member of the renovation team asking what should be done with the art trove. 
No reply to the memo has been found, and Pinchot family members said they feared, and suspected, that the paintings might simply have been dumped into a hole on the property and buried. Hudson River art, which has risen sharply in value over the last 25 years, was out of fashion then. Family members said they still recalled the appraisers from the New York art auction houses who said after Mrs. Pinchot's death that 19th-century landscapes were worth nothing more than the canvases they were painted on.
But the imprint of the Hudson River School's message, along with the old Pinchot obsession with the forests, lives on. Peter Pinchot, Gifford's grandson, is a forester, though he said he resisted it for years. The family legacy, he said, was simply too great.
"I spent half my life running from forestry," said Mr. Pinchot, 55. For eight years, he ran an organic dairy. He renovated houses in Brooklyn.
In the mid-1980's, he enrolled in the Yale School of Forestry and now manages an experimental forest in Pennsylvania that was started by his great-grandfather James.
"I finally realized you should go where your heart lies," he said.

In Art's Footsteps
The paintings of the Hudson River School are portraits of the Northeast, captured at a time when 19th-century America was re-examining its ideas about nature. The landscapes helped spur tourism, forestry and environmentalism. 
This is the second of 10 summer articles in which The New York Times returns to the places illuminated by Hudson River School artists. In the third article, a group of artists hikes into the Adirondacks, hoping to find a deep-woods waterfall that inspired the 1875 painting called "The Flume." Whether "The Flume" has changed is one question. Whether jaded 21st-century eyes can see the natural world the way a romantic 19th-century artist did is another.
The articles and additional materials will also be available at:
www.nytimes.com/nyregion

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Philip Morris Ordered to Pay $3 Billion in Smoking Case
A longtime smoker afflicted with lung cancer won the largest ever individual civil award against a tobacco company, slightly more than $3 billion from Philip Morris.
 A jury in Los Angeles ordered Philip Morris to pay $3 billion in punitive damages and $5.5 million in general damages. In its 18-page verdict, the jury found against Philip Morris on all six counts of fraud, negligence and making a defective product. Page A14. 

Philip Morris is shopping around a plan that would let the F.D.A. limit the tobacco industry's reach. But the company is having a hard time finding Congressional backers. C4.

Hewlett Plans Further Cutbacks
Hewlett-Packard, contending that falling demand has spread to Asia and Latin America, said that it planned to further cut costs in hope of meeting Wall Street profit forecasts. C2.

Fisher-Price Fined Over Toy Cars
The Consumer Product Safety Commission fined the Fisher-Price division of Mattel $1.1 million for failing to report defects in a line of toy cars, the largest fine the agency has ever leveled against a toymaker. The agency said that Fisher-Price failed to report 116 fires and 1,800 incidents involving failures of the electrical system of the cars. C4.

Deal Is Seen for Travel Companies
Navigant International, a supplier of corporate travel management services, is expected to announce today that it has agreed to acquire SatoTravel for $45 million, creating the nation's second-largest travel management company based on airline ticket sales. C10.

Europe Opens Door to Hostile Deals
European leaders agreed on a law that would make it easier to carry out hostile takeovers and more difficult for companies to defend themselves. World Business, Section W.

Shares of Europe Steel Makers Fall
Reacting to steps taken by President Bush that could lead to new restrictions on steel imports, the stocks of European steel makers dropped sharply. World Business, Section W.

S.& P. 500 Leads Stocks Lower
Stocks fell as investors stepped back after four days of gains. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 105.60 points, or 0.9 percent, to 11,070.24. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 13.54 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,270.03. The Nasdaq composite index declined 15.93 points, or 0.7 percent, to 2,217.73. C12.

Gillette Chief Revises Expectations
James M. Kilts, the chief executive of Gillette, was critical of decisions made by his predecessors and told analysts that the problems experienced by the company in recent years were self-inflicted. Mr. Kilts lowered expectations for profit growth and projected long-term sales growth of 3 percent to 5 percent. Shares of Gillette fell 62 cents, to $28. C4.

U.S. and China Make Trade Progress
The United States and China have narrowed their differences over farm subsidies, a leading issue holding up Chinese entry into the World Trade Organization. C6.

Ruling Sought on CD Technology
Computer scientists asked a federal court for permission to explain how they cracked the antipiracy technology for compact discs. C5.

System Skewed Toward the Wealthy
Favoring the wealthy has become a habit in Washington for a couple of decades and may help explain why so many average Americans feel the government does not do much for them. Jeff Madrick: Economic Scene. C2.
