HEADLINE: DiFrancesco Proposes New Arena Plan for Newark 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 6 

 BODY:
Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco and the owner of the New Jersey Devils and Nets announced a tentative agreement today for a $355 million arena to be built in downtown Newark and paid for largely with sales taxes collected in the area surrounding it.
 The deal is far more generous to the YankeeNets, the partnership that owns those teams and the New York Yankees, than one proposed by the former governor, Christie Whitman, on Jan. 31, her last day in office. But Mr. DiFrancesco said that unlike her plan, his would pose no financial risk to the taxpayers if the project failed. 
 If completed, the arena would be a major step in the long-running redevelopment of the once-blighted heart of Newark's business district, and would continue the nationwide exodus of sports teams from their sprawling but aging concrete complexes in the suburbs to trendier downtown locations.
But the share of public money involved -- $270 million toward the $385 million cost of the arena and road improvements -- would run counter to another trend, in which teams are privately financing more and more of the costs of their buildings. Two-team arenas in Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles and Philadelphia have been built in recent years with little public money.
The Newark plan would still require state legislation. And Mr. DiFrancesco, who is also the president of the State Senate, cannot speak for the Assembly. Today, Assembly leaders said they would not go along with the Newark plan until an agreement was struck to replenish the lost economic activity at the Meadowlands sports complex, where the Continental Arena would go dark after the exit of the Devils and the Nets, its two main tenants.
In addition, Assembly Speaker Jack Collins said he would hold up the proposed deal until South Jersey, his political base, received some form of enticement. He is said to favor development of a Nascar race track, or perhaps a new arena for Rowan University, his alma mater.
The proposed deal could also be affected by the New Jersey governor's race. Bret D. Schundler, a Republican candidate for governor, called today for a referendum on any state involvement in a Newark arena. Referendums are often fatal: In Charlotte, N.C., voters on Tuesday overwhelmingly rejected a $342 million package for that city's pro basketball team, the Hornets.
Despite the political obstacles, officials say they expect the required legislation to be enacted by the end of the month, when the state budget has to be passed. Asked whether the deal would still exist if that deadline passed, Harvey Schiller, chairman of the YankeeNets, said, "We've tried to avoid those kinds of conversations, so let's just see what happens."
The agreement in principle announced today calls for the YankeeNets to pay $115 million, or less than 30 percent of the total cost. The rest would come from several public sources. Roads would be rebuilt with $30 million from the state's Transportation Trust Fund. Essex County and the City of Newark would pay $50 million, probably using bonds issued by the county's improvement authority, local officials said.
The largest part, $190 million, would come from bonds sold by an unspecified state entity, to be paid off using sales taxes collected in downtown Newark. That part of the city is now an urban enterprise zone, with a 3 percent sales tax, half the statewide sales tax of 6 percent. Of that 3 percent, 1 percent goes to the city and 2 percent to the state. The arena plan calls for converting the enterprise zone to a "sports entertainment district," and restoring the sales tax there to the full 6 percent.
Officials said that Newark now gets about $2 million a year as its share of the sales tax in the enterprise zone, and the state gets $4 million. The arena plan would allow the city and state to keep receiving those amounts each year, but anything over $6 million would go to pay off the bonds on the arena.
As with any mortgage, over the 30-year life of the bonds, the cumulative payments made from collections of sales taxes would total far more than $190 million, perhaps nearly twice that, officials said. Only after the bonds were paid off would the city and state receive any sales taxes from businesses in downtown Newark above their current amounts.
Mayor Sharpe James, who embraced the plan, said he was not concerned that the higher tax rate would drive away retail customers, saying Newark shopkeepers would end up benefiting from added activity generated by the arena.
"I'd rather pay 6 percent on $5 million gross than 3 percent on $1 million gross," he said.
Officials said that Mr. DiFrancesco, mindful that he has little time to carve out a legacy, was eager to reach a deal for the arena. Indeed, he called his plan a "major improvement" over Mrs. Whitman's proposal because, if the project failed, only bondholders would be hurt. Mrs. Whitman's plan called for no more than $215 million in public money. But the state's share, $125 million, would have come in the form of up-front grants and loans, which could have been lost if the project went into default.
Under his plan, the arena would be owned by the state, but built, run and maintained by the YankeeNets. The Devils and Nets would sign a 30-year lease, albeit at a nominal rent of $500,000 for the first five years and $1 million a year after that; the rent money would be used only for arena repairs and upgrades.

HEADLINE: Armies of Europe Failing to Meet Goals, Sapping NATO 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: LONDON, June 6 

 BODY:
Two years after NATO vowed to improve its military forces, the organization is falling well short of its goals, leaving a yawning gap between the United States and its European allies.
 An internal NATO review has concluded that if the alliance's current spending plans are carried out, it will fulfill less than half its "force goals" -- its 1999 plans to build up its military effectiveness and deal with problems that surfaced during the bombing campaign in Kosovo. 
 And NATO's secretary general, Lord Robertson, said in an interview that European members of the alliance are not doing enough to remedy their deficiencies. 
As a result, European forces could be overly dependent on the United States if they became involved in a new conflict. And if European nations try to tackle the crisis themselves, they may find they lack the means to do the job. 
"For the Europeans there is a clear message," Lord Robertson said. "If a crisis comes along, the capability will not be there."
The sobering assessment comes at a crucial time. The allies' defense ministers are to meet in Brussels on Thursday, and President Bush is to visit NATO's headquarters there next week.
A major topic on the ministers' agenda is NATO's effort to fill the gaps that emerged during its war with Yugoslavia. The conflict demonstrated that European nations have fallen well behind the United States in many areas, including precision-guided weapons, mid-air refueling, airlifting of war materiel, electronic jamming and weapons to knock out enemy air defenses.
European leaders have promised to remedy the shortfalls, both to strengthen their role within NATO and to develop the means to act independently of the United States through a 60,000-member rapid reaction force, which the European Union plans to establish by 2003. But only limited progress has been made. 
"We need to do more," Lord Robertson said.
Much of the consternation at NATO headquarters centers on the objectives the alliance set for itself at its summit meeting in Washington in 1999, for NAT0's 50th anniversary.
At the time, it was clear that the United States was carrying the main burden for the air campaign against Yugoslavia. And with much fanfare NATO approved a program to redress the imbalance and improve the alliance's ability to mount multinational operations, a program it calls the Defense Capabilities Initiative.
A series of "force goals" were specified for five areas: logistics, command and control, mobility, the survivability of forces and infrastructure, and "effective engagement," which essentially means the ability to find and strike targets from the air with precision-guided munitions.
A committee, with NATO's deputy secretary general, Sergio Balanzino, as chairman, was set up to monitor progress. But a review overseen by Mr. Balanzino indicates that NATO's current spending plans would enable it to completely fulfill less than half the "force goals." 
Nor is it clear whether remaining objectives will be met. The review notes that one-third of these objectives would be only partly reached under current spending plans. Other goals are still under discussion or appear to be effectively abandoned.
According to the review, most of the progress has been in logistics and in the materiel needed to sustain a conflict. 
Effective engagement, the term for precision-guided munitions and the systems that support them, is the weakest of the five areas: NATO's spending plans will only enable it to meet 35 percent of its goal, the review states. 
One major reason for the meager progress is lagging support in Europe for military spending. NATO's calculations show that only 11 of its 19 members have increased their spending, after inflation is taken into account.
"The constituency for defense spending is weaker now that the threat appears to have gone away," Lord Robertson said.
Spending estimates by the International Institute for Strategic Studies, a London-based research center, paint a bleaker picture. The institute notes that European Union nations as a whole spend about 60 percent as much as the United States. 
The level of effort varies widely. Britain's military spending, for example, far outstrips that of Germany, whose defense reforms are faltering. Another problem is competition among military programs. 
"Rising personnel costs and a wave of systems acquisitions initiated some time ago, as well as the costs of ongoing operations, leave little room for investment to satisfy newly identified requirements," the institute noted in its annual Strategic Survey.
Two items on Thursday's agenda for the defense ministers illustrate the alliance's difficulties. 
One is a proposal to acquire the ability to find and track enemy forces using an airborne radar, a program known as aerial ground surveillance. This has been a top priority for NATO's military command since 1991. But the alliance has not agreed on how to proceed, and few members have indicated any enthusiasm for paying for it. 
The United States currently has such a system, known as J-Stars. And it would like NATO nations to join Washington in developing a system for the alliance. But Europeans have different programs and ideas for how to go about this.
The other subject is development of weapons to attack enemy air defenses, like missiles fired from warplanes that home in on enemy radars. With the public increasingly loath to accept casualties, such suppression of enemy air defense is important. 
But only seven NATO nations have or are acquiring such systems. And of these, few can attack air defenses with real precision. Only the United States has an effective airborne capability to jam enemy communications.
The shortfalls have implications that go beyond NATO. With the encouragement of the United States, NATO has supported the European Union's efforts to develop a rapid reaction force. 
NATO's reasoning was that the European Union force might take on tasks that NATO is not eager to handle. Also, casting defense as an exercise in European integration, allied officials argued, could be a useful way to encourage support in European parliaments for military spending, which could end up benefiting NATO. 
In return, the organization has offered to give the European Union access to its military planners and, on a case-by-case basis, assets like bases and Awacs battle-management planes. 
But Europe's faltering effort raises the question of whether European Union nations are keeping their side of the bargain and whether their rapid reaction force will ever be more than a paper tiger.
"Capabilities is the European side of the bargain," Lord Robertson said. "If we are going to be able to handle a crisis with the E.U. in the lead or NATO in the lead, we need to have a better capability, or the crisis will simply not be tackled."

HEADLINE: Coalition Builder Wins Los Angeles Mayoral Race 

BYLINE:  By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 6 

 BODY:
Riding the solid support of older black and white voters, City Attorney James K. Hahn emerged today as this city's mayor and quickly promised to form a government that reflected not only his coalition but also Latinos, who turned out in record numbers and had hoped to make his opponent, Antonio Villaraigosa, the city's first Hispanic mayor in more than a century.
 Mr. Hahn is a 20-year veteran of local politics and the son of a beloved political family that, with Tuesday's election, became a virtual dynasty, as his sister, Janice, handily won a City Council seat. The Hahns' father, Kenneth, was a county supervisor representing a heavily black district for 40 years ending in 1992. 
 Mr. Hahn beat Mr. Villaraigosa, the former speaker of the State Assembly, 54 percent to 46 percent, and in some ways his victory could be seen as a throwback to an earlier era in a city whose population is now nearly half Hispanic. 
But Mr. Hahn, who is white and who won roughly 80 percent of the city's black vote plus a large majority among conservative whites in the suburban San Fernando Valley, vowed to focus on the future. He said in a news conference this morning that Los Angeles was "poised for greatness, greatness based on the great diversity we have." 
In keeping with his low-key style, Mr. Hahn, who won about 20 percent of the Hispanic vote, said he did not believe Los Angeles was divided, but he acknowledged the strains inherent in the nation's second-largest city by vowing to form a "government that looks like the city it represents."
Rocky Delgadillo, the city's deputy mayor for economic development, won his race to succeed Mr. Hahn as the city's chief lawyer, defeating a longtime city councilman, Mike Feuer, to become the first Latino official elected citywide since Mayor Cristobal Aguilar left office in 1872.
Latino voter turnout edged up to 22 percent of the overall electorate, a record for a municipal election here, according to surveys of voters leaving the polls conducted by the William C. Velazquez Institute, a nonprofit research organization. The institute estimated that about 35 percent of registered Latino voters turned out, roughly the same percentage as the overall voter turnout. 
"This election is going to be seen as the turning point, the first time that Latinos have contended for power in modern Los Angeles history," said Antonio Gonzalez, president of the institute. "In the Villaraigosa campaign in 2001, Latinos began to assert their true leadership. He came close. He set the agenda. He provided cover for Delgadillo to coast to victory behind his heat shield. So I think it is something that, when you really look at it, ultimately indicates a step forward for the city."
Mr. Villaraigosa was upbeat in defeat, declaring at his news conference today: "When they write about it, they'll say we opened a door. We opened a door to opportunity, and it will never be closed again." 
Mr. Hahn, a Democrat like Mr. Villaraigosa, will succeed Mayor Richard J. Riordan, the millionaire Republican businessman who has led the city since 1993 but was barred from seeking a third term and is, in fact, considering seeking the Republican nomination to challenge Gov. Gray Davis, a Democrat, next year. Mr. Villaraigosa had the support of both Mr. Davis and Mr. Riordan, along with much of organized labor and the state Democratic Party, but Mr. Hahn himself is a foursquare Democrat expected to forge more effective alliances than Mr. Riordan did with the overwhelmingly Democratic City Council. 
Mr. Hahn, 50, and Mr. Villaraigosa, 48, agreed on most municipal issues, like transportation, education and housing. But Mr. Hahn, the city's chief civil lawyer and prosecutor of minor crimes since 1985, consistently portrayed himself as tougher on crime. In the last week of the campaign, he ran a television advertisement that used ominous images of drug paraphernalia to question Mr. Villaraigosa's support for clemency for Carlos Vignali, a convicted drug dealer whose sentence was commuted by President Bill Clinton after Mr. Villaraigosa and other local officials intervened at the request of the man's father, a contributor.
"Obviously, the Vignali ad had an impact," said Art Torres, the chairman of the state Democratic Party. "And there was also the fear factor of a Latino candidate that we were picking up in walking precincts in the San Fernando Valley in recent days. But I think it's very clear that there's a new threshold that appears to have been achieved here, and Antonio has laid the groundwork and there's no turning back now."
Indeed, there was powerful evidence of Mr. Villaraigosa's appeal to newer voters. A survey of voters leaving the polls conducted by The Los Angeles Times found that 5 percent of the electorate was made up of voters casting their first ballots in a California election, and among this group, Mr. Villaraigosa far outperformed Mr. Hahn, drawing 70 percent to 30 percent for Mr. Hahn.
Two of the three incumbent Latino City Council members endorsed Mr. Hahn, and one of them, Alex Padilla, who represents the most heavily Latino district in the city, said he saw the high Latino turnout -- well more than twice the level of the last contested mayoral race eight years ago -- as a good sign.
"Not to say that there weren't any tensions in the campaign," Mr. Padilla said, "but I think they're being overblown."
"In Jim Hahn, we still have a friend in City Hall," he added. "To me, the Latino agenda's the American dream, and that's going to be the agenda for the next four years."
Overall voter turnout stood at about 36 percent of the city's 1.5 million registered voters, well below the 45 percent turnout in the last contested mayoral runoff in 1993. With all precincts reporting in unofficial returns, Mr. Hahn had 293,273 votes to Villaraigosa's 254,491.
Mr. Villaraigosa, a onetime high school dropout and the son of a Mexican immigrant, grew up on the gritty Eastside. He began his career as a bargainer for the teachers' union and became president of the local chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union in 1994. Term limits propelled him to the speaker's chair four years later and out of office last year, and he began his mayoral campaign, which was considered a long shot.
Still, over two years of campaigning, Mr. Villaraigosa managed to forge a formidable coalition and finished first in a crowded field in the April primary, with 30 percent of the vote then, to 25 percent for Mr. Hahn. But on Tuesday, Mr. Hahn managed to win the overwhelming share of the moderate and conservative voters who had backed other candidates in the primary, and he won a majority of Jewish voters, whom Mr. Villaraigosa had courted aggressively.
Mr. Villaraigosa said he had no plans to run for office at the moment but acknowledged that he has more than $1 million in an account that he could use to run for a State Senate seat that will be vacant next year. Many local politicians expect he might do just that.
In a City Council race to succeed Mike Feuer on the city's politically eclectic Westside, former state Senator Tom Hayden, who left office because of term limits last year, struggled to continue his 20-year political career. He appeared to have lost a tight race with Jack Weiss, a former federal prosecutor, who claimed victory with 25,550 votes to 25,261 for Mr. Hayden, who had yet to concede. Mr. Weiss said he was already planning for his transition to office.

GRAPHIC: Photo: James K. Hahn celebrated his victory as mayor of Los Angeles early yesterday. With the support of black and white voters, he defeated Antonio Villaraigosa, for whom Latinos had turned out in record numbers. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Jersey City's Mayor-Elect Seeks Wider Prosperity 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY, June 6 

 BODY:
Over the last 20 years, developers have transformed Jersey City's waterfront on the Hudson River from a gritty industrial neighborhood to a bustling downtown of gleaming office towers and apartment buildings. Property-tax abatements and other economic incentives have lured the builders and their billions in investment over the two decades.
 But as Glenn D. Cunningham prepared to take over as the mayor of Jersey City after his victory in Tuesday's mayoral runoff, he took notice today of what has been achieved and what has not been achieved here. 
 And in between accepting congratulations from well-wishers, Mr. Cunningham, who will be sworn in July 1, made it clear that one of his goals is to see that the prosperity of the waterfront is shared more evenly with the poor and working-class neighborhoods that have been left far behind. 
"There's a feeling that the city's been too easy to roll over for the developers at the expense of the rest of the city," said Mr. Cunningham, the first black to be elected mayor here. "We want the benefits of the growth and prosperity to filter into the other neighborhoods."
Particularly under the current mayor, Bret D. Schundler, who is seeking the Republican nomination for governor, the waterfront of this city of 240,000 came to be known as the Gold Coast. But Mr. Cunningham said during an interview, "The other neighborhoods are anything but golden neighborhoods."
Mr. Cunningham, 57, said one of his top priorities would be to draft a policy that future tax abatements be linked to developers' willingness to provide money for lower-cost housing, more police officers, two new swimming pools, summer jobs for unemployed teenagers, parks and teams in youth baseball and soccer.
During a victory visit in midafternoon to a grocery store on Newark Avenue, in a frayed commercial district west of the waterfront, Mr. Cunningham took up the issue again with happy supporters. He noted that the population of Jersey City, the state's second-largest city, grew by about 11,000 in the 1990's. Most of the newcomers, he said, settled in new luxury condominiums and high-rent apartments on the waterfront.
"The rest of the city is stagnant," he said. "Development has to penetrate every neighborhood of the city. No one has made the developers care about the rest of Jersey City."
During the visit, Mr. Cunningham said he was proud to be the first black elected mayor here. But he quickly stressed that he wanted to be known as a mayor of all races and ethnic groups. "Jersey City is not a black city, or a Latino city or a white city," he said. "We want to empower all the people."
In Tuesday's nonpartisan runoff election, Mr. Cunningham, a Democrat, beat Tom DeGise, a Democrat and the City Council president, who had been endorsed by Mr. Schundler. Many here viewed the runoff as a referendum on the Schundler era. 
 In Trenton on Wednesday, Mr. Schundler said he thought that Mr. Cunningham had won the race because he generated excitement among black voters, who turned out to the polls in large numbers. 
Mr. Cunningham, a tall, trim man, is no stranger to local politics. From 1981 to 1989, he served on the City Council in the early years of waterfront development. He joined the police force in 1967 after serving in the Marines and rose to the rank of captain. He resigned from the Police Department in 1991 and was Hudson County's director of public safety until 1996, when President Clinton named him head of the United States Marshals Service in New Jersey. Mr. Cunningham resigned from that position in December to run for mayor. 
Mr. Cunningham said today that he considered himself pro-development but added that residents would be more likely to support tax abatements for the waterfront if developers provided tangible benefits for other neighborhoods.
Real estate interests seemed receptive to Mr. Cunningham's comments. Brian C. Doherty, a lawyer who represents some of the waterfront's biggest developers, said his clients were willing to work with Mr. Cunningham.
"Obviously, there is the ability to better utilize monies generated from tax abatements for such things as affordable housing and inner-city commercial development," Mr. Doherty said. "The development community welcomes the opportunity to explore those issues with the administration."

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Europe: Britain: Rates Held Steady 

BYLINE:  By Suzanne Kapner (NYT) 

 BODY:
 The Bank of England's monetary policy committee voted to hold the benchmark interest rate at 5.25 percent, as the threat from an economic slowdown imported from the United States subsides. 
Recent data show that British consumers are spending more, house prices are rising and tourism is recovering from the country's worst outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease that placed many rural areas off limits. To fight the threat of an economic slowdown, the central bank had reduced rates three times in the last four months, taking the key interest rate to its lowest level in seven months. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
SharesRetreat Amid Doubts About Economy's Revival

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday as investors, without any fresh major economic data to consider, cautiously stepped back after four days of gains.
 Discouraging forecasts from Hewlett-Packard and J. P. Morgan Chase added to investors' uncertainty. 
 "Market rallies are brief encounters, to say the least," said Alan Ackerman, market strategist at Fahnestock & Company. "A short-term pullback under the current economic climate just doesn't seem to be surprising." 
He said traders seemed to be nervous as companies prepared quarterly earnings forecasts, adding, "that's why one would expect that under these conditions investors would tip-toe through the tulips."
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 105.60 points, or 0.9 percent, to 11,070.24. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 13.54 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,270.03. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index declined 15.93 points, or 0.7 percent, to 2,217.73.
Weak economic reports have led some analysts and economists to revise their predictions about when the economy will rebound. Many are now looking at the second half of the year, at the earliest, in line with remarks from a Federal Reserve governor. That outlook, coupled with fears of dismal earnings forecasts during the next few weeks, has made some investors cautious.
Still, some analysts said yesterday's weakness provided little evidence of the stock market's trend. "I wouldn't put much credence in it from a fundamental standpoint," said John O'Donoghue, co-head of listed trading at Credit Suisse First Boston. "There's no huge drive one way or the other that's got the market doing what it's doing."
Shares of Hewlett-Packard fell $1.34, to $28.71, after company officials told analysts that sales in May were "softer than expected." Carleton S. Fiorina, the company's chairman and chief executive, said the company was "more cautious" about its projections for its fiscal third quarter. 
J. P. Morgan slumped $1.66, to $46.84, after it projected that its trading revenue for the second, third and fourth quarters would be lower than revenue in the first quarter, which totaled $2.09 billion. The company cited seasonal patterns and market conditions. Analysts at Merrill Lynch and Sanford C. Bernstein were among those who cut their earnings estimates for the company.
Shares of oil companies slipped as oil prices declined on a report from the American Petroleum Institute that said oil and gasoline supplies had increased. Exxon Mobil weighed on the Dow, falling $2.15, to $89.40. Chevron slipped $1.54, to $96.16; Phillips Petroleum fell $1.22, to $63.30; and Royal Dutch Petroleum lost $1.98, to $60.27.
Technology stocks, which have had a run-up as investors started to favor the sector again, were mixed.
Shares of Sun Microsystems gained 59 cents, to $17.61, after Laura Conigliaro, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs, said that the "worst may be over" for the company.
 --------------------

Treasury Prices Mixed
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Bond prices were mixed yesterday after Laurence H. Meyer, a Federal Reserve governor, said economic growth was likely to be "sluggish" until sometime in the third quarter, a sign the central bank may lower interest rates further.
Mr. Meyer, who spoke to the New York Association for Business Economics, said "the economy isn't likely to rebound soon," and that is good for bonds, said James Caron, a fixed-income strategist at Merrill Lynch.
The price of the benchmark 10-year note rose 3/32, to 98 3/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.23 percent from 5.27 percent on Tuesday.
The 30-year bond was unchanged at 96 1/32. Its yield was 5.65 percent.

HEADLINE: Circuit City Says It Expects Results to Improve 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: RICHMOND, Va., June 6 

 BODY:
Circuit City Stores Inc. said today that it expected to report better-than-expected results for its fiscal first quarter and that it planned to cut its stake in CarMax Group by 10 percent to help pay for the remodeling of its electronics stores.
 Earnings in the quarter ended May 31 fell to 4 cents a share from 28 cents in the quarter a year earlier, said Dandy Barrett, a spokeswoman. 
Analysts were forecasting a loss of 3 cents a share, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. Circuit will report final results on June 15. 
 Sales at stores open at least a year fell 25 percent, more than the 20 percent drop that Circuit City forecast in March for the first and second quarters. The company has attributed the sales decline to a slowdown in consumer spending on high-price products like computers. Excluding appliances, same-store sales fell 13 percent. Same-store sales are an important indicator of a retailer's business because they exclude new and closed locations.
The retailer, which has said five times since July that profit would miss analysts' forecasts, has been cutting jobs and revamping stores to exit the appliance business and increase sales of electronics.
The company said that while computer sales remained slow, purchases of technology items in space previously allocated to appliances will rise. A new advertising campaign also is helping sales and the release of Microsoft's Windows XP computer operating system in October should also help increase sales. Circuit City will file with the Securities and Exchange Commission within the next week to sell 7.5 million of CarMax's tracking shares. Shares of Circuit City, based in Richmond, fell 14 cents, to $15.67.

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing Cisco Thinks Smaller 

BYLINE:  By Charles V. Bagli (NYT) 

 BODY:
 Cisco Systems, a manufacturer of computer networking equipment, is backing away from plans to take a major block of space in the proposed 37-story, 1.3-million-square-foot tower over the north wing of the Port Authority Bus Terminal on Eighth Avenue. The company, based in San Jose, Calif., had initially talked about having a major presence in the tower, about 500,000 square feet. That would have enabled the developers, the Lawrence Ruben Company and Vornado Realty Trust, to start construction on the project. But Cisco has been battered by a slowing economy and a drop in its stock price. "We have decided not to seek additional space in New York City right now," said Steve Landon, a spokesman for Cisco. "We are staying in New York and expect to grow there over time. We'll continue conversations about new locations." The company currently has about 100,000 square feet at 1 Penn Plaza, a building owned by Vornado.

HEADLINE: Hewlett-Packard Plans New Cuts in Costs 

BYLINE:  By MATT RICHTEL 

 BODY:
Hewlett-Packard, contending that falling demand has spread to Asia and Latin America, said yesterday that it planned to further cut costs to increase the probability it can meet the earnings forecasts of analysts.
 At a meeting with securities analysts in Cupertino, Calif., Carleton S. Fiorina, chairman and chief executive of the company, said demand had slowed, making a point to single out China and noting that "this is a global economic slowdown which may last for some time." 
 The company did not modify its earnings projection, saying it continues to expect quarterly revenue to equal or be 5 percent less than the previous quarter, when it took in $11.6 billion. However, some industry analysts said the tenor of yesterday's announcement was leading them to modify their own earnings and revenue projections. 
"The question is whether we'll take them down a lot, or a little," said John B. Jones Jr., an industry analyst with Salomon Smith Barney, noting he plans to further analyze his projections in coming days. Mr. Jones initially had projected Hewlett-Packard would report earnings of 24 cents a share for its third fiscal quarter, which ends on July 31, compared to a consensus of industry analysts polled by Thomson Financial/ First Call of 23 cents a share.
The news from Hewlett-Packard follows a spate of earnings warnings from technology companies, including one last week from Sun Microsystems. Intel, the giant chip maker, has an announcement planned for today and Dan Niles, a computer and semiconductor industry analyst with Lehman Brothers, said he expected the company to join the list of companies warning it was suffering from a slowdown.
Mr. Niles attributed the flow of pre-announcements in part to a failure by companies to appreciate the gravity of a slowdown in information-technology spending overseas. "Everyone is so focused on the U.S., but they forget that over half the world's I.T. spending comes outside the U.S.," he said, adding that the prospect that the economy would turn around during the second quarter was getting less likely. 
Many analysts said the slowdown had reached its bottom in the second quarter. "Now they're calling that into question," Mr. Niles said. "This could drag on for some time."
As for Hewlett-Packard, Mr. Jones said the news from the company was neither surprising nor a particular indictment of the company's own efforts. Rather, he said Hewlett-Packard, like many of its competitors in the technology business, was succumbing predominately to macro-economic pressures.
The company said it still expected to cut $1 billion from expenses by the end of its 2002 fiscal year, including being on pace to cut 3,000 jobs by the end of this quarter.
Mr. Jones said the company had stated that it partially shifted its cost-cutting strategy, finding that it would have to increase spending on information technology and make up for those increases with additional cuts elsewhere in the budget. Mr. Jones said he found the shift encouraging because it suggested the company was not "just taking a hatchet but cutting intelligently and evaluating how to get their cost structure down."
Wendy I. Abramowitz, a market strategist with Argus Research, an investment research firm, said the continued stagnation in the United States and Europe was not surprising, but that the additional slowdown in Asia was of some concern. She said Hewlett-Packard could find itself facing increasing pricing pressure from other computer makers seeking to maintain or build market share amid a sluggish market.
Ms. Abramowitz said earnings might have bottomed out for Hewlett-Packard, but that its revenue might continue to deteriorate.
Last month, Hewlett-Packard reported earnings of 18 cents a share, 3 cents more than the prognosis of Wall Street analysts who had twice lowered their projections. 
Mr. Jones said he had initially projected profits of $487 million on revenues of $11.6 billion but said he would re-evaluate those figures.

HEADLINE: Don't Count on That Tax Cut 

BYLINE:  By Robert D. Reischauer; Robert D. Reischauer, president of the Urban Institute, was the director of the Congressional Budget Office from 1989 to 1995.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
President Bush will sign his long-promised tax cut today. But conservatives shouldn't break out the champagne just yet, nor should liberals start taking their antidepressants. 
 Passing the cuts was easy. Mesmerized by projections of mountainous surpluses, few legislators could say no. But Congress and the president have turned their attention to crafting solutions to the nation's other problems, and now the real battle over taxes will begin. When the dust from this struggle settles, much of the relief the tax bill promises for later this decade is likely to be delayed, scaled back or repealed altogether. 
 Already, we know that there is bipartisan support in Congress for spending significantly more money on elementary and secondary education, defense and a Medicare prescription drug benefit. Other costly new proposals include a reform of the flawed farm support program, the president's energy plan and assistance to those without health insurance.
The costs of the tax cuts, the new initiatives and the government's ongoing activities are likely to strain available revenues. Barring an unexpected explosion of economic growth, the Treasury will have to dip into the Medicare and Social Security surpluses to pay for the income tax cuts scheduled for 2004 and 2006, the marriage-penalty relief that will start in 2005 and the elimination of the estate tax in 2010. 
How can the Medicare and Social Security surpluses be protected? Paradoxically, the much-derided timing gimmicks in the tax bill, which keep its sticker price below the $1.35 trillion limit allowed by the budget resolution, will give Congress an opportunity to reconsider its generosity.
One gimmick involves the termination after 2005 of the deduction for college tuition and of relief for those facing the alternative minimum tax, both of which start this year. If Congress doesn't extend them, many Americans -- particularly those in high-tax states like New York -- will be hit with tax increases in 2006.
So lawmakers will be under pressure to renew the breaks well before they expire. If they want to continue the provisions, while also allowing the 2004 and 2006 income tax cuts and the full repeal of the estate tax to take place, they will have to tap into the trust fund surpluses even more.
As they consider this possibility, lawmakers will inevitably look ahead to the consequences of a second gimmick they tucked into the tax bill -- the Cinderella provision that magically terminates the entire act at midnight on Dec. 31, 2010, just to keep the 10-year costs of the bill within the budget.
Extending the fully implemented tax bill through the following decade -- at a cost of over $4 trillion -- would require digging deep into the Medicare and Social Security surpluses or drastically reducing basic government services. Not extending the bill would trigger a big tax increase in 2011.
Every politician knows that it is easier to take away promised tax relief that has not yet been enjoyed than to raise actual taxes or cut existing programs. And so they will undoubtedly take the more fiscally sustainable and politically prudent route of scaling back or rescinding the 2004 and 2006 income tax cuts and reducing, rather than eliminating, the estate tax -- before any of these cuts takes effect. These actions would protect the nation's ability to support retiring baby boomers while maintaining necessary government programs.
As the rhetoric about tax cuts rings forth today, rest assured that the final outcome is almost surely not yet decided. Some of the excessive cuts will probably never come to pass -- which is what happened in the 1980's, when Congress passed legislation in 1982, 1983 and 1984 that rolled back about one-third of Ronald Reagan's huge 1981 tax cut.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Sean Kelly)

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
In America, to therichest go the biggest tax benefits. So what else is new?

BYLINE:  By Jeff Madrick; This column appears here every Thursday. Jeff Madrick is the editor of Challenge Magazine and a fellow at the Shorenstein Center at Harvard. E-mail: challenge@mesharpe.com.

 BODY:
HISTORY may judge it a little odd that after the greatest accrual of private wealth in a century, the United States decided to give its richest citizens a giant tax break. But in truth, favoring the wealthy has become a habit in Washington for a couple of decades, and may help explain why so many average Americans feel the federal government does not do much for them. Even President Bill Clinton adopted policy after policy that disproportionately benefited those who made the most money.
 I am referring to what are commonly called "tax expenditures." These are credits to and deductions from federal income taxes that usually reward some kinds of spending or saving. When businesses deduct the health care benefits they pay employees, for example, it is a sizable loss of revenue to the government. In effect, it is a government expenditure that subsidizes health insurance for the employed -- usually those employed by big corporations. The same is true of deductions for pensions and countless special corporate benefits, like accelerated depreciation. 
 The home mortgage interest deduction, so popular among all Americans, is among the largest such tax expenditures, costing the federal government some $100 billion a year. Individual retirement accounts, which enable Americans to deduct contributions, are also tax expenditures.
There are two reasons these programs almost always favor the wealthy. First, the higher the tax bracket, the more valuable the deduction. Second, people who are better off can spend more than others can. They buy bigger homes, so they get a larger mortgage deduction. They put more away in pension programs, so they benefit more from the tax advantages.
The top 10 percent of earners, for example, receive 24 percent of employer-sponsored health insurance benefits. Imagine the federal government giving $1,700 a year for health insurance to families that earn $100,000 to $200,000 a year but only $150 to those that earn $10,000 to $20,000. That is exactly what the current health care deductions add up to, says Jacob Hacker, a fellow at Harvard University.
The deductions for pension accounts, including I.R.A.'s, are skewed even further toward the wealthy, with the top 20 percent of earners receiving two-thirds of the benefits. 
Furthermore, as the political scientist Christopher Howard points out, the nation's policy makers do not know how effective or efficient the programs are. Mr. Howard thinks they are often wasteful. Many employees take more health insurance than they need because the corporation gets a tax benefit and the beneficiary is not taxed on the benefits received. Or, Mr. Howard says, the home mortgage deduction may encourage purchases of enormous houses. Or consider credits for college tuition: most of the people who use them would send their children to college anyway.
But the appeal of tax expenditures is compelling in an age of tight federal budgets because they do not appear to cost the government anything. "Even most Democratic legislators have forgotten how to defend direct government spending," says Mr. Howard, who has published a book on the subject, "The Hidden Welfare State" (Princeton University Press). "So, rather than make outright payments, they resort to these measures."
Several agencies estimate that tax expenditures now total $700 billion to $800 billion a year. When combined with traditional social programs, that makes true social spending in the United States about as large as it is anywhere compared with the size of the economy. Mr. Hacker figures that the combined social programs and tax expenditures, after taxes, come to 24.5 percent of gross domestic product each year in the United States. But in Sweden, which is widely criticized for running a welfare state, the equivalent social programs and tax expenditures are only slightly higher, at 27 percent of G.D.P. In Britain, they are 26 percent, and in the Netherlands 25 percent. The United States, however, has the highest proportion of tax expenditures.
That is a lot of money for programs that favor the wealthy, and it may not be an efficient use of money. But the United States keeps adopting tax-expenditure policies. Under Mr. Clinton, there was a tax credit for long-term care, more tax benefits for higher education, additional tax breaks for health insurance and still further breaks for retirement. Under President Bush's tax-cut plan, the allowable contribution to I.R.A.'s would ultimately more than double, to $5,000, but most Americans do not even participate in the program, let alone contribute the maximum. Limits on itemized deductions are also being raised.
What particularly grates is the complaint that there is no money in the budget for social programs. A sensible cap could be placed on the health insurance deduction for business, for example, and the regained revenues could be directed toward health insurance for the uninsured or to subsidize small business to provide employee health insurance. The health insurance deduction costs the federal government approximately $70 billion a year.
It may also make sense to reduce rather than increase the maximum allowable contributions to pension plans. The current limit for contributions to 401(k) plans is $10,500. Under the new tax law, it will eventually rise to $15,000. Why not cut it back and use the funds to help needier workers?
The relatively new Roth I.R.A.'s are especially costly because, in contrast to conventional pension programs, the proceeds are not taxed at all when withdrawn if they are used for certain purposes, like putting down a deposit to buy a house. There are a wide range of corporate deductions, involving special depreciation allowances and upfront deductions for capital expenditures, which are also ripe for cutting back.
The point is that there is plenty of grist for the social mill. It would be nice if a few legislators started to be straightforward about the true costs of tax expenditures, despite their popularity. They should be at best only one of many tools to make new social policy, but they have become nearly the only tool available.

HEADLINE: Willing but Wary, Irish Vote on Wider Europe 

BYLINE:  By BRIAN LAVERY 

DATELINE: DUBLIN, June 6 

 BODY:
On the surface, a referendum in Ireland on Thursday is asking voters a basic question: should the European Union be expanded to include poorer Eastern European countries like Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic?
 While the "yes" vote is expected to prevail by a fair margin, the referendum has raised broader questions, and some soul-searching, about Ireland's relationship with Europe. 
 "This is payback time for us," said Prime Minister Bertie Ahern when he began the government's "Vote yes" campaign. "This is our chance to show that generosity of spirit that was shown to us so often in the past." 
He was referring to Ireland's years of taking $25 billion in aid from the European Union when it was one of the poorer relations. German taxpayers, so the story goes, paid for Irish roads.
That changed when the boom of the 90's filled Ireland's coffers. But now, just as the Irish will start giving rather than receiving aid, they find they also have the power to shut the door on poorer applicants.
Technically, the decision is an yes-or-no vote on the Treaty of Nice, which sets the stage for expanding the European Union to 27 members during the coming decade. Of the 15 current members, only Ireland -- which has approved four other referendums on the union -- is requiring a vote to approve the treaty.
Most everyone agrees with Mr. Ahern's altruistic message that it is time for Ireland to share the wealth. So the debate has centered on emotionally charged issues like Ireland's historic neutrality and the concept of a two-tier Europe, in which smaller members lose their voices in the councils that determine policy.
According to the Irish government, the decision is simple: the Treaty of Nice sets up an administrative framework to expand the union.
According to the vociferous "No to Nice" campaign, which includes such odd political alliances as Sinn Fein, the Green Party and assorted right-wing groups, the treaty is hardly so innocuous. It will lead to a European army, they say, which would compromise Ireland's neutrality, and the treaty transfers too many decisions to Brussels.
An antitreaty campaign poster on nearly every Dublin street corner spells it out clearly: "You will lose!" it screams in capital letters on a blood-red background. And in case voters are not sure what is at stake: "Power. Money. Freedom."
The "Vote yes" campaign has tried to pass off such claims as paranoid posturing. Mr. Ahern has said English and American interests paid for the posters, a claim that nearly led to a lawsuit against him. 
But the prime minister's message of helping poorer countries has been echoed by influential groups like trade unions and the association of Catholic bishops. In an editorial last week, the Irish Farmers' Journal asked, "With 0.75 percent of the population of the European Union , could we seriously expect the torturously put together treaty to be renegotiated to suit our concerns?"
As it stands, the treaty already suits Irish concerns quite well: when it was negotiated over four long days last December, Ireland and England successfully fought against proposals to harmonize tax rates across the European Union. Ireland uses its low corporate tax rate of 10 percent (compared to more than 30 percent elsewhere on the continent) to encourage multinational companies to set up operations here.
Critics say greater economic unity with Europe will eventually threaten Ireland's control over issues like taxes. France's prime minister, Lionel Jospin, corroborated those fears in Paris last week, saying, "It is not acceptable for certain member-states to practice unfair tax competition."
Should the public reject the treaty, Irish politicians are likely to be greeted with daggers drawn when they go back to the negotiating table to work out a new version. A similar, less serious spat occurred last winter, when Ireland's finance minister, Charlie McCreevy, was publicly scolded at a ministerial meeting for his refusal to follow European Union guidelines in his annual budget.
It remains to be seen whether voters understand such issues, let alone care about them. An Irish Times poll found that 27 percent of people are still undecided on the Treaty of Nice. Two other domestic items on Thursday's ballot -- the abolition of the death penalty, and recognizing the international criminal court -- are expected to pass by wide majorities.
"Our approach to Europe has always been very short term, very pragmatic and very utilitarian," said Dr. Ben Tonra, deputy director of the European Institute at University College Dublin.

PERSON: Joseph P. McMurray 

HEADLINE: Joseph P. McMurray, 89, An Expert on Housing Policy 

BYLINE:  By PAUL LEWIS

 BODY:
Joseph P. McMurray, an expert on national and New York housing policy who was chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board and president of three colleges, died on May 21 at Long Beach Medical Center on Long Island. He was 89.
 From 1959 to 1961 he was president of Queensborough Community College. He returned from government to the world of education in 1965, becoming president of Queens College of the City University of New York, a post he held during years of student unrest in the late 1960's. From 1970 to 1975 he was president of the College of New Rochelle. 
 Mr. McMurray thought government had a duty to provide everyone with access to suitable housing. His long association with housing began in 1948, when he was staff director of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, which had jurisdiction over housing matters. He played a role in drafting the 1949 Housing Act, which expanded the supply of housing for low-income families and encouraged urban renewal.
In 1954 he became executive director of the New York City Housing Authority, with responsibility for the city's low-cost housing program. The next year he was appointed New York State commissioner for housing under Gov. W. Averell Harriman and oversaw the Mitchell-Lama program, which encouraged developers to build housing that people of moderate means could afford.
In 1960 he published a report, requested by the National Association of Home Builders, on low-cost rental housing. It led to a federal program to encourage private developers to build rental apartments for the poor in the Housing and Urban Development Act of 1965.
In 1961, the newly elected president, John F. Kennedy, asked Mr. McMurray to be chairman of his Task Force on Housing and Urban Affairs. The next year, President Kennedy summoned him back to Washington to become chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, a bank regulatory agency established during the Depression to oversee and provide liquidity for savings and loan institutions. 
Mr. McMurray was born in the Bronx on March 4, 1912. He received a bachelor's degree in economics at Brooklyn College in 1936 and did postgraduate work at the New School for Social Research. He then worked as an economist and statistician for federal agencies, including the Department of Commerce, National Resources Planning Board and Bureau of Labor Statistics.
He published studies on many aspects of housing policy, examining cooperative housing and housing for the aged in Europe and the United States.
Mr. McMurray's first wife, the former Isabelle Kenny, died in 1960. His second wife, the former RoseMarie Barker, died in 1996. He became a resident of Atlantic Beach, N.Y., in 1998. 
He is survived by four sons, Gerald, of Alexandria, Va.; Joseph, of Atlantic Beach; Kevin, of Brewster, N.Y.; and Brien, of Severna Park, Md.; and by two daughters, Kathleen Nelson of Atlantic Beach and Isabelle Pullis of Centerport, N.Y.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 13, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An obituary on Thursday about Joseph P. McMurray, a New York housing policy expert and college president, misstated the date of his death. It was May 31, not 21.

HEADLINE: The Ballyhoo's Over and Britain Is Voting 

BYLINE:  By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: LONDON, June 6 

 BODY:
The battle buses made their final journeys, the candidates declaimed their final speeches in rallies around the country and workers stuffed mailboxes with 11th-hour get-out-the-vote leaflets as Britain's national election campaign came to an end tonight.
 "The future of Britain is on the ballot paper tomorrow," Tony Blair said in West Yorkshire. His Conservative rival, William Hague, countered in Hampshire, "Tomorrow the world will find out that the forces of conservatism are on the march." 
 On Thursday the country will be electing the 659 members of Parliament and determining whether Mr. Blair, 48, will, as expected, achieve his ambition to serve a second term, and by what telltale measure of support. 
Despite intense door-to-door canvassing, main street button-holing by incumbents and hopefuls, and multipage sections of newspaper coverage and extended radio and television attention, all indications were that the British public had generally clung to the same voting intentions it had when all the sound bites and photo calls began four weeks ago.
Election eve polls continued to show Labor and its candidate, Mr. Blair, with steady double-digit leads over the Conservatives and their leader, Mr. Hague, 40. The numbers translate into another parliamentary majority similar to the 179-seat one he gained in the last election, in 1997. 
"Very few British election campaigns decide the outcome," said Anthony King, professor of government at Essex University. "In the United States, voters are frequently confronted with at least one or two unknown or little known candidates. Here, voters have four or five years to make a judgment about a government's record in office and form opinions about the main opposition party and its probable performance if it were to win." 
That didn't stop Labor, the Conservatives and the third party Liberal Democrats from mounting media-conscious campaigns aimed at influencing people's choices. Still, with all the stage-managing, the most telling moments in the campaign were the unscripted ones. 
Mr. Blair was forced to come face to face with voter disgust over crumbling public services when a woman interrupted his tour of a Birmingham hospital to lecture him angrily on how her partner had been poorly treated there. The incident caused Labor to step up its emphasis on new spending promises, with the campaign changing its theme slogan in later days from "The Work Goes On" to "Schools and Hospitals First".
As for Mr. Hague, he was thrown on the defensive when a Conservative Treasury spokesman let slip that the party planned on $:20 billion ($29 billion) in tax cuts, a number that Labor artfully converted into the amount of money that the Conservatives would be taking out of public services. 
The profile of the national attitude arising out of all the opinion sampling suggested that Britons, while distinctly unconvinced by Mr. Blair and his New Labor project, were prepared to grant him a second term to see if he could redeem the ambitious promises he made in the first. 
Mr. Hague, who took over the party in 1997 less than two months after it received the worst drubbing from Labor in its history, may have faced an impossible task in trying to turn out the government after only four years.
"The Blair government has been the first very normal and competent Labor government, the first ever Labor government not only to preside over an economic crisis but to actually deliver economic success," Mr. King said. "They found themselves confronting a Labor Party in power that appeals to Conservative instincts and Conservative voters."
"Second," he said, "the British public always prefers Labor on major public services, and that was the issue of this campaign."
Mr. Hague told cheering supporters in Winchester today that "the forces of conservatism," reviled in a famous Blair party convention speech, were in fact "on the march." He said that the key choice for voters was whether Britain keeps the pound or joins the single European currency.
"Here in Winchester," he said, "the coins of our nation were minted for a very long time. The fact that we have had our own currency and coinage has been part of the independence of our country. Those people you see with Labor posters want to destroy the independence of our country within two years."
Mr. Blair has said that within two years he will decide whether the time is right for a promised referendum on Britain's swapping the pound for the euro. Mr. Hague has said he will bar any consideration of entering monetary union for at least five years, and he has pledged to renegotiate existing treaties with Europe to get Britain a better deal. 
Mr. Blair spent his last day on a helicopter dash to stops in England, Wales and Scotland, urging his crowds not to take Labor's win for granted because of its persistent lead in the polls. He sought to link Mr. Hague with former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who in the past week has campaigned for the Tories, sometimes on positions that go beyond the party stance.
"Today's Conservative Party is effectively Thatcherism plus," he said. "It's a more extreme version of the Thatcherism than we had, and it's pretty obvious who would be pulling the strings if they came back."

PERSON: Rosemary Verey 

HEADLINE: Rosemary Verey, 82, Dies; Grew Legendary Gardens in England and Tutored America 

BYLINE:  By ANNE RAVER

 BODY:
Rosemary Verey, the tough, artistic English gardener who brought the art of clipped boxwoods, laburnum walks and ornamental vegetable gardening to America, died in Chelsea Memorial Hospital in London on May 31. She was 82.
 "She was a marvelous lecturer and she knew so much," said Gregory Long, the president of the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. He first heard her speak about her famous garden at Barnsley House, a 17th-century rectory in the Cotswolds of England, about 20 years ago at the Horticultural Alliance of the Hamptons. 
 The four-acre garden was her working laboratory, where she domesticated elements from legendary gardens, like the yellow-flowering laburnum arch at the National Trust's Bodnant Garden, in North Wales, or the ornamental potager, or vegetable garden, at the Chateau de Villandry, in the Loire Valley in France, and made them seem possible for the home gardener. 
Mr. Long remembers staring longingly at the slides of the neo-Classical temple that Mrs. Verey's husband, David Verey, an architectural historian, had dismantled in an English park and rebuilt himself, stone by stone.
"It was a really good lesson in garden-building," Mr. Long said. "None of this redwood pergola stuff from catalogues."
Years later, when he became the president of the New York Botanical Garden, he would ask her to design an ornamental vegetable garden for the Bronx, complete with cold frames for extending the seasons and herbs that are used by gardeners from other cultures. She was working on the design with the sculptor Simon Verity the week that she died of pneumonia, possibly contracted while flying to Cincinnati and on to Kentucky to work on gardens there.
She was mentor to many American garden leaders like Marco Polo Stufano, who transformed Wave Hill, the public garden in the Riverdale section of the Bronx; Robert Dash, the painter who created the Madoo Conservancy, on the East End of Long Island, and Mr. Long.
Ms. Verey wrote more than a dozen garden books including "The Classic Garden" and "The Garden in Winter," which were seminal works for Americans interested in design and sophisticated use of plants, with color and texture year-round.
In her later years, she designed gardens for British celebrities like Prince Charles and Elton John. But her favorite people were gardeners. She often gave them cuttings and seeds from plants she herself had clipped or gathered from such legendary gardens as Gethsemane, outside the city of Jerusalem, or Monet's garden at Giverny. 
For more than 20 years she redesigned the grounds around Barnsley House, which is near Cirencester, in Gloucestershire, first with her laburnum arch, which dangles chains of gold flowers over purple alliums in May. Her husband laid the path beneath, a mosaic of colorful stone and pebbles collected from the Pembrokeshire beaches.
"She had an impeccable eye for color, an ability to embroider gold against purple," said Mr. Dash, whose gardens at Madoo, in Sagaponack, N.Y., are widely considered an American work of art. "She took that grim forbidding aristocratic face off English gardening, and with her charm and her writings, gave it a friendly, domesticated face."
Mr. Dash and Ms. Verey would occasionally lecture together, playfully arguing over whose garden was more original and just who stole from whom. Did Ms. Verey really swipe her famous laburnum arch from Bodnant?
"Of course!" Mr. Dash said, laughing. "But my laburnum arch bears no resemblance to hers. It's a question of following your own light."
She studied mathematics and economics at University College in London, but left before earning her degree to marry Mr. Verey in 1939, and proceeded to raise four children, like a proper English gentlewoman of her day. She was an accomplished horsewoman, until she fell in a hunting accident.
"A horse rolled over on her," Mr. Dash said. "So her husband gave her a book on mandrakes that piqued her interest." And a temple just to get her started.
A scholar and perfectionist, she began to read widely, collecting rare first editions usually seen only in the British Museum or the Royal Horticultural Society's Lindley Library. Her redesign project began in 1950, and the grounds opened to the public in 1970. By the time her husband died in 1984, she had started a new career, and a garden that would eventually attract 30,000 visitors a year.
She lectured widely in the United States, where she made five or six trips a year to cities like New York, Seattle, Atlanta or Chicago, or to Indiana and Kentucky. "Flower shows in winter and the garden clubs in spring and summer," Mr. Long said. "We began to see a lot of laburnum arches in the Hamptons."
She took many young gardeners under her wing, drilling them in the Latin names of plants, and shooing them off for the day to plunge into the great gardens of England.
"She would get very cross with us if we didn't speak to the head gardener," recalled Mr. Stufano, who with his companion, John Nally, spent many days in the gardens at Barnsley. "Her garden was a very personal garden. She was always trying new things. It had the feeling of someone who loved plants and she was out in it constantly. She was a wonderful cook and one of my fond memories is being sent out to the garden for a few marrows, or zucchinis, for dinner."
Long before Mr. Long became president of the New York Botanical Garden, he made a gardener's pilgrimage to Barnsley, to learn some secrets for his place upstate. He had been happily wandering about in the rain, poking about as gardeners do, when he saw her looking out the window.
"She was so imposing in those days, I was a bit intimidated by her," he said. "I almost wished that she not come out. She showed me Phlomis fruticosa, which is a silver-leafed thing with yellow flowers in the fall. I tried to grow it at home and couldn't." 
Then she locked the gate and invited him in for drinks. Years later, at his own garden upstate, she sat on his compost pile and showed him how to dry the bulbs he had carelessly thrown away. They bloomed the next year.
Her influence was not restricted to naive Americans. David Wheeler, the editor of Hortus, a garden quarterly in England, who has built, with the artist Simon Dorell, a garden on the edge of Wales, was also nurtured by Ms. Verey, who opened up her library, garden and larder to him. 
She was a great networker, or Miss Fix-It, as Mr. Wheeler put it. When he admitted that he would like to meet Prince Charles, she simply rang him up. "Be here at 5," she said." "We're expected at Highgrove at 6."
Her vegetable garden, a tapestry of ever-changing cabbages, lettuces, strawberries, hop vines and espaliered fruit trees, "has become a cliche copied around the world," Mr. Wheeler said. "But she made us look at growing vegetables in these times of peace and well-being. We were no longer digging for victory and growing rows of vegetables. We could do this decoratively."
She also reinvented the formal garden, he said, with little parterres of clipped boxwood. "Those had been part of the English garden since Elizabethan times," he said, "but it had all but washed away with modernism and the 20th century." 
In 1999, Ms. Verey received a special award from the Massachusetts Horticultural Society for her work with English gardens, and the same year, was given the Royal Horticultural Society's most distinguished award, the Victoria Medal of Honor. 
She leaves two sons and two daughters. Over the last two years, her son Charles has overseen the gardens, which are still open to the public. "But the eye is gone," Mr. Dash said. "The artist is gone."

HEADLINE: U.S. Sees Some Progress With Chinese onTrade 

BYLINE:  By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, June 6 

 BODY:
The United States and China have narrowed their differences over farm subsidies, the thorniest issue holding up Chinese entry into the World Trade Organization. But many more questions must be resolved if China is to enter the global forum this year, the chief American trade official said today.
 The official, Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, said that two days of talks with Chinese negotiators on the sidelines of an Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum meeting here had made some progress in setting limits for Chinese subsidies of fruit, vegetables and specialty agricultural products. And he said that the discussions had broadened to other W.T.O. membership issues, including details of how China would open its insurance, distribution and retail industries to foreign participation. 
 "I think it moved closer," Mr. Zoellick said of the Chinese position on farm subsidies, "and I think in that context the Chinese wanted to discuss other issues as well, so they're all going on together."
But he said that the talks would have to make quick headway if China is to join the organization in time to participate in a new round of global trade talks, which the United States and others hope to set in motion at a meeting at Doha, Qatar, in November.
China has trade agreements with the United States and many other individual nations, and questions over the details of those agreements have stalled the drafting of an accord necessary for China to join the organization. A principal American worry has been that subsidized Chinese produce could flood the United States, hurting domestic growers.
Advances in refrigerated shipping and mass distribution have made it possible for fruit and vegetables to enter markets that were logistically out of reach a few years ago, increasing the competitive pressure on local growers. Most recently, raspberry farmers in Washington State complained about imported fruit from Chile, which they contend is sold in the United States for less than it costs to grow and pick. 
The notion of competing with state-subsidized fruit and vegetable growers in a country China's size rattles some American farmers, Mr. Zoellick said.
Japan, which has protected its farmers from being undercut by cheaper produce from the United States, is already dealing with China's growing agricultural exports. It has temporarily raised import duties on inexpensive Chinese leeks, shiitake mushrooms and rushes used to make tatami mats for home use.
In response, China has threatened to halve its import of Japanese cars this year.
Mr. Zoellick said that the United States, which today set in motion steps that could lead to restrictions on steel imports, was not contradicting the wider free trade message it is promoting in China and other developing countries. "Sometimes the view in some quarters of the world is that the United States is always the market of last resort," he said, adding that is one reason Washington had a $370 billion current-account deficit last year. 
"If other countries are unwilling to move forward," he said, "we will take care of our own economic interests, whether with bilateral agreements, regional agreements or other steps."
In addition to settling its differences with the United States, China must reach agreement with Mexico, which has not yet endorsed the Chinese bid for W.T.O. entry. The Mexican president, Vicente Fox, who arrived in Beijing today, promised that his government would be flexible in negotiations and would work for China's speedy entry into the trade organization.

HEADLINE: City Officials Agree on Budget With $500 Million Tax Cut 

BYLINE:  By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council reached an agreement yesterday on a $39.6 billion budget that would trim the city's income and sales taxes while restoring money to libraries, cultural institutions and services for the elderly that the mayor had sought to cut.
 The tentative budget settlement comes after earlier predictions that the Council might be forced to adopt its own spending plan this year because of disagreements with Mr. Giuliani on the tax and spending plan, particularly when it came to money for city schools. 
 But yesterday, a handshake between Mr. Giuliani and Speaker Peter F. Vallone ended the division, as the two agreed to a compromise package of $500 million in tax cuts, and the mayor backed off his plan to set aside $80 million to hire private companies to run some of the city's most troubled schools, and he offered to add money to keep city health clinics open. 
"A budget is a compromise," Mr. Giuliani said yesterday evening, standing in the City Hall rotunda alongside Mr. Vallone and nearly a dozen other City Council members. "You win some and you lose some."
The agreement would eliminate part of a surcharge on the personal income tax first imposed during the Dinkins administration, saving a household whose income is about $95,000 a year about $83 annually. The local tax on clothing purchases would be eliminated, as would a $2 fee on hotel rooms. Parents with children in child care would receive a new city tax credit, and more than 3,000 businesses in parts of Manhattan would no longer have to pay a tax on their rent. Most of the tax changes still need to be approved by legislators in Albany.
Leaders of the City Council -- which is expected to approve the budget as early as today -- complimented the mayor and their staffs, expressing broad satisfaction with a package that includes a collection of initiatives that seem tailor-made for Mr. Vallone's mayoral campaign, like a new prescription drug benefit for the elderly.
But school officials were not nearly as pleased. Even with the abandonment of the effort to hire private companies to run certain troubled schools, they said they were disappointed with their $11.5 billion allotment, which the Giuliani administration said was about a $50 million increase from the current fiscal year.
That increase, school officials said, is not enough to cover inflationary growth in spending. Restrictions have been placed on other school funds, and school officials estimated that they would need to find about $200 million in savings just to maintain existing services for the 1.1 million students.
"We have to take teachers out of school or reduce programs that all of us agree are tremendously valuable to children," said Deputy Chancellor Anthony Shorris.
Councilman Herbert E. Berman, chairman of the Finance Committee, said that the Council and the administration would be prepared, at the end of this summer, to discuss possible additional funds for the schools, but that Chancellor Harold O. Levy must first reduce spending on school administration.
"All they have to do is become accountable," Mr. Berman said.
The negotiations followed an annual ritual in which the mayor proposes large cuts only to have the Council restore much of that money during ensuing negotiations.
The budget for the 2002 fiscal year -- which begins July 1 -- includes about $50 million worth of restorations in spending on city libraries, $20 million in restored funds for hundreds of museums and cultural institutions, $5 million in reinstated spending for the elderly and $3.5 million in money that was going to be cut from parks and recreation programs.
There is also about $55 million in new spending for initiatives proposed by the City Council, like a $5 million program to help elderly citizens buy prescription drugs, $5 million in extra money for H.I.V. prevention programs and $5 million for initiatives that will try to reverse a recent rise in the city's infant mortality rate.
On the mayor's side, there is money to offer enhanced science and English classes to more than 40,000 students on the weekends, as well as about 50,000 more slots in the summer school program, among other initiatives.
Council members yesterday were particularly pleased with $4 million added to the budget to ensure that about 20 health clinics the Health and Hospitals Corporation had proposed to close will be maintained. As with the school system, Council officials have told the Health and Hospitals Corporation, the nation's largest public hospital system, that if it runs out of money, the Council is prepared to help. The system expects to run a large deficit in this fiscal year.
"If they have a problem with cash flow, we are committed to look and provide the means," said Councilman Victor L. Robles, chairman of the Health Committee.
Mr. Vallone dismissed suggestions that any of these new initiatives were intended to aid his mayoral campaign.
"The best politics is simply good government," Mr. Vallone said.
The total tax cut package agreed upon is $21 million less in the 2002 fiscal year than the mayor had first requested, but $151 million more than the Council had proposed.
Even with the new spending and tax cuts agreed to yesterday, city officials said they were confident that the next mayor would not be left with large budget deficits.
Yesterday's budget plan includes $25 billion over the next four years for city construction projects. Among the dozens of projects included on this capital plan are a new family court in Brooklyn, the renovation and expansion of the Museum of Modern Art, and the new Guggenheim Museum in Lower Manhattan.
And what about the baseball stadiums? Mayor Giuliani yesterday would provide no details, but once again he predicted that he was close to announcing plans to build new stadiums for the Yankees and the Mets.
"The money is there," the mayor said, although he would not point to where. "We will talk about that later."
