HEADLINE: Meadowlands Is Loose End In Arena Plan For Newark 

BYLINE:  By MARIA NEWMAN and RICHARD SANDOMIR

 BODY:
When Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco announced plans Wednesday for a proposed $355 million arena in Newark, he said he hoped to sign legislation by the end of the month that would move the New Jersey Devils and Nets to a new home there. 
 That timetable may be optimistic. 
 While the proposal was hailed in Newark, officials in Bergen County, where the teams' Continental Arena in the Meadowlands is located, said yesterday that no proposal could go forward without a firm development plan for the Meadowlands. Assembly Speaker Jack Collins said he was concerned that the plan offered nothing for South Jersey. At the same time, officials with the football Giants and Jets have already begun talks about a possible new football stadium to replace their current one in the Meadowlands complex. 
So Mr. DiFrancesco still needs to put a number of pieces together before his plan, which would shut the Continental Arena, can become a reality.
"I'm disappointed that the announcement was made about the Newark arena without a corresponding announcement with regard to the future of the Meadowlands," said William Schuber, the Bergen County executive. "Accordingly, I will be withholding my support until such time as I see what the state's proposal for the Meadowlands will be."
The sports arena at the Meadowlands was built in 1981, and the entire complex, including a racetrack and stadium that opened in 1976, draws six million people a year. But last year it lost $3.3 million, and it requires a taxpayer subsidy of more than $10 million a year.
Mr. DiFrancesco vowed on Wednesday to find a way to quickly ensure the fiscal viability of the Meadowlands. "We are not going to let that golden piece of property lie fallow, even for a moment," he said.
He said negotiations were under way with "major entertainment companies" interested in building at the Meadowlands. The state is also in talks with officials from the Giants and Jets for long-term commitments to keep the teams in the Meadowlands and could build them a new football stadium, Mr. DiFrancesco said.
The governor enlisted Lewis M. Eisenberg, the chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, to put together the Newark deal and a Meadowlands plan. He said he had spoken to more than 60 companies about possible attractions for the site, including a ski slope and a mall. 
Even as the YankeeNets, which owns the Nets and the Devils, was negotiating the tentative agreement on the Newark arena, the Giants and Jets were quietly discussing the possibility of a new football stadium in the Meadowlands. Officials from the teams met with Mr. Eisenberg two hours before the governor announced the arena deal. 
The discussions are still preliminary, with the Giants more interested in pursuing a new stadium and the Jets focused on moving to a proposed stadium on the West Side of Manhattan. But the Jets are also considering either staying in New Jersey or returning to their past home Flushing, Queens.
"I think we're making progress with Lew Eisenberg," said Robert Tisch, the co-owner of the Giants, who met with Mr. Eisenberg, along with Jay Cross and Steve Gutman, Jets officials. "We need as much revenue as we can get. By 2004, 26 of the 32 teams in the N.F.L. will have new stadiums. We have to compete."
But Mr. Cross, the Jets president, said, "I don't think there's anything particularly serious to it."
The possibility of building a new stadium has emerged from discussions about renovating Giants stadium, which the Giants and Jets have shared since 1984.
But as the cost estimates have risen, attention has shifted to building a new stadium.
"It doesn't take long to get to $200 million," said James A. DiEleuterio, president of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, which runs the Meadowlands. 
If a new stadium is built, the Giants and Jets would want the maximum revenue, which would mean that the authority would take less than it does now.
Also in consideration as part of the development effort is the Meadowlands Mills, a proposed $1 billion shopping and entertainment complex being planned for a swath of wetlands in nearby Carlstadt known as the Empire Tract.
Environmentalists have said they would like to see Meadowlands Mills replace the Continental Arena -- which would maintain the Meadowlands' economic vitality and move the mall to a less environmentally sensitive area. 
In March, Mr. DiFrancesco called on the mall's developers to consider alternative sites, saying the 592 acres of wetlands should remain undeveloped. During a news conference in the Meadowlands, Mr. DiFrancesco hinted that building at the site of the sports complex might be an appropriate alternative.
Although it has not ruled out the arena site, the Mills Corporation, which plans to build the mall, said it preferred the Empire Tract. The company is still awaiting a ruling from the Army Corps of Engineers that will determine whether the project threatens the ecosystem. 
Rich Fritzky, president of the Meadowlands Regional Chamber of Commerce, has opposed any deal that would leave a hole in Bergen County. But he said he was hopeful the negotiations would yield something for the Meadowlands.
"If they can work out the Newark thing, God bless them," he said, "as long as they don't disinvest in the Meadowlands." 

CORRECTION-DATE: June 9, 2001

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about plans for the Meadowlands and for a new arena in Newark referred incorrectly in some copies to the football team that used to play in Flushing, Queens. It is the Jets, not the Giants.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Rally by Semiconductor Shares Lifts Technology Issues

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
Semiconductor stocks rallied sharply yesterday, leading the overall technology sector higher, as investors hoped that Intel, the world's largest chip maker, would add to the evidence that the industry's decline was ending and that sales would revive in the second half of the year.
 After the market closed Intel said that its sales in the current quarter would be within the lower end of its previous forecast. Intel did not comment on the industry and whether it might be seeing a turnaround in demand. But analysts predicted the industry might be seeing a bottom. 
 "What Wall Street looks to is to discount and anticipate the future, and so you'd much rather have a situation where a company says we're not quite where we want to be now but we're upbeat in terms of where we're going," said David G. Dietze, president and chief investment officer of Point View Financial Services Inc. in Summit, N.J. 
The semiconductor rally helped lift the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index 46.27 points, or 2.1 percent, to 2,264.00. 
Arthur Hogan, chief market analyst at Jefferies & Company, called Intel's announcement "terrific news."
"This is exactly the kind of news that is going to get people that are sort of in the wait-and-see mode off of the sidelines and back into the marketplace," he added.
The rest of the stock market was modestly higher as weakness in Philip Morris and financial stocks weighed on the Dow Jones industrial average and the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. The Dow gained 20.50 points, or 0.2 percent, to 11,090.74, while the S.& P. 500 rose 6.93 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,276.96.
Ahead of its midquarter forecast, Intel rose $1.32, to $31.14. In after-hour trading, Intel rose as high as $33.
Intel's forecast came after other signs that the semiconductor industry had reached a bottom and was beginning to rebound. Late Wednesday, the Semiconductor Industry Association projected that the chip industry would bounce back in the second half of this year, and it increased its 2002 sales growth forecast to 20.5 percent from 10 percent.
And National Semiconductor, even though it reported a quarterly loss yesterday, said it saw signs that the worst might be behind it. Its stock rose $3.07, to $31.04.
Among other semiconductor stocks, Broadcom gained $4.67, to $40.24, even though it forecast a decline of 32 percent to 35 percent in second-quarter revenue from the first quarter. Applied Materials gained $3.36, to $56.02; Xilinx rose $4.15, to $49.37; and Advanced Micro Devices climbed $1.91, to $30.28.
The Philadelphia Stock Exchange's semiconductor index jumped 49.70 points, or 7.7 percent, to 697.03.
Elsewhere, Philip Morris fell $1.48, to $48.52, a day after a California jury awarded $3 billion to a smoker with incurable cancer who said the company did not inform him of the product's health risk.
The financial services sector was also weak yesterday. J. P. Morgan Chase lost $1.21, to $45.63. Wells Fargo fell 18 cents, to $47.66, after company officials said that it would have an after-tax charge of about $1.13 billion, mostly linked to declines in investments in the technology and communications industries. 
Despite Intel's positive announcement, some analysts warned against the notion that semiconductor stocks would see a sustainable and sizable run-up in the market. 
"What's going to prevent a big rally from being sparked is that, yes, there are many signs of stabilization, but there are also still signs of deterioration," said Stephen J. Massocca, president of Pacific Growth Equities, an investment bank in San Francisco.

Treasury Prices Fall
By Reuters
Bond prices fell yesterday as dealers took profits after a strong six-day rally, which was based on expectations that the economy was unlikely to bounce back much before the end of the year.
"There is no question we have had a heck of a run, so I guess giving back a little is nothing to be surprised with," said John Santoro, head of government trading at SG Cowen Securities.
The price of the benchmark 10-year Treasury note fell 13/32, to 97 22/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.31 percent from 5.23 percent on Wednesday.
The 30-year bond fell 30/32, to 95 3/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.72 percent from 5.65 percent.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Intel Remains Cautious Amid Conflicting Industry Reports

BYLINE:  By MATT RICHTEL 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, June 7 

 BODY:
The Intel Corporation, a closely watched bellwether of the semiconductor industry, said today that it was on target to meet revenue projections for the quarter, but that it saw no indication that the industry had hit its nadir. 
 Andy D. Bryant, Intel's chief financial officer, said the company expected gross margins, expenses and revenues to be slightly below the midpoint of projections given in April. It had estimated that revenue would be $6.2 billion to $6.8 billion. Mr. Bryant did say that while the personal computer market was on track, Intel's sales to networking and communications clients were weaker than expected. 
 Mr. Bryant, speaking on a conference call to investors, stopped short of broad-level analysis of the industry and of whether it may be seeing a turnaround in demand. He noted specifically that it was "too murky" to know whether its business related to the communications sector had bottomed out.
Shares of Intel, based in Santa Clara, Calif., rose as high as $33 in after-hours trading. The company issued its forecast after the markets had closed. Its shares rose $1.34, to $31.16, in regular trading.
Intel's announcement came amid a flurry of news, some of it conflicting, in the semiconductor industry. National Semiconductor reported a fourth-quarter loss, and said today that it would post bigger than expected losses for the current quarter. It also indicated that its customers' inventory backlog was clearing up, suggesting recovery is in sight.
The Semiconductor Industry Association forecast on Wednesday evening that chip sales would fall 14 percent this year. But Doug Andrey, director of information systems and finance for the association, said the group also thought sales to computer makers would recover late in the third quarter, would become a broader turnaround for chip makers by the end of the year, and would lead to growth for the industry of 20 percent or more in 2002.
Taken as a whole, the evidence led some industry analysts to suggest that chip makers might indeed be seeing a bottom -- a conclusion analysts have not embraced in recent weeks for other high-tech industries, particularly those that rely heavily on information technology spending.
Referring to Intel's announcement that it will essentially meet earlier forecasts, Jonathan J. Joseph, an analyst with Salomon Smith Barney, said, "No news is good news in this environment."
"It all points toward a bottoming in August and a re-acceleration from there," Mr. Joseph said. "Basically we've been in a very deep recession in semiconductors. This speaks to some recovery."
Fueling some optimism, Mr. Bryant, the Intel executive, said the company was not as concerned as it had been about having orders canceled -- a commonplace activity that causes high-tech companies to modify their projections -- and, in this case, was a sign that business was stabilizing. "We're getting pretty close to being able to say we're not worried about cancellations," Mr. Bryant said.
"If you ask me how much sleep I'll lose over the possibility we'll be slipping below low end of the range, I'm not losing any sleep," he said. The quarter "is unfolding exactly as I expected."
Investors were similarly heartened by news that Broadcom, which makes chips for cable modems and data and voice networks, was seeing signs that order cancellations were slowing. However, reinforcing the idea that news is mixed for the industry, the company warned that its revenue would fall below earlier estimates, and was now expected to be $207 million to $216 million, below the analyst consensus of $254.7 million.
Also on Wednesday, IDC, a market research firm, reported that domestic sales of personal computers -- a huge market for chip makers -- were expected to fall during 2001. If that holds true, it will be the first year the figure has dropped since 1994, when the firm started tracking the category, said Loren Loverde, a PC market analyst. IDC projected that PC sales in the United States would fall to 45.3 million this year, a 6.3 percent drop from 2000. Worldwide, the company projected PC sales to hit 138.9 million, an increase of 5.8 percent over last year.
Mr. Joseph, the Salomon Smith Barney analyst, said the numbers should not be seen as indicative of continued bad news for the industry. Rather, he said the companies and their investors had already taken expectation of slowed PC sales into account and now were preparing for a rebound.

HEADLINE: The Presidential Tax-Cut Moment 

 BODY:
Appropriately enough, President Bush signed his $1.35 trillion tax cut into law yesterday in a ceremony that looked like a campaign stop from last year. After all, a president who can get his No. 1 priority enacted within five months of taking office has accomplished something impressive politically. However, as this page has often noted, it is an achievement that comes at great cost. It will now be extremely hard to finance Mr. Bush's and the Congress's spending priorities, especially in health, education and defense. Indeed, lawmakers of all persuasions were predicting yesterday that the tax cut would have to be revised fairly soon just to fix the accounting tricks that disguised its cost. 
 In a book about the tax cut and budget wars of another era, Richard Darman, a budget director for Mr. Bush's father, described a similar ceremony two decades ago at which Ronald Reagan signed his own tax cut into law. The signing took place in the midst of a thick fog at Mr. Reagan's ranch, which Mr. Darman saw as a metaphor for the way he and others had failed to see the problems the tax cut would eventually create. The problems that Mr. Bush set in motion yesterday were much more obvious, in part because of what happened in the years after the Reagan tax cut. Mr. Reagan and his two successors all ended up raising taxes to pay for vital federal programs and balance the budget. The senior George Bush and former President Bill Clinton paid a big political price for doing so. 
 One of yesterday's oddities was the agreement among both conservatives and liberals that the tax bill was a kind of sham. Conservatives are upset that many of the provisions they favor -- particularly the reductions for the richest taxpayers and the repeal of the estate tax -- do not take effect for years. They expressed alarm that these are the very features that may be susceptible to repeal when Congress starts looking for the money to pay for school aid or a prescription drug benefit for the elderly. In addition, independent estimates suggest that if all the expiration clauses in the bill were eliminated, it would cost nearly $1.9 trillion by the end of 2011, forcing even tougher budgetary choices.
There is no telling at this point exactly how the tax cut will affect Mr. Bush politically. That will more likely be determined by the performance of the economy than by any voter feelings about the tax cut per se. Mr. Reagan's approval ratings sank after he signed his tax cut because of the recession that followed. For now the provision that is likely to register most strongly with Americans is the bill's $300 rebate for individuals and $600 for families due later this year. Economists tend to think that the rebate might help the economy a little but not much. If the economy sinks, Americans may well look at what Congress and Mr. Bush have wrought as a missed opportunity. A great many Americans at the lower end of the economic scale who pay sizable payroll taxes for Social Security and Medicare will not be getting the rebate in any case.
In political terms, Mr. Bush is surely entitled to savor his achievement.If he can persuade Congress to pass education legislation in a form similar to what he has asked for, as seems likely, his second-biggest priority will also have come to pass. But the greatest test of his leadership will be to digest the consequences of this moment and make the appropriate adjustments as Americans come to realize that some of the other things they want out of Congress cannot get enacted because of what was signed into law yesterday.

HEADLINE: Badillo Opens Another Run For Mayor 

BYLINE:  By MIRTA OJITO 

 BODY:
After a record-setting political career that many believed dormant, Herman Badillo announced yesterday that he, too, wanted the city's top job.
 In a five-minute speech that relied heavily on his experience in government, Mr. Badillo outlined the themes of his mayoral campaign: crime reduction, educational reform and urban renewal. He joins a race already crowded with four Democrats and one other Republican. 
 "I believe that New York City is a jewel, and, as mayor, I will work to make it shine and brighten our whole environment," he said to reporters and supporters gathered in the solarium of the Women's National Republican Club in Midtown Manhattan. 
Mr. Badillo's announcement came two days after Michael R. Bloomberg, the entrepreneur and newly minted Republican, started his own candidacy with a series of bilingual television advertisements. Although both Republicans have earned words of praise from Gov. George E. Pataki, Mr. Bloomberg is thought to be the governor's favorite. Republican leaders tried unsuccessfully for the last few weeks to pressure Mr. Badillo into not entering the race.
In front of a banner that read, "Experience Money Can't Buy," Mr. Badillo portrayed himself as the anti-Bloomberg: a poor Puerto Rican orphan who made good and has the know-how to make life better for all New Yorkers.
Simultaneously translating many of his answers from Spanish to English and vice versa, Mr. Badillo compared this race to the 1989 Republican mayoral primary, in which the cosmetics millionaire Ronald S. Lauder spent $13 million but lost against Rudolph W. Giuliani, who spent $3 million.
"In fact, we can even call Mr. Bloomberg, Ron Lauder II," he said and the audience giggled. He then challenged Mr. Bloomberg to weekly debates, in English and Spanish.
Edward Skyler, a spokesman for Mr. Bloomberg, took a minute to respond to Mr. Badillo's challenge. "I've got a one-sentence reply to that," he said. "There will be debates."
Mr. Badillo's decision to run worries party leaders who fear that a Republican primary will be divisive in an overwhelmingly Democratic city, and it confounds political pundits who say Mr. Badillo's time has passed. "This campaign will cloud his legacy," said Juan Figueroa, president of the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund. "It won't be his finest hour."
In a career that took him from the Bronx to the United States Congress, Mr. Badillo managed to be the first Puerto Rican congressman, borough president and city commissioner in just under two decades. But Mr. Badillo, who is 71 and says he still runs five miles several times a week in Central Park, does not think of his career as being in the past. He says he is intent on becoming the city's first Hispanic mayor, a feat he has attempted three times before. 
He has been campaigning all over the city, courting elderly Hispanic voters, young Republicans and Republican women. He said he has raised $180,000 and has the support of several Republican clubs, including the New York Young Republican Club. 
Although Mr. Badillo has been careful not to criticize his longtime friend, Mr. Giuliani, he portrayed himself yesterday as a candidate who harbors no ill feelings toward any group and is capable of working with all citizens of New York.
"The hostility that divides our city must end, and the absence of hostility must begin at the mayor's office," he said, distancing himself from Mr. Giuliani's failure as mayor to achieve alliances with black and Hispanic leaders.
Mr. Badillo said his candidacy would also help the Republican Party reach out to Hispanic voters. Few Hispanic voters are registered Republicans, he said, but more and more they are moving closer to Republican positions. A poll released Wednesday by the Hispanic Federation, an umbrella organization for Hispanic nonprofit groups, said 52 percent of Hispanic New Yorkers evaluate Governor Pataki's job performance positively.
"The Republican Party in New York City is not aware of what goes on in the nation," Mr. Badillo said. "Our community is gradually moving to the Republican Party."
He also said that only about 10 percent of Hispanic voters were Republicans, an estimate supported by the federation's poll. Norman Adler, a political consultant and lobbyist who has worked for both Republican and Democratic campaigns, disputed Mr. Badillo's assessment of Hispanic voting trends.
"People get their politics the way they get their religions, through their parents," Mr. Adler said. "And the truth is that, at least rhetorically, the Democratic Party continues to be the party of the disenfranchised and the disinherited."
Mr. Badillo knows the rhetoric of the Democratic Party better than most. For most of his political career -- city commissioner and borough president of the Bronx in the 1960's, congressman and deputy mayor in the 1970's -- he was a liberal Democrat, a Puerto Rican pushing the agenda he thought would improve the lives of those he calls "my people." He was the voice of urban renewal and bilingual education, securing an amendment to the Voting Rights Act for bilingual voting.
Then, eight years ago, he switched parties because, he said, his views on education were more in line with the Republican Party. In 1999, Governor Pataki appointed him chairman of the board of trustees of the City University of New York, a position he resigned earlier this week.
As a Republican Hispanic in an overwhelmingly Democratic city running for mayor against a billionaire who is trying hard to become a household name, Mr. Badillo is, once again, playing against the odds. "All he has is money," he said of Mr. Bloomberg. "I have everything else: the experience, the support, the vision, and the drive."
Details of Mr. Badillo's life suggest a man who thrives on adversity.
Born in rural Caguas, Puerto Rico, Mr. Badillo lost both parents to tuberculosis, his father when he was 1 and his mother at 5. Because his mother became ill with tuberculosis shortly after he was born, the only memories Mr. Badillo has of her are the glimpses he stole of her sickbed as the door to her room swung open to allow the rare visitor in.
"That's your mother," his aunts told him, quickly shutting the door before the little boy could catch a whiff of her disease.
At 11, without being able to speak English, he moved to the United States but he bounced from relative to relative until he settled in New York with an aunt at 14. By then, Mr. Badillo knew that school would get him out of poverty.
He went on to graduate with top grades from high school, City College, and Brooklyn Law School. At the beginning of his political career he was often dismissed because potential backers thought he wasn't Puerto Rican enough. He was told he was too tall (he is 6 foot 1) or that his English was too good to be a viable Hispanic candidate, he said. When he first ran for office, he recalled yesterday, he did not have the support of Democratic leaders. 
His political positions are often colored by his personal experience. He seems to believe that because he made it, others can, too. He is against social promotion in school and for rigorous standards in elementary and secondary education, beginning in the first grade.
"All human beings are created equal," he said. "The most insulting and demeaning policy we could follow is to continue to have a double standard -- one for whites and one for African-Americans and Latinos."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 9, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about Herman Badillo's official announcement that he will run for mayor referred imprecisely to his nationality. He was born in Puerto Rico, a United States commonwealth, and was thus an American citizen when he moved to New York at age 11.

HEADLINE: In a Shift, White House Cites Global Warming as a Problem 

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7 

 BODY:
With a new scientific report in hand that reaffirms the reality of global warming, the Bush White House readily acknowledged today that climate change was a problem but gave little clue as to what it intended to do about it.
 Ari Fleischer, the president's spokesman, told reporters that when President Bush heads for Europe next week: "He's going to tell the Europeans that he takes this issue very seriously, that global climate change is an issue that nations do need to deal with -- all nations, industrialized nations, the United States, developing nations, as well. And that through technologies and through growth and through other measures, that the world has a responsibility to face up to this." 
 This is the strongest language the White House has used on the issue and a far cry from its earlier position that the science was too uncertain to proclaim global warming a problem. 
But a report from the National Academy of Sciences, requested by the White House and released on Wednesday, reaffirmed the mainstream scientific view that the earth's temperature is rising, largely because of human activities, and that this could cause drastic climate changes throughout the century.
Even before the report, the president was meeting with cabinet officials to work out a position and figure out how to present it at home and abroad.
Mr. Bush is expected to address the subject of global warming on Monday before leaving for Europe that night. Administration officials said that a draft of his remarks was being reworked to reflect a more accommodating tone because of the new report.
Still, it is not clear whether the president will speak in generalities or put forth a specific proposal that he will take to appease European leaders, who have been furious with him for walking away in March from the international treaty on global warming, known as the Kyoto Protocol.
Environmentalists say that the central argument in the White House is whether to require countries to live under mandatory emission limits or to allow them to comply voluntarily.
Mr. Fleischer declined today to specify what approaches the White House was considering but said that it was looking at a wide variety of proposals, "many with great specificity about what to do."
Another debate is over how much to rely on the framework of the Kyoto accord, with its market-based incentives, to draft a new proposal. Some administration officials contend that Kyoto, which required mandatory emission reductions, is something the president would never accept and that it would be bad for the American economy.
Eileen Claussen, president of the Pew Center on Global Climate Change, which represents several multinational corporations that favor the Kyoto accord as a basis for some kind of agreement, said: "Our companies are convinced this is a serious problem, convinced there will be an international agreement, and want the rules flexible and market based. And Kyoto has that framework." The companies represented by Pew include DuPont, the Enron Corporation and Alcoa. 
Ms. Claussen said the Bush administration was trying to figure out what approach to take on emissions in the United States before agreeing with other countries on limiting emissions. "They are weighing very heavily what they are prepared to do at home before deciding what to do abroad," she said.
But that inevitably leads to a conflict with the administration's energy proposal, which relies heavily on increasing production of coal and oil refineries, a difficult position for the administration to advocate at the same time it advocated reduced emissions. The problem of global warming was given only glancing attention in the energy report released last month.
Ian Bowles, President Bill Clinton's senior director of global environmental affairs at the National Security Council, said that he understood the Bush White House to be focusing on domestic emissions as well, and that this could be useful.
"The big-picture dynamic that the Clinton administration faced on Kyoto was that Europe never thought the U.S. was serious about reducing its own emissions," Mr. Bowles said. "Bush is correct that this boils down to whether the U.S. does anything domestically. But if Bush says our plan is to acknowledge that global warming is real and create incentives and voluntary commitments, that will be wholly unpersuasive to Europe."
Mr. Bowles is a co-author of an article in the journal Science in which he discusses the challenges of creating an international treaty on climate change. One of the big problems, he noted, is that climate change is occurring on a vast geologic time scale that is not usually evident to politicians running for office on a four-year cycle.
"Temperature changes during any single election cycle are likely to be quite small," the article says.
